2201 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bradford


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Bronx County


96 Misc. 2d 298; 408 N.Y.S.2d 1013; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2596



September 27, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant brought a motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol on the ground that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192 was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. He moved to dismiss the indictment on the ground that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192 failed to set forth definite elements and failed to distinguish between driving while impaired and driving while intoxicated. The court held that: (1) the statute was not vague as impairment and intoxication were defined qualitatively; (2) the difference between intoxication and impairment was a matter of degree to be determined by a jury; (3) although the degrees as proved in § 1192(1), (2), and (3) were separable offenses, they closely overlapped and were but species of the generic offense of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol; and (4) where defendant had exercised his right to refuse to submit to chemical analysis, evidence of intoxication could be established by other evidence including the testimony of police officers that they smelled alcohol on defendant's breath, that his eyes were bloodshot and watery, that he could not intelligibly answer civil questions, and that they saw him slump over the wheel and fall to the floor. Defendant's motion to dismiss was denied.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Driving While under Influence of Alcohol

 Section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which makes it a crime to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, is not unconstitutionally vague on the ground that it fails to distinguish between impairment and intoxication or fails to define the elements with appropriate clarity so as to fix an ascertainable and immutable standard of guilt; impairment and intoxication are defined qualitatively, and, where the defendant has exercised his right to refuse to submit to chemical analysis, will be established by police witnesses; moreover, although the degrees as proved in subdivisions 1, 2 and 3 are separable offenses, they closely overlap and are but species of the generic offense of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

 

2202 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re R.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Kings County


96 Misc. 2d 221; 409 N.Y.S.2d 79; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2584



September 19, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The placement of a minor in need of supervision came before the court for its consideration after the Division of Youth rejected him from placement in its facility pursuant to its authority under N.Y. Exec. Law § 502, subd. 4.


OVERVIEW: A minor was found to be a Person In Need of Supervision (PINS), and the recommendation was made that he be placed in a Division of Youth facility. The Division of Youth, however, rejected the PINS youth pursuant to its discretion under N.Y. Exec. Law § 502(4) to refuse to admit a youth if admission was not in the youth's best interest. Due to the dilemma in finding suitable placement for the youth, the matter came before the court for its consideration. The court directed that the youth's placement be with the Division of Youth as it was in his best interests because it afforded him the best opportunity to receive the treatment to which he was entitled. In arriving at that decision, the court declared N.Y. Exec. Law § 502(4) unconstitutional as violating due process since it was broad, vague, and did not provide adequate standards for the guidance of Division of Youth in applying the statute. This statute was also held to have been superseded by subsequent legislation as well. Furthermore, the refusal by the Division of Youth in accepting the youth was found to be arbitrary, capricious, and unreasonable since there was no good cause shown for rejecting the youth.


OUTCOME: The court directed placement of the PINS youth with the Division of Youth as it was in his best interests. In holding so, the state executive law that the Division of Youth relied upon in initially refusing to admit the youth was declared as unconstitutional since it violated due process and was superseded by subsequent legislation. The court also found that said refusal was arbitrary, capricious, and unreasonable.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision

1. The Family Court may not make unspecified placements in which the Division for Youth is given complete discretion for placement in any type of facility.

 [***2] Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision

2. Section 502 (subd 4) of the Executive Law, which permits the Division for Youth, "in its discretion", to refuse to admit a youth to a division facility designated as a title 2 facility "if such admission would not be in the best interest of the youth", is unconstitutional in that it violates due process, is broad and vague, does not provide adequate standards for the guidance of the division, and, to the extent that the alleged guide is "the best interest of the youth", usurps the power of the court to make the determination as to the best interest of the youth.

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision

3. The object of the statute which governs proceedings concerning persons in need of supervision (Family Ct Act, art 7) is to provide rehabilitation and treatment for young persons who engage in the sort of conduct there proscribed.

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision

4. Assuming the constitutionality of section 502 (subd 4) of the Executive Law, which permits the Division for Youth, "in its discretion", to refuse to admit a youth to a division facility designated as a title 2 facility "if such admission [***3] would not be in the best interest of the youth", a determination of the division rejecting a youth for such a placement is arbitrary, capricious and an abuse of discretion where the reasons assigned are that title 1 facilities are open and that the youth's problems are "a little too serious" for title 2 placement, and there is no discussion regarding his best interest.

Statutes -- Construction

5. An imperative statute generally takes precedence over a conflicting permissive one.

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision

6. Section 502 (subd 4) of the Executive Law, which permits the Division for Youth, "in its discretion", to refuse to admit a youth to a division facility designated as a title 2 facility "if such admission would not be in the best interest of the youth", and which was enacted prior to sections 754 and 756 of the Family Court Act, which mandate the court to enter an appropriate dispositional order upon a finding of a need for treatment and give it discretion as to placement, has been superseded by those sections of the Family Court Act.

 

2203 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Grandy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, City of Long Beach, Nassau County


96 Misc. 2d 494; 409 N.Y.S.2d 77; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2629



September 18, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: This matter came before the court on defendants' motions for dismissal of disorderly conduct charges, filed under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(2), (3), on the ground that the sections were unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were each charged with disorderly conduct, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(2), (3). Defendants moved for dismissal on the ground that the statutory sections were unconstitutionally vague. The court denied defendants' motion, ruling that the statutory sections were not ambiguous and that defendants failed to establish the contrary beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions because defendants failed to establish beyond a reasonable doubt that the statutory sections at issue were ambiguous.


HEADNOTES

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

1. There is a strong presumption that a statute duly enacted is valid; a court is not bound to set aside a law as unconstitutional unless that conclusion is inescapable and demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt by the one asserting it.

Statutes -- Construction

2. In interpreting penal statutes the words thereof are afforded their commonly accepted meaning; a penal law is void for vagueness when it fails to give fair notice of the proscribed conduct. Although more precise language might have been used in drawing a statute, it is not thereby rendered unconstitutional.

Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct

3. Subdivisions 2 and 3 of section 240.20 of the Penal Law (disorderly conduct) are not void for vagueness; when reasonably viewed they are not ambiguous.

 

2204 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Lindner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oneida County


96 Misc. 2d 234; 408 N.Y.S.2d 920; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2588



September 8, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Therefore, the application is denied, and David Lindner and John Cesario shall be returned to Elmira Correctional Facility for such action as shall be deemed appropriate.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the acting superintendent of a correctional facility, asked the court to designate physicians to examine two prisoners pursuant to N.Y. Correct. Law § 402(1). The prisoners had already been transferred to a psychiatric center pursuant to the emergency provisions of N.Y. Correct. Law § 402(2).


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Correct. Law § 402(9) an inmate of a correctional facility could be admitted on an emergency basis to a designated psychiatric center upon the certification of two of the center's physicians. Section 402(1) provided that before a transfer from a correctional facility to a mental health facility was made, a prisoner was entitled to court review. The court held that the prisoners were entitled to the minimum procedural due process protections set out in § 402(1). The court ruled that because § 402(9) failed to define emergency, or to provide for any input from outside the mental health facility, it failed to provide the necessary minimum due process. The fact that § 402(9) provided for review following the transfer was not sufficient because the statute was to protect the individual from unconstitutional discretion by public officials. Because § 402(9) attempted to circumvent the procedural due process protections of § 402(1), it could not be upheld. The State's argument regarding procedures for civil commitment was irrelevant because the prisoners were already in custody and could be isolated and protected until they could be properly transferred.


OUTCOME: The court denied the superintendent's application to designate physicians to examine two prisoners who had been transferred to a psychiatric center and ordered that the prisoners be returned to the prison where they had been incarcerated for such action as was deemed appropriate.


HEADNOTES

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons -- Transfer of Inmate from Correctional to Mental Health Facility

1. Subdivision 9 of section 402 of the Correction Law, which provides that an inmate of a correctional facility may be admitted on an emergency basis to the Central New York Psychiatric Center upon the certification by two examining physicians associated with the correctional facility that he suffers from a mental illness that is likely to result in serious harm to himself or others, fails to provide adequate due process safeguards for the inmate and cannot be reconciled with other provisions of that section which provide that, whenever the physician of any correctional facility shall report to the superintendent that an inmate is mentally ill, the superintendent shall apply to a Judge of the County Court or Justice of the Supreme Court in the county for appointment of two examining physicians (subd 1) and which authorize the court to transfer the inmate forthwith, prior to hearing if there is proof [***2] that the correctional facility cannot adequately care for him (subd 8).

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons -- Transfer of Inmate from Correctional to Mental Health Facility

2. A protected right is involved in a transfer of an inmate from a correctional facility to a mental health facility, and, prior to such a transfer, the inmate must be afforded procedural due process protection; subdivision 9 of section 402 of the Correction Law, which permits a correctional facility to effect such a transfer on an "emergency" basis, without defining an "emergency" and without providing for any input or control from outside the correctional facility, attempts to circumvent that right, is inconsistent with other provisions of the section which require examination of the inmate by court-appointed physicians prior to such a transfer, and cannot be upheld.

 

2205 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Offen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


96 Misc. 2d 147; 408 N.Y.S.2d 914; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2569



September 6, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with obstructing governmental administration in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 195.05 and littering in violation of N.Y. City Health Code § 153.01. After the close of the prosecution's case, defendant filed a motion to dismiss both charges. The court reserved decision on that motion. After trial, the jury rendered a verdict finding defendant guilty of both charges.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested after two police officers observed him place two bags of trash at the curb in front of the store where he worked. The evidence at trial indicated defendant walked away from the officers and did not heed their request for identification. Additionally, defendant sought refuge in the store and barred the officers' entry into the store. In his motion to dismiss, defendant asserted the information charging obstruction was insufficient. Also in the motion to dismiss, defendant claimed that the existence of two almost identical statutes proscribing littering, with great disparity in authorized punishment and with no guidelines for the application of either, violated his rights of equal protection and due process. The court first found defendant had not been charged with a crime because fleeing from an officer prior to arrest was not obstructing governmental administration as charged. However, the court held the littering charge was proper considering the presumed constitutionality of statutes and ordinances and the reservation of such questions for appellate review.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss the charge of obstructing governmental administration was granted. The motion to dismiss the littering charge was denied.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Obstructing Governmental Administration

1. An accusatory instrument, in order to be valid, must state not only the crime with which a defendant is charged but also the particular acts constituting the crime; accordingly, a motion to dismiss a charge of obstructing governmental administration (Penal Law, § 195.05), after the close of the People's case, is properly granted under circumstances where the complaint states only that "the defendant did flee in attempt to avoid being summoned" by a police officer, as fleeing from an officer prior to arrest is not a crime and while the alleged act of flight may have been further defined by the evidence during trial, such acts were not charged in the information.

Crimes -- Littering

2. A denial of defendant's motion to dismiss a charge of littering (New York City Health Code, § 153.01), a class A misdemeanor, is proper despite the existence of another, almost identical littering statute (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 755[2]-7.0), a violation, as despite the fact that the two statutes, while proscribing the same conduct, have a disparity in authorized punishment and have no guidelines for application,  [***2] the prosecution is empowered with wide discretion and there is a presumption of constitutionality regarding statutes and any constitutional questions are appropriately reserved for appellate review.

 

2206 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Dutchess County


95 Misc. 2d 1010; 408 N.Y.S.2d 748; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2540



September 5, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the motion to dismiss or reduce the first count of the indictment, by which first degree sale is charged, is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss a charge of sale and possession of approximately nine pounds of marihuana under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 221.55, 221.25 after a police chemist testified that he could not determine the "pure weight." The Marihuana Reform Act, 1977 N.Y. Laws 360, required that marihuana be measured under a "pure weight" standard, i.e., that of the marihuana itself, rather than an "aggregate weight" standard, i.e., that of the blend.


OVERVIEW: The chemist testified that no quantitative analysis could be performed to determine the "pure" weight of the marihuana itself, as that term was defined in N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 3302(20). He could only state that marihuana was present in some unknown quantity in each of the samples taken from each of the bags which comprised the alleged sale. He could not, to a reasonable degree of scientific certainty, rule out the presence or gauge the amount of non-marihuana. His test was essentially an aggregate weight analysis. Because it was impossible to determine exactly how much marihuana was involved, the court dismissed the possession count to the extent it contemplated possession of more than a pound of marihuana and reduced it to mere possession of any amount of marihuana under N.Y. Penal Law § 221.05. The court denied the motion to dismiss or reduce the sale count because scientific proof of pure weight was not an element of sale by offer under N.Y. Penal Law § 221.55. An offer to sell could be established circumstantially. It was sufficient that defendant made and carried out an offer to deliver of nine pounds of a substance, accompanied by representations that it was marihuana.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss as to the possession count to the extent it contemplated possession of more than a pound of marihuana and reduced the count to a violation based on mere possession of any amount of marihuana. The court denied the motion to dismiss or reduce the sale count.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Controlled Substances -- Marihuana Reform Act of 1977

1. The Marihuana Reform Act of 1977 (L 1977, ch 360), which classifies marihuana as a commodity to be measured, for purposes of determining the levels of culpability for sale and possession, under a "pure weight" standard, i.e., the weight of the marihuana itself, rather than an "aggregate weight" standard, i.e., the weight of the blend within which it is contained, forecloses prosecution for possession of a given weight of marihuana where the defendant possessed a mass in excess of that weight [***4] but it cannot be established, with reasonable scientific certainty, what quantity of that mass was pure marihuana as defined in section 3302 (subd 20) of the Public Health Law, which defines marihuana as "all parts of the plant of the genus Cannabis, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plant, its seeds or resin", but specifically excludes "the mature stalks of the plant, fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil, or cake, or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination".

Crimes -- Controlled Substances

2. A sale of a controlled substance may be committed either by actual sale, in the conventional sense, by delivery, or by offer. (Penal Law, § 220.00, subd 1.)

Crimes -- Controlled Substances

3. A prosecution for sale of a controlled substance based on an offer to sell it may be circumstantially sustained without production [***5] of the substance itself.

Crimes -- Controlled Substances -- Marihuana Reform Act of 1977

4. Although, under the Marihuana Reform Act of 1977 (L 1977, ch 360), which classifies marihuana as a commodity to be measured, for purposes of determining the levels of culpability for sale and possession, under a "pure weight" standard, i.e., the weight of the marihuana itself, rather than an "aggregate weight" standard, i.e., the weight of the blend within which it is contained, a prosecution for sale of a given weight of marihuana, based on an offer to sell, may be sustained notwithstanding the absence of expert testimony as to the actual weight of the marihuana where there is evidence from which a jury may find an offer by the defendant to sell marihuana in excess of that weight and an actual delivery by him, accompanied by representations and negotiations, of a substance which was in excess of that weight and which was seized, analyzed and found to contain marihuana.

Crimes -- Controlled Substances

5. A sale of a given weight of marihuana based on an offer to sell does not require proof that the defendant had knowledge of the actual weight of the marihuana where there [***6] is evidence from which a jury may find that he offered to sell marihuana in excess of that weight, specifically intended to do so, and had a reasonable basis to conclude that he could do so.

Crimes -- Controlled Substances

6. Corpus delicti may be established circumstantially in drug cases.

Crimes -- Controlled Substances

7. Section 15.15 of the Penal Law, which provides that, when the term "knowingly" appears in a statute, it is presumed to apply to every element of the offense unless an intent to limit its application clearly appears, does not require that a defendant charged with the sale of a given weight of marihuana, based on an offer to sell, be shown to have known the pure weight of the marihuana.

 

2207 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bye


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


95 Misc. 2d 1031; 408 N.Y.S.2d 740; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2542



August 31, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, defendant's motion to vacate his judgment of conviction is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10, to vacate a judgment of conviction for menacing and possession of a dangerous instrument rendered against him in 1973.


OVERVIEW: In 1973 defendant was arrested and charged with menacing, a class B misdemeanor, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 120.15 and possession of a dangerous instrument, a class A misdemeanor, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 265.05(9). A one judge trial was conducted and a verdict of guilty on all counts was rendered. Defendant never filed a notice of appeal subsequent to his resentencing. Five years after his conviction, defendant claimed that his constitutional right to a jury trial was denied him and that the procedural infirmity mandated that his conviction be set aside under either N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10(1)(a) or (h). The court stated that there was no doubt that defendant was entitled to a jury trial in 1973. His right to a jury trial was subject to divestiture by an affirmative waiver only. For some reason not readily apparent, defendant was never asked to execute such a waiver at any time and never did execute one. The court held that although defendant's rights were violated in 1973, his opportunity to assert the rights was never substantially impaired. Defendant unjustifiably failed to appeal his lack of a jury trial and he was foreclosed from collaterally attacking it.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to vacate his judgment of conviction.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Right to Trial by Jury

1. There is a fundamental right to a jury trial for "serious offenses", a deprivation of which constitutes a violation of due process; a "serious offense" is one carrying a potential prison sentence of more than six months.

Crimes -- Collateral Attack on Prior Conviction

2. A defendant who, in 1973, was charged with a class A misdemeanor, and was convicted following a one Judge trial cannot, five years later, collaterally attack the judgment of conviction on the ground that his constitutional right to a jury trial was denied ( CPL 440.10, subd 1, par [h]), since although he had a statutory and constitutional right to a jury [***2] trial and never executed an affirmative waiver of this right, CPL 440.10 (subd 2, par [c]) precludes the court from vacating a judgment when the defect appears on the face of the record; inasmuch as defendant could have reviewed the defect, which is violative of both State and Federal constitutional law, on appeal, had one been taken, his motion to vacate the judgment of conviction is denied.

Crimes -- Collateral Attack on Prior Conviction

3. It is the general rule that constitutional defects which appear on the record may not be collaterally attacked; an exception is where a conviction involves an interference with the right to counsel since this is a denial of due process which may preclude the possibility of appeal.

 

2208 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Giese


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Suffolk County


95 Misc. 2d 792; 408 N.Y.S.2d 693; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2507



August 16, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged in consolidated indictments with eight counts of illegal possession of a vehicle identification number (VIN) plate in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 170.70 and being an unregistered motor vehicle dealer in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 415(3), 418. At the close of the prosecution's case at trial, the court dismissed two of the counts charging illegal possession of VIN plates.


OVERVIEW: Police officers armed with a search warrant approached defendant's residence. As the officers approached the premises, they observed defendant backing one of the target vehicles out of the driveway. The officers stopped the car in the street and began a search. The search of the vehicle resulted in the discovery the evidence supporting four of the first five counts in the indictment. During the subsequent trial, defendant contended N.Y. Penal Law § 170.70 was pre-empted by federal law, was vague as to form, and did not embrace used cars manufactured in a foreign country. In addition, defendant asserted the warrant did not authorize the search of the vehicle once it left the premises described in the warrant. The court found § 170.70 was neither unconstitutionally vague nor pre-empted by federal legislation. The court also denied defendant's request for suppression because exigent circumstances extended the premises defined in the warrant to the street location at which the car was stopped and the search was valid.


OUTCOME: The court refused to dismiss the remaining charges against defendant related to illegal possession of vehicle identification numbers. In addition, the court denied defendant's motion to suppress the evidence seized from the car he was driving.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Illegal Possession of Vehicle Identification Number Plate

1. Section 170.70 of the Penal Law, concerning illegal possession of a vehicle identification number plate, is not pre-empted by Federal statute, as while vehicle identification numbers are specified as part of the Federal standards established by Congress to promote motor safety (US Code, tit 15, § 1381 et seq.), it does not necessarily follow that this area has been pre-empted by the "Safety Act" in that the promulgation of the safety standards cannot be said to be so pervasive of the area to prevent the State of New York from enacting and enforcing laws with respect to the illegal possession of vehicle identification [***2] number plates in aid of the effort to reduce the incidence of theft of motor vehicles or enhance powers of enforcement of the laws with respect thereto.

Statutes -- Pre-Emption Doctrine

2. The pre-emption doctrine requires State laws to defer to Federal legislation where any of three elements exist: (1) the scheme of Federal legislation is so complete and pervasive that no room is left for the State to supplement it; (2) the Federal interest is so dominant that State laws on the same subject must yield; or (3) the enforcement of the State statute presents a substantial conflict with the administration of the Federal program.

Crimes -- Illegal Possession of Vehicle Identification Number Plate

3. Section 170.70 of the Penal Law, concerning illegal possession of a vehicle identification number plate, is not unconstitutionally vague as its purpose and language are consistent with the Federal "Safety Act". (US Code, tit 15, § 1381 et seq.)

Crimes -- Illegal Possession of Vehicle Identification Number Plate

4. Section 170.70 of the Penal Law, concerning illegal possession of a vehicle identification number plate, is applicable to foreign made cars [***3] as Federal regulations provide that effective January 1, 1968 a car manufactured on or after that date is not permitted entry in the United States unless it conforms to the "Safety Act" (US Code, tit 15, § 1381 et seq.) or will be put in compliance therewith and while the January 1, 1968 date has application only to the obligations of a manufacturer, it does not exclude from the ambit of section 170.70 of the Penal Law those earlier cars which, in fact, do have such plates as all such vehicles and their vehicle identification number plates are subject to the limits and penalties of that section.

Crimes -- Search Warrant -- Exigent Circumstances Regarding Automobiles

5. A search warrant, which describes the location of the intended search and the property to be seized, i.e., a stolen vehicle, does not render a search and seizure of the target vehicle defective merely because the vehicle was stopped some 100 to 200 feet away from that location whereupon the car, after being returned to the described premises, was searched, as exigent circumstances extended the defined premises to where the car was stopped; such a conclusion is consistent with the so-called "automobile [***4] exception" which holds that an automobile may be searched without a warrant if there is probable cause to believe that the vehicle contains contraband and by inference that exception should apply where there is probable cause to believe it is contraband.

 

2209 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. P.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


96 Misc. 2d 12; 408 N.Y.S.2d 880; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2543



August 16, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, age 16, filed a motion to declare unconstitutional N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(7), which denied trial by jury to a youth who was eligible for mandatory youthful offender treatment at the same time the right was available to any other defendant, a discretionary youthful offender included, who was charged with the same crime; and for trial by jury.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, age 16, was charged with petit larceny and criminal possession of stolen property, both arising out of an alleged pocketbook snatch. Because defendant had never been convicted of a crime or found to be a youthful offender, he was eligible for mandatory adjudication as a youthful offender carrying a maximum penalty of six months incarceration. Defendant filed a motion to declare unconstitutional N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(7), which denied a jury trial to a youth who was eligible for mandatory youthful offender treatment at the same time the right was available to any other defendant, a discretionary youthful offender included, who was charged with the same crime; and for a jury trial. The court granted the motion, determining that § 340.40(7) was unconstitutional because (1) the crimes charged were "serious" under U.S. Const. amend. VI and mandated trial by jury; (2) the statute unconstitutionally permitted the mandatory youthful offender finding for a first conviction to serve as a predicate in a future prosecution without the mandated jury trial; and (3) the statute failed to provide constitutionally mandated treatment as quid pro quo for denial of a jury trial.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Reaching Issue of Constitutionality

1. While a statutory enactment is presumed constitutional and will be struck down only when its "unconstitutionality is shown beyond a reasonable doubt" and courts of first instance particularly should not exercise transcendent power of declaring a statutory enactment unconstitutional except in rare cases where life and liberty are involved and the invalidity of the act is apparent on its face and the conclusion of unconstitutionality is inescapable, when, however, courts of original jurisdiction are unavoidably confronted with the issue of constitutionality, such as where a potential deprivation of liberty is at stake requiring a "leap" in judicial reasoning, they are morally and legally bound to consider it and rule accordingly.

Constitutional Law -- Right to Trial by Jury

2. The right to trial by jury, as transferred from the Sixth Amendment to the Fourteenth Amendment applicable to the separate States, exists in absolute form equal to but separate from the other classic "due process" rights so that the right to trial by jury is applicable to all crimes, felonies or misdemeanors where a [***3] sentence in excess of six months might be handed down regardless of the niceties of language used by the individual States to describe them.

Constitutional Law -- Right of Mandatory Youthful Offender to Trial by Jury

3. CPL 340.40 (subd 7), which denies trial by jury to a youth who is eligible for mandatory youthful offender treatment at the same time this right is available to any other defendant including a discretionary youthful offender who is charged with the same crime, is unconstitutional since the crimes charged are "serious" rather than "petty" within constitutional criteria thus mandating trial by jury regardless of the six-month maximum period of incarceration upon a mandatory youthful offender adjudication. Since the ultimate sentence imposed does not, a fortiori, define the nature of the crime, a crime may be designated as "serious" requiring a jury trial even where a six-month sentence is not imposed by statute such as where the crime itself is morally offensive or in the case of drunken driving, where the accused, in addition to a maximum six-month sentence, is also subject to the loss or suspension of his driver's license, a fine and community criticism,  [***4] having a substantial impact not only on the accused's liberty, but upon his financial resources, travel and occupation as well. The nature of the crimes cannot be changed nor can the moral condemnation of society and the stigma of conviction be diluted simply by trimming some time off the prescribed sentences by sleight of hand.

Constitutional Law -- Right of Mandatory Youthful Offender to Trial by Jury

4. CPL 340.40 (subd 7), which denies trial by jury to a youth who is eligible for mandatory youthful offender treatment at the same time this right is available to any other defendant including a discretionary youthful offender who is charged with the same crime, is unconstitutional in that it permits the mandatory youthful offender finding for a first conviction to serve as a predicate or basis for denial of youthful offender status in a future prosecution. (see CPL 720.10 et seq.) without a constitutionally mandated trial by jury in violation of the predicate felony statute ( CPL 400.21) which requires that a previous conviction be constitutionally rendered before serving as a predicate crime, and contrary to the primary purpose of the youthful offender law of preventing [***5] the imposition of increased punishment on a subsequent conviction of the defendant of a crime. The special classification of youth versus adult which can justify the denial of trial by jury to a youthful offender is not applicable since, in reality, the classes matched against each other under the statutory scheme are youths with no convictions as against youths with prior convictions. The State may not constitutionally move a youth from one category to another on the basis of State action via court proceedings which deny the right to trial by jury.

Constitutional Law -- Right to Treatment in Juvenile Justice System

5. Where a State guarantees benevolent treatment to a classified group, and thereby deprives an individual of liberty for any period however brief through proceedings which lack full constitutional due process protections such as the commitment of mental defectives, the involuntary commitment of persons acquitted of criminal offenses by reason of insanity, and the commitment of youths by judicial proceedings which are constitutionally defective in that they lack trial by jury, it is under a positive obligation to furnish treatment. When a State deprives an [***6] individual of liberty in the name of treatment and fails to furnish it, the cause or pretense of detention becomes illusory thus rendering further confinement constitutionally unlawful.

Constitutional Law -- Right to Treatment in Juvenile Justice System

6. Since the constitutional validity of procedural safeguards in juvenile adjudications, which do not embrace all of the rigorous due process safeguards of criminal court adjudications, rests on the adherence of the juvenile justice system to rehabilitative rather than penal goals giving rise to a positive obligation on the part of the State to furnish treatment where it commits a youth in an otherwise constitutionally defective proceeding, New York's youthful offender statute ( CPL 340.40, subd 7), which denies trial by jury to a youth who is eligible for mandatory youthful offender treatment at the same time this right is available to any other defendant including a discretionary youthful offender charged with the same crime and which provides for benign handling of youthful offenders, is constitutionally defective for totally failing to provide constitutionally mandated treatment as quid pro quo for denial of trial [***7] by jury.

Constitutional Law -- Right of Mandatory Youthful Offender to Trial by Jury

7. The fact that there is a valid basis for classification between adults and young persons does not serve a basis to uphold the constitutionality of New York's youthful offender statute ( CPL 340.40, subd 7), which denies trial by jury to a youth who is eligible for mandatory youthful offender treatment at the same time this right is available to any other defendant including a discretionary youthful offender who is charged with the same crime, since, when one young person commits the same alleged act committed by another youth of the same age and is tried without a jury only because his proposed youthful offender status is mandatory upon conviction as opposed to the other's discretionary status because of a prior record, it is not young person against adult which is the classification under constitutional attack, but rather young person without a record as against young person with a record.

 

2210 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Corr v. Clavin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


96 Misc. 2d 185; 409 N.Y.S.2d 334; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2575



August 11, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Petitioner's application is granted and he shall have judgment as requested in his petition.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner requested a judgment prohibiting the enforcement of an order of respondent judge that rescinded his earlier order granting an application pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.50 to reduce the charge of burglary in the second degree to criminal trespass in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner requested a judgment prohibiting the enforcement of an order of respondent judge that rescinded his earlier order granting an application pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.50 to reduce the charge of burglary in the second degree to criminal trespass in the second degree. Respondent declared that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.40 was unconstitutional and on that basis referred the case to the grand jury. Petitioner claimed that respondent exceeded his authorized powers by rescinding the order granting the reduction of the charge against petitioner. The court granted petitioner's application since respondent exceeded his authority by rescinding the order granting the reduction of the charge against petitioner. Section 180.40 was constitutional under both the federal and state constitutions. Thus, respondent erred in rescinding his order.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioner's application to prohibit the enforcement of an order of respondent judge that rescinded his earlier order granting an application to reduce the charge of burglary to criminal trespass since respondent exceeded his authority by rescinding the order.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Order Regarding Reduction of Charge Pursuant to CPL 180.50

1. A judgment prohibiting the enforcement of an order of respondent, a District Court Judge, which rescinded an earlier order by respondent that had granted an application pursuant to CPL 180.50 reducing the criminal charge against petitioner, is properly granted as the respondent Judge, under such circumstances, lacked the power to issue an order that rescinded his earlier order.

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition

2. A CPLR article 78 proceeding in the nature of prohibition is a proper remedy under circumstances where petitioner claims that respondent, a Judge,  [***2] is acting beyond his jurisdiction and is thereby exceeding his authorized powers in a proceeding over which he has jurisdiction.

Crimes -- Reduction of Felony Complaint to Misdemeanor

3. CPL 180.40 is not rendered unconstitutional by the fact that a felony complaint, prior to its being submitted to the Grand Jury, may be returned by a superior court to a lower court for reconsideration and upon such reconsideration the matter is prosecuted as a misdemeanor, as section 6 of article I of the New York State Constitution mandates Grand Jury action only for capital and otherwise infamous crimes and thus misdemeanors do not come within the purview of that section; moreover, CPL 180.40 involves only a preliminary proceeding and no State constitutional language or case law requires that matters preliminary to a potential felony indictment be conducted or processed only after a Grand Jury proceeding.

Constitutional Law -- Where Grand Jury Action Required

4. CPL 180.40 does not violate the due process clause of the Federal Constitution as Grand Jury action is guaranteed only for capital and other infamous crimes and not for misdemeanors; moreover, such clause is inapplicable [***3] to criminal prosecutions in State courts.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

5. There is a strong presumption that a statute duly enacted by the Legislature is constitutional.

Crimes -- Reduction of Charge

6. CPL 180.40 is not rendered unenforceable by the mandatory language of CPL 190.55 (subd 2, par [a]) as the two statutes must be read together, and as so construed, mean that the District Attorney must present a pending felony complaint to the Grand Jury unless the case is returned to the lower court for reconsideration and upon such reconsideration the matter is prosecuted as a misdemeanor.

Crimes -- Reduction of Charge

7. CPL 180.40 does not improperly permit the District Attorney a unilateral review of a local criminal court's action regarding a pending felony complaint as the District Attorney is not authorized to reduce the pending felony to a misdemeanor but is authorized only to apply to a superior court which is then empowered to request the lower court to reconsider its decision.

 

2211 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York v. State


Claim No. 47847


Court of Claims of New York


95 Misc. 2d 810; 408 N.Y.S.2d 702; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2512



August 10, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner city filed a motion for summary judgment in its action against respondent state to recover interest the city paid to persons whose property had been taken by the city by condemnation under N.Y. High. Law § 340-b.


OVERVIEW: The city filed an action seeking reimbursement from the state for interest in excess of one year, which it had paid to persons whose property the city had taken by condemnation. During the city's pending action, the appellate court held in a similar action that all interest paid by the city was recoverable. The city then filed a motion for summary judgment in view of the appellate court's decision. The state opposed the motion's amount of damages and the city's request for prejudgment interest on the damages. The state stipulated its liability on a large portion of the amount requested by the city, leaving a small portion in dispute. The court granted partial summary judgment for the stipulated amount and held that the state was collaterally estopped from raising the issue of prejudgment interest, that awarding interest on money the city was entitled to over 10 years ago did no more than compensate the city for the state's wrongful withholding and that an award of interest from the date of filing the claim was mandatory and would fully compensate the city.


OUTCOME: The court awarded partial summary judgment to the city in its action to recover from the state interest the city had paid when taking property by condemnation.


HEADNOTES

Damages -- Waiver of Right to Contest Amount of Damages

1. Where a city's claim against the State for reimbursement of interest paid on certain condemnation awards was filed at a time when the Court of Claims Act did not require the State to put in an answer, and the claim was originally dismissed on jurisdictional grounds only, but, on appeal, the State was held liable to the city and the case was remitted for further proceedings, the issue of the city's damages did not become material until that finding of liability was made, and, accordingly, the State's failure to contest the amount of those damages prior to that time did not constitute a waiver of its right to do so in the subsequent proceedings on the claim.

Judgments -- Collateral Estoppel

2. The doctrine of collateral estoppel, as traditionally stated, precludes the relitigation of an issue of fact or law which was necessarily determined in a prior action between the same parties or those in privity with them.

Judgments -- Collateral Estoppel

3. The two necessary requirements [***3] for application of the doctrine of collateral estoppel are (1) an identity of issue which has necessarily been decided in the prior action and which is decisive of the present one, and (2) a full and fair opportunity to contest the decision now said to be controlling.

Interest -- Entitlement to Interest

4. An award of a specific amount of interest necessarily presupposes a finding of a party's entitlement to interest, just as an award of damages necessarily entails a finding of liability.

Judgments -- Collateral Estoppel

5. Where, after the State was held liable on one of a number of pending claims by a city for reimbursement of interest paid on certain condemnation awards, it fully litigated the question of what interest rate was applicable to the judgment awarded by the court, and that judgment made provision for prejudgment interest, the State is collaterally estopped from raising the issue of the city's entitlement to prejudgment interest on another of the city's claims for the identical relief.

Interest -- Award of Prejudgment Interest on Claim for Interest

6. An award of prejudgment interest on damages awarded to a city on a claim by it against [***4] the State for reimbursement of interest paid on certain condemnation awards is not against public policy.

Interest -- Award of Interest against State

7. The prohibition against awarding interest against a governmental entity is simply an element of sovereign immunity which has been waived in this State by virtue of the Court of Claims Act.

Interest -- Award of Interest against State

8. Permission to prosecute a claim in the Court of Claims has been construed, in the absence of restrictive provisions respecting interest, to permit the award of interest to be determined as a matter of discretion.

Courts -- Power of Court of Claims to Award Interest

9. The Court of Claims has authority to award interest upon a judgment in any cause of action which would ordinarily bear interest.

Courts -- Power of Court of Claims to Award Interest

10. The decision of the Court of Appeals in Matter of Brodsky v Murphy (25 NY2d 518), wherein it was held that, absent specific statutory authority, the State was not obliged to pay interest on a tax refund, was decided on the basis of legislative pre-emption in the taxing field and is expressly limited to [***5] awards by administrative agencies, as opposed to courts; that decision imposes no limitation upon the power of the Court of Claims to award interest against the State.

 

2212 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Muessman v. Ward


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


95 Misc. 2d 478; 408 N.Y.S.2d 254; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2450



July 31, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the court finds that the plaintiffs have failed to meet the burden of establishing the unconstitutionality of section 79-a of the Civil Rights Law and grants the motion of the defendant dismissing the complaint pursuant to CPLR 3211 (subd [a], par 7).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff prisoner filed a motion for a declaratory judgment seeking to declare N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 79-a, that prohibited against marriage for prisoners with life sentences of imprisonment, unconstitutional. Defendant warden filed a motion to dismiss the prisoner's action.


OVERVIEW: The prisoner was serving a sentence of three years to life upon her conviction of a class A-III felony. She requested permission to be married from the superintendent of the correctional facility where she was serving her life sentence. The department of corrections denied her request pursuant to § 79-a. The prisoner argued that the right to marry was fundamental and could not be denied without a showing by the State that such a restriction was necessary to promote a compelling State interest. The prisoner also argued that preventing the right to marry violated the equal protection guarantees. The court found that the State's interest in regulating the question of marriage did not constitute a denial of equal protection. The court also found that the statute did not constitute cruel and unusual punishment. Therefore, the prisoner failed to meet the burden of establishing the unconstitutionality of § 79-a.


OUTCOME: The warden's motion to dismiss was granted.


HEADNOTES

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

1. Every legislative enactment carries a strong presumption of constitutionality including a rebuttable presumption of the existence of necessary factual support for its provisions. If any state of facts, known or to be assumed, justifies the law, the court's power of inquiry ends; questions as to wisdom, need or appropriateness are for the Legislature, and courts strike down statutes only as a last resort when unconstitutionality is shown beyond a reasonable doubt.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection -- Identity of Treatment not Required

2. The equal protection clause [***2] of the New York State Constitution (art I, § 11) does not require identity of treatment; the Legislature may classify persons for purposes of legislation without infringement of the equal protection guarantee and its discretion in this regard is broad and will not be disturbed if any state of facts can reasonably be conceived to sustain its classification or even if the classification be fairly debatable, provided only it shall not be palpably arbitrary.

Prisons and Prisoners -- Ban on Marriage for Prisoner with Life Term

3. When a prisoner has been convicted pursuant to a trial in which full due process safeguards have been accorded, incarceration is not the only consequence which can be lawfully imposed following sentence; the prohibition against marriage contained in section 79-a of the Civil Rights Law for those who have been convicted and sentenced for life imprisonment is neither a denial of equal protection nor cruel and unusual punishment; accordingly, since the burden of establishing the unconstitutionality of section 79-a has not been met, a motion to dismiss the complaint is granted.

 

2213 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davoli


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Onondaga County


95 Misc. 2d 402; 407 N.Y.S.2d 432; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2438



July 25, 1978 



DISPOSITION: For the above reasons, then, defendant's motion to dismiss on constitutional grounds is hereby denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the counts of an indictment that charged him with rape in the first degree, attempted rape in the first degree, rape in the third degree, and sexual misconduct on the ground that the statutes were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with numerous counts of sexual assault. Defendant contended that the statutes were unconstitutional because they were gender-based and therefore violated his equal protection rights. The court found that neither the charge of sexual misconduct, under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.20, nor rape in the first degree, under § 130.35, dealt with age, and both involved nonconsensual acts. The court determined that the charge of rape in the third degree, under § 130.25, addressed an age disparity between the parties that was determined to have justified the classification. The court determined that defendant failed in his arguments as to the unconstitutionality of the statutes used in the charges against him. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Rape -- Acts Involving Use of Force

1. New York penal statutes under which a defendant was charged with sexual misconduct (Penal Law, § 130.20, subd 1) and rape in the first degree (Penal Law, § 130.35) deal with nonconsensual acts involving the use of force to some degree. Accordingly, while those statutes are gender based in that only male perpetrators are punished, they are not unconstitutional as being [***2] violative of the equal protection clause.

Crimes -- Rape -- Statutory Rape

2. The age disparity in the definition of rape in the third degree, or statutory rape, which requires that the male be 21 years of age or over and the female less than 17 years of age (Penal Law, § 130.25) is sufficient to justify the gender classification and, accordingly, the statute is not unconstitutional as being violative of the equal protection clause.

Crimes -- Sexual Misconduct

3. Section 130.20 (subd 2) of the Penal Law, which defines sexual misconduct by means of deviate sexual intercourse and is equally applicable to male or female perpetrators, is not gender based and, therefore, is not unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection clause.

 

2214 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Iannucci v. Melton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


95 Misc. 2d 836; 408 N.Y.S.2d 662; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2517



July 21, 1978 



DISPOSITION: The application is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner driver brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 for a judgment directing respondent Commissioner of the Department of Motor Vehicles of the State of New York to issue an operator's license to the driver.


OVERVIEW: The driver pleaded guilty to a charge of operating an uninsured vehicle and was fined $ 100 and had his operator's license revoked. When he subsequently applied for a license, he was informed that his conviction had subjected him to a civil penalty of $ 300. The driver brought an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 for a judgment directing the Commissioner to issue the driver an operator's license. The court denied the application. The court held that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 319, under which the driver's civil penalty was imposed, imposed a civil penalty for operation of a motor vehicle without insurance. This fact may be brought to the Commissioner's attention through receipt of a certificate of conviction or through some other means. The court found that § 319 served a legitimate public purpose and was therefore deemed constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied the driver's application.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Operating Uninsured Motor Vehicle

1. Under section 319 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides that a person convicted of operating a motor vehicle without insurance may be fined not less than $ 100 and, upon conviction, becomes liable for the payment of a civil penalty of $ 300, and which further provides that "Where the commissioner finds, other than by means of the receipt of a certificate of conviction, that a person has violated * * * this section, such person shall become liable for payment * * * of the civil penalty", liability for the civil penalty may be imposed upon a person whose operation of a motor vehicle without insurance was brought to the attention of the Department of Motor Vehicles through receipt of a certificate of conviction or through some other means.

Constitutional Law -- Presumption of Constitutionality

2. Legislative enactments are presumed constitutional and are presumed to be supported by facts known [***3] to the Legislature and found by it to require the legislation.

Motor Vehicles -- Operating Uninsured Motor Vehicle

3. Section 319 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides that a person convicted of operating a motor vehicle without insurance may be fined not less than $ 100 and, upon conviction, becomes liable for the payment of a civil penalty of $ 300, does not violate the constitutional prohibition against double jeopardy, nor does it constitute punishing for the same offense twice, since the imposition of the penalty and of the criminal prosecution are but parts of one punishment for the offense.

Constitutional Law -- Police Power

4. Through its police power, the State may impose penalties for violation of statutory requirements.

Motor Vehicles -- Operating Uninsured Motor Vehicle

5. Section 319 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides that a person convicted of operating a motor vehicle without insurance may be fined not less than $ 100 and, upon conviction, becomes liable for the payment of a civil penalty of $ 300 serves a legitimate public purpose and is constitutional.

 

2215 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Thomas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


95 Misc. 2d 289; 407 N.Y.S.2d 812; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2419



July 13, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants were charged with tampering with utility meters in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15. Defendants moved to dismiss all charges contending that § 165.15 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15 provided that proof that a meter had been tampered with shall be presumptive evidence that the person to whom the service was being furnished had created the condition so existing. Thus, whenever a meter had been tampered with, the statute permitted the trier of fact to conclude that the tampering was done by the person who received the metered service. The court held that a presumption in a criminal case must satisfy the "reasonable doubt" standard. The court concluded that because the presumed fact did not flow from the established fact beyond a reasonable doubt, its use in a criminal case was constitutionally impermissible. Therefore, the court held that § 165.15(6) was constitutionally defective under the due process clause. Accordingly, the court granted defendants' motions to dismiss.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed defendants' motion to dismiss the charges of tampering with utility meters.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Theft of Services

A presumption in a criminal case, which serves to supply an element of the crime charged, must satisfy the reasonable doubt standard as the due process clause protects the accused against conviction except upon proof beyond a reasonable doubt of every fact necessary to constitute the crime; accordingly, the recent amendment to section 165.15 of the Penal Law concerning theft of services, which provides that proof that a utility meter has been tampered with shall be presumptive evidence that the person to whom the service is being furnished has created the condition, is constitutionally defective, as while it may be likely or probable that a defendant has the requisite knowledge of the condition, this likelihood or probability is not certainty beyond a reasonable doubt and the fact that the presumption is rebuttable does not make it any less impermissible, as a presumption that permits the jury to find an element of the offense when it has not been established independently beyond a reasonable doubt is alone sufficient to invalidate the statute.

 

2216 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Williamsburg Volunteer Ambulance Corps v. Wendt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Civil Court of the City of New York, New York County


95 Misc. 2d 414; 408 N.Y.S.2d 207; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2441



July 11, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff volunteer ambulance corps filed a motion for summary judgment in its replevin action against defendant Property Clerk of the Police Department of the City of New York to recover cash that was held by the property clerk.


OVERVIEW: The volunteer ambulance corps held a gambling night, and police, with a search warrant, seized various gambling machines and an amount of cash and arrested several people. Most of the charges were dismissed and the cash returned to individuals. The money which belonged to the volunteer ambulance corps was found not to be contraband and not to be needed as evidence. The district attorney issued a release. The volunteer ambulance corps made a demand on the property clerk for release of the money. The property clerk refused to release the money and did not institute a forfeiture proceeding. The volunteer ambulance corps then filed this replevin action. The court granted its motion for summary judgment and found that it was entitled to have the money returned. The court concluded that the property clerk could not claim any legal interest in the property if it was not contraband. The court found that once the district attorney's office issued a release and the owner had made a demand for the property, the property clerk had to release the property or within 10 days institute a forfeiture proceeding to contest the claim on the property.


OUTCOME: The court granted the volunteer ambulance corps' motion for summary judgment and ordered the property clerk to return the money to it.


HEADNOTES

Replevin -- Property Held by Police Property Clerk -- Obligation to Return to Claimant

1. Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is granted in a replevin action to recover $ 4,015.06 in cash held by the property clerk of the New York City Police Department, the money having been seized at a "Las Vegas Nite" sponsored by the plaintiff, since the property clerk refused to return the funds to the plaintiff although presented with the District Attorney's release and a demand by the plaintiff,  [***2] inasmuch as the clerk did not institute a forfeiture proceeding challenging the plaintiff's claim of rightful ownership; once the criminal proceedings relating to the money in question were terminated or adjourned in contemplation of dismissal and the District Attorney's release verified that the money was no longer needed as evidence, its retention by the property clerk after due demand for its return constituted an illegal act and an unconstitutional deprivation of property without due process. Except for contraband, property forfeited by court order or abandoned property, the police property clerk can claim no legal interest in money or property taken from an arrested person or obtained as evidence in a criminal proceeding once the related criminal proceeding has been terminated, or the property is no longer needed as evidence.

Replevin -- Property Held by Police Property Clerk -- Burden of Proof

2. The police property clerk may not constitutionally impose upon a claimant the burden of proving rightful ownership of property or money held by the property clerk; rather, the only course by which the property clerk can raise a dispute as to the claimant's claim of ownership [***3] or assert that the money is the proceeds of or was used in furtherance of a crime is by promptly instituting a forfeiture or other similar judicial proceeding.

Municipal Corporations -- Notice of Claim -- Actual Notice Sufficient

3. In a replevin action to recover $ 4,015.06 in cash held by the police property clerk of the New York City Police Department, the money having been seized at a "Las Vegas Nite" sponsored by the plaintiff, the defendants cannot avoid return of the property by raising as an affirmative defense the failure of the plaintiff to file a notice of claim pursuant to section 50-e of the General Municipal Law since the record establishes that the defendants had substantial actual notice of the plaintiff's claim constituting compliance with the statute's notice of claim provision.

 

2217 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Quinn v. Aetna Life & Casualty Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


96 Misc. 2d 545; 409 N.Y.S.2d 473; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2639; 4 Media L. Rep. 1049



July 5, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a suit for a permanent injunction against defendants insurance company and publishers to restrain the publication of advertising which implied that large damage awards in personal injury actions were often unrelated to the extent of the injury, plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, and defendants sought to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action. U.S. Const. amend. I, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 350-a.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, three women, each of whom was also a plaintiff in a personal injury action, sued to restrain the publication of two advertisements entitled "Too Bad Judges Can't Read This to a Jury" and "And Now, The Big Winners in Today's Lawsuits," submitted for publication by defendant insurance company to defendant newsmagazines. The court held that plaintiffs stated a cause of action against defendant insurance company, because commercial speech was protected only so long as it was truthful, as reflected in N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 350-a, and could be regulated in ways that noncommercial speech could not. Further, because the advertising was clearly geared toward influencing jurors and potential jurors, it also violated state public policy against jury tampering, and distorted the trial process by providing otherwise inadmissible evidence. However, the court did not grant plaintiffs a preliminary injunction because they failed to sustain their burden of demonstrating a clear right to it. Because a different standard, that of actual malice, was applied to news media than to an advertiser, the court dismissed the action against defendant publishers.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the suit against the publishers because no actual malice was shown. However, plaintiffs did state a cause of action against the advertising insurance company, because commercial speech has less protection than noncommercial speech, and misleading speech has no protection. The court did not grant the preliminary injunction, because plaintiffs did not demonstrate a clear right to the relief.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Prior Restraint on Press

1. While there is a "heavy presumption" against the constitutional validity of prior restraints which impose a limitation on what the press may publish, injunctive relief may be permissible to regulate the content of speech in certain areas such as cases involving obscenity or advocating the overthrow of the government. Similarly, statutes which reasonably regulate the time, manner and place of speech have been upheld. Legitimate attempts to protect the public from present excesses of direct, active conduct, are not presumptively bad because they interfere with and, in some of its manifestations, restrain the exercise of First Amendment rights.

Constitutional Law -- Prior Restraint of Commercial Speech

2. While commercial speech is constitutionally protected [***3] from prior restraint under the First Amendment since the free flow of commercial information is indispensable to an informed public (see Virginia Pharmacy Bd. v Virginia Consumer Council, 425 U.S. 748), the protection afforded is less than that provided for noncommercial speech, so that when commercial expression is false or misleading it is afforded no protection whatsoever and may be regulated by the State. (See General Business Law, § 350-a.)

Constitutional Law -- Restraint of Misleading Advertising

3. The continued publication of misleading advertisements paid for by defendant insurance company which imply that personal injury awards are often excessive and unwarranted, without mentioning that such allegedly excessive awards may be reduced or set aside if, in fact, excessive or unwarranted, may be constitutionally restrained since said advertisements, formulated to convince prospective jurors to arbitrarily reduce personal injury awards, directly contravene the rights of plaintiffs in pending personal injury actions to an impartial jury and directly contravene the State public policy against the publication of misleading advertising. (General Business Law, § [***4] 350-a.)

Constitutional Law -- Restraint of Misleading Advertising

4. While false or misleading advertising is not protected under the First Amendment and can constitutionally be restrained, the right of the news media to publish the commercial speech is constitutionally protected from prior restraint since the news media, which is subject to a different standard than the advertiser, is merely the conduit for the speech of the advertiser and therefore will not be held liable for the publication of advertising which is false or misleading unless actual malice is shown.

Constitutional Law -- Prior Restraints on Reporting of Judicial Proceedings

5. When the right of free speech conflicts with the right to an impartial judicial proceeding, a "balancing" approach must be employed to assure that neither of these fundamental rights encroaches too far upon the other. The reporting of, or commenting on, judicial proceedings must pose a "clear and present danger" constituting an "imminent, not merely a likely, threat to the administration of justice" before interference with First Amendment rights can be permissible by the issuance of prior restraints which carry a "heavy [***5] presumption" against their constitutional validity.

Constitutional Law -- Restraint on Misleading Advertising

6. Advertisements paid for by defendant insurance company geared toward influencing potential jurors in personal actions in their decision-making process by implying that personal injury awards are often excessive and unwarranted to the detriment of "every payer of liability insurance premiums" and by cautioning juries "to bear in mind that money doesn't grow on trees", may be restrained as violative of the public policy against jury tampering. (Penal Law, § 215.25.) While there is a balancing between free speech and fair trial, where, as here, there is a direct assault upon the jurors, the balance weighs more heavily on the side of a fair trial, thereby permitting the restraint of information which poses a threat to the impaneling of an impartial jury, not curable by voir dire, despite the First Amendment. Moreover, since due process requires "that the jury's verdict be based on evidence received in open court, not from outside sources", the advertisements may lawfully be restrained for supplying evidence which might otherwise be inadmissible at trial and [***6] which the plaintiffs have no opportunity to refute.

Constitutional Law -- Restraint of Misleading Advertising

7. Since advertisements paid for by defendant insurance company, which imply that personal injury awards are often excessive and unwarranted to the detriment of "every payer of liability insurance premiums", violate the State public policy against jury tampering (Penal Law, § 215.25), unduly burden plaintiffs' right to an impartial jury, distort the trial process by providing otherwise inadmissible insurance evidence, and do not represent the speech of the news media, an injunction restraining these advertisements may constitutionally lie as against defendant insurance company, but not against the news media which publishes the advertisements since, as to them, the more stringent "clear and present danger" standard necessary for a direct prior restraint of the press has not been satisfied.

Injunctions -- Preliminary Injunction

8. Even if a preliminary injunction may constitutionally be granted, the motion must nevertheless be denied unless plaintiffs demonstrate that they are entitled to such relief by satisfactorily establishing a likelihood of success [***7] on the merits, that irreparable injury will result absent injunctive relief, and a balancing of equities in their favor.

Constitutional Law -- Restraint of Misleading Advertising

9. Although plaintiffs, who have pending personal injury actions, have shown that advertisements paid for by defendant insurance company which imply that personal injury awards are often excessive and unwarranted, violate their right to an impartial jury, not curable by voir dire, they are not entitled to a preliminary injunction restraining defendant from continuing the advertisements since they have not sustained their burden of showing a clear right to such preliminary relief in the first instance. Since there is a basis for finding that the language of the advertisements is not constitutionally protected and that the language impedes plaintiffs' ability to impanel a constitutionally guaranteed impartial jury, plaintiffs have established a cause of action for a permanent injunction against defendant insurance company, but, due to the stringent conditions which must be satisfied when seeking to restrain freedom of the press, the cause of action is dismissed as to defendant publishers.

 

2218 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Zanders


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Bronx County


95 Misc. 2d 82; 407 N.Y.S.2d 410; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2385



June 23, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The District Attorney served a subpoena on the New York City Transit Authority (transit authority) to produce the entire personnel file of the defendant, a transit police officer. The state filed a motion to quash the subpoena on the grounds that the subpoena sought privileged material and that it was too broad in scope.


OVERVIEW: The court found that prior to the enactment of N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 50, police personnel files were confidential and were not open to inspection by a district attorney or anyone else. The most the law permitted was an in camera inspection. The court then found that § 50 sets strict limitations on the availability of such files and that § 50 expanded the prior law to allow the portion of personnel files that are used to evaluate performance toward continued employment or promotion to be available upon a clear showing of facts sufficient to warrant an in camera inspection by a judge, after which, only the relevant portion shall be made available. The transit authority's regulations as to personnel records, promulgated pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 88, led to a similar conclusion. The court found total access to such personnel files was not allowed by anyone. The court found an in camera inspection by the court was necessary to determine which records of the transit police officer pertain to evaluation towards continued employment or promotion.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to quash as to the parts of the personnel files that pertain to evaluation towards continued employment or promotion. The court granted the motion as to those portions not within the classification. The court ordered an in camera inspection to determine what fell within the classification and what without.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Discovery -- Personnel Records of Police Officers

A portion of defendant police officer's personnel file, specifically those records used to evaluate performance toward continued employment or promotion, may be made available to the District Attorney upon a clear showing of facts sufficient to warrant an in camera inspection by the Judge; after such inspection, only the relevant and material portion shall be made available to the requesting party. (see Civil Rights Law, § 50-a; Public Officers Law, § 89.)

 

2219 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Nyquist


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


94 Misc. 2d 466; 408 N.Y.S.2d 606; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2270



June 23, 1978 



DISPOSITION: For their consistently co-operative and courteous relationship with the court, all counsel have its sincere thanks.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following interventions, plaintiffs, school districts, students, cities, cities' officials, boards of education and parent association (schools), alleged that defendant, state and its university, education commissioner, comptroller, and finance commissioner (state), had implemented a method of financing public education which was unconstitutional under N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 1, N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11, and U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: Through utilization of local property taxes, the state enacted a sliding scale formula for dispersing state aid to public schools. However, the vast majority of school districts operated under a "save-harmless" provision that prevented reduction of the state aid, which rendered the equalization measures useless. The schools filed suit to challenge the formula. The court awarded judgment to the schools. The evidence was uncontroverted that the formula had resulted in spending variations of more than 80 percent between districts and adversely affected educational quality, which denied equal educational opportunity. The federal equal protection attack based solely on property tax use was foreclosed by precedent. But, the aid's disbursement violated both the sliding scale and the rational basis tests for state and federal equal protection, because the formula irrationally perpetuated the inequities it was enacted to avert.
