Penal Law § 265.15 that the presence in an automobile of any firearm was presumptive evidence of its possession by all persons occupying the automobile at the time the weapon was found.


OVERVIEW: Defendants asserted that a legal impediment to conviction existed in that a federal court of appeals had declared the presumption of possession of a firearm contained in N.Y. Penal Law § 265.15 unconstitutional on its face. The State argued that the federal decision was not binding on the court. The court denied the motion. The court pointed out that it was clear that in New York, the courts had generally felt that absent a direction of the Supreme Court of the United States, the decisions of lower federal courts were not controlling. The court found that where a New York statute was declared unconstitutional by a United States court, other than the Supreme Court of the United States, such federal decision did not constitute a "legal impediment" under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(1)(h) to a continuing prosecution under the same statute in the New York state courts.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion of one defendant, joined in by all defendants in the prosecution of defendants for unlawful possession of a firearm, that sought a finding that the presumption of possession of a firearm discovered in an automobile was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Effect of Rulings of Lower Federal Courts

A decision by a Federal court, other than the Supreme Court of the United States, declaring a New York penal statute unconstitutional, does not constitute a legal impediment ( CPL 210.20, sudb 1 par [h]) to a continuing prosecution under the same statute in New York State courts.

 

2237 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Spa Xanadu, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


94 Misc. 2d 10; 403 N.Y.S.2d 1009; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2188



April 10, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The convictions are vacated and proceedings dismissed in the interests of justice pursuant to CPL 170.40.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a corporation, was substituted without objection for the individual named defendant after a verdict of guilty had been entered on the charges that defendant had violated building regulations.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a health club and took over its present location from a prior lessee, also a health club, which failed because of insufficient funds to complete a swimming pool. All work left undone by the prior lessee had been approved by the department of buildings and was completed by defendant. Five months after moving in defendant applied for a building permit. The department served a peremptory vacate notice on defendant on the grounds that egress was inadequate. The order was challenged and set aside. An ad hoc agreement was immediately reached where the department allowed the egress to have been constructed by defendant. The department permitted the work to go forward and then brought the prosecutions against defendant for completion of the work without approval. The court held that the same instrumentality that prosecuted defendant was responsible, by its own informal agreement, for the violation of which it complained. Even though the doctrine of estoppel was inapplicable the court concluded that good faith was still relevant and the department had created an impossible burden.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the convictions and dismissed the proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Enforcement of Building Regulations

The conviction of corporate defendant, a health club, for completing work on the egresses from its premises without the approval of the Department of Buildings of the City of New York, in violation of the zoning moratorium aimed at the proliferation of massage parlors, is vacated in the interests of justice ( CPL 170.40) since the Department of Buildings, by first serving a peremptory vacate notice on defendant on the grounds that egress was inadequate after defendant had completed previously approved work which had been left undone by the prior lessee and then closing off the means of compliance with the building regulations by withholding its approval, created an impossible burden tantamount to a confiscatory deprivation of property. The department, which brought on the prosecutions for completion of the work without approval only after permitting the work to go forward, has already granted an exception to the zoning moratorium to another health and racquet club. It would therefore be counterproductive to the [***2] orderly administration of justice to have the stigma of an adjudication of guilt and its attendant cloud on title stand in the face of the overpowering equities in favor of defendant.

 

2238 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Malcuria v. Seneca


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Ontario County


93 Misc. 2d 799; 403 N.Y.S.2d 880; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2137



April 4, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all of the foregoing, and this being a motion for summary judgment, the county's motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant county filed a motion for summary judgment to dismiss plaintiff owners' complaint as to the county in the owners' action against the county and defendant town. The owners demanded a permanent injunction to restrain defendants from discharging water onto the owners' property, requiring defendants to proceed with plans to make adequate legal disposition of the water. The owners also requested recovery for damages.


OVERVIEW: There was a ditch along the side of a road that collected surface water, which was carried under the road through three culverts allegedly installed by defendants, discharging water on the owners' land. The road was a town highway. It was the county's position that it had no duty in relation to the road and that, therefore, it could not have been held accountable for any claims arising from the operation or maintenance of the road. The court denied the county's motion for summary judgment to dismiss the owners' complaint as to the county. Under N.Y. High. Law § 102, the county had an obligation to inspect, repair, or otherwise maintain the road. Assuming that the county performed those duties as required, the county superintendent, pursuant to § 102(6), approved the plans and specifications for the construction and maintenance of the road, including the installation of the culverts in question. Pursuant to § 102(1), the superintendent had general charge and supervision of the work. The question was still open as to whether compliance with N.Y. County Law § 52, and through it N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law §§ 50-e, 50-i, was a condition precedent in an action seeking injunctive relief.


OUTCOME: The court denied the county's motion for summary judgment to dismiss the owners' complaint as to the county in the owners' action against the county and the town for injunctive and other relief for damages caused to the owners' property from discharged water.


HEADNOTES

Counties -- Responsibility for Maintenance of Town Road

1. In plaintiffs' action to permanently enjoin defendant town and defendant county from discharging water onto their land from a drainage ditch running along the side of a town highway, the allegations of defendant county that it was in no way involved in the construction or maintenance of the town highway and the drainage ditch and could therefore not be held accountable for any claims arising from the operation and maintenance of the road, are insufficient to foreclose plaintiffs on a motion for summary judgment since, under section 102 of the Highway Law, the county Superintendent of Public Works has general charge and supervision of the work of constructing, improving, repairing and maintaining all county roads and town highways within the county and has the duty of approving plans and specifications for the construction and maintenance of town highways. Assuming that the county performed its duties as required, the superintendent approved the plans and specifications for the construction and maintenance of [***2] the town road including the installation of the culverts which allegedly cause the discharge of water onto plaintiffs' land.

Counties -- Notice of Claim Requirement in Equitable Action

2. Plaintiffs' failure to comply with the notice of claim requirements of section 52 of the County Law before commencing an action to permanently enjoin defendant county from discharging water onto their land from a drainage ditch running along a town highway does not warrant the dismissal of the complaint on defendant's motion for summary judgment in light of the lack of any definitive case law holding the notice of claim requirements applicable where the relief demanded is primarily equitable in nature and the monetary relief demanded is merely "incidental to" the equitable relief sought. Plaintiffs are entitled to the benefit of the doubt on a motion for summary judgment since the question is still open as to whether or not compliance with section 52 of the County Law is a condition precedent in an action seeking injunctive relief.

 

2239 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Shore


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


93 Misc. 2d 933; 403 N.Y.S.2d 990; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2157



April 4, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent corporation sought to strike the testimony of petitioner shareholders' expert witnesses in their appraisal action under N.Y. Bus. Corp. Law § 623, claiming that it was given on the basis of illegal compensation arrangements. They sought a stay of the proceeding until the resolution of a related federal class action for damages.


OVERVIEW: The court found that experts were not incompetent to testify simply because they were being paid a contingent fee. The nature of the fee arrangement was relevant only as to credibility, not competency to testify. Further, the experts were hired at a time when Model Code of Prof'l Responsibility DR 7-109, which limited the manner in which a lawyer could compensate a witness, had been held unconstitutional. Thus, to deprive shareholders of the opportunity to have the testimony considered would have punished them for what hindsight showed to have been a mistake of judgment in relying on a lower court holding. The court found that corporation's right to seek a stay of the action was waived by its failure to do so previously. It had, in fact, previously opposed an application for a stay brought by shareholders. Respondent attempted to explain its inconsistent positions by asserting a change in the law on collateral estoppel. However, the court found that that decision should have come as no surprise based upon its recent decisions.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Witnesses -- Contingent Fee Paid to Expert Witness

1. Three accountants who are being paid a contingent fee by petitioners to testify as expert witnesses in a consolidated appraisal proceeding (Business Corporation Law, § 623) brought by two groups of dissenting shareholders, are not incompetent to testify in the appraisal proceeding by reason of the contingent fee since the nature of an expert's fee arrangement is relevant only to his credibility not his competency to testify. DR 7-109 (C) of the Code of Professional Responsibility which prohibits a lawyer from offering to pay or acquiescing in the "payment of compensation to a witness contingent upon the content of his testimony or the outcome of the case" only represents an indirect "legislative judgment" with respect to contingent fees and in no way limits the applicability of CPLR 4512 which does not preclude a witness from testifying "by reason of his interest in the event". The disciplinary rule only gives the Appellate Division, through its disciplinary powers over attorneys, the power to indirectly limit the provisions of CPLR 4512 and does not provide an exception thereto.

Corporations -- Stay of Appraisal  [***2] Proceeding Pending Outcome of Federal Action

2. Respondent, formerly a "public" corporation which went "private" to enable the major shareholder to repay his personal indebtedness, waived its right to a stay of a nonjury appraisal proceeding (Business Corporation Law, § 623) pending the determination of the Federal court class action suit brought against respondent and its officers for damages arising out of misrepresentations made in a prospectus, by successfully opposing petitioner's prior application for a stay pending the outcome of the Federal action. Respondent should have been aware at the time of petitioner's application for a stay that its right to a jury trial on the issue of damages in the Federal action could be lost by the application of collateral estoppel based on a finding of fair market value in the appraisal proceeding.

 

2240 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kuhl v. Hubbard


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


93 Misc. 2d 1058; 403 N.Y.S.2d 871; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2174



March 29, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, Commissioner of Assessment of the City of Middletown and others, filed a motion to dismiss the proceeding for want of prosecution in petitioner taxpayers' action pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law art.7 to review the 1976 tax assessment on certain real property of the taxpayers.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers filed an action under N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law art.7 to review the 1976 tax assessment on certain real property. Respondents filed a motion to dismiss for want of prosecution under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3216(e) after more than a year passed following joinder of issue and the taxpayers did not respond within 45 days to a written demand filed by respondents for resumption of the prosecution of the proceeding and a note of issue. The court denied the motion, holding that, although N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3216 was applicable to tax certiorari proceedings, and N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 718 was not applicable, respondents had not shown prejudice by the delay, the taxpayers had shown merit to the proceeding and justification for the delay, and the taxpayers would be grievously injured if the motion to dismiss were granted. The court directed the taxpayers to serve and file a note of issue in compliance with respondents' previously served demand.


OUTCOME: The court denied respondents' motions to dismiss upon the condition that the taxpayers, within 20 days of service of a copy of the order with notice of entry, serve and file a note of issue in compliance with the previously served demand by respondents.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Failure to Prosecute Tax Assessment Review Proceeding

1. Since there is no specific statute regulating tax certiorari procedure, CPLR 3216, which authorizes the dismissal of an action or proceeding for want of prosecution if the party upon whom is served a demand to resume prosecution of the action more than one year after joinder of issue, fails to serve and file a note of issue within 45 days "unless the said [***2] party shows justifiable excuse for the delay and a good and meritorious cause of action", is applicable to tax certiorari proceedings (Real Property Tax Law, art 7) in which the customary and long-standing practice is to accumulate several years of tax assessment review proceedings for ultimate consolidation in one trial prior to filing notes of issues because of the prohibitive costs involved in challenging tax assessments. If certain of the rules or statutes which comprise the tax assessment review procedure are unduly costly and burdensome to small taxpayers the remedy lies in challenging those specific rules and procedures or in seeking legislative relief.

Taxation -- Failure to Prosecute Tax Assessment Review Proceeding

2. Section 718 of the Real Property Tax Law, which mandates the automatic dismissal of a tax assessment review proceeding in which a note of issue is not filed within four years after service of the petition and notice, does not evince a legislative determination that four years is a reasonable time within which to file a note of issue in a tax review proceeding and therefore does not conflict with CPLR 3216 which involves possible dismissal of the [***3] proceeding for want of prosecution where there has been a delay in prosecution of one year and a subsequent demand made to resume prosecution. Under section 718 a four-year delay is not per se unreasonable, but a delay of one year followed by a demand to resume prosecution under CPLR 3216, which is not complied with, may be grounds for a dismissal for want of prosecution.

Taxation -- Failure to Prosecute Tax Assessment Review Proceeding

3. Notwithstanding the applicability of CPLR 3216, which authorizes the dismissal of an action or proceeding for want of prosecution where there has been a delay of one year followed by an uncomplied with demand to resume prosecution, to tax certiorari proceedings (Real Property Tax Law, art 7) petitioners' delay in filing notes of issue does not warrant dismissal of the tax review proceedings since petitioners have shown some merit to the proceedings and justification for the delay which resulted from the customary practice of accumulating several years of tax review proceedings for ultimate consolidation in one trial prior to filing notes of issue. In addition, since the 30-day Statute of Limitations has long since run, petitioners would [***4] be grievously injured if the proceedings were dismissed.

 

2241 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Washington Federal Sav. & Loan Asso. v. Schneider


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


95 Misc. 2d 924; 408 N.Y.S.2d 588; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2529



March 27, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, for the reasons noted, the referee's report is confirmed and defendant Stonegate's motion is granted in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff bank challenged the decision of the Supreme Court in Rockland County (New York), which found in favor of defendant condominium association and ruled that even though the association's lien against foreclosed property was filed subsequent to the bank's second mortgage, the association's lien had priority under N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 339-z.


OVERVIEW: The condominium owners (owners) gave a second mortgage affecting their home to the bank, which recorded the mortgage. The condominium association (association) subsequently filed a lien against the property for principal and interest then due for the condominium's common charges. The premises were eventually sold in foreclosure. However, there was not enough money to pay off both liens. The referee found that the association's lien had priority under N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 339-z. On review, the court found that under § 339-z, once notice of the lien was filed, by such act the lien for common charges obtained a priority over previously filed liens and mortgages, even that of the bank. The only exceptions were liens for taxes or first mortgages. Therefore, the referee's report that found in favor of the association was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The trial court's decision was affirmed. The condominium association's lien for unpaid principal and interest on condominium unit had priority over the bank's second mortgage.


HEADNOTES

Condominiums -- Statutory Lien for Unpaid Common Charges

1. Pursuant to section 339-z of the Real Property Law, which provides that a lien for condominium common charges in favor of the condominium's board of managers is "prior to all of other liens" other than that of a first mortgagee of record or a municipality for realty taxes, and the ensuing section 339-aa, which provides that such a lien for common charges is not effective until filed "in the office [***2] of the recording officer", a properly filed statutory lien for condominium common charges is entitled to priority over a previously recorded second mortgage since, although the lien for common charges is without force and effect until filed, once the notice of lien is so filed, however, such lien obtains a priority over previously filed liens and mortgages except for the two statutory exceptions. Any contrary interpretation of the statutory scheme, granting priority to a lien for condominium common charges over a second mortgage only where such lien was filed prior in time to said second mortgage, would be a perversion of the apparent legislative intention to afford priority to a lien for common charges over a second mortgage even where such lien was filed after the second mortgage and would render section 339-z largely meaningless since the concept of prior in time, prior in right, is already well established by the "recording acts". (Real Property Law, art 9.)

Condominiums -- Statutory Lien for Unpaid Common Charges

2. The priority of a properly filed statutory lien for "unpaid common charges" in favor of a condominium's board of managers over a previously recorded [***3] second mortgage, "such unpaid common charges" to be "paid out of the sale proceeds or by the grantee" upon the sale or conveyance of a condominium unit (Real Property Law, § 339-z), is not limited to the accrued common charges of record at the time of the foreclosure, but instead covers the total accrued common charges due at the time of the sale or conveyance of the underlying property since, consistent with the overriding legislative concern of ensuring the continued viability of the entire condominium project and protecting those who have invested substantial sums of their life savings from unit owners who have failed to pay their common charges, the statute, which lacks any limiting language, must be interpreted to include all unpaid common charges which have accrued. A requirement that the board of managers update its liens monthly in order to protect additional amounts accruing each month would be costly, burdensome and contrary to the legislative objective.

Condominiums -- Statutory Lien for Unpaid Common Charges

3. Sections 339-z and 339-aa of the Real Property Law, which grant a properly filed lien for unpaid condominium common charges priority over a previously [***4] recorded second mortgage, are constitutional, being reasonable and necessary to protect a legitimate interest of the Legislature, which has the power to make reasonable exceptions to New York's recording acts. Defendant second mortgagee bank should have been aware of the fact that, at the time it agreed to take a second mortgage on the subject condominium unit, such a second mortgage was subject to having its priority displaced by a lien for common charges.

 

2242 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. O'Neal


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rome


93 Misc. 2d 953; 404 N.Y.S.2d 250; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2160



March 22, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The informations herein are dismissed and the defendants are released.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved to dismiss the informations charging them with behaving in a disorderly manner in violation of Rome, N.Y., Code of Ordinances art. XXI, § 21-3, alleging that the informations were defective within the meaning of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.30(1)(a) because the ordinance was unconstitutional or otherwise invalid.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with behaving in a disorderly manner in private premises in violation of Rome, N.Y., Code of Ordinances art. XXI, § 21-3. They moved to dismiss the informations alleging that they were defective within the meaning of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.30(1)(a) because the city ordinance defining the offense charged was unconstitutional or otherwise invalid. The court dismissed the informations, holding that the city ordinance was more restrictive than the analogous state disorderly conduct statute and was therefore unconstitutional under the home rule provisions of the New York constitution. Under N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(c)(ii)(10), N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(ii)(a)(12), and N.Y. Gen. City Law § 20(13), the city had the power to enact penal ordinances within their power, provided the field was not pre-empted. However, the state had adopted N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20, which preempted varying local disorderly conduct laws. The city's disorderly conduct ordinance made unlawful disturbances in private premises, which were clearly not proscribed by the state statute. Accordingly, the city's ordinance was preempted.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the informations, holding that the city ordinance was more restrictive than the analogous state disorderly conduct statute and was therefore unconstitutional under home rule provisions of the New York constitution. The city's ordinance made unlawful disturbances in private premises, which were not proscribed by the state statute.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Pre-emption of State Law

A municipality's penal statute is unconstitutional under the "home rule" provision of the State Constitution (NY Const, art IX, § 2) if the field has been pre-empted; where the State has acted upon a subject and, in so acting, has evidenced a desire that its general laws should pre-empt the possibility of varying local laws, a local enactment may be said to be inconsistent with State law if it prohibits that which has been found acceptable under State law. Accordingly, a local disorderly conduct ordinance that is more restrictive than the State statute, in that the local ordinance prohibits the creation of unlawful disturbances not merely in public places but also in private premises, is unconstitutional as it prohibits that which is not proscribed by State law in an area that has been pre-empted.

 

2243 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cunningham v. Stern


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County (Action No.1.); Niagara County (Action No. 2.)


93 Misc. 2d 516; 404 N.Y.S.2d 241; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2092



March 9, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In the proceedings brought under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioner town justices sought to contest the legality of an investigation and prosecution by respondent, the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct, of the town justices for alleged misconduct in the performance of their judicial duties. The Commission filed a motion to dismiss pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7804, subd. f.


OVERVIEW: The petitions sought relief in the nature of a writ of prohibition enjoining the Commission's further investigation and prosecution of the justices under N.Y. Jud. Law art. 2-A and N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 22. The actions were primarily founded upon allegations of unconstitutional and unlawful investigative practices and other prosecutorial misconduct by the Commission. The Commission was also said to have acted in excess of its authority and in an arbitrary and capricious manner. The pending charges were said to constitute discriminatory enforcement of judicial standards and selective prosecution. The court found that the constitutional and statutory provisions established a quasi-judicial administrative procedure for the investigation and prosecution of alleged judicial misconduct. The actions of the Commission were investigatory and advisory in nature and were nothing more than nonfinal administrative activities as to which judicial review under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 would not lie. Nor did the prosecutorial misconduct, selective prosecution, or other alleged errors justify a different result. The extraordinary remedy of prohibition was not available in the case.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petitions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Judges -- Disciplinary Proceedings

The investigatory and advisory actions of respondent commission, a Statewide quasi-judicial administrative agency empowered to receive, initiate, investigate, report, or otherwise act on complaints concerning the qualifications, conduct, fitness, or official performance of any Judge or Justice within the unified court system (NY Const, art VI, § 22; Judiciary Law, art 2-A), in requesting the convening of the Court on the Judiciary to hear charges of alleged misconduct against three Town Justices are not subject to judicial review in an article 78 proceeding since such actions only constitute nonfinal administrative activities. Alleged prosecutorial misconduct and selective enforcement does not warrant invoking the extraordinary remedy of prohibition, which is a preventive rather than a remedial procedure which may only be invoked to restrain a court's unwarranted assumption of jurisdiction or to prevent judicial authority from acting in excess of its authorized powers and is not available for the purpose of reviewing or restraining interlocutory or preliminary determinations for which appropriate trial or appellate relief is available.

 

2244 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


G. v. New York Foundling Hospital


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York City Foster Care Review Term County


94 Misc. 2d 133; 403 N.Y.S.2d 646; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2206



March 1, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother, a minor, brought an action against respondents, Commissioner of Social Services (CSS) and hospital, an agent for the CSS, to revoke the surrender that she executed pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384 to give guardianship of her baby to the CSS. The mother also sought custody of the baby. Intervenor prospective adoptive parents joined the proceeding. A law guardian was appointed for the baby.


OVERVIEW: The mother, alone and unaware of her right of choice and of the consequences, signed a two-page printed form agreement, drafted by the CSS, providing for the surrender of her eight-week-old baby to the CSS. The mother challenged the surrender as unconscionable and violative of due process under all the circumstances, especially her age, and claimed that she did not voluntarily, knowingly, or intelligently surrender her baby. The CSS, the hospital, and the prospective adoptive parents relied upon the surrender itself and the mother's constitutional right to surrender her child for adoption. The court found that the surrender was not voluntary, informed, and knowing and set it aside as violative of due process because the mother's constitutional right to surrender her baby did not relieve the state of its parens patriae responsibilities to minors. The court held that the parens patriae obligation imposed a moral duty on the state in its dealings with minors; that vindication of its interest in the baby did not relieve the state of its obligations to the minor mother; and that the state had to provide safeguards to ensure that a minor's surrender was voluntary, knowing, and informed.


OUTCOME: The court set aside the surrender, as requested by the mother in her action against the Commissioner of Social Services and the hospital to revoke the surrender.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Constitutionally Protected Right to Raise Children

1. The right of parents to raise their children and the right of children to be raised by their parents are constitutional rights of the first magnitude. Freedom [***2] of personal choice in matters of family life, including the right to surrender parental rights, is one of the liberties protected by the due process clause.

Parent and Child -- Surrender of Parental Rights by Minor

2. The fact that a minor has the same constitutional right to surrender parental rights as does an adult (Social Services Law, § 384) and the State's primary and legitimate interest in protecting the interests of the baby who is the subject of a surrender agreement, does not relieve the State of all responsibility as parens patriae in dealing with minors who are parents or allow the State, in the name of the individual's constitutional rights, to treat minors as the contractual equals of the State and to deal with them according to the "morals of the market place." Accordingly, a complex, printed form surrender agreement executed by a 17-year-old mother who received no counseling services from the foundling hospital acting as agent for the Commissioner of Social Services regarding adoption or alternatives thereto; was not made aware of the technical provisions of the instrument; was not advised that she did not then have to make a decision regarding her child [***3] or to sign the papers presented to her; was not permitted to have a sister or friend present as she had requested; was not afforded an opportunity to reflect on the terms of the instrument or to discuss the instrument with her father or mother; and was not afforded an opportunity to seek legal advice, is set aside as violative of due process and null and void.

Parent and Child -- Surrender of Child by Minor Parent

3. Since legal advice is a basic component of an informed surrender agreement (Social Services Law, § 384) between the State and a parent who is a minor, the Legislature should create an Office of Ombudsman for Minors in order to fulfill the State's affirmative moral obligation to the minor in its role as parens patriae to safeguard a voluntary, informed and knowing surrender decision by the minor.

 

2245 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Joseph


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


93 Misc. 2d 267; 402 N.Y.S.2d 751; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2046



February 27, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved to dismiss their indictment for criminal possession of a weapon on the grounds that the evidence before the grand jury was insufficient.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were indicted for criminal possession of a weapon. They moved to dismiss the action on the ground that the evidence before the grand jury was insufficient to support the indictment. Defendants contended that the police had no justification to stop the car in question. The court was persuaded by a federal circuit court decision, which held that N.Y. Penal Law § 265.15, which made the presence of a firearm in an automobile presumptive evidence of its possession by the vehicle's occupants, was unconstitutional. The court held that defendants' motion should be granted because under the present circumstances, in the absence of the statutory presumption, the entire evidence against defendants amounted to the fact that one defendant allegedly reached for the glove compartment and there was no testimony that either defendant touched the gun.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motion to dismiss the indictment, because the evidence before the grand jury was inadequate to sustain the charges against defendants.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Presumptive Possession of Gun by Occupants of Automobile

1. Regardless of the constitutionality of subdivision 3 of section 265.15 of the Penal Law, which makes the presence of a firearm in an automobile presumptive evidence of its possession by all persons occupying the vehicle at the time when the weapon is found, the owner of a vehicle who was not in the car when the gun was discovered, cannot be charged with illegal possession of a gun under the statute.

Crimes -- Presumptive Possession of Gun by Occupants of Automobile

2. Although lower Federal court rulings are not binding upon State courts, a decision of the Second Circuit of the United States Court of Appeals holding subdivision 3 of section 265.15 of [***2] the Penal Law, which makes the presence of a firearm in an automobile presumptive evidence of its possession by all persons occupying the vehicle at the time when the weapon is found, unconstitutional on its face on the ground that there is no rational basis for such an inference of possession (see Allen v County Ct., 568 F2d 998), should be followed in view of the compelling reasons for unconstitutionality advanced therein and the fact that, in the final analysis, "as to Federal matters, the Federal courts speak with supremacy". If defendants were convicted of possession of a firearm under the statute and then subsequently commenced a habeas corpus proceeding in the Federal courts, a ruling there in favor of their application would, in any event, bind the parties pending a final determination by the United States Supreme Court.

Crimes -- Presumptive Possession of Gun by Occupants of Automobile

3. In view of the unconstitutionality of subdivision 3 of section 265.15 of the Penal Law, which makes the presence of a firearm in an automobile presumptive evidence of its possession by all persons occupying the vehicle at the time when the weapon is found, defendant's mere [***3] act of reaching for the glove compartment where a gun was discovered prompted by the police officer's demand for identification, is insufficient to sustain a charge of possession of a firearm.

 

2246 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Love Towing, Inc. v. Beame


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


93 Misc. 2d 1064; 404 N.Y.S.2d 501; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2175



February 23, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, individual towing car operators and an association of licensed towing car operators, filed an action to enjoin respondents, various city and state officials and others, from enforcing various provisions of the city code relating to licensing and regulation of towing cars, the police department tow car regulations, and the transportation department regulations relating to towing on enumerated bridges and roadways.


OVERVIEW: New York, N.Y., Admin. Code § 436-7.0 provided for two types of tow car licenses, an unrestricted license, for towers who operate facilities for repair of vehicles requiring body or collision work and who could solicit at the scene of accidents, and a restricted license, for owners of tow trucks for public hire. Petitioners filed an action to enjoin respondents from enforcing § 436-7.0 and to challenge the licensing and the regulatory scheme of the tow car industry. The court granted petitioners' application in part and held that: (1) the legislation and regulations were subject to a rational basis test; (2) the licensing scheme was reasonably related to the objective of protecting the public in their dealings with the tow car industry, and the rate structure for licensed towers was necessary to protect the public; (3) the color scheme requirement to distinguish between licensees was related to assisting in identifying which tow cars were authorized to solicit at the scene of a disablement; and (4) there was no basis for allowing the transfer of an existing tow car license by a corporate holder and for restricting such transfer by a partnership or by an individual.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioners' application for injunctive relief to the extent of the regulations that restricted the transfer of the existing tow car licenses by discriminating between the right to transfer by corporate holders and the right of individual or of partnership holders of such licenses, in petitioners' injunctive relief action to enjoin respondents from enforcing certain regulations relating to the tow car industry.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Tow Car Industry

1. The licensing and regulatory scheme of the tow car industry in New York City established by section 436-7.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York and implemented by police department regulations which provides for an "unrestricted license" for towers who are authorized to [***2] solicit at the scene of accidents and must maintain 24-hour a day two service, a police radio, facilities for body and collision work and be open for reclamation of cars at specific hours, and a "restricted license" for owners of other tow trucks for public hire, while exempting from the licensing requirements those tow cars which are not available for public hire, is valid, constituting a reasonable mechanism for supervising and administering the complex and important tow car industry and being reasonably related to the objective of protecting the public in their business dealings with the tow car industry. The rate structure for both types of licensees established under the licensing scheme is integral and necessary to the protection of the public and the mandated color scheme, which requires unrestricted licensees to paint their tow vehicles chrome yellow with medium blue trim, is reasonably related to assisting the public as well as the police force in identifying which tow cars are authorized to solicit at the scene of an accident. The fact that some unlicensed tow cars operate illegally within the city cannot be used to invalidate the entire licensing scheme.

Municipal  [***3] Corporations -- Regulation of Tow Car Industry

2. Since tow vehicles which are not available for public hire are exempted from the licensing requirements applicable to tow vehicles for public hire operating within the City of New York (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 436-7.0), the award of a contract by the city for the towing of illegally parked cars from the midtown area to a company with unlicensed tow cars with a per tow charge in excess of the fees licensed towers are permitted to charge, does not warrant the invalidation of the entire licensing and regulatory scheme of the tow car industry. Towers acting as agents on behalf of the police department may lawfully charge a different fee than commercial licensed towers.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Tow Car Industry

3. The licensing and regulatory scheme for the tow car industry in New York City (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 436-7.0) does not unduly burden licensed towers by subjecting them to police department regulations and administrative hearings for violations thereof in addition to being subject to Criminal Court appearances for violations relating to the operations of their [***4] tow cars since each forum serves a different function and they cannot be mutually exclusive. The police commissioner had authority to order a moratorium on the issuance of new unrestricted towing car licenses, which allow the holders to solicit at the scene of accidents, pending new legislation to alleviate industry abuses under the current licensing system. The authority to issue a license does not confer a vested or absolute right thereto, but only permits a personal privilege to be exercised under restrictions existing at the time of the issuance of the license and such as may thereafter be reasonably imposed.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Tow Car Industry

4. The Transportation Department of the City of New York acted within its legal discretion in granting exclusive franchises for towing on 50 enumerated roadways, parkways, expressways and bridges to only holders of unrestricted towing car licenses (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 436-7.0) in order to provide adequate road service as quickly as possible so as to reduce delay and congestion on the heavily traveled arteries of the city. Permitees must meet certain requirements as to 24-hour a [***5] day operation, specific hours of patrol, and offer efficient service and are subject to periodic review by the department, after which their permits may be rescinded.

Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Tow Car Industry

5. Although the over-all regulatory scheme of the tow car industry in New York City is valid (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 436-7.0), the restriction upon the transfer of existing tow car licenses held by individuals or partnerships is invalid since there is no basis for a restriction upon the transfer of existing tow car licenses, assuming the party to whom the license is to be transferred meets the existing criteria for such license.

 

2247 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fernandez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


93 Misc. 2d 127; 402 N.Y.S.2d 940; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2027



February 22, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Under the circumstances, all other motions with regard to the above indictment are herewith denied without prejudice to renewal upon and if defendants be reindicted on this charge.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed motions to dismiss the indictments against them for "loansharking" or criminal usury, in violation N.Y. Penal Law § 190.40, on the grounds that § 190.40 was unconstitutional and that the indictment lacked the specificity required by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 200.50(7).


OVERVIEW: Defendants contended that language contained in N.Y. Penal Law § 190.40, which stated "not being authorized or permitted by law," invalidated § 190.40 for failure to specify which other laws it referred to, which the court determined was a reference to N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16. The court held that N.Y. Penal Law § 190.40 had not violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16 because it was within the purview of the presumptive validity of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 21. The language of N.Y. Penal Law § 190.40 was clearly stated, and there was a reasonable connection between § 190.40 and the promotion of the welfare of society. Section 190.40 specifically proscribed and fixed the standard as to what was prohibited to give a reasonable man notice of what constituted unlawful conduct. Defendant's due process rights under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6, the Fifth Amendment, and the Fourteenth Amendment were not violated by their prosecution. The court found that the language of the indictment was insufficient, because it was a mere restatement of N.Y. Penal Law § 190.40 and failed to allege the specific facts of the alleged loansharking activities.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the constitutionality of the loansharking statute, but dismissed the indictments against defendants for lack of specificity. The court dismissed the charges without prejudice, gave the state leave to refile the charges within 45 days, and set the amount of bond for defendants' bail.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Criminal Usury

1. The "loansharking" statute (Penal Law, § 190.40) which provides that a "person is guilty of criminal usury when, not being authorized or permitted by law to do so, he knowingly charges, takes or receives any money or other property as interest on the loan" at a rate exceeding 25% per annum, does not unlawfully incorporate other laws by reference in defining the crime in violation of section 16 of article III of the State Constitution. Defendants have failed to overcome the presumption of constitutionality that attaches to an act which might otherwise be void under section 16 of article III of the State Constitution when such act, as the "loansharking" statute, has been recommended to the Legislature by commissioners appointed pursuant to law to revise statutes (NY Const, art III, § 21). The "loansharking" statute does not violate due process since there is a fair, just and reasonable connection between the statute and its proscription and the promotion of the [***2] health, comfort, safety and welfare of society. The statute is sufficiently definite so as to give a reasonable man of ordinary intelligence fair, unequivocal warning of what conduct is prohibited and what is required of him. Persons such as defendants engaged in the business of making loans have sufficient intelligence in mathematics to know when the "rates" exceed the statutory limit and to therefore seek legal advice. No fundamental "sense of justice" will be denied defendants by subjecting them to prosecution under the statute.

Crimes -- Criminal Usury

2. An indictment charging defendants with committing criminal usury (Penal Law, § 190.40) by merely setting forth the concise verbiage of the statute without asserting "facts supporting every element of the offense charged * * * with sufficient precision to clearly apprise the defendant * * * of the conduct which is the subject of the accusation" ( CPL 200.50, subd 7) is legally insufficient and must be dismissed. A criminal indictment for usury should set forth the amount of the claimed usurious loans, the time the loans were made, the manner in which the loans were usurious and the amount of principal and interest [***3] paid on the loans.

 

2248 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fillhart


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Jefferson County


93 Misc. 2d 911; 403 N.Y.S.2d 642; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2154



February 17, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' motion is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a criminal action charging them with criminal possession of marihuana in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 221.3, defendants moved to suppress the marihuana seized without a warrant by a deputy sheriff from their private property and oral admissions made by one defendant.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with criminal possession of marihuana in the first degree for growing marijuana on their private property. Defendants moved to suppress the marihuana, which was seized without a warrant by a deputy sheriff, and oral admissions made by one defendant. The court denied their motion. U.S. Const. amend. IV did not protect defendants in this case. Growing a prohibited product in an open field constituted a waiver of any expected privacy guaranteed by U.S. Const. amend. IV and invited confiscation without a warrant. In addition to the presumption of the constitutionality of a statute of the New York State Legislature, there was an adequate foundation to hold that the Marihuana Reform Act of 1977 was constitutional. Further, defendant's oral admissions concerning the marihuana were admissible because they were spontaneously made while not in police custody.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motion to suppress marihuana and oral admissions was denied because defendants waived any expectations of privacy by growing marihuana in an open field, the Marihuana Reform Act of 1977 was constitutional, and the oral admissions were spontaneously made while not in police custody.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Controlled Substance

1. The protection of the Fourth Amendment against unreasonable searches and seizures does not extend to the growing of marihuana on one's private property in an open field. Growing such a prohibited product in an "open field" constitutes a waiver of any privacy which anyone might expect to be constitutionally protected by the Fourth Amendment, inviting confiscation without a warrant. Accordingly, since a police officer who received information that defendant was growing marihuana on his property and who observed and identified cannabis plants growing in a garden on defendant's property, had probable cause to enter defendant's property, the marihuana seized by him will not be suppressed.

Crimes -- Controlled Substance

2. The Marihuana Reform Act of 1977 (L 1977, ch 360), which prohibits the growing, possession and use of marihuana, decriminalizing only the possession of small amounts of marihuana, is constitutional since the manufacture, use and possession of any controlled substance which affects the behavior, mood and judgment of persons is a legitimate area of concern over which [***2] the Legislature has the power to regulate.

 

2249 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lieberman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


94 Misc. 2d 737; 405 N.Y.S.2d 559; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2353



February 17, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Branch 9A is therefore granted to the extent that counts one through eight are dismissed for the reason the defendant has immunity as indicated above.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted and charged with one count of conspiracy in the fourth degree and 12 counts of willful violation of the heath laws in that he had accepted illegal rebates in connection with his duties as an employee at a nursing home. Defendant sought an inspection of the grand jury minutes and an order of dismissal.


OVERVIEW: The court dismissed the conspiracy in the fourth degree count and seven of the counts of willful violation of the health laws. Defendant contended that his testimony before the grand jury had granted him immunity pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.40. The court agreed and held that while defendant had not admitted his guilt as to any specific crime, he was questioned and did respond to acts that bore a direct relationship to the transaction for which he was indicted. However, the alleged crimes fell within three time periods. The first category dealt with acts committed before the date of defendant's testimony, the second category dealt with acts committed before defendant's grand jury testimony, and the final category dealt with acts committed after defendant's testimony. The court held that immunity extended to all the acts committed before defendant had appeared in any manner. But, the court decided that immunity had not extended to the acts committed after defendant's testimony because defendant had not yet committed any crimes and testimony before the grand jury did not give future immunity.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the conspiracy in the fourth degree count and seven of the counts of willful violation of the health laws because defendant was entitled to immunity.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- Immunity

1. The immunity statute ( CPL 50.10, 190.40)  [***2] is intended to reaffirm the traditional New York concept that, when a witness is compelled to yield his privilege against self incrimination, he should be granted transactional immunity, i.e., immunity from prosecution for any transaction concerning which he was compelled to give evidence.

Statutes -- Construction

2. Where words of a statute are free from ambiguity and express plainly, clearly and distinctly the legislative intent, resort may not be had to other means of interpretation.

Grand Jury -- Immunity

3. The word "evidence" in the immunity statute ( CPL 50.10, 190.40), under which a witness in a Grand Jury proceeding receives immunity from prosecution for any transaction concerning which he gives evidence, with specified exceptions, cannot be restricted to mean "indictable evidence", or such testimony as would substantially link him to crimes; although the testimony must have a connection with the indictable crimes and be relevant to the prosecution of them, the relationship may be less than a substantial one.

Grand Jury -- Immunity

4. A nursing home employee who has been indicted on a count of conspiracy and 12 counts of willful violations of the health laws,  [***3] in that he allegedly accepted illegal rebates from a supply company, and who previously gave testimony before a Grand Jury investigating nursing homes, during which he did not admit guilt to any specific crime but named the supply company, is entitled to transactional immunity from prosecution for the crime of conspiracy, which was based on alleged overt acts committed before and after the date of his Grand Jury testimony, and for seven of the other 12 counts, which were based on acts committed prior to the date of that testimony, but not for the other five counts, which were based on acts committed after the date of that testimony.

Grand Jury -- Immunity

5. Testimony before a Grand Jury does not give future immunity, i.e., immunity for a crime committed after the Grand Jury appearance.

Crimes -- Suppression

6. Where, in the course of testimony given by a nursing home employee before a Grand Jury, he named a supply company which, subsequent to the date of that testimony, allegedly issued illegal rebates for which he now stands indicated, the information furnished by him as to the identity of the supply company does not fall under of the poisonous tree doctrine.

 

2250 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bennett v. County of Nassau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


93 Misc. 2d 992; 402 N.Y.S.2d 329; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2166



February 14, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff county employees moved for summary judgment in their action against defendant county for payment of accumulated vacation time and converted sick leave at the termination of their county service, pursuant to the terms of a collective bargaining agreement.


OVERVIEW: Under the parties' collective bargaining agreement, accumulated vacation time and converted sick leave were to be paid to any county employee upon his termination from service unless he was discharged for cause. When the county employees became state employees under N.Y. Jud. Law § 220(6)(d), they applied for payment of their accumulated leave. The county rejected the claims. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the county employees. The language of the agreement was clear and unambiguous and precluded any conclusion that the county employees' service was not terminated by operation of the statute. The county employees' right to an immediate cash payment vested at the time their service was terminated. The provision in § 220 allowing a transfer of a limited number of days of accumulated vacation was unconstitutional and invalid to the extent that it retroactively modified the existing obligation in the collective bargaining agreement.


OUTCOME: The court granted the county employees' motion for summary judgment against the county for the payment of accumulated vacation time and converted sick leave at the termination of their county service.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Transferal of Accumulated Vacation Leave under Uniform Court System

Section 220 (subd 6, par [d]) of the Judiciary Law, which, in establishing a uniform State-wide court system as of April 1, 1977, provides that nonjudicial court officers and employees who become members of the unified court system may only transfer up to 40 days of accumulated vacation leave to State service and defers cash payment of terminal leave not transferred to the State until the termination of an individual's employment with the State, is unconstitutional and invalid to the extent that it conflicts with the pre-existing 1977 collective bargaining agreement between nonjudicial officers and employees of the court system in Nassau County and the county which creates a right to an immediate cash payment for accumulated vacation time and converted sick leave at the termination of an individual's county service without cause which termination occurred for the subject county employees on the takeover of the court system by the State on April 1, 1977. Although the State may constitutionally modify its own existing contractual obligations where such modification is reasonable and necessary to [***2] serve an important public purpose, and although the establishment of a unified court system throughout the State is an important public purpose, the legislative infringement on contractual rights and obligations with respect to termination pay is not reasonable under the circumstances since Nassau County is not on the brink of bankruptcy nor is the county faced with any dire financial problems as the result of State's takeover of the court system.

 

2251 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wood


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Greenburgh, Westchester County


93 Misc. 2d 25; 402 N.Y.S.2d 726; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2048



February 10, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved to dismiss an information charging them with peddling without a license in violation of a town's peddling and soliciting law.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were affiliated with a church. The complaint alleged upon direct knowledge of a police officer that defendants solicited money by giving out lollipops in a shopping center. The ordinance required a license to engage in the business of peddler. Although religious or political organizations were exempted from the application of the ordinance, representatives of defendants failed to file the required forms with town officials. Defendants moved to dismiss the information on grounds that it was insufficient on its face and that the ordinance violated the Fourteenth Amendment as applied because of vagueness and indefiniteness. Defendants also denied that their conduct came within the ambit of the ordinance. The court denied in all respects defendants' motion to dismiss the information. Defendants gave out lollipops, not for the purpose of furnishing religious instruction or to make a gift, but to obtain funds. Moreover, the information was sufficient on its face, and the ordinance was not vague or indefinite within the meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment, or unconstitutional as applied.


OUTCOME: The court denied in all respects defendants' motion to dismiss the information charging them with violating the town's peddling and soliciting law.


HEADNOTES

Hawkers and Peddlers -- Violation of Town Peddling and Soliciting Law

1. The activities of defendants in soliciting money for the Unification Church by giving out lollipops in a shopping center without a license falls within the ambit of the peddling and soliciting law of the Town of Greenburgh which, with the exception of bona fide charitable [***2] religious or political organizations, prohibits the selling or bartering of goods, wares or merchandise by going from place to place on foot without first obtaining a license. In contrast to the sale of religious publications in return for contributions, the sale of lollipops imports no religious activity and has no reverential connotation. The peddling may have been an ancillary endeavor by the Unification Church to obtain funds subject to taxation under the Internal Revenue Code.

Hawkers and Peddlers -- Constitutionality of Town Peddling and Soliciting Law

2. The peddling and soliciting law of the Town of Greenburgh, which, with the exception of bona fide charitable, religious or political organizations, prohibits the selling or bartering of goods, wares or merchandise by going from place to place on foot without first obtaining a license and is designed to protect the community from the cheats, frauds and thefts which are likely to attend the itinerent and irresponsible peddling from place to place and from door to door, is an unambiguous, valid exercise of police power. Defendants may therefore be tried for exchanging lollipops for funds for the benefit of the Unification [***3] Church without a license in violation of the ordinance. There is no requirement that the town code define a bona fide religious organization since a court can determine whether a proposed association is in essence a truly religious corporation under the Religious Corporations Law without having to pass judgment on the religious quality or spiritual probity of the faith sought to be established. While the First Amendment proscribes any governmental regulation of religious belief, the free exercise clause does not proscribe governmental regulation of overt criminal acts prompted by religious beliefs or principles.

Hawkers and Peddlers -- Constitutionality of Town Peddling and Soliciting Law

3. Defendants, charged with exchanging lollipops in return for contributions for the Unification Church without a license in violation of the peddling and soliciting law of the Town of Greenburgh which, with the exception of bona fide charitable, religious or political organizations, prohibits the selling or bartering of goods by going from place to place on foot without a license, have failed to sustain their burden of proving that the ordinance is unconstitutional beyond a reasonable [***4] doubt. Defendants have failed to overcome the presumption of regularity which attaches to the town's action of denying tax exempt status to the Unification Church on the ground that it is not a bona fide religious organization.

 

2252 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Revell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


93 Misc. 2d 159; 402 N.Y.S.2d 522; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2030



February 2, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss the informations is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss certain informations against him pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.35, alleging that the informations were defective since the court was without jurisdiction to hear the domestic violence offenses charged.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with violations of state law after his wife alleged that he engaged in conduct that harassed, threatened, and endangered his wife's life. Defendant's wife exercised her right to proceed with a complaint in district court as opposed to family court. Defendant argued that wife had not filed any documents electing district court as her forum. However, the court found that there was no such filing requirement. Defendant also argued that the district court did not have jurisdiction over the matter because family court had exclusive jurisdiction. The court looked to the statutory language and determined that the grant of jurisdiction was permissive as to the family court and that therefore the family court could divest its exclusive original jurisdiction. Defendant then argued the process was vague and therefore unconstitutional. However, the court found that the vagueness related to the actual administration of the statute by the court system and was not the statute itself; therefore, defendant's argument failed. Defendant's motion to dismiss was denied.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the informations.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Jurisdiction of Family Offenses

1. Section 812 of the Family Court Act (as amd by L 1977, ch 449, § 1), which gives to the criminal courts concurrent jurisdiction with the Family Court over certain acts between spouses that have come to be known as family offenses, requires that a complainant be advised of certain procedures, but does not require that a document be filed indicating that such advice has been given.

 [***3] Courts -- Jurisdiction of Family Offenses

2. Section 812 of the Family Court Act (as amd by L 1977, ch 449, § 1), divesting the Family Court of exclusive original jurisdiction over certain acts between spouses that have come to be known as family offenses, and giving the criminal courts concurrent jurisdiction with the Family Court over those offenses, does not violate section 13 (subd b) of article VI of the State Constitution, which vests the Family Court with exclusive original jurisdiction over certain categories of proceedings, but, with respect to that category relating to family offenses, gives it such jurisdiction "as may be provided by law" (par [7]).

Courts -- Jurisdiction of Family Offenses

3. A defendant facing criminal liability because his wife, whom he allegedly harassed, threatened and endangered, has elected to proceed in a criminal court rather than the Family Court, as she may elect to do under section 812 of the Family Court Act (as amd by L 1977, ch 449, § 1), which gives criminal courts concurrent jurisdiction with the Family Court over family offenses, who alleges that section 812 is violative of due process and equal protection and is unconstitutionally [***4] vague, has not proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the section is unconstitutional.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

4. There is an exceedingly strong presumption of constitutionality concerning legislation and, while this presumption is rebuttable, unconstitutionality must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt, and only as a last resort should a court strike down legislation as unconstitutional.

Statutes -- Unconstitutional Vagueness

5. A statute is unconstitutionally vague if it fails to give a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice that his contemplated conduct is forbidden by it.

 

2253 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Christiano v. Whalen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


92 Misc. 2d 961; 401 N.Y.S.2d 976; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1990



January 30, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner individual brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding seeking judgment annulling the order of respondent, the state commissioner of health. The operating certificate of the individual as an operator of a nursing home had been revoked and annulled by order of the commissioner of health.


OVERVIEW: The individual held an interest in a partnership, which owned and operated a nursing home. He had been convicted on three felony counts of an indictment related to his employment in an administrative capacity at another nursing home. The individual argued, among other things, that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2806(5), adopted after the individual's conviction, was an "ex post facto" law and therefore unconstitutional. The court held that § 2806(5)(d) required that a copy of the notice and charges be served in person or mailed before the hearing. The record was silent, however, as to the service of notice of the hearing. Although the title page identifying the proceeding before the hearing referee listed an appearance for the partnership's nursing home by the same attorney who represented the individual at the hearing, the transcript of the minutes of the hearing reflected an appearance on behalf of the individual only. No appearance was made by the partnership or the nursing home. The court held that if the notice was in fact served, it was improper, for it did not name the holder of the operating certificate.


OUTCOME: The action of the commissioner of health in revoking the certificate of the nursing home and directing the individual to surrender the operating certificate was in violation of lawful procedure, affected by an error in law, and was annulled.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Health -- Proper Parties to Proceeding to Revoke Operating Certificate of Nursing Home Operated by Partnership

The Public Health Law ( § 2801-a, subd 12; §§ 2805, 2806, subd 5, par [a]) and regulations thereunder (10 NYCRR 401.1 [a]) clearly indicate that an operating certificate issued to a nursing home operated by a partnership is issued to the partnership and not an individual member thereof. Thus, the action of the State Health Department pursuant to subdivision 5 of section 2806 of the Public Health Law in revoking the operating certificate of petitioner member of a partnership, which owns and was issued a certificate to operate a nursing home, by reason of petitioner's conviction on felony counts related to his employment in the home, is in violation of lawful procedure, affected by error of law and must be annulled since the revocation proceeding did not name the partnership -- the actual holder of the certificate -- as a party.

 

2254 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. McLaughlin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


93 Misc. 2d 980; 402 N.Y.S.2d 137; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2165



January 18, 1978 



DISPOSITION: The motion to dismiss is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants brought separate motions to dismiss the indictments charging them with the felony of grand larceny in the theft of electricity from a power company.


OVERVIEW: The indictments were founded on the proof that there was tampering with the meters measuring the electricity supplied to premises allegedly owned or operated by the various defendants. The court denied the motions to dismiss. Defendants argued, inter alia, that the misdemeanor theft of services statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15, preempted the field with respect to meter tampering and that such tampering involved a theft of services and nothing more. The court first found that metered electricity was a commodity which could be the subject of larceny. The court then held that there was no conflict in § 165.15 and the larceny statutes embodied in N.Y. Penal Law art. 155. Following the rule of construction that statutes should be read together wherever possible, the court held that a person who has stolen electricity has committed two separate crimes, theft of services and larceny. The validity of the indictments was not affected by the duplicative counts. Therefore, defendants were properly charged with the felony of grand larceny.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motions to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Larceny of Metered Electricity

1. Metered electricity, natural gas, water in pipes, heat, power, and similar forms of "intangible" energy are commodities which may be the subjects of larceny (Penal Law, art 155). The meter tamperer who, by such tampering, receives electric current without payment, takes or obtains an "article of value" under circumstances amounting to a "deprivation" in that the "major portion" of the "economic value" of this "property"  [***2] is lost to the supplier. Accordingly, the meter tamperer commits a larcency when he receives for himself the diverted electricity.

Crimes -- Larceny of Metered Electricity

2. Prosecution of a theft of metered electricity as a larceny is permissible notwithstanding the existence of a special detailed misdemeanor theft of services statute, which, in addition to covering the supply of electricity, also covers such items as restaurant, hotel, railroad, subway and bus services (Penal Law, § 165.15), since both the larceny and theft of services statutes are applicable where there is both a service and an actual commodity. The misdemeanor theft of services will constitute a lesser included offense as to larceny in most meter-tampering situations. In such cases of statutory duplication, the Trial Judge protects the defendant from duplicate punishments for the same act by eliminating duplicative counts in an indictment from a jury's consideration ( CPL art 300).

Crimes -- Meter-Tampering Presumption

3. The statutory meter-tampering presumption which makes proof of meter tampering "presumptive evidence" that the recipient of the service created that condition (Penal [***3] Law, § 165.15) is constitutional since the meter-tampering presumption is an inevitable inference resulting from the fact that the subscriber is the only party who could possibly benefit from tampering with the meter. The statutory terminology of "presumptive evidence" merely has the effect of permitting an inference to be drawn from the established facts that another fact exists without the necessity of proof of the inferred fact and it does not mandate guilt nor obviate the fundamental burden of the prosecution to prove the elements of the offense beyond a reasonable doubt.

Crimes - Larceny of Metered Electricity

4. The common-law presumption of guilty knowledge which attaches to those in recent exclusive possession of stolen property may appropriately be applied to the receiver of stolen electric current who is instantaneously in possession of stolen property when he diverts the electricity to his own use without payment by means of meter tampering.

Crimes -- Larceny of Metered Electricity

5. Proof of purposeful tampering with a meter measuring electric current plus proof of protracted and continuous receipt of an inordinately low current charge, if unexplained [***4] and uncontradicted, constitute sufficient circumstantial evidence to support a conviction for larceny of electricity by the subscriber, provided that where a corporate or company subscriber is involved, additional proof is presented that any individual defendant indicted for the larceny participated in active management of the enterprise to such an extent that knowledge of the situation relating to the receipt of the current without appropriate charge may properly be imputed to such defendant beyond a reasonable doubt. The circumstantial evidence in such a meter-tampering situation excludes to a moral certainty every reasonable hypothesis except guilt since there is no other reasonable hypothesis as to why someone other than the subscriber himself would tamper with a meter so as to deprive the supplier of its lawful charges.

 

2255 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Williams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


93 Misc. 2d 93; 402 N.Y.S.2d 289; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2017



January 17, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to set aside a jury verdict finding defendant guilty of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: After trial, a jury found defendant individual guilty of the felony of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree. In its charge to the jury, the trial court instructed the jury concerning the presumption of possession by all persons in an automobile of a weapon found in that automobile, under N.Y. Penal Law § 265.15 subdiv. 3. Approximately three weeks after the verdict, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit declared § 265.15 subdiv. 3 unconstitutional as applied and on its face. Based on that opinion, defendant moved to set aside the jury verdict of guilty. The court found that it was not bound by the federal court of appeals' interpretation of state law, unless and until the Supreme Court validated that interpretation. Therefore, the court denied defendant's motion, as the court and other state courts had found the presumption to be constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to set aside the jury verdict of guilty, as the presumption allowing defendant to be charged with possession of a weapon was not unconstitutional, and the court was not bound by the contrary analysis of lower federal courts.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Courts -- Appellate Jurisdiction in Event of Conflicting Decisions by State and Federal Courts on Same Issue -- Constitutionality of Presumption as to Possession of Weapon Found in Automobile

When a conflict regarding the constitutionality of a State statute exists as between a State court and a Federal court, other than the Supreme Court of the United States, the State court is not bound by the Federal court's reading of the statute. More specifically, in the event of contrary views between the New York Court of Appeals and a United States Court of Appeals, the rulings of the New York Court of Appeals are controlling upon all this State's courts and only the decision of the United States Supreme Court is determinative of such conflict. Accordingly, in view of a New York Court of Appeals holding to the contrary in People v Lemmons (40 NY2d 505), a trial court in this State is not bound by a United States Court of Appeals decision in Allen v County Ct. of Ulster County (568 F2d 998) declaring subdivision 3 of section 265.15 of the Penal Law unconstitutional on its face and a motion by defendant to set aside a jury verdict finding him guilty of criminal possession of [***2] a weapon found in an automobile of which he was the single occupant, based on the fact the court in its charge instructed the jury concerning the presumption of possession by all persons in an automobile of a weapon found therein under such subdivision, must be denied.

 

2256 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Campbell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


92 Misc. 2d 732; 401 N.Y.S.2d 152; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1963



January 16, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Therefore, the defendant's motion to dismiss all charges against him is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charges against him of grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property, and unauthorized use of a vehicle, in that he was denied his right to confront a witness in violation of the U.S. Const. amend. VI, by the use in a preliminary hearing of a sworn written statement of a witness in lieu of the personal appearance of such witness pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.60(8).
