OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property, and unauthorized use of a vehicle. At the preliminary hearing, the prosecution sought to introduce into evidence, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.60(8), an affidavit, signed by the owner of the vehicle in question, which stated that defendant had no right to take, operate, use, damage, tamper, or exercise dominion or control of the vehicle and had no right to possession. Defendant contended that the introduction of the affidavit was unconstitutional in that it deprived him of the right to confront witnesses against him. The court denied his motion to dismiss all the charges against him, holding that the U.S. Const. amend. VI guaranteed confrontation at some point in the over-all prosecution, and not at each and every stage of the prosecution. There was no Sixth Amendment requirement that defendant be allowed to confront a witness at a preliminary hearing prior to trial.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion was denied because there was no requirement under the Sixth Amendment that defendant be allowed to confront a witness at a preliminary hearing prior to trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Preliminary Hearing

1. A preliminary hearing, in the absence of a statute providing otherwise, is not a prerequisite or an indispensable step in the prosecution of a person accused of a crime. At the preliminary hearing, the People need only present a broad outline of the facts and the court may narrowly limit cross-examination. A preliminary hearing,  [***2] when it does, in fact, take place, is a "critical stage" of a State's criminal process at which the accused has a constitutional right to the assistance of counsel.

Constitutional Law -- Right of Accused to Confront Witnesses Against Him

2. If an accused is to be deprived of his constitutional right under the Sixth Amendment to confront witnesses against him, there must be salient and cogent reasons for the deprivation.

Crimes -- Use of Affidavit in Lieu of Personal Appearance of Witness at Preliminary Hearing

3. The use in a preliminary hearing of an affidavit signed by the owner of a vehicle stating "the absence of his consent to the defendant's taking, operating, exercising control over or using" said vehicle, in lieu of a personal appearance as authorized by CPL 180.60 (subd 8) and CPL 190.30 (subd 3, par [d]), does not violate defendant's Sixth Amendment constitutional right to confront the witnesses against him since the right to confrontation is basically a trial right and there is no Sixth Amendment requirement that a defendant be allowed to confront a witness at a preliminary hearing prior to trial. The Sixth Amendment guarantees confrontation with [***3] witnesses at some point in the over-all prosecution but not at each and every stage of the prosecution. Confrontation and cross-examination of witnesses is not essential, as a matter of constitutional principle, for judicial determination of probable cause for detention. The use of an affidavit of permission and authority at a preliminary hearing promotes justice in that the witness is not inconvenienced by having to wait many hours or suffering adjournments without even testifying. The witness' testimony would take place at the trial. The defense attorney can avail himself of the affidavit which he may then utilize in his strategy for trial and to cross-examine the witness at trial.

Constitutional Law -- Presumption of Constitutionality of Legislative Enactment

4. Defendant, in attacking the constitutionality of the statute permitting the use of sworn statements in lieu of personal appearances of certain witnesses in a preliminary hearing ( CPL 180.60, subd 8) as being violative of his Sixth Amendment right to confront the witnesses against him, failed to overcome the burden of the strong presumption of constitutionality of a legislative enactment. A statute should [***4] not ordinarily be set aside as unconstitutional by a court of original jurisdiction unless such conclusion is inescapable.

 

2257 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Nassau Regional Off-Track Betting Corp. v. New York State Racing & Wagering Board


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


93 Misc. 2d 359; 402 N.Y.S.2d 134; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2064



January 16, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, an off-track betting corporation, brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, seeking a declaration that a certain rule and regulation was null and void, authorizing it to operate a premises as an off-track betting parlor and enjoining respondent, State racing and wagering board, from interfering with such operation.


OVERVIEW: The state racing and wagering board brought a motion to dismiss the petition on the ground that it failed to state a cause of action. The issue related solely to an off-track betting office which the corporation sought to establish within one mile of a racetrack. In its motion to dismiss the petition, the State board relied solely upon its contention that the proceeding was premature in that the corporation failed to formally apply for the approval since the adoption of the rule, and had not yet exhausted its administrative remedies. The court held that it was clear, according to the petition, which for the purposes of the motion had to be deemed to be true, that the corporation would be embarking on a futile, wasteful and counter-productive procedure to seek to have the State board overturn its own rule. The relevant rule would have effectively excluded the corporation from opening the office in question since it precluded the opening of an office within one mile of a racetrack. The court held that the law did not require such a useless act. The court further held that the rule was void and unconstitutional and beyond the authority of the State board.


OUTCOME: The court held that the challenged rule was void and unconstitutional and beyond the authority of the State board. The court directed that the matter be remanded to the State board for a determination with respect to the corporation's application and that the determination be without consideration to the relevant rule.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Horse Racing -- Off-Track Betting

A rule of respondent State Racing and Wagering Board, adopted at the behest of the New York Racing Association, a nonprofit racing association which controls operations of all flat race tracks in the State, requiring the "specific written consent" of a race track before an off-track betting (OTB) parlor could be opened within one mile of said track (9 NYCRR 5204.14 [b]), is void and unconstitutional constituting an unauthorized delegation of respondent's authority to approve OTB offices to a private organization. Petitioner is not first required to pursue further administrative remedies since it would be a waste of time and a charade for petitioner to apply to respondent for permission to open a betting parlor within one mile of Belmont Race Track or for a hearing before respondent as to the validity of its rule where said rule was adopted over the objections of petitioner and was prompted to thwart petitioner's application to open the office.

 

2258 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Goldstein v. Bartlett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


92 Misc. 2d 262; 401 N.Y.S.2d 706; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1954



January 6, 1978 



DISPOSITION: Petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner law secretary sought review of a decision from the Supreme Court of Albany County (New York), which held that the secretary was not entitled to a "grandfather" exemption from the application of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 25.44 by reason of his reliance upon prior, less restrictive, administrative measures in favor of respondent state administrative judge.


OVERVIEW: The secretary sought judgment requiring the board to nullify N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 25.44 insofar as it applied to him. The trial court held that the board had the statutory authority to promulgate a rule closely restricting the right of lawyers employed full time in the judicial system to engage in the private practice of law under § 25.44 for the reasonable purpose of preventing the appearance of impropriety arising from the inevitable and inherent conflict between public employment and the private practice of law. The trial court held that the law secretary was not entitled to a "grandfather" exemption from the application of § 25.44. The law secretary appealed and the court dismissed his petition. The court held that § 25.44 did not assume to regulate law practice. It required that law secretaries to justices were to be lawyers not engaged in private practice. The court held that the law secretary could have a constitutional right to conduct a private law practice, but he did not have a constitutional right to be or continue to be a law secretary under any and all circumstances. The court concluded that there was a completely rational basis for the rule.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the secretary's petition for a "grandfather" exemption from the application of a newly promulgated administrative rule on the basis of his reliance upon prior, less restrictive, administrative measures in favor of the administrative judge.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Restricting Right of Employees in Judicial System to Engage in Private Practice of Law

1. The Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference, under its broad statutory authority to regulate employment within the judicial system by the establishment of "standards and policies" relating to "personnel practices" concerning nonjudicial employees (Judiciary Law, § 212), had the power and authority [***2] to promulgate a rule closely restricting the right of lawyers "employed full time in any court or agency of the unified court system" to engage in the private practice of law (22 NYCRR 25.44) in order to prevent the appearance of impropriety arising from the inevitable and inherent conflict between public employment and the private practice of law. The rule adopted by the board does not assume to regulate private law practice. It only requires that employees such as law secretaries to Supreme Court Justices not be engaged in private practice. The cardinal rule interdicting the appearance, no less than the reality, of judicial impropriety (Code of Judicial Conduct, Canon 2, subd B) applies with equal force to the conduct and activities of those individuals, such as law secretaries, who have a close and confidential relation with Supreme Court Justices.

Courts -- Restricting Right of Employees in Judicial System to Engage in Private Practice of Law

2. The Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference did not act arbitrarily and capriciously in adopting a rule closely restricting the right of lawyers "employed full time in any court or agency of the unified court system"  [***3] to engage in the private practice of law (22 NYCRR 25.44) for the reasonable purpose of preventing the appearance of impropriety arising from the inevitable and inherent conflict between public employment and the private practice of law. The rule adopted by the board does not regulate the private practice of law but instead only regulates employment within the judicial system. While petitioner, a law secretary for a Supreme Court Justice, may have a constitutional right to conduct a private law practice, he does not have a constitutional right to be or continue to be a law secretary under any and all circumstances.

Courts -- Restricting Right of Employees in Judicial System to Engage in Private Practice of Law

3. Respondent Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference is not estopped from applying a rule which closely restricts the right of lawyers "employed full time in any court or agency of the unified court system" to engage in the private practice of law (22 NYCRR 25.44), to petitioner, a law secretary to a Supreme Court Justice, who is not entitled to a "grandfather" exemption from such application by reason of his reliance upon prior, less restrictive, administrative [***4] measures. Respondent rationally concluded that the immediacy of the problem caused by the conflict between public employment and the private practice of law required not only immediate application of the curative rule but application as against all incumbents without exception. In any event, estoppel does not lie against a State agency where the governmental body was exercising its statutory or regulatory authority.

 

2259 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Neiss


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


92 Misc. 2d 839; 401 N.Y.S.2d 422; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1974



January 5, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, in an omnibus motion seeking divers relief, alleged that the indictment, which charged him with grand larceny and theft of services, was defective. Defendant claimed that the indictment failed to allege a larceny because it failed to charge him with the wrongful taking of property, that gas was not a property but a service, and that the presumptions contained in N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15(5), (6) were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: On the grand larceny charge, defendant was accused of stealing property, gas, from a gas company. Defendant claimed that gas was not property, but was a service, and that the presumptions contained in § 165.15, that a person who tampered with a meter without the consent of the supplier was presumed to do so with the intent to avoid payment, and proof that service had been diverted was presumptive evidence that the person who accepted the use of the service had done so with knowledge of the diversion, were unconstitutional on their face because they did not logically flow from the state of facts that had to be proved. The court denied the motion to dismiss. The indictment, which charged the crime of larceny within the language of N.Y. Penal Law § 155.05(1), was sufficient. "Gas" was not a service and could be the subject of a larceny. The crime of larceny was a separate and distinct offense from that created by making it unlawful to tamper with a gas meter. The issue of the constitutionality of the presumptions was premature because there was nothing in the record to indicate the proof the State would introduce and the extent the State would rely on the presumptions.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Stealing Gas from Gas Company -- Gas as Property Subject to Larceny

1. The product "gas" falls within the statutory definition of property in that it is minimally an "article, substance or thing of value" (Penal Law, § 155.00, subd 1) and is not a "service" either by statutory definition (Penal Law, § 155.00, subd 8) or common understanding, and may therefore be the subject of larceny. Thus, the count of an indictment charging that defendant "did steal property, to wit, a quantity of gas" from a gas company sufficiently alleges a larceny within the language of subdivision 1 of section 155.05 of the Penal Law.

Constitutional Law -- Statutory Construction -- Premature Determination of Constitutionality of Statutory Presumptions

2. It is a principle of law that a court of original jurisdiction should not engage in statutory construction of constitutional import absent compelling circumstances. Thus, where there is nothing in the record to indicate the quantum of proof the State will introduce upon the trial and the extent to which it will rely upon such presumptions, the issue raised by defendant regarding [***2] the constitutionality of the presumptions set forth in the theft of services statute (Penal Law, § 165.15, subd 5) is premature.

 

2260 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Askew


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


93 Misc. 2d 754; 403 N.Y.S.2d 959; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2131



January 4, 1978 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted in the Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County, of the class A-III felony sale of $ 20 of cocaine and received a mandatory life sentence. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: After defendant withdrew a plea of guilty to a lesser offense, defendant went to trial on an indictment for the class A-III felony sale of $ 20 of cocaine, which carried with it a mandatory life sentence. Defendant was convicted by a jury. On the date of sentencing defendant's counsel moved to have the sentencing provisions of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.00 declared unconstitutional as applied to defendant, who had never been in any conflict with the law prior to his drug conviction. The trial court denied the motion and defendant received the mandatory life sentence. On review, the court vacated the life sentence and imposed a definite sentence of one year. The court found that the punishment as to defendant was cruel and unusual because its severity served no valid penological purpose. The court held that there was no valid penological purpose to be served in inflicting on defendant the second most severe punishment in the jurisdiction for the same offense that the legislature decreed a sentence of one year or less would adequately protect society had defendant pled rather than chosen a trial alternative.


OUTCOME: The court vacated defendant's life sentence and imposed upon defendant a definite sentence of one year for his conviction for the class A-III felony sale of $ 20 of cocaine.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional Law -- Constitutionality of Statute

1. In examining constitutionally challenged legislation, the courts are required to review subsequent developments which may have changed the validity of information before the Legislature at the time of the statutory enactment.

Crimes -- Constitutionality of Drug Laws

2. Empirical data collated subsequent to the enactment of the new drug laws in 1973 indicating that the severe penalties imposed by the drug laws including a mandatory life sentence for those convicted of class A-III drug felonies, have not had a deterrent effect on drug abuse and drug trafficking in the State, together with the 1976 amendments to subdivision 4 of section 70.00 of the Penal Law and CPL 220.20, which permit small scale sellers of narcotics charged with class A-III drug felonies to plead down to class C felonies and thus be eligible to receive a sentence of probation or a definite sentence of imprisonment of one year or less, have, on the facts of this case, rebutted the legislative presumptions in 1973 that the new drug laws would serve the valid penological ends of deterrence and the isolation of narcotics sellers from society for [***2] a long duration (see People v Broadie, 37 NY2d 100). Accordingly, since the mandatory imposition of a life sentence upon defendant following his conviction, after trial, of the class A-III sale of $ 20 worth of cocaine is grossly disproportionate to the sentence he would have received had he pleaded guilty to the class C felony, serving no valid penological purpose thereby amounting to cruel and inhuman punishment, he is sentenced to one-year imprisonment based upon his prior good record, the small amount of cocaine involved and the letters of commendation received on his behalf.

 

2261 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gayton v. Shang


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Cattaraugus County


93 Misc. 2d 780; 400 N.Y.S.2d 1016; 1978 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2134



January 3, 1978 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petitioner's request for attorney's fees is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner filed a motion seeking attorney's fees pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. §§ 1983, 1988 in an action brought to compel respondents, the Acting Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services and others, to issue a decision in a fair hearing proceeding held to review a determination regarding petitioner's eligibility to receive funds for housekeeping services.


OVERVIEW: A decision was not issued within 90 days of petitioner's fair hearing request as required by N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 358.18(a). Rather, the decision was issued one week after petitioner commenced the N.Y.C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding to compel the decision and it was in her favor. Thus, petitioner argued that the delay in rendering the decision constituted a deprivation of her rights in violation of 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 and that the issuance of a decision in her favor entitled her to an award of fees and costs under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1988. After review, the court disagreed. First, there was no merit to petitioner's claim that a fee award under § 1988 was mandatory because petitioner's issue involved the performance of an act required by a state official rather than a civil rights violation which the statutes were intended to remedy. Second, there was no basis for finding that the interests of justice warranted a discretionary fee award in petitioner's case. 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 had not been extended to permit the recovery of monetary damages in suits against state officials and to allow petitioner to recover fees would have impermissibly permitted such recovery.


OUTCOME: The court denied the request for attorney's fees.


HEADNOTES

Civil Rights -- Award of Attorney's Fees in Federal Civil Rights Action

An award of attorney's fees under the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Act of 1976 (US Code, tit 42, § 1988), which authorizes the court, in its discretion, to award the prevailing party "a reasonable attorney's fee as part of the costs" of maintaining a Federal civil rights action (US Code, tit 42, § 1983), is not justified where petitioner had to bring an article 78 proceeding in order to compel the State Department of Social Services to issue a decision in a fair hearing proceeding as required by department regulations (18 NYCRR 358.18 [a]). Allowing an award of attorney's fees where only the performance of a required act by a State official is at issue would contravene the national policy of denying awards of attorney's fees except in restricted areas of litigation involving important areas of civil rights such as illegal bias or discrimination. In addition, an award of attorney's fees where the respondent is a State official responsible for the operation of a department which discharges quasi-judicial functions is not permissible in a Federal [***2] civil rights action, which is limited to suits against "persons" and not states.

 

2262 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. S.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Mount Vernon


92 Misc. 2d 674; 401 N.Y.S.2d 141; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2604



December 28, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion for an order declaring CPL 340.40 (subd 7) unconstitutional is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant juvenile filed motions for a bill of particulars, Brady materials, and for a Huntley hearing, as well as for an order declaring N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(7) unconstitutional. The juvenile contended that § 340.40(7) deprived her of her fundamental right to a jury trial, as well her right to equal protection, unless she waived her right to benefits conferred by mandatory youthful offender treatment.


OVERVIEW: After conviction for a misdemeanor, the juvenile made an omnibus motion requesting a bill of particulars, Brady materials, a Huntley hearing, and for an order declaring § 340.40(7) unconstitutional. Specifically, the juvenile contended that § 340.40(7), by requiring a non-jury trial for individuals accorded a mandatory youthful offender status, violated her Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial, as well as her right to equal protection. The court determined that § 340.40(7) was unconstitutional, because it did not provide mandatory youthful offenders with the full protections. The court determined that § 340.40(7) violated the Fourteenth Amendment guarantee of equal protection of the law; its differentiation between mandatory and discretionary youthful offenders had no rational basis but, rather, discriminated against the group that had the strongest claim to statutory protection. Further, the statute deprived mandatory youthful offenders of the fundamental right to trial by jury, in violation of the Sixth Amendment, to the extent that such youthful offenders were exposed to effective punishments in excess of six months' imprisonment.


OUTCOME: The court denied a juvenile's motions for a bill of particulars, granted a motion for Brady materials and a Huntley hearing, and granted her motion for an order declaring a disputed statute unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Required Nonjury Trial for Mandatory Youthful Offender

Although the Sixth Amendment does not require a jury trial for "petty" offenses punishable by a maximum of six months' imprisonment (see Baldwin v New York, 399 U.S. 66), CPL 340.40 (subd 7), which requires a nonjury trial for a defendant who is accorded mandatory youthful offender status in a local criminal court proceeding, unless he waives the statutory right to youthful offender protection, deprives such mandatory youthful offender of the constitutional right to a trial by jury to the extent that such youthful offenders are exposed to effective punishments in excess of the maximum six months' imprisonment imposed by the statute by reason of the possibility of the imposition of an additional sentence of probation, which, is, because of the significant restrictions on liberty that attend such a sentence, in effect, a criminal sanction. The special benefits conferred by the rehabilitative orientation of the juvenile process do not outweigh the disadvantages occasioned by the loss of the right to a [***2] jury trial. In addition, the statute denies mandatory youthful offenders equal protection of the laws since the differentiation between such offenders and discretionary youthful offenders, who, by contrast, are entitled to a jury trial by reason of their exposure to a sentence in excess of six months, has no rational basis and instead discriminates against the group that has the strongest claim to statutory protection. Denial of a jury trial to mandatory youthful offenders is inconsistent with the benevolent legislative purpose of according favored treatment to young persons.

 

2263 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Casteneda


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


92 Misc. 2d 687; 400 N.Y.S.2d 702; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2606



December 22, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charges against him for theft of electrical services under N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15(6), following his preliminary hearing. Defendant contended that the evidence was insufficient to support a finding of reasonable cause and that the statutory presumption that would supply the evidence needed to hold him for trial was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: An employee of the electric company testified that an examination of the electric meter that serviced defendant's business demonstrated that it had been tampered with so that the meter registered a lesser amount of electrical current than was actually being consumed. Defendant had testified that he had not tampered with the meter, had not procured anyone to do so, and had not known that such tampering had taken place. Under N.Y. Penal Law § 165.15(6) it was presumed that a user of electricity whose supply of electricity was not being properly measured by reason of meter tampering had knowledge of such tampering. The test used to determine whether the presumption was constitutional included whether it made sense, if it was logical, and whether it could be said that the presumed fact was more likely than not to flow from the proved fact. The court held that the presumption in § 165.16(6) exceeded even the strictest application of this test. The court held that it would be illogical and contrary to experience to conclude that the meter tampering was done without the knowledge of the one benefited thereby.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss, determined the presumption to be constitutional, and ordered defendant held for trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Constitutionality of Criminal Presumption

1. In order for a statutorily created criminal presumption to be constitutional, the facts presumed must have "a natural, not an unreasonable or unnatural, connection with facts proven". The test is whether, based on life and life's experience, a rational connection between the fact presumed and ultimate fact presumed may be said to exist and whether it is logical and fair to impose the burdens of the presumption on the defendant in the circumstances of the particular case. A criminal presumption is violative of due process "unless it can at least be said with substantial [***2] assurance that the presumed fact is more likely than not to flow from the proved fact on which it is made to depend".

Crimes -- Presumption in Prosecution for Theft of Electric Service

2. Subdivision 6 of section 165.15 of the Penal Law, which creates the presumption that a user of electricity whose supply of electricity is not being properly measured by reason of meter tampering, has knowledge of such tampering, does not invalidly shift the burden of proof to defendant. The ultimate burden of proof beyond a reasonable doubt with respect to all of the elements of the crime charged always remains with the prosecution. A presumption merely provides a method whereby certain facts are deemed to be prima facie proof of other facts. The question of whether defendant had knowledge of the tampering of the meter must still be proven by the prosecution beyond a reasonable doubt despite the presumption.

Crimes -- Presumption in Prosecution for Theft of Electric Service

3. Subdivision 6 of section 165.15 of the Penal Law, which creates the presumption that a user of electricity whose supply of electricity is not being properly measured by reason of meter tampering, has [***3] knowledge of such tampering, is constitutional since the presumption exceeds the strictest constitutional standards in that the presumed fact is more likely than not to flow from the proved fact on which it is made to depend. It would be illogical and contrary to experience to conclude that meter tampering is done without the knowledge of the one benefited thereby.

 

2264 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ronayne v. Lombard


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


92 Misc. 2d 538; 400 N.Y.S.2d 693; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2582



December 21, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a deputy sheriff, brought an action in the Supreme Court of Monroe County (New York) seeking to prohibit respondent sheriff from conducting disciplinary hearings and for an order directing his reinstatement.


OVERVIEW: After consulting with his attorney, the deputy met with the FBI regarding allegations of misconduct in the sheriff's department. He was suspended after refusing to answer the sheriff's questions about the FBI meeting. Scheduled disciplinary proceedings were stayed by order to show cause. The deputy sought cancellation of the hearings and reinstatement. The court held that such proceedings were subject to U.S. Const. amend. XIV due process, including notice of the nature of the charges, cross-examination, and judicial review. The court found that the deputy could not be disciplined for refusal to answer the sheriff's questions. The court held that the deputy could invoke his right against self-incrimination under U.S. Const. amend. V and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6, because the information sought about the meeting went beyond narrow questions about the performance of his duties, and, further, the deputy had the constitutional right to refuse to disclose his conversations with his attorney. The court, thus, limited the scope of the hearing to the remaining charges, and retained jurisdiction to implement directions for the hearing.


OUTCOME: The court, upon the deputy's petition, directed that the sheriff could not charge the deputy with violation of department rules by reason of his refusal to disclose the content of his conversations with his attorney or federal officials related to misconduct in the sheriff's department. The court held that any hearings on remaining charges were subject to Fourteenth Amendment due process protections.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Police Officer's Right to Due Process Hearing to Refute Disciplinary Charges

1. The absence of a regulation requiring a hearing, and the presence of a personal right of the Sheriff to appoint and remove officers "at will", does not deprive [***2] petitioner, a suspended Deputy Sheriff Investigator, of his absolute right to a full due process hearing to refute the charges of insubordination levied against him. In proceedings where a person's property or liberty interest is at stake due process entitles him to notice and an opportunity to be heard as a matter of right. The person whose interest is at stake must be fully apprised of the nature of the charges against him, the evidence to be considered and the witnesses against him who must testify under oath and be subject to cross-examination. He has a right to a hearing before an unprejudiced and impartial official and to findings supported by some competent evidence having probative value.

Constitutional Law -- Privilege Against Self Incrimination

2. The constitutional privilege against self incrimination extends to all compulsory oral testimony and may be invoked in any civil, criminal, investigatory, accusatory or legislative inquiry. The witness asserting the privilege is the initial arbiter of the legitimacy of the claim and a presumption exists in favor of the judgment of the witness which will be sustained by the court, unless it is "perfectly evident and [***3] manifest" that there is no legitimate claim to the privilege.

Constitutional Law -- Discharge of Public Employee Who Refuses to Answer Questions Specifically Relating to His Official Duties

3. Incriminating statements obtained from police officers given the choice between forfeiting their jobs or waiving their privilege against self incrimination are coercive and not voluntary and as such may not be used against them in subsequent criminal proceedings. However, in the public interest, a police officer may lawfully be discharged from office for failing to answer questions "specifically, directly and narrowly" relating to the performance of his official duties since public employees subject themselves to dismissal if they refuse to account for their performance of their public trust, after proper proceedings, which do not involve an attempt to coerce them to relinquish their constitutional rights. The ferreting out of internal corruption relates specifically to a police officer's official duties, and touches the public's interest which extends to all matters directly relating to the performance of police officers in their official duties.

Constitutional Law -- Police  [***4] Officer's Privilege Against Self Incrimination

4. Petitioner, a Deputy Sheriff Investigator who was suspended from his duties primarily as the result of his refusal to answer the Sheriff's questions about his conversations with Federal authorities concerning alleged acts of misconduct by members of the Sheriff's department, had the right to exercise his privilege against self incrimination since the Sheriff's questions about discussions he had with Federal officials were not "specifically, directly and narrowly" related to his duties. A police officer or other public employee may only be discharged from office for refusing to answer questions specifically concerning his official duties.

Civil Service -- Disciplinary Charges Based on Past Occurrences for Which No Administrative Action Was Taken

5. Petitioner, a Deputy Sheriff Investigator who was suspended from his duties primarily as the result of his refusal to answer the Sheriff's questions about his conversations with Federal officials concerning alleged acts of misconduct by members of the Sheriff's department, cannot be subjected to disciplinary charges based on past occurrences which were previously investigated [***5] and reported and for which no administrative action was taken. However, petitioner's prior record may be considered in determining the appropriate punishment to be imposed in the event he is found to have violated any of the rules and regulations of the Sheriff's department.

Attorney and Client -- Privileged Communication

6. Petitioner, a Deputy Sheriff Investigator who was suspended from his duties primarily as the result of his refusal to answer the Sheriff's questions about his conversations with Federal officials concerning alleged acts of misconduct by members of the Sheriff's department, had the absolute right to refuse to disclose the contents of his conversations with his attorney concerning the alleged acts of misconduct since all communications with his attorney are privileged and confidential ( CPLR 4503, subd [a]). A privileged communication between petitioner and his attorney cannot constitute a violation of departmental rules prohibiting the disclosure of confidential information.

Constitutional Law -- Right to Counsel in Investigatory Administrative Proceedings

7. The constitutional rights of petitioner, a Deputy Sheriff Investigator who was [***6] suspended from his duties primarily as the result of his refusal to answer the Sheriff's questions about his conversations with Federal officials concerning alleged acts of misconduct by members of the Sheriff's department, were not infringed by the absence of counsel at his meeting with the Sheriff since no constitutional right is violated by the denial of assistance of counsel in purely investigatory preliminary administrative proceedings even though information obtained at the proceedings might provide the basis for subsequent criminal charges. In any event, no statements were taken or given by petitioner who asserted his privilege against self incrimination and remained silent.

 

2265 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Andrew J. Corsa & Son, Inc. v. Harnett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


92 Misc. 2d 569; 400 N.Y.S.2d 1009; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2587



December 21, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff independent insurance agent sought a judgment declaring that N.Y. Ins. Law § 167-a(9) allowed him to refuse to handle the renewal of automobile policies.


OVERVIEW: The independent insurance agent filed a declaratory judgment action seeking a judgment declaring that N.Y. Ins. Law § 167-a(9) allowed him to refuse to handle the renewal of automobile policies. The court held that § 167-a(9) prohibited independent insurance agents from refusing to handle the renewal of automobile policies. The court held that because the insurers were so prohibited, an independent agent could not stand in a more favorable position than his principals and was also bound by the mandates of 167-a(9).


OUTCOME: The court held that independent insurance agents were prohibited from refusing to handle the renewal of automobile policies.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Insurance -- Mandatory Renewal of Automobile Insurance Policies

Subdivision (9) of section 167-a of the Insurance Law, which prohibits "an insurer or an agent who is authorized by such insurer to accept lines of insurance from licensed agents or brokers" from refusing to renew certain automobile insurance policies, also prohibits independent insurance agents from refusing to handle the renewal of automobile policies for brokers, agents and their insureds, since such independent agents, acting as agents for insurers pursuant to contract (Insurance Law, § 110, subd 3-a), are, under the well-settled law of agency, bound by the authority and statutory duties imposed upon their principals as long as the contractual relationship is maintained. Independent insurance agents may not stand in a more favorable position than their principals and are therefore bound by the mandate of subdivision (9) of section 167-a of the Insurance Law. Insurers and their agents by law may not continue to renew and accept a profitable line of insurance while rejecting a less profitable line of insurance. Such attempt at self-regulation is contrary to the public interest which is expressed through legislative [***2] mandate.

 

2266 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Amodeo v. County of Orange


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


94 Misc. 2d 53; 404 N.Y.S.2d 221; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2677



December 20, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlord sought a declaration that defendant county's requirement that apartments offered for rental to recipients of public assistance be first inspected for the existence of violations of applicable health or safety regulations was unconstitutional. The county filed a motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action, to join a necessary party, or to proceed pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78.


OVERVIEW: The landlord sought an order enjoining the enforcement of the county's inspection requirement. Despite noting that the county was entitled to take all steps necessary, including inspections of any buildings in which welfare recipients would reside, to determine whether the condition of such buildings was dangerous or otherwise unsuitable for their occupancy, the court refused to dismiss the complaint because a question of fact arose in view of the landlord's contention that the rule requiring inspection of such rental apartments had not been uniformly applied, and that, in the application of such rule, the county had discriminated against the landlord. A hearing was therefore necessary to resolve the question of fact. Moreover, dismissal of the complaint was not the proper remedy to obtain the joinder of a necessary party to the action. In any event, a city was not necessary party.


OUTCOME: The court denied the county's motion to dismiss the landlord's complaint.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parties -- Necessary Party

1. The City of Newburgh is not a necessary party to an action seeking a judgment declaring unconstitutional the requirement of the Orange County Department of Social Services that apartments offered for rental to recipients of public assistance be first inspected for the existence of violations of applicable health or safety regulations, since it is not the method by which the city conducts such inspections pursuant to the requirement or the fee charged for that service which are challenged in such action, but rather the right of the Department of Social Services to require such an inspection.

Social Services -- Inspection of Apartments Offered for Rental to Public Assistance Recipients -- Constitutionality

2. The requirement of the Orange County Department of Social Services pursuant to section 143-b of the Social Services Law that apartments offered for rental to recipients of public assistance be first inspected for the existence of violations of applicable health or safety regulations is constitutional.

 

2267 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Strong


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


93 Misc. 2d 170; 402 N.Y.S.2d 508; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2649



December 16, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner moved pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.20(1) to set aside his sentence of eight and one-third years to life imprisonment following affirmance of his conviction on charges by the State for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 220.18(1), 70.00 by the Appellate Division, Fourth Judicial Department (New York).


OVERVIEW: Petitioner was convicted of the criminal possession of a package of the aggregate weight of more than once ounce that contained heroin, which was classified as a class A-II felony, the sentencing range for which was six years to life imprisonment under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 220.18(1), 70.00. Petitioner alleged that his sentence denied him equal protection and constituted cruel and unusual punishment. The court denied petitioner's motion to set aside his sentence. Petitioner failed to establish that his sentence was unauthorized, illegally imposed, or otherwise invalid as a matter of law under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.20(1). At the time of petitioner's sentence, he was charged under three other indictments for drug offenses and conspiracy. Petitioner was not an "accidental offender" as to whom the sentence imposed under state statute was unconstitutionally applied.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's motion to set aside his sentence.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- Constitutionality of Drug Laws

Defendant has failed to establish that his mandatory maximum sentence of life imprisonment upon his conviction for possessing a package containing more than one ounce of heroin, a class A-II felony (Penal Law, § 220.18, subd 1), was unauthorized, illegally imposed or otherwise invalid as a matter of law ( CPL 440.20, subd 1). Defendant's conviction has already been unanimously affirmed (55 AD2d 1055). A decision of a Federal District Court holding the mandatory maximum lifetime terms imposed on defendants convicted of trafficking in cocaine under New York's drug laws unconstitutionally "cruel and unusual" is inapplicable to the present defendant who was convicted of possessing heroin and not cocaine and should not be followed in any event in light of the binding decision of the Court of Appeals which specifically upheld the constitutionality of the statutes under which defendant was convicted and sentenced rejecting claims that the drug law provisions constituted cruel and unusual punishment and denied equal protection ( People v Broadie, 37 NY2d 100, cert den 423 U.S. 950).

 

2268 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Caruso


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Onondaga County


92 Misc. 2d 559; 400 N.Y.S.2d 686; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2585



December 12, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The judgment of conviction, as well as the sentence of the lower court, is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged a judgment of the Syracuse City Court (New York), which convicted appellant and which refused to treat him as a youthful offender.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was charged with resisting arrest and obstructing governmental administration. After plea negotiations, appellant was allowed to plead guilty to disorderly conduct and was sentenced to a $ 25 fine and a one-year conditional discharge. His request for youthful offender treatment was denied. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720 and the relief afforded by its provisions did not apply to appellant because, although he was an eligible youth within the stated age limitations, he was ultimately convicted of only a violation, rather than a crime. His was not a misdemeanor or felony, but only a petty offense under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 10.00. Because the purpose of the youthful offender status was to enable youthful wrongdoers to avoid convictions for crimes, the legislature's distinction had a rational basis in fact. If the legislature wanted to afford individuals youthful offender treatment for convictions of violations, they could have easily defined the term "youth" in N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.10 to include persons charged with offenses considered violations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, which convicted and sentenced appellant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Mandatory Youthful Offender Treatment

Defendant, who pleaded guilty to the violation of disorderly conduct in a local criminal court after being originally charged with the crimes of resisting arrest and obstructing governmental administration, is not entitled to mandatory youthful offender treatment, since, under CPL 720.20 (subd 1, par [b]), mandatory youthful offender treatment is only available to an "eligible youth" ultimately convicted of a "crime" not a violation. The essential purpose of the youthful offender process is to enable a youthful wrongdoer to avoid the stigma and practical consequences of a conviction for a "crime". CPL article 720 does not mandate youthful offender treatment to those who are convicted of offenses which are not crimes, even if those individuals were in the first instance "eligible youths" charged with the commission of a crime. The availability of youthful offender treatment depends upon the ultimate adjudication of the matter not the seriousness of the crime originally charged. Had the Legislature wanted to afford individuals youthful [***2] offender treatment for convictions of violations, they could have defined the term "youth" ( CPL 720.10) to include persons charged with offenses considered violations.

 

2269 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hynes v. Moskowitz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


92 Misc. 2d 495; 401 N.Y.S.2d 398; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2574



December 8, 1977 



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, it is hereby ordered, pursuant to CPLR 2308 (subd [b]), that the Special Prosecutor's motion be granted and that, by no later than 5:00 p.m., Tuesday, December 20, 1977, the named respondents are directed to comply with the subpoena issued on October 7, 1977, by producing and turning over to the Special Prosecutor for inspection,  [***2] examination or audit those books and records requested, for such time as would be reasonably required for inspection, examination and audit; it is further ordered, however, that the Special Prosecutor's request to impose $ 50 costs, pursuant to CPLR 2308 (subd [b]), is hereby denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In its investigation of respondent adult home, petitioner special prosecutor filed a motion for an order mandating and directing compliance by the adult home with the special prosecutor's subpoena duces tecum that sought the production of the adult home's books and records. The adult home filed an opposition to the motion.


OVERVIEW: The special prosecutor investigated the adult home because of reports of wrongdoing by residents of the adult home and by the home's owners. As part of the investigation, the special prosecutor issued a subpoena duces tecum calling for the production of the adult home's books and records. The adult home did not produce the records and the special prosecutor filed a motion for an order mandating compliance with the subpoena. The adult home opposed the motion and argued that surrender of the records would violate the adult home's Fourth and Fifth Amendment rights. The court granted the motion and held that adult homes fell under the required records exception to the Fifth Amendment, that the statutory authority permitting the special prosecutor the authority to issue the subpoena duces tecum, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2305(c) and N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(8), when read in conjunction, were not unconstitutional, and that the special prosecutor established good cause for issuing the subpoena.


OUTCOME: The court granted the special prosecutor's motion for an order directing the adult home to comply with the special prosecutor's subpoena duces tecum.


HEADNOTES

Health -- Validity of Investigative Subpoena Served Upon Private Proprietary Home for Adults

1. An office subpoena duces tecum issued by petitioner, the Special State Prosecutor for Nursing Homes (Executive Law, § 63, subd 8), pursuant to CPLR 2308 (subd [b]) requiring respondent to produce and surrender possession of certain books and records of a private proprietary home for adults, for purposes of inspection, examination or audit, does not violate respondent's Fifth Amendment right against compulsory self incrimination since adult homes fall within the "required records" exception to the Fifth Amendment with respect to facilities subject to extensive State regulation (see Matter of Sigety v Hynes, 38 NY2d 260).

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

2. There is a strong presumption that a statute duly enacted by the Legislature is constitutional and that in order [***3] to declare a law unconstiutional, the invalidity of the law must be demonstrated by the person attacking it beyond a reasonable doubt. Legislative enactments should be struck down by a lower court "only as a last unavoidable result" upon a showing that the statute is unreasonable and arbitrary and that the "conclusion of unconstitutionality is inescapable".

Health -- Validity of Investigative Subpoena Served Upon Private Proprietary Home for Adults

3. A subpoena duces tecum issued by the Special State Prosecutor for Nursing Homes (Executive Law, § 63, subd 8) pursuant to CPLR 2308 (subd [a]) requiring respondent to produce and surrender "a multitude of documents" concerning the operation of a private proprietary home for adults for purposes of examination and audit, is not constitutionally infirm on grounds of overbreadth or unreasonableness.

Health -- Validity of Investigative Subpoena Served Upon Private Proprietary Home for Adults

4. A subpoena duces tecum issued by the Special State Prosecutor for Nursing Homes (Executive Law, § 63, subd 8) requiring respondent to produce and surrender possession of certain books and records of a private proprietary [***4] home for adults for purposes of inspection, examination or audit, does not constitute an unreasonable search and seizure since CPLR 2305 (subd [c]) requires the court to make the determination whether the issuing party in fact has good cause to demand a surrender of the requested records. Such a requirement satisfies fundamental due process in that it interposes the determination of a neutral and detached Magistrate between the Special Prosecutor and the objecting party.

Health -- Validity of Investigative Subpoena Served Upon Private Proprietary Home for Adults

5. Unlike a search warrant which requires a showing of probable cause to sustain its issuance, a subpoena duces tecum need only rest upon a showing that the records sought bear a reasonable relationship to the subject matter under investigation and the public purpose to be served. The agency asserting such subpoena power must show its authority, the relevancy of the items sought and some articulable, factual basis for inquisitorial action. Accordingly, the Special State Prosecutor for Nursing Homes (Executive Law, § 63, subd 8), by listing a wide range of specific instances of alleged wrongdoing involving [***5] the subject private proprietary home for adults, supplied the required factual basis necessary to establish the requisite "good cause" to support the issuance of a subpoena duces tecum requiring respondent to produce and surrender certain books and records of said home for adults for purposes of inspection, examination or audit ( CPLR 2305, subd [c]).

 

2270 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re P.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


92 Misc. 2d 62; 400 N.Y.S.2d 455; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2504



December 5, 1977 



DISPOSITION: For the reasons stated, the sexual conduct charge against respondent is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent juvenile filed a motion to dismiss the prostitution charge against in her in a delinquency proceeding.


OVERVIEW: The juvenile approached the complaining witness and offered to engage in sexual acts with him for a fee. The parties proceeded to a hotel where the witness paid the juvenile. The juvenile was charged with prostitution in that she offered to perform a deviate sexual act for money in violation of the state prostitution statutes, N.Y. Penal Law § 230.00 et seq. The state filed a delinquency petition. The juvenile filed a motion to dismiss the charges alleging that the state prostitution statutes and the sodomy statutes, N.Y. Penal Law §§ 130.38, violated the state equal protection clause found at N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11. The court dismissed the charge against the juvenile. The state prostitution statute was facially neutral, but it was intentionally and selectively enforced almost exclusively against females. The sodomy statutes violated equal protection principles because it made sodomy between married couples legal, while sodomy between unmarried persons was illegal.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the prostitution charge against the juvenile.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents

1. The threshold question in all juvenile delinquency proceedings is not whether a respondent committed a particular act but whether [***2] such an act would be a crime if committed by an adult (Family Ct Act, § 731, subd 1, par [a]; § 752). Accordingly, if acts committed by an adult would not constitute a crime because the criminal statute or statutes making such alleged acts a crime were unconstitutional, such acts could not be the basis for a charge of juvenile delinquency.

Crimes -- Prostitution

2. The State prostitution statutes (Penal Law, § 230.00 et seq.) are unconstitutional since, although such laws are facially sex neutral, proscribing both prostitution and the act of patronizing a prostitute (Penal Law, § 230.05), the intentional and selective enforcement of the prostitution statutes almost exclusively against females because of their sex violates the equal protection clause of the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, § 11). The method of enforcement of the prostitution laws is sex biased, aimed only at punishing the female prostitute in that female plainclothes police officers are not assigned to pose as prostitutes to entrap male patrons while male undercover officers are assigned to pose as patrons to entrap streetwalkers. Since the male patron and female prostitute are equal partners [***3] in commercial sex, there is no reasonable justification for penalizing the conduct of female prostitutes more severely than the conduct of their male patrons.

Crimes -- "Deviate" Sexual Intercourse Between Unmarried Persons

3. The criminalization of "deviate" sexual intercourse only between unmarried persons (Penal Law, §§ 130.38, 130.00, subd 2) is an unconstitutional denial of equal protection of the laws since there is no logical or factual basis on which to distinguish between the private consensual conduct of married and unmarried persons. There is no evidence that "deviate" sexual intercourse is more harmful to unmarried persons or that such conduct between unmarried persons is more harmful to the public. There is no empirical evidence that "deviate" sexual intercourse is intrinsically harmful to the participants or that it has a deleterious effect on the moral fibre of the community by undermining the stability of marriage and the family.

Crimes -- Sodomy

4. Private, intimate, consensual sexual conduct not harmful to others whether "deviate" (Penal Law, §§ 130.38, 130.00, subd 2) or "normal" does not violate public morality and is constitutionally protected [***4] by the right of privacy which protects the individual's right to engage in nonprocreative recreational sex. The mantle of constitutional protection surrounding personal intimacy is not limited to married persons. Absent empirical evidence demonstrating that private, consensual "deviate" sexual acts cause harm in fact to the public health, safety or welfare, the State may not legitimately proscribe such conduct. Since there is no proof that public harm is caused by consensual sodomy, the government may not intrude in private, personal decisions regarding sexual preference.

Crimes -- Prostitution

5. The attenuated relationship between prostitution and venereal disease makes it unreasonable to prohibit all prostitution for the sake of eradicating 5% of the venereal disease health hazard actually attributable to prostitution.

Crimes -- Prostitution

6. Prostitution may not be proscribed as a means to eradicate ancillary crimes since there is no empirical evidence that prostitution in fact causes ancillary crimes. Crimes ancillary to prostitution are a by-product of the environment to which society consigns prostitution. It is the criminalization of prostitution [***5] and not prostitution itself that leads to ancillary crime. The State must proceed against ancillary crimes directly by enforcing the specific sanctions against such conduct and may not rely on the blunderbuss approach of incarcerating all prostitutes.

Crimes -- Prostitution

7. It is improper and unreasonable for the State to proscribe prostitution as a method of curbing organized crime since there is no proof that prostitution is the cause in fact of organized crime. Rather than encourage the spread of organized crime, prostitution only plays a "small and declining role in organized crime's operation".

Crimes -- Prostitution

8. Prostitution may not be proscribed on the ground that it is injurious to the community since there is no empirical connection between prostitution and the stability of marriage or the family. The State cannot rely upon the bare assertion of immorality to justify a criminal prohibition. Attempts by the State to regulate lifestyle choices on the bare assertion that the regulation serves morality are impermissible. Conduct that does not interfere with the rights and interests of others may not be regulated by the State.

Crimes  [***6] -- Prostitution

9. However offensive it may be, recreational commercial sex threatens no harm to the public health, safety or welfare and, therefore, may not be proscribed.

Crimes -- Prostitution

10. While prostitution may not be proscribed since it threatens no harm to the public health, safety or welfare, the prohibition of the offensive public conduct associated with the solicitation of prostitution may be a legitimate State objective. The public's right not to be repeatedly accosted on the streets by prostitutes may be protected by less intrusive means than those now employed without depriving the individual of his or her right to engage in private, consensual, sexual conduct which is protected by the right of privacy. It is unreasonable for the State to completely proscribe private, sexual conduct in order to reach distinct public solicitation.

 

2271 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Mandelkern v. Buffalo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


92 Misc. 2d 425; 400 N.Y.S.2d 285; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2560



November 28, 1977 



DISPOSITION: Permanent injunction is granted restraining and enjoining respondents from enforcing section 4 of chapter 1 of the city ordinances of Buffalo, which is herewith declared unconstitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorneys brought a N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding to enjoin respondents, City of Buffalo, Corporation Counsel of the City of Buffalo, the Common Council of the City of Buffalo, and Mayor of the City of Buffalo, from enforcing Buffalo, N.Y., Ordinance ch. 1, § 4 as unconstitutional after the attorneys were not granted waivers from the requirement that they permanently reside in the city while employed by the city.


OVERVIEW: After Buffalo, N.Y., Ordinance ch. 1, § 4 was revised, the attorneys applied for a waiver from the requirement that they live within the city during their employment at the corporation counsel's office. Their requests were denied and they brought the proceeding to enjoin respondents from enforcing the ordinance. The court found that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The court converted the action from a N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding, which was meant to test the action of a public official but not the constitutionality of a legislative enactment, to an action for a declaratory judgment to determine the constitutionality of the ordinance. The court found that there was a valid controversy because of the denial of the attorneys' applications for a waiver. The court looked at the meaning of the ordinance in conjunction with N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75(3), which provided a variety of sanctions for misconduct. The court determined that the ordinance was invalid because removal from employment was mandated for nonresidency and it did not allow the hearing officer any discretion. The court found that the ordinance was not with the scope of § 75(3) and was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted a permanent injunction against the enforcement of the residency requirement and found the ordinance unconstitutional in the attorney's action to declare the ordinance unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding Against Body or Officer -- Improper Use of Article 78 Proceeding to Test Constitutionality of Legislative Enactments

1. Since a CPLR article 78 proceeding is not the proper vehicle to test the constitutionality of legislative enactments, petitioners' article 78 proceeding to have the "residency" ordinance of the City of Buffalo requiring city employees to live within the city during their period of employment declared invalid is converted into an action for declaratory judgment pursuant to CPLR 103 (subd [c]). Article 78 proceedings are available [***2] to determine whether a statute, ordinance or regulation has been applied in an unconstitutional manner, whereas a declaratory judgment tests the basic scope and validity of a statute pursuant to which officials are acting and is the proper vehicle to direct the nonenforcement of an unconstitutional law.

Actions -- Standing to Challenge Constitutionality of City Ordinance

2. Petitioners, members of the office of the Corporation Counsel of the City of Buffalo who were denied permission to move outside the city, have standing to challenge the constitutionality of an ordinance requiring city employees to live within the city since they have a "personal stake in the outcome of the controversy".

Municipal Corporations -- Constitutionality of "Residency" Ordinance

3. The "residency" ordinance of the City of Buffalo, which requires city employees to reside within the city during their period of employment and provides that any employee who "fails to comply" with the residency requirement "shall forfeit his employment and shall be removed therefrom" following a "hearing upon stated charges", is violative of subdivision 3 of section 75 of the Civil Service Law, which [***3] empowers the hearing officer to determine an appropriate penalty upon a finding of misconduct, and is therefore unconstitutional being a local law inconsistent with a general State law (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [c], par [ii]). While an ordinance may validly categorize nonresidency as one form of misconduct for which removal may be an appropriate penalty, automatic removal upon a finding of nonresidency is completely contrary to the five penalties set forth in section 75 which may be assessed in the discretion of the hearing officer.

 

2272 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Young v. Toia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orleans County


93 Misc. 2d 1005; 403 N.Y.S.2d 390; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2675



November 23, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, recipients of public assistance, sought an adjudication punishing defendants, Commissioner of Social Services and his general counsel, for contempt for failing to comply with the court's order preliminarily enjoining them from implementing 1977 N.Y. Laws 77, § 8, which amended New York's "work rule." Plaintiffs also requested a summary judgment declaring § 8 unconstitutional and permanently enjoining its enforcement.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs were recipients of public assistance in the state's Home Relief Program, and the number of days of work to be given each person was originally determined pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 164(3)(b) by the amount of budget deficit of the recipient and his family. However, 1977 N.Y. Laws § 8 amended N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law §164(3)(b) to state that each person assigned to a public work project would be required to participate an average of three days per week without regard to the amount of the recipient's or his family's budget deficit. The court explained that 1977 N.Y. Laws § 8 confronted the needy within its purview with two alternatives: either refuse to work and lose the home relief grant, or comply with the new law and work in a kind of involuntary servitude at a very low hourly rate for which no one would seriously expect an employee to work. The court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and held that 1977 N.Y. Laws § 8 was unconstitutional and violative of N.Y. Const. art. XVII, § I, which guaranteed relief assistance to the needy. However, the court denied plaintiffs' motion to punish any disobedience on defendants' part.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment that the work-relief requirement was unconstitutional and that its further enforcement was enjoined. The court denied plaintiffs' motion to punish defendants' violation of a preliminary injunction that prohibited them from enforcing the work-relief requirement.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social Services -- Work Relief Program for Home Relief Recipients

Section 8 of chapter 77 of the Laws of 1977 (amdg Social Services Law, § 164, subd 3, par [b]) which requires only recipients of home relief public assistance in order to receive their grants, to participate in a public works project "an average of three days per week without regard to the amount of the budget deficit of the person or his family", thereby compelling such home relief recipients to either refuse to work and lose the home relief grant or to "work in a kind of involuntary servitude at an hourly rate which no one would seriously expect an employee to work for", is unconstitutional, being violative of section 17 of article I of the State Constitution which provides that no "laborer, workman or mechanic, in the employ of any public works * * * shall * * * be paid less than the rate of wages prevailing in the same trade or occupation in the locality within the state where such public work is to be situated, erected or used" and also violative of the constitutional mandate to provide relief assistance to eligible needy persons (NY Const, art XVII, § 1). Accordingly, further implementation of the [***2] work relief requirement is permanently enjoined.

 

2273 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Doe v. Roe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


93 Misc. 2d 201; 400 N.Y.S.2d 668; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2650



November 21, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff patient brought a breach of privacy action via N.Y. Civ. Rights Law §§50, 51 for defendant psychiatrist's unauthorized disclosure in a book of matters revealed during the patient's psychoanalysis.


OVERVIEW: The psychiatrist and her husband published a book that reported communications of the patient and her husband revealed during treatment. N.Y. Civ. Rights Law §§50, 51 were not violated because the patient's name, portrait, or picture were not used. While New York did not recognize a common law right of privacy, the physician, by agreeing to provide medical attention, impliedly promised to keep in confidence matters uncovered during treatment. N.Y.C.P.L.R. 4504 embodied a public policy prohibiting disclosure of patient information. While the patient's right of privacy was not absolute, the psychiatrist and her husband failed to demonstrate that the publication represented a contribution to science. There was no issue of prior restraint because the book had already been published and found to violate the patient's privacy. The psychiatrist's husband was liable because he was a willing co-violator of the patient's rights. Because the psychiatrist and her husband had no motive to harm, punitive damages were not available. Because damages did not provide an adequate remedy, the court enjoined the circulation of the book.


OUTCOME: The court held that the psychiatrist and her husband violated the patient's right of privacy found in public policy and contract. The court awarded the patient compensatory damages and enjoined distribution of the book.


HEADNOTES

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Public Policy of State

1. The Legislature, in excluding from CPLR 4504 (subd [a]) the opening words of section 354 of the Civil Practice Act, intended to reinforce the public policy of this State expressed in numerous statutes and regulations ( CPLR 4504, subd [a]; 4508; Education Law, §§ 6509-6511; Mental Hygiene Law, § 15.13, subds [c], [d]; § 35.11; Public Health Law, § 2803-c, subd 3, par f; § 2805-e, subd 3; § 3371; 8 NYCRR 60.1 [d] [3]) prohibiting physicians, persons in allied fields and medical institutions [***2] from disclosing, without authorization of the patient, information discovered in attending the patient.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Implied Covenant against

2. A physician, who enters into an agreement with a patient to provide medical attention, impliedly covenants to keep in confidence all disclosures made by the patient concerning the patient's physical or mental condition as well as all matters discovered by the physician in the course of examination or treatment. This is particularly and necessarily true of the psychiatric relationship, for in the dynamics of psychotherapy the patient is called upon to discuss in a candid and frank manner personal matter of the most intimate and disturbing nature.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Remedies

3. Under the law of the State of New York in a proper case, the contract of private parties to retain in confidence matter which should be kept in confidence will be enforced by injunction and compensated in damages. The implied covenant between psychiatrist and patient not to disclose information received during the course [***3] of treatment is such a contract.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Breach of Privacy under Civil Rights Law

4. A complaint alleging unauthorized publication, verbatim, by a psychiatrist of a patient's disclosures during the course of a lengthy psychoanalysis does not state a cause of action for breach of privacy under sections 50 or 51 of the Civil Rights Law, since the patient's "name, portrait or picture" has not been used, or under a common-law right of privacy, since to date there has not been recognized in this State such a right. It does, however, state a cause of action arising from two other sources: the public policy of the State of New York proclaimed by statute and regulation, which bars a physician from disclosing a patient's confidences, and the implied promise of confidentiality which every physician makes his patient.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences

5. Every patient, and particularly every patient undergoing psychoanalysis, has a right to privacy arising from the public policy of the State proclaimed by statute and regulation which bars the physician from [***4] disclosing a patient's confidences and from the implied promise of confidentiality which every physician makes his patient. The name affixed to the wrong of violating this right is unimportant since there is no necessity that a tort have a name; what is important is that there must be the infliction of intentional harm, resulting in damage, without legal excuse or justification.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Exceptions

6. Under the public policy of this State, a patient's right of confidentiality against unauthorized disclosure of his confidences is less than absolute, but in no case has the curiosity or education of the medical profession superseded such right.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Injunction against Distribution of Book Containing as Prior Restraint

7. Enjoining distribution of a book by a psychiatrist containing the verbatim disclosures of a patient made during the course of a lengthy psychoanalysis is not an unconstitutional "prior restraint" on publication thereof, since such book offends against the patient's right of privacy, contractual and otherwise.

 [***5] Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Laches

8. The defense of laches is groundless in an action by a patient to enjoin the unauthorized publication of a book by a psychiatrist containing the patient's verbatim disclosures during the course of a lengthy psychoanalysis, where, although publication occurred 10 years after the last discussion of the book and eight years after treatment had stopped, as soon as the patient heard of the impending publication she protested orally and in writing through her attorney.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Liability of Third Party

9. The husband of the psychiatrist author of an unauthorized book containing the verbatim disclosures of a patient during the course of a lengthy psychoanalysis, who knowing of its source manufactured, advertised and circulated the book, despite the fact he was not involved in a physician- patient or contractual relationship with the patient, is a coviolator of the patient's right of confidentiality and therefore equally liable.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Attorney's  [***6] Fees

10. As punitive damages or otherwise, attorneys' fees are not available in an action by a patient to enjoin the unauthorized publication of a book by a psychiatrist containing the verbatim disclosures of the patient during a lengthy psychoanalysis there being no statutory authority providing for them.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Punitive Damages

11. In order to warrant an award of punitive damages, it must be affirmatively demonstrated that the wrong committed was willful and malicious. Accordingly, where defendant psychiatrist's acts in publishing an unauthorized book containing the verbatim disclosures of plaintiff patient during the course of a lengthy psychoanalysis were not willful, malicious or wanton, but merely stupid, punitive damages are not available.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Compensatory Damages

12. Further damaging publicity resulting from plaintiff patient's prosecution of a lawsuit brought in connection with unauthorized publication of a book by a psychiatrist revealing her verbatim disclosures during the course of a lengthy psychoanalysis [***7] may not be considered in determining compensatory damages due plaintiff, since public policy requires persons be encouraged to assert legal rights and any loss resulting thereby should fall upon defendant whose conduct made the lawsuit necessary.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Unauthorized Disclosure of Patient's Confidences -- Remedies

13. Where in an action by a patient for damages for breach of privacy in connection with publication of a book by a psychiatrist relating the verbatim disclosures of the patient during the course of lengthy psychoanalysis damages alone do not provide an adequate remedy because should the book continue to circulate damage will accrue anew, plaintiff patient is entitled to a judgment permanently enjoining further violation of her right to privacy whether by further circulation of book or otherwise disclosing any matters revealed by plaintiff in the course of psychotherapy.

 

2274 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Agron


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]
