County Court of New York, Dutchess County


91 Misc. 2d 1091; 399 N.Y.S.2d 383; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2486



November 4, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged under N.Y. Penal Law § 205.17 with absconding from a release program, moved for dismissal of the indictment, contending that § 205.17 unconstitutionally violated his equal protection rights.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pointed out that, although he had been charged with a felony for absconding from a state correctional facility while in a release program, others who absconded from local facilities under similar circumstances were punishable only as misdemeanants. The court concluded, however, that the distinction had a rational basis. The presence of the additional element of confinement in a state institution was a legislative recognition that, generally speaking, state facilities maintained the more serious offenders, whose unauthorized departure from confinement could be said to pose a greater risk to the community.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Grading Criminal Conduct

1. A State may constitutionally grade criminal conduct by employing rational standards.

Crimes -- Felonious Absconding from Temporary Release Program at State Correctional Facility

2. A defendant charged with the felony of absconding from a temporary release program at a State correctional facility (Penal Law, § 205.17) is not denied equal protection by reason of the fact that an individual who absconds from a temporary release program at a local correctional facility may only be charged with a misdemeanor (Penal Law, §§ 205.16, 205.18). The distinction between State prisoners and others is based upon a rational legislative recognition that State facilities generally maintain the more serious offenders whose unauthorized departure from confinement may be said to pose a greater risk to the community.

 

2275 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Christian v. County of Ontario


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Ontario County


92 Misc. 2d 51; 399 N.Y.S.2d 379; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2502



November 3, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After the contract between plaintiff employees and defendant employer expired, the employer, a county, passed a resolution that imposed new terms and conditions of employment, pursuant to the Disability Benefits Law, N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law art. 9. The employees brought suit against the employer challenging the constitutionality of the resolution. The employer filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Under the new contract, sick days previously accumulated were retained, but could not be used during the first seven days of sickness, which was the waiting period under the Disability Benefits Law. However, these accumulated days could be used after an employee had exhausted benefits under the Disability Benefits Law. The employees claimed that the provision preventing them from using accumulated sick leave during the first seven days of sickness was unconstitutional because it deprived them of a vested property right and impaired the obligation of the contract. The court granted the motion and held that the resolution was constitutional. Whether the resolution impaired the obligation of the contract depended upon whether the employees had acquired any vested rights in accumulated sick days. Under the expired contract, the employees had no vested interest in their accumulated sick days, and the right to use of the benefits was contingent upon sickness during the period of employment. The accumulated days were lost upon termination of employment.


OUTCOME: The court granted the employer's motion for summary judgment and declared that the employer's resolution, which imposed new terms and conditions of employment under the Disability Benefits Law, was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Property Right

1. A right is a property right within the meaning of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution when it is a vested right.

Constitutional Law -- Vested Right

2. Generally the term "vested right" expresses the concept of a present fixed interest which in right reason and natural justice should be protected against arbitrary State action.

Constitutional Law -- Vested Right

3. A vested right cannot be contingent nor a mere expectance of a future benefit.

Civil Service -- Sick Leave

4. Sick leave benefits [***2] are part of an employee's over-all compensation earned during the period of employment.

Civil Service -- Sick Leave

5. Where statute or contract provides that the employee may accumulate his sick leave with "cash on termination", the sick benefit is not contingent, but is vested as soon as the sick leave is accumulated.

Civil Service -- Sick Leave

6. Where there is no provision for a cash payment on termination sick leave benefits are contingent upon the employee becoming sick during the term of employment and they are lost upon termination of the employee or at least upon his termination while in a healthy condition.

Civil Service -- Enforcement of Contract Rights After Expiration

7. Only rights that have accrued within the contract period can be enforced after the contract has expired.

Civil Service -- Sick Leave

8. The right to sick pay, unlike vacation time which is vested as soon as an employee has enough time in his position and is not contingent upon some future event that may or may not occur, accrues not when sick days are accumulated, but only when the employee becomes sick during the term of his employment.

Civil Service  [***3] -- Sick Leave

9. A resolution adopted by a county supervisor imposing new sick leave provisions in place of those in an expired employment contract with county employees and providing that sick days previously accumulated by the employees are retained but cannot be used during the first seven days of sickness, does not deprive such employees of a vested property right or impair the obligations of their contract so as to be unconstitutional.

 

2276 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Monroe v. Carey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


96 Misc. 2d 238; 412 N.Y.S.2d 939; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2699



November 3, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff town brought an action against defendant county and others for a judgment declaring N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law §§ 24-0501, 24-0903 of the Freshwater Wetlands Act, 1975 N.Y. Laws 614, unconstitutional. The town contended that the statutes violated the "home rule" protections of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(b)(1) because the statutes were laws that impaired the power of the town granted to it by N.Y. Stat. Law § 10(7).


OVERVIEW: The Freshwater Wetlands Act was enacted for the purpose of conserving freshwater wetlands and to regulate their use and development. The overall scheme of the act was to require local governments, under the supervision of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, to adopt regulations for the purpose of contracting the use and development of wetlands. The town did not adopt a protection plan but the county enacted a local law that provided for the protection, regulation, and preservation of wetlands within the boundaries of the county. The town contended that the statutes violated the "home rule" protections of the state constitution and impaired the power granted to the town in N.Y. Stat. Law § 10(7). The court held that after reviewing the purposes and functions of the statutes in question, no supportive reasoning could categorize the preservation of natural resources as a matter of local concern. It was clear that the legislation in question addressed an issue of substantial state concern. The preservation of freshwater wetlands had to have broader protections because the substance of the resource transcended local boundaries.


OUTCOME: The court awarded judgment to the county and declared the two environmental conservation statutes constitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule -- Freshwater Wetlands Act

1. Encroachments upon zoning and planning powers of local governments by the State has been held proper when the subject of such legislation serves a supervening State concern transcending local interests; accordingly ECL 24-0501 and ECL 24-0903 (Freshwater Wetlands Act), enacted for the purpose of conserving freshwater wetlands and to regulate their use and development requiring local governments, under the supervision of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, to adopt regulations for the purpose of contracting the use and development of wetlands, are not invalid because they encroach upon the zoning and planning powers of local government and there is no violation of the home rule provisions of the State Constitution and the Statute of Local Governments for failure of the Legislature to reinact the statute in a second legislative session since the legislation is addressed to an issue of substantial State concern; no supportive reasoning can categorize the preservation of natural resources as a matter of local concern and the preservation of freshwater wetlands has to have broader protections because the [***2] substance of the resource transcends local boundaries.

Constitutional Law -- Constitutionality of Statute

2. A statute under constitutional attack must be afforded a strong presumption of validity and the party attacking the constitutionality of the statute bears a heavy burden.

 

2277 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davan Executive Services, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


91 Misc. 2d 1020; 399 N.Y.S.2d 368; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2471



October 28, 1977 



DISPOSITION: For the above reasons, the motion to dismiss and to suppress statements made by defendant corporation's president is in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with operating an employment agency without a license in violation of N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 172. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charge and to suppress statements allegedly made by its corporate president.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a business that provided mailing service, desk space, and confidentiality for executives searching for employment. Defendant was charged with operating an employment agency without a license in violation of § 172. Defendant filed a motion to suppress statements made by its corporate president and to dismiss the charge. The court denied both motions. The court held that the motion to suppress was unfounded because motions to suppress statements only relate only to those statements made by actual defendants. Also, the court found that § 172 was constitutional. Although defendant alleged discriminatory treatment, it failed to show that the alleged selectivity in enforcement was deliberately based upon an unjustifiable standard such as race, religion, or other arbitrary classification. Defendant also failed to overcome the presumption that N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 171 was not void for vagueness in its definition of an employment agency. The acts of providing appropriate corporate mailing lists and guidance in preparation of individual resumes were clearly within the realm of "vocational guidance" and "counseling services" as defined by N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 171(2)(c).


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to suppress statements made by its corporate president and its motion to dismiss the charge of operating an employment agency without a license.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Evidence -- Suppression of Statement Made by Defendant

1. Motions to suppress statements relate only to those statements made by actual defendants, and are not applicable [***2] to statements made by the president of a corporate defendant. ( CPL 710.20, subd 3.)

Constitutional Law -- Discriminatory Enforcement of Statute -- Operation of Employment Agency Without License

2. The allegation that on a previous inspection 11 months earlier no summons was served charging defendant with operating an employment agency without a license, fails to show the invidious discriminatory selectivity necessary to invoke equal protection. (General Business Law, § 172.)

Constitutional Law -- Statute Void for Vagueness -- Operation of Employment Agency Without License

3. A statute proscribing the operation of an employment agency without a license is not void for vagueness in that it does not fairly apprise a defendant of the necessity of procuring a license. (General Business Law, § 172.) Section 171 of the General Business Law has sufficient precision to apprise a defendant of what constitutes an employment agency.

Words and Phrases -- Employment Agency

4. The acts of providing corporate mailing lists and guidance in preparation of individual resumes are within the realm of "vocational guidance" and "counselling services", included in [***3] the statutory definition of employment agency. (General Business Law, § 171, subd 2, par c.)

Licenses -- Employment Agency

5. An employment agency is not exempt from a statutory licensing requirement (General Business Law, § 172) by virtue of a prior inspection of its premises by an inspector from the Bureau of Consumer Affairs who issued a certificate to the effect that the premises were inspected.

 

2278 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Arendes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


92 Misc. 2d 372; 400 N.Y.S.2d 273; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2555



October 21, 1977 



DISPOSITION: The application to convert to civil status pursuant to article 31 of the Mental Hygiene Law is consequently granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Supreme Court of Queens County (New York) held that defendant, a chronic schizophrenic who has been confined in criminal mental institution for more than 13 years solely as result of his incapacity to stand trial, had to be granted civil status since he was not likely to regain competency to stand trial in the foreseeable future.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for murder in the first degree over 13 years ago. Thereafter, defendant was committed to a state hospital as incompetent to stand trial. According to defendant he had been confined in a criminal capacity for more than 13 years without being brought to trial and therefore sought conversion to civil status alleging violation of his constitutional rights of equal protection and due process. The issue before the court was whether defendant would again regain competency to stand trial in the reasonable future. The court held that the state had the burden of proving defendant's present mental state by a preponderance of the evidence. Moreover, the court held that defendant could not be retained in a criminal institution on the sole ground of dangerousness under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 730.50(1), (2), but he could be transferred to a civil institution which was able to supervise and treat potentially dangerous inmates such as defendant. Therefore, the court held that defendant's application to convert to civil status under N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 31 was proper.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's application to convert to civil status.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Hearing to Convert Incapacitated Defendant From Criminal to Civil Status

1. A person charged by a State with a criminal offense who is committed solely on account of his [***2] incapacity to proceed to trial cannot be held more than the reasonable period of time necessary to determine whether there is a substantial probability that he will attain that capacity in the foreseeable future. If it is determined that this is not the case, then the State must either institute the customary civil commitment proceeding that would be required to commit indefinitely any other citizen, or release the defendant since the purpose for his initial hospitalization would no longer exist upon a finding that there was no substantial probability that the defendant would recover capacity to stand trial in the foreseeable future (see Jackson v Indiana, 406 U.S. 715). Since there is no way of ascertaining whether a defendant is competent to stand trial in the future without first determining whether he is presently fit to proceed to trial, the same procedural rules applicable to a fitness proceeding ( CPL 730.50) are also applicable to a Jackson hearing.

Crimes -- Burden of Proof in Hearing to Convert Incapacitated Defendant From Criminal to Civil Status

2. Even though a hearing to determine whether a defendant committed to a criminal institution will regain [***3] competency to stand trial in the foreseeable future thereby determining if he should be converted from criminal to civil status (see Jackson v Indiana, 406 U.S. 715) is criminal in nature, the burden of proof applicable in such hearing is by a preponderance of the evidence which is the same standard of evidence applicable in a competency hearing dealing with the commitment, confinement and release of a defendant acquitted on the grounds of mental disease or defect ( CPL 330.20).

Crimes -- Burden of Proof in Hearing to Convert Incapacitated Defendant From Criminal to Civil Status

3. In a hearing to determine whether a defendant committed to a criminal institution will regain competency to stand trial in the foreseeable future thereby determining if he should be granted civil rather than criminal status (see Jackson v Indiana, 406 U.S. 715), the People have the burden of proving defendant's present mental condition by a preponderance of the evidence. It would be paradoxical for a rule of law to declare a man legally incompetent and yet still rational enough to have him prove his present mental state.

Crimes -- Issue of Dangerousness in Hearing to Convert Incapacitated  [***4] Defendant From Criminal to Civil Status

4. While there is no statutory requirement ( CPL 730.50, subds 1, 2) that a finding on the issue of dangerousness be made in a hearing to determine whether an incapacitated defendant will attain competency in the foreseeable future thereby determining if he should be granted civil status (see Jackson v Indiana, 406 U.S. 715), the question of dangerousness is, however, relevant in its relationship to a patient's mental condition either as a symptom of mental disorder or part of an underlying illness. If the evidence of violence is so strong as to clearly label a defendant as dangerous, a court should highlight this fact although it cannot deny civil status to defendant on grounds of dangerousness. Dangerousness as an issue now lies only in the civil side of the law.

Crimes -- Hearing to Convert Incapacitated Defendant From Criminal to Civil Status

5. Since defendant, a chronic schizophrenic, who has been confined in a criminal mental institution for more than 13 years solely as a result of his incapacity to stand trial on a murder charge, is not likely to regain competency to stand trial in the foreseeable future, he must [***5] be granted civil rather than criminal status (see Jackson v Indiana, 406 U.S. 715). Although defendant cannot be retained in a criminal institution on the sole ground of dangerousness ( CPL 730.50, subds 1, 2), he should be transferred to a civil institution such as the Mid-Hudson Psychiatric Center, which is able to supervise and treat potentially dangerous inmates such as defendant (14 NYCRR 57.1, 57.2).

 

2279 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York Public Interest Research Group, Inc. v. Carey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Rensselaer County


91 Misc. 2d 122; 398 N.Y.S.2d 965; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2251



October 19, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of the foregoing, the motion of the defendant for summary judgment dismissing the complaint is denied, and the plaintiffs' cross motion for summary judgment for the relief demanded in the complaint is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a public interest research organization and the taxpayers, filed a declaratory judgment action against defendant state officials seeking a declaration that 1977 N.Y. Laws 455 was unconstitutional, a permanent injunction to enjoin its operation and enforcement, and an order that the state election board chairman rescind his certification of the general proposition under ch. 455 from the ballot for the next general election.


OVERVIEW: 1977 N.Y. Laws 455 authorized the creation of $ 750,000,000 in state debt through the sale of bonds to implement a comprehensive economic action program upon approval of the state's voters at a general election. The bond proceeds were to be used for four separate and distinct purposes of industrial and community development, tourism and recreation, conservation and environment, and local transportation access. Plaintiffs contended that the bond authorization unconstitutionally violated the requirement of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 11 that bond authorization be for a single work or purpose and asserted that the certification of the proposition language on the general election ballets was wrongful and illegal. The court awarded plaintiffs summary judgment and the relief they sought by finding that plaintiffs had standing. The court held that held that N.Y. State Fin. Law art. 7-A was not an exclusive remedy and that 1977 N.Y. Laws 455 unconstitutionally and impermissibly linked four distinct functional categories in one bond proposition and violated the state constitutional mandate that allowed voters to cast informed votes for or against a single bond issue.


OUTCOME: The court denied the officials' motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint and granted plaintiffs' cross-motion for summary judgment for the relief demanded in their complaint.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- State bond issues -- single purpose.

1. The Economic Action Program Bond Act of 1977 (L 1977, ch 455) violates section 11 of article VII of the State Constitution, since a debt is contracted thereby which is not for "some single work or purpose * * * distinctly specified therein". The Legislature and Governor agree that the bond proceeds will be used for four distinct purposes: (1)industrial and community development; (2) tourism and recreation; (3) conservation and environment and (4) local transportation access. A 1938 consitutional amendment allowing debt for a single "purpose" rather than a single "object" does not allow a grouping of projects under the single purpose of economic development, and the Legislature's finding that there is a single purpose is not binding on the court.

2. Article 7-A of the State Finance Law is not the exclusive remedy for challenging unconstitutional State action and plaintiff citizen-taxpayers have [***2] standing despite lack of authority therefor in article 7-A.

3. Accordingly, plaintiffs are granted summary judgment enjoining the operation of chapter 455 of the Laws of 1977.

 

2280 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Periconi v. State


Claim No. 59788


Court of Claims of New York


91 Misc. 2d 823; 398 N.Y.S.2d 959; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2423



October 19, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant public officer filed a claim to recover for unpaid salary from defendant state based on the allegedly illegal termination of his appointment as a member of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission (commission). He sought summary judgment on a claim for back pay and on a claim seeking damages for denial of equal protection.


OVERVIEW: The public official's appointment as a member of the commission was terminated on April 8, 1975 by a letter from the governor, which referenced legislation that eliminated the commission. The public official filed a claim against the state to recover his back pay, asserting an unlawful termination. The trial court granted him summary judgment, but held that factual issues remained as to damages. A special provision granted gubernatorial removal power, but only for cause after an opportunity to be heard. 1973 N.Y. Laws 676. The governor's letter did not comply with this provision and thus, the termination was invalid. The trial court found that before the legislation abolishing the commission, 1975 N.Y. Laws 667, became law on August 6, 1975, the public official had the right to sue for his unpaid and statutorily fixed salary up to that date. His cause of action having accrued prior to the abolishing legislation, the legislation could not retroactively destroy it. The trial court declared 1975 N.Y Laws 667 unconstitutional to the extent that it attempted to retroactively deprive the public official of his statutorily fixed salary.


OUTCOME: The trial court granted the public official's motion for summary judgment as to the state's liability for back pay, but deferred ruling on the appropriate amount of back pay pending the parties' submission of papers to resolve that issue.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Public officers -- recovery of salary -- constitutionality of retroactive statute.

1. Claimant, who was appointed as a member of the former State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission, predecessor of the Drug Abuse Control Commission, the members of which had statutorily fixed terms, salaries and duties and were removable by the Governor for cause after an opportunity to be heard, and whose term was not due to expire until December 31, 1978, was notified on April 8, 1975 of the elimination of the commission and the termination of his services, but, in fact, the legislation abolishing the commission, chapter 667 of the Laws of 1975, did not become law until signed by the Governor on August 6, 1975, although it was expressly made retroactive to April 1, 1975. He is entitled to summary judgment, as to liability only, on a cause of action by him for unlawful termination of his services on April 8, 1975 and for unpaid salary up to August 6, 1975. Just before the subject enactment became law, he had the right to sue for his unpaid and statutorily fixed salary up to that date, and this right to enforce a legal cause of action had thus accrued prior to the legislation, and hence [***2] could not be retroactively destroyed thereby. Furthermore, based on allegations by him of performance of his duties during the period in question, with respect to which the State raises no issue, he had, as of August 6, 1975, a valid claim on an implied in law contract for services performed theretofore, and such a claim has been characterized as a property right, and, as such, is entitled to constitutional protection. In any event, whether denominated a property, vested or accrued right, or a cause of action, and whether enforceable as an incident to his public office, and its statutorily fixed salary, or in equity on the basis of an implied in law contract, claimant's entitlement to his salary up to August 6, 1975 was of such a fixed and substantial nature that the destruction of it by the retroactive application of chapter 667 of the Laws of 1975 was constitutionally impermissible. Therefore, that chapter is unconstitutional to the extent that it attempts to retroactively deprive him of his statutorily fixed salary.

2. There are insufficient facts to enable the court to fix the damages to which claimant is entitled on his cause of action for unpaid salary up to August 6, 1975,  [***3] and a hearing thereon will be required unless the parties can stipulate to the amount thereof or submit additional evidence to the court, including evidence of the period covered by his last salary payment and the basis on which he was customarily paid.

3. Neither claimant nor the State is entitled to summary judgment on a cause of action by him for salary from August 6, 1975 to December 31, 1975. Allegations by him as to denial of equal protection and discrimination, based on the retention of two other commission members whose terms were to expire prior to his term, are merely conclusory, but, on the other hand, the State has presented nothing requiring dismissal of the cause of action.

4. On a claim by him that chapter 667 of the Laws of 1975 was not timely signed by the Governor, claimant would have to establish by convincing proof that it was either not signed or signed on other than August 6, 1975, the date specified in the official Session Laws of the State, which are statutorily required to include the date a bill becomes a law with the Governor's approval, and which are accorded prima facie status, but he has merely raised the issue and presented no evidence with respect [***4] thereto.

 

2281 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Heimbach v. Mills


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


91 Misc. 2d 958; 398 N.Y.S.2d 953; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2457



October 18, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, supervisors of townships within a county, brought an action seeking to vacate county equalization rates established by respondent county executive and seeking a declaration that Orange County, N.Y., Charter § 3.02(c) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The challenged charter provision authorized the county executive to determine and fix real property tax equalization rates among the various taxing districts of the county. The court held that, unless a statute specifically provided otherwise, legislative and discretionary powers vested in the governing body of a municipality could not be delegated to the administrative officials of the municipality. Pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 800, the board of supervisors of each county was to be the county equalization agency. The court found no statutory authority for a county legislative body to transfer such power to a county executive.N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 33, which made all county charter provisions subject to restrictions in any other applicable law, did not provide authority for such transfers. Therefore, in a county charter, the obligation for county equalization had to remain with the county legislature or in its commissioners as designated by N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 800.Moreover, the charter provision was an invalid attempt to transfer a legislative function because it lacked guidelines or standards as to the power being conveyed.


OUTCOME: The court declared the challenged charter provision to be invalid and vacated the county equalization rates established thereunder.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Delegation of Discretionary Powers -- Establishment of County Equalization Rates

1. Unless a statute clearly provides otherwise, legislative and discretionary powers vested in the governing body of a municipality cannot be delegated to the administrative officials of the municipality. Since the power to establish county equalization rates is not purely ministerial in nature, this function cannot be delegated to the office of the County Executive without clear enabling legislation.

Taxation -- Assessments -- Establishment of Equalization Rate by County Executive

 [***2] 2. A statute which purports to transfer the power to establish county equalization rates from the county legislative body to the County Executive violates the constitutional mandate (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [c]) requiring that local laws be consistent with the Constitution and any general law and is therefore invalid. (Orange County Charter, § 3.02, subd [c] [Local Laws, 1968, No. 8 of County of Orange].)

Counties -- Intragovernmental Transfer of Functions -- Establishment of Equalization Rate by County Executive

3. A constitutional provision and its implementing statutory provision to the effect that a county in its adoption of an alternative form of government may transfer functions or duties of the county or of the cities, towns and villages to "each other", only authorize an intergovernmental transfer of overlapping and similar functions between the county and the various governmental subdivisions contained therein and may not be construed as authority for intragovernmental transfers of functions, that is, to another branch within the same unit of municipal government. (NY Const, art IX, § 1, subd [h]; Municipal Home Rule Law, § 33, subd 4, par c.)

 [***3] Taxation -- Assessments -- Establishment of Equalization Rate by County Executive

4. A statute which states that a County Charter shall provide for the equalization of real property taxes consistent with standards prescribed by the Legislature (Municipal Home Rule Law, § 33, subd 3, par c) does not authorize a county to transfer the function of equalization to its executive officer. Since the Legislature has also provided that all County Charter provisions must comply with provisions of the general law (Municipal Home Rule Law, § 33, subd 1), the obligation for county equalization must remain with the County Legislature in accordance with section 800 of the Real Property Tax Law.

Statutes -- Transfer of Legislative Function -- Failure to Establish Guidelines or Standards

5. A statute which purports to transfer the power to establish county equalization rates from the county legislative body to the County Executive, constitutes an invalid attempt to transfer a legislative function since there are absolutely no guidelines or standards set forth therein to proscribe the power being conveyed. (Orange County Charter, § 3.02, subd [c] [Local Laws, 1968, No. 8 of [***4] County of Orange].)

 

2282 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Herrington v. Mexico


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oswego County


91 Misc. 2d 861; 398 N.Y.S.2d 818; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2432



October 15, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner property owner initiated a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, seeking relief from an adverse determination by respondent town concerning an application for a permit to place a mobile home on a site in the town.


OVERVIEW: The property owner sought a permit to place a used mobile home on his farm property for the purpose of renting it to unrelated tenants. The application was denied pursuant to Town of Mexico, N.Y., Land Use Ordinance § 540(4)(D), which restricted mobile homes to original owner units. The property owner challenged the constitutionality of the ordinance. The court, noting that a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding was not the proper vehicle for a determination of constitutionality, converted the proceeding into a declaratory judgment action. The court held that the town's lack of a master plan for land use did not invalidate its zoning laws under N.Y. Town Law § 263, absent a showing that the town had ignored the general welfare of the community. The court determined, however, that the ordinance was an arbitrary and unreasonable restraint upon the owner's use of his property. It was unreasonable to presume that only newly built mobile homes were sufficiently safe and aesthetically pleasing to satisfy the health, safety, and welfare standards of the community.


OUTCOME: The court declared the challenged ordinance to be invalid and restrained the town from acting pursuant to it.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- zoning.

1. There is no evidence that section 540 of the Land Use Ordinance of the Town of Mexico was enacted without regard to a comprehensive plan.

2. Section 540 (subd 4, par D) of the Land Use Ordinance, which prohibits mobile homes unless emplaced by the original occupants within one year of its manufacture, is unconstitutional. The restriction is arbitrary and capricious since a newer, used home or an older, more expensive home might be in better condition than that required.

3. Accordingly, the ordinance exceeds the scope of the town's zoning power and is void.

 

2283 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York Topless Bar & Dancers Asso. v. New York State Liquor Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Sullivan County


91 Misc. 2d 780; 398 N.Y.S.2d 637; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2413



October 7, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff topless bar and dancers' association sought a preliminary injunction against defendant state liquor authority to enjoin the enforcement of N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 106(6-a), insofar as the statute prohibited topless dancing in premises licensed for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages by the state liquor authority.


OVERVIEW: The topless bar and dancers' association contended that the total statutory prohibition of topless dancing in premises licensed for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages by the state liquor authority was an unwarranted invasion of the freedom of expression guaranteed by the First Amendment. In attacking the constitutionality of N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 106(6-a), the association sought a preliminary injunction to enjoin the enforcement of the statute's prohibition against topless dancing. As the association failed to establish the requisite clear right to relief, the court denied the association's motion for a preliminary injunction. As the state liquor authority was empowered to ban nude dancing as part of its liquor license program, there was no constitutional infirmity in the legislation. The state's broad powers to regulate the sale of liquor pursuant to the Twenty-first Amendment outweighed any First Amendment interest in nude dancing.


OUTCOME: The court denied the association's motion for a preliminary injunction against the state liquor authority.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Intoxicating liquors -- prohibition of "topless" dancing in licensed premises.

Subdivision 6-a of section 106 of the Alcoholic Beverages Control Law (L 1977, ch 321) which prohibits "topless" dancing in premises licensed for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages by the State Liquor Authority except in the case of a "female entertainer performing on a stage or platform which is at least 18 inches above the immediate floor level and which is removed at least six feet from the nearest patron" (9 NYCRR 53.1 [r], [s]), is not an unwarranted unconstitutional invasion of the freedom of expression. Nude dancing should be accorded only the "barest minimum of protected expression" under the First Amendment. A statute which prohibits females from appearing with uncovered breasts "in any public place" is unconstitutionally overbroad since such a statute would prohibit artistic and other socially redeeming works. However, a State may lawfully ban nude dancing as part of its liquor license program since the broad powers of the States to regulate the sale of liquor outweigh any First Amendment interest in nude dancing (see Doran v Salem Inn, 422 U.S. 922).

 

2284 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sherwood v. Toia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


92 Misc. 2d 149; 400 N.Y.S.2d 32; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2517



September 27, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In all other respects, petitioners' motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, recipients of public assistance, filed an action contesting a rent increase and seeking a declaration that § 2 of 1977 N.Y. Laws 77, which amended N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131-a, was void. The recipients and respondent Commissioner of Social Services of the State of New York filed motions for summary judgment. The recipients also sought attorney fees.


OVERVIEW: The recipients argued that but for § 2 of 1977 N.Y. Laws 77, they would not have had to pay increased rent. Section 2 limited increases in rent grants for public assistance recipients. It also stated that public assistance recipients could appeal to the State if charged an unauthorized amount of rent and that the State would provide relief through increased rent grants if the State found such relief was warranted under regulations to be promulgated. Section 2 stated that fair hearings would not be provided. The court granted the recipients' summary judgment motion in part. Section 2 violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1 because it improperly delegated legislative power by not setting forth guidelines or standards for relief from rent increases.


OUTCOME: The court granted the recipients' summary judgment motion insofar as finding that the provision was unconstitutional. The court denied the Commissioner's summary judgment motion and denied the recipients attorney fees.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Limitation Upon Increases for Rent Grants

Section 2 of chapter 77 of the Laws of 1977 (amdg Social Services Law, § 131-a) which provides for a limitation upon increases for rent grants provided to existing recipients of public assistance constitutes an impermissible delegation of legislative power (NY Const, art III, § 1) in that there is a total lack of standards or guidelines setting forth the factors which would warrant the granting of a rent increase in excess of the amounts otherwise authorized by the statute. Accordingly, respondent State Commissioner of Social Services is ordered to pay petitioners any moneys that they have actually expended for increased rent to which they would have been entitled but for the enactment of the statute.

 

2285 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Villani v. Berle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


91 Misc. 2d 603; 398 N.Y.S.2d 796; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2370



September 26, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Settle one consolidated judgment dismissing, in both Actions Nos. 1 and 2, all causes of action of the plaintiffs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court considered complaints in two actions by plaintiffs, towns and individuals (towns), against defendants, Commissioner and Regional Director of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (commissioner), that challenged the commissioner's order that shellfish harvesting be stopped in waters around the towns.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner ordered that shellfish harvesting in certain waters be stopped. The towns filed separate complaints against the commissioner challenging the orders. The trial court consolidated the two actions and dismissed all complaints against the commissioner. The court held that the commissioner was not required to hold a public hearing on the matter or to file an environmental impact study for the order. The court concluded that the testing method employed by the commissioner in concluding that the shellfish harvesting created a potentially harmful situation was a proper testing method and in no way violated the towns' due process rights. The court held that the commissioner's decision was not arbitrary or capricious but was based on the determination from the testing performed and the intensive analysis performed of the quality of the waters in question.


OUTCOME: The court consolidated the two actions and dismissed all complaints against the commissioner in connection with its order prohibiting all harvesting of shellfish in certain waters.


HEADNOTES

Environmental conservation -- certification of shellfish waters -- negative environmental impact statement -- notice and public hearing.

1. Defendant Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation lawfully closed certain areas in the Great South Bay in Suffolk County to the harvesting of shellfish on public health grounds pursuant to ECL 13-0307 based upon valid scientific standards of testing utilizing the coliform testing methodology which constitutes the most accurate testing procedure presently available to ascertain the presence of harmful human pathogens in shellfish. While there may exist other possible procedures for detecting the presence of pollution in water, the scientific community has yet to develop such procedures to the degree that they are accepted as valid. There exists no test other than the coliform indicator test which has the credentials of valid criteria, standardized methodology and economy. Past outbreaks of various diseases have been associated with the harvesting of shellfish in waters having a higher reading [***2] than 70 MPN (most probable number) per 100 milliliters as determined by the coliform test. The testing criteria and methodology of sampling, utilized by the department, including the frequency of testing, the physical obtaining of water samples, the initial refrigerated storage of the samples, the laboratory testing of the samples and the ultimate analysis, all complied with acceptable scientific procedures. Concerted action, both legislative and executive in the public sector, and industry-wide in the private sector, together with the utilization of vast expenditures of both private and public funds, must be undertaken to correct those conditions which are eroding and destroying an irreplaceable resource.

2. The orders issued by defendant commissioner designating certain shellfish waters as uncertified under ECL 13-0307 (6 NYCRR 41.3) were not subject to the notice and public hearing provisions of the State Administrative Procedure Act (L 1975, ch 167, as amd by L 1976, ch 935) since said orders are not a "statement, regulation or code of general applicability that implements or applies law or prescribes the procedure or practice requirements of any agency" (State Administrative [***3] Procedure Act, § 102, subd 2, par [a], cl [i]). ECL 13-0307 which mandates the issuance of the commissioner's orders designating the shellfish waters as uncertified provides merely for the publication of such certification as giving proper notice of the commissioner's actions.

3. The acts of the commissioner in filing a negative environmental impact statement pursuant to his statutory obligation to determine for public health reasons whether or not certain waters are suitable for the harvesting of shellfish, were not subject to the notice and hearing requirements of ECL 8-0109 which is concerned with the issue of preserving environmental, human and community resources of the State and does not concern itself with any of the issues of public health and safety which are involved in the certification of shellfish waters. In any event, the Department of Environmental Conservation is exempt from the necessity of preparing any environmental impact statement and from conducting public hearings involving its own actions. The department's failure to give adequate consideration to environmental issues may be judically reviewed. The commissioner should not be obliged to cease in the [***4] middle of shellfish land certification proceedings having public health consequences in order to conduct hearings bearing upon the nature and effect of his actions.

 

2286 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Marine Midland Realty Credit Corp. v. Drake Evergreen Park, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oswego County


91 Misc. 2d 569; 398 N.Y.S.2d 241; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2361



September 20, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petitioner's application for payment of legal fees from the account and funds of the receiver in this proceeding is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner defense counsel filed an application for payment of legal fees in the foreclosure action that plaintiff mortgagee had filed against defendant mortgagor.


OVERVIEW: Counsel commenced two successful legal proceedings for the mortgagor regarding a licensing fee ordinance and a tax assessment. The mortgagee later commenced a foreclosure action against the mortgagor, and a receiver was appointed for the mortgagor. Counsel filed an application requesting to be paid from the receiver's account for legal services rendered to the mortgagor in the two prior actions and the foreclosure action. The court denied the application. The court found that the order of appointment of the receiver was not broad enough to authorize the receiver to obtain counsel for litigation involved in the two prior actions in which counsel was retained by the mortgagor before the receiver was appointed and before the foreclosure action was commenced. The court held that the receiver could not have been bound for payment of legal fees in the litigation because it would have made counsel a preferred creditor without any authority in law. The court noted that the legal services were rendered to the mortgagor and were not services rendered to the receiver. The court held that the legal fees were a debt of the mortgagor and that counsel was a general creditor.


OUTCOME: The court denied counsel's request for payment of legal fees in the foreclosure action.


HEADNOTES

Receivers -- liability for legal fees incurred prior to appointment of receiver -- payment of legal fees from receiver's account.

Petitioner law firm, which commenced litigation on behalf of defendant corporation, the owner of a mobile home park, before institution of the action to foreclose the mortgage covering the real property upon which the mobile home park was located and prior to the appointment of the receiver in foreclosure, and which continued to render legal services after the commencement of the foreclosure action, is not entitled to be paid for legal services rendered from the receiver's account. The legal services rendered by petitioner, which resulted in the reduction of the annual tax assessment against defendant's property, were services rendered to to defendant corporation and were not services rendered to the receiver for which the funds in the hands of the receiver are primarily chargeable. Whatever obligation defendant had incurred to petitioner for legal services rendered to it as the client of petitioner in [***2] proceedings prior to the appointment of the receiver was a debt of the corporation, not a charge against the property in the hands of receiver. The receiver cannot be compelled to pay the expenses incurred by defendant in prior proceedings. In addition, the receiver may not assume the obligation for legal fees for protracted litigation so as to bind his funds as receiver without being expressly authorized by court order ( CPLR 6401, subd [b]). Compelling the receiver to pay petitioner's legal fees from his account would improperly elevate the status of petitioner from a general creditor to a lienor or preferred creditor giving petitioner priority over plaintiff mortgagee to proceeds of the foreclosure sale and also priority over the other lienors whose liens and respective priorities are established by statute. Any payment to petitioner from the receiver's account would reduce the amount of any surplus or increase any deficiency in the proceeds and thereby reduce the amount of payment to any mechanics' lienors who have duly perfected their liens.

 

2287 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Mansfield State Bank v. Cohn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


95 Misc. 2d 326; 407 N.Y.S.2d 373; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2695



September 15, 1977 



DISPOSITION: The Supreme Court, New York County (Israel Rubin, J.), denied the motion to vacate, holding that, since the Texas court had personal jurisdiction of defendant and jurisdiction of the subject matter, and absent any showing of fraud in the entry of the judgment rendered by it, that judgment was entitled to full faith and credit; that the court could not go behind the court in Texas and decide that it had abused its discretion in not vacating the judgment, and that the fact that the judgment was under appeal did not detract from its validity nor render it less conclusive while it remained in full force and effect. Mansfield State Bank v Cohn, 95 Misc 2d  .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant judgment debtor brought a motion to vacate the filing of a judgment by plaintiff judgment creditor of a Texas default judgment he obtained against the debtor. In the alternative, the debtor sought a stay of execution on the judgment and an order permanently enjoining enforcement of the judgment in New York.


OVERVIEW: After a Texas court rendered a default judgment against the debtor, the debtor brought a motion in Texas to set it aside. That Texas court denied the motion. A transcript of the judgment was filed in New York under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 54. The debtor brought a motion in New York to vacate that filing, raising substantially the same grounds he had unsuccessfully raised before the Texas court. The court held that the Texas court had personal jurisdiction of the debtor because he voluntarily appeared in Texas in connection with the litigation and entered an answer to the complaint. There was likewise no objection to the subject matter jurisdiction of the Texas court. The debtor, who was also an attorney, argued he misunderstood the rules of the Texas court. This court found that was not valid attack on the default judgment. Under full faith and credit principles, the court could not look behind the Texas judgment, and the mere fact that the Texas judgment was under appeal did not remove the court's obligation to treat it with full faith and credit.


OUTCOME: The court denied the debtor's motion to vacate the foreign default judgment. However, the court stayed execution for 10 days in order to give the debtor an opportunity to file the necessary security for the satisfaction of the judgment pending appeal.


HEADNOTES

Judgments -- Foreign Judgment -- Full Faith and Credit

1. The judgments of sister States are entitled to full faith and credit so long [***2] as the rendering court had personal or subject matter jurisdiction, and such a judgment, is only subject to collateral attack when the rendering court either lacked jurisdiction or there was fraud in the entry of the judgment.

Judgments -- Foreign Judgment -- Res Judicata

2. Where there is jurisdiction of the parties and of the subject matter, a judgment of a sister State operates as res judicata in the absence of fraud or collusion, even if obtained upon default.

Judgments -- Foreign Judgment -- Default Judgment

3. The grounds listed in CPLR 5015 (subd [a], par 1) for relief from a default judgment do not apply to relief from a foreign default judgment filed pursuant to CPLR article 54 where the rendering court had personal jurisdiction of the defendant and jurisdiction of the subject matter and where the defendant, in seeking to excuse his default, has asserted substantially the same grounds which he unsuccessfully raised on a motion to vacate made before the rendering court, and has not shown the type of fraud necessary to come within the exceptions of full faith and credit.

Judgments -- Foreign Judgment -- Default Judgment

4. The fact that [***3] a foreign default judgment is under appeal does not detract from its validity nor render it less conclusive while it remains in full force and effect.

 

2288 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re N.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Schenectady County


91 Misc. 2d 738; 398 N.Y.S.2d 613; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2406



September 15, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, Department of Social Services, brought suit to terminate the parental rights of respondent parents on the ground of permanent neglect. The two children at issue were previously adjudicated as neglected children and placed in the custody of the Department for a period of 18 months. The parents were directed to co-operate and fully participate in a plan of rehabilitation involving various services.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner alleged that for more than one year the parents had failed to maintain contact with the children and also failed to plan for their children's future, although able to do so. The petitions further alleged that the parents had failed to co-operate with the Department in attempts to strengthen the parental relationship and to follow the rehabilitative plan. The parents moved to dismiss the petitions on the grounds that New York's permanent neglect statute was unconstitutional for vagueness and infringement of their First Amendment rights of privacy and denied them equal protection of the laws. The court rejected the parents' arguments and denied their motion to dismiss. The court ruled that the statute in question more than adequately satisfied the constitutional requirement for definiteness under the due process clause. The court found that the parents were not in a position to complain that they lacked sufficient notice of what was expected of them. The court further held that the statute on its face did not treat persons similarly situated differently nor did it reveal any distinctions in the treatment of the respondents or indeed any parent or child on "suspect" bases.


OUTCOME: The court denied the parents' motion to dismiss in the action brought by the Department to terminate the parents' parental rights to the children at issue.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and child -- termination of parental rights -- failure to plan for future of child.

1. New York's permanent neglect statute (Social Services Law, § 384-b) which permits termination of parental rights of parents whose children are in the care and custody of an authorized agency solely on the basis of the "failure to plan for the future of the child" irrespective of the qualitative and quantitative substantiality of continued contacts with the child by the parents, is not unconstitutionally vague since the statute gives parents adequate notice of what they must do to avoid losing parental rights. The purpose of permitting termination of parental rights on the basis of either the failure to keep in contact or the failure to plan is to avoid the deleterious effects of protracted foster care by freeing children for adoption when parents insist upon retaining formal ties to their child but are unwilling to take the necessary steps within their power and ability to restore the child to their home. The requirement of the parent to "plan for the future of the child" means not only to formulate, but also to accomplish a "realistic and feasible" plan to restore the child to [***2] a permanent, "stable home" (Social Services Law, § 384-b, subd [7], par [c]). Consideration may be given to the "failure of the parent to utilize medical, psychiatric, psychological and other social and rehabilitative services and material resources made available". Respondents totally failed to follow through on the "plan" contained in the order of disposition in the previous neglect proceeding wherein specific programs for the rehabilitation of the family unit were set forth.

2. The State's legitimate concern in preventing the evils of protracted foster care and their children's right to continuous care in a stable, permanent home environment take precedence over respondents' right to privacy to rear their children as they wish. Respondents forfeited any absolute right to the privacy of their child-rearing decisions when they admitted to neglect in the previous proceeding. New York's permanent neglect statute safeguards parental rights by requiring diligent agency efforts to strengthen the parental relationship and parental physical and financial ability to keep in contact and plan, before an adjudication of permanent neglect may be made.

3. The permanent neglect statute,  [***3] by subjecting only parents whose children are in the care of an authorized agency to the sanction of termination of parental rights for permanent neglect, does not unconstitutionally discriminate against such parents. The statute itself does not create any class of parents, but instead deals with a class of children. Parents only become affected by the statute through their own actions by the neglect, abuse or abandonment of the child or the voluntary transfer of the child into foster care.

 

2289 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Wickersham Press, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


91 Misc. 2d 503; 398 N.Y.S.2d 233; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2340



September 12, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: On behalf of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, petitioner Attorney General of the State of New York filed a motion to vacate an order that, on default of opposition from the State, granted the motion of respondent creditors' assignee to reduce the State's claims for sales and withholding taxes. In the alternative, the State sought an order opening the default of the State in failing to oppose the assignee's motion.


OVERVIEW: In a proceeding involving the assets and debts of the assignee, who received an assignment from individuals responsible for the payment of sales and withholding taxes, the assignee filed a motion to reduce the State's claim for taxes. After the State failed to respond to the motion, the court entered an order granting the relief requested by the assignee. The State filed a motion to vacate the order or, alternately, to "open" the State's default. The court granted the State's motion, and it opened the default and vacated the order. The court held that the assignee failed to exhaust its administrative remedies as required by N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 because the assignee was subject to all the equities and burdens that attached to the property assigned, and he received no more and was unable to do more than his assignor, who initiated a pending tax appeal proceeding before the Department.The court held that it had no jurisdiction to consider a tax appeal unless there was a full exhaustion of the procedures set forth in N.Y. Tax Law §§ 1138(a), 1140.


OUTCOME: The court granted the State's motion to open its default and vacate the order granting the assignee's motion to reduce the State's claims for sales and withholding taxes.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Assignments for benefit of creditors -- judicial review of State tax liability imposed -- exhaustion of administrative remedies.

A court order, which, on default of any opposition from the State, granted a motion by the assignee for the benefit of creditors to reduce the claims made by the State against the assignor for sales and withholding taxes is vacated since the assignee failed to complete all the administrative proceedings to review the tax liability imposed (Tax Law, § 1138, subd [a]). The administrative remedy set forth in section 1138 is the exclusive remedy available to "any person" seeking review of the tax liability imposed (Tax Law, § 1140). Judicial review is and was precluded to the assignee since the petitions for review filed with the State Tax Commission by the assignor and the "individuals determined to be responsible for the sales and withholding taxes" are still pending. The assignee is bound by the provisions of the Tax Law setting forth the method of reviewing the tax liability imposed. An assignee never stands in any better position than his assignor. He is subject to all the equities and burdens which attach to the property assigned because [***2] he receives no more and can do no more than his assignor. Judicial review is only available after all administrative proceedings have been fully exhausted. To hold otherwise would be to open the door to flaunting of legislative dictate as to statutory exclusivity of procedure.

 

2290 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Abrams v. Brooklyn Hospital, New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


91 Misc. 2d 380; 398 N.Y.S.2d 114; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2310



September 2, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a hospital and a doctor, filed a motion to reconvene the medical malpractice panel to make specific findings or to quash the findings made by the panel. In a hearing under N.Y. Jud. Law § 148-a, the panel had found that another doctor was not liable and had not made any findings with respect to defendants. Plaintiff executrix had filed a medical malpractice action against defendants and the other doctor.


OVERVIEW: The executrix commenced a medical malpractice action against defendants and the other doctor. Pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 148-a, the matter was referred to the panel for a hearing. The panel found that the other doctor was not liable, but did not make any findings with respect to defendants. Defendants then filed a motion to reconvene the panel to make specific findings or, in the alternative, to quash the findings made by the panel. The court denied the motion. The court held that although it was most sympathetic to defendants' position and was fully aware that without specific findings many problems were created, the panel was not required under § 148-a to make specific findings. A panel finding was only required to concern itself merely with liability. The type of relief requested by defendants was a matter for legislative action if such body deemed it in the interest of the public.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion to reconvene the panel to make specific findings or to quash the findings made by the panel.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Physicians and surgeons -- medical malpractice panel -- specific findings of panel.

The medical malpractice panel consisting of a Justice of the Supreme Court, a medical doctor and an attorney (Judiciary Law, § 148-a) is not required to make specific findings when making its recommendation as to the question of liability in a medical malpractice action. The medical malpractice panel in this case found no liability on the part of defendant doctor and made no findings with respect to defendant hospital and its employee. The panel hearings are informal with no stenographic record. There are no sworn witnesses nor any cross-examination. A unanimous panel finding on the question of liability may be read to the jury which must pass upon the probative value or weight of such panel finding. The statute states that a unanimous panel finding shall concern itself solely with liability. There is no direction to make specific findings. However, if the doctor member or the attorney member of the panel is called as a witness with reference to the unanimous recommendation of the panel as authorized by subdivision 8 of section 148-a, such witness panelist may be examined as to the basis [***2] upon which the panel finding was made. The failure to permit questioning of the panelists concerning the panel's specific findings would violate due process and would negate the mandate of the Legislature to have the jury pass upon the probative value of the panel findings.

 

2291 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


County of Oneida v. Berle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Oneida County


91 Misc. 2d 694; 398 N.Y.S.2d 600; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2394



August 30, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner municipalities brought a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 against respondents, the Commissioner of the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, the Governor of the State of New York, and the Budget Director of the State of New York.


OVERVIEW: The municipalities brought an action against respondents asserting that the Commissioner's act of setting a certain date as the date in which municipalities' fiscal years ended was arbitrary and capricious and allowed some municipalities to qualify for a higher rate of reimbursement for sewage treatment expenses. The municipalities argued that the fiscal year of each municipality controlled; the State argued that the State's fiscal year controlled. The court concluded that the fiscal year was that provided for by statute. The municipalities also challenged an impoundment of the Department's appropriated funds by the Governor, allegedly to balance the state budget. The court concluded that the reduction of the appropriation by more than 25 percent of the amount appropriated was an attempt by executive edict to defeat the legislative intent of the law passed by the state legislature. The impoundment of appropriated funds was without authority in law.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the Commissioner to recompute reimbursement rates to the municipalities and to restore the impounded sum to the Department's budget for dispersement to the municipalities.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] State -- municipal reimbursement rates -- executive impoundment of appropriations.

1. Respondent Commissioner of Environmental Conservation improperly set varying rates of reimbursement to municipalities under ECL 17-1905 for operation and maintenance of sewage treatment plants, based upon their fiscal years. ECL 17-1905 does not allow such varying rates within the same year and establishes the year beginning June 1 for purposes of reimbursement. Accordingly, the rates should be recomputed and reimbursement paid uniformly within the confines of the appropriated funds.

2. The Governor and the Director of the Budget improperly impounded seven million dollars of the amount appropriated by the Legislature for the pure waters program. The Governor has the right to line veto items of an appropriation subject to the Legislature's right to override the veto, and by impounding the funds without line veto, the Legislature was deprived of the right to legislate appropriation bills. An interchange of appropriations is limited to a 5% charge under section 51 of the State Finance Law and the impoundment resulted in a charge exceeding 25%. Accordingly, the sum should be restored to [***2] the budget of the Department of Environmental Conservation and dispersed to the appropriate municipalities.

 

2292 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Fullilove v. Carey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


91 Misc. 2d 531; 398 N.Y.S.2d 226; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2350; 17 Empl. Prac. Dec. (CCH) P8431



August 26, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, building contractor organizations and labors unions, commenced a proceeding against respondents, the Governor of the State of New York and others, in order to challenge the constitutionality of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 3.45. The proceeding was converted into one for declaratory judgment. Respondents' request to have the Order declared constitutional was considered a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The Governor issued an executive order, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 3.45, which provided that to be included in all State contracts was a provision that contractors would undertake programs of affirmative action. Petitioners commenced a proceeding in order to challenge the constitutionality of the executive order. In light of petitioners' requested relief, the court converted the proceeding into an action for declaratory judgment. Respondents moved to dismissed the petition on the ground that it failed to state a cause of action; respondents further sought an order declaring the order to be constitutional. The court treated respondents' request as a motion for summary judgment on the constitutionality of the order. The court then granted summary judgment for petitioners and held that the order was unconstitutional. The court held that the order extended and expanded the requirements of statutes; thus, it did not serve an enforcement function and constituted an unwarranted exercise of legislative power.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of petitioners.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Governor -- imposition of affirmative action programs -- discriminatory employment practices.

Respondent Governor had no authority to require all contractors, as part of every State construction contract, to establish affirmative action programs which must include "goals and timetables" for minority hiring as prescribed by the State Division of Human Rights (Executive Order No. 45; 9 NYCRR 3.45). The sanctions for violating Executive Order No. 45 or of any regulations or orders adopted by the Commissioner of Human Rights thereunder include withholding of contract payments, termination or suspension of the contract and a declaration of ineligibility for future contracts for a two-year period. Legislation prohibiting discrimination in employment requires executive enforcement. Executive action in enforcing such legislation may not go beyond stated legislative policy and prescribe a remedial device not embraced by the policy. An executive order which extends and expands statutory requirements does not serve the enforcement function and therefore constitutes an unwarranted exercise of legislative power. By empowering the Division of Human Rights to prescribe "goals and timetables"  [***2] for minority hiring by contractors, the executive order improperly vests the division with broad authority beyond any legislative mandate to establish employment proportions and percentages. The statutory enforcement procedure for remedying discrimination in employment only authorizes the Division of Human Rights to act on complaints of discriminatory employment practices by fashioning appropriate remedial orders on a case-by-case basis (Executive Law, § 297). The legislative scheme regarding discrimination in employment permits but does not require employers to establish affirmative action plans (Executive Law, § 296, subd 12).

 

2293 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bethlehem Steel Corp. v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


91 Misc. 2d 258; 397 N.Y.S.2d 882; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2291



August 18, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer commenced an action for declaratory judgment against respondents, the Board of Education of the City School District of Lackawanna and others, in order to obtain an order declaring that respondents' appropriations for pension and health insurance expenses, and for capital reserve pursuant to the Emergency City and School District Relief Act and 1976 N.Y. Laws 484, were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The Board's budget included appropriations for pension and health insurance expenses, and capital reserve. The appropriations were justified under 1976 N.Y. Laws 349, or the Emergency City and School District Relief Act, and 1976 N.Y. Laws 484. The taxpayer commenced a declaratory judgment action to have the appropriations declared unconstitutional, contending that they exceeded the constitutional tax ceiling. The Board contended that an emergency situation permitted certain budgetary appropriations to be excluded from the tax limitation. The court rejected the Board's argument, and held that Chapters 349 and 484, as well as the health insurance and pension appropriations were unconstitutional; the court made no ruling on the capital reserve issue. The court held that the appropriations were contrary to the law and that they were outside the limitations placed in N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 10. The court held that the Board's budget crisis did not fit the definition of an emergency, which the court defined as an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action.


OUTCOME: The court made no ruling on the issue of the capital reserve, but held that the appropriations for the pension and health insurance expenses were unconstitutional. The court held that the Emergency City and School District Relief Act and the other law upon which respondents justified their appropriations were unconstitutional. The court directed respondents to submit a final budget that was in conformity with the court's opinion.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Schools -- budgets -- debt limitation.

The Emergency City and School District Relief Act (L 1976, ch 349) and chapter 484 of the Laws of 1976, which purport to exclude certain budgetary appropriations for school expenses from constitutional tax limitations are unconstitutional under Hurd v City of Buffalo (34 NY2d 628) and the legislation is not justified under the emergency powers of section 25 of article III of the New York State Constitution. An emergency thereunder envisions a calamity engendered by outside forces endangering the functioning of State government and not mere fiscal distress. Accordingly, the budget adopted by respondents improperly excludes health insurance and pension expenses from the budgetary ceiling.

 

2294 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Burden


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


91 Misc. 2d 368; 398 N.Y.S.2d 88; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2308



August 15, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The appeal from the pro forma order fixing New York estate tax is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant executors sought review of a pro forma order of appellee state tax commission (commission) (New York), which fixed an estate tax on tangible personal property situated outside the State of New York at the time of the decedent's death.


OVERVIEW: The decedent made a gift of a necklace to her granddaughter, who took it to another state immediately thereafter. After the decedent's death, the commission included the necklace in the decedent's gross estate for tax purposes. The executors appealed that decision. The court denied the appeal and held that the pro forma order fixing the New York estate tax correctly included the value of the necklace in the gross estate. The court found that the right to impose the tax arose at the time of and by reason of the gift made by the decedent because the gift was made in contemplation of death, and even though the necklace was located outside the state at the time of death, its permanent situs for tax purposes was in New York. The court also found that the contemplation of death having existed at the time of the gift, for tax purposes it was as though death itself had occurred at the time of the gift.


OUTCOME: The court denied the executors' appeal from the pro forma order fixing New York estate tax on the necklace located outside the state.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- estate taxes -- situs of tangible personal property -- gifts in contemplation of death.

A necklace decedent gave to her granddaughter, included in decedent's gross estate for Federal estate tax purposes because it was the subject of a gift in contemplation of death, should also be included in her estate for New York State estate tax purposes, although the actual situs of the necklace is the State of Connecticut. Since the gift was made in contemplation of death, it is to be treated as part of the estate passing at death, as if the earlier transfer had not been made. While it has been held unconstitutional to tax tangible personal property located outside of the State, such holding did not involve a gift in contemplation of death and should not limit New York's power to tax in that situation.

 

2295 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Corley


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


91 Misc. 2d 255; 397 N.Y.S.2d 875; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2289



August 10, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to suppress is therefore granted and the defendant is acquitted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to suppress evidence of a loaded gun that had been seized on his person when he was arrested for loitering under suspicious circumstances, a violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35(6).


OVERVIEW: The arresting officer had not observed defendant doing anything except standing outside of subway turnstiles for a period of 25 minutes before making the arrest for a violation of § 240.35(6). Defendant argued that that his arrest was unlawful, lacking probable cause, and that the search incident to the arrest that resulted in the seizure of a loaded .32 caliber revolver was also unlawful. Legal argument was heard on the suppression issue and the court granted the motion, holding that the gun could not have been introduced into evidence because it had been produced by an illegal search of defendant since any search made pursuant to an unlawful arrest was improper. The court acquitted defendant of the charge of loitering under suspicious circumstances after determining that § 240.35(6) had been declared unconstitutional.
