The court ruled that an unconstitutional law was incapable of being violated as it was in effect a nonentity, and with such status the question of probable cause was not an issue. The court concluded that no arrest made pursuant to § 240.35(6) could have been based upon probable cause since an unconstitutional statute had not demanded probable cause.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to suppress and acquitted him on the charge of loitering under suspicious circumstances.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- unlawful search and seizure -- unlawful arrest.

A motion to suppress a revolver seized from defendant upon his arrest for loitering under suspicious circumstances pursuant to subdivision 6 of section 240.35 of the Penal Law should be granted. The statute was declared unconstitutional ( People v Berck, 32 NY2d 567) and an unconstitutional statute is incapable of being violated as it is in effect a nonentity. Therefore, there could be no lawful arrest, any search made pursuant to an unlawful arrest is improper, and the product of such a search is not admissible.

 

2296 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cooper v. Morin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


91 Misc. 2d 302; 398 N.Y.S.2d 36; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2305



August 5, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff inmates filed a class action against defendants, county, county officials, and prison officials, under § 1983 of the Civil Rights Act of 1871, codified at 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 seeking money damages, declaratory judgments, injunctive relief and attorneys' fees.


OVERVIEW: Inmates, composed of female prisoners and pretrial detainees, filed an action against the county, a county official, and prison officials for alleged constitutional violations. The court dismissed the action against the county official, because he did not participate in any of the alleged violations, and the county because it was immune under § 1983 of the Civil Rights Act of 1871. The court denied injunctive relief on several claims because they were not recognized rights under the Constitution. The court found that (1) the pretrial detainees were lawfully incarcerated under same conditions as the prisoners because the detainees were not entitled to the presumption of innocence, (2) the inmates had no constitutional right to use their own stationery or to contact visits, (3) the detainees' rights to telephone use, access to counsel, and bail opportunities were adequately protected, (4) the detainees were not entitled to rehabilitative programs, and (5) the inmates were not adversely affected by the lack of outdoor exercise or recreation. However, the court found that the inmates were entitled to hygiene products, uncrowded housing conditions, and access to printed materials.


OUTCOME: The court rejected the inmates' equal protection claims regarding publications, telephone use, visitation, disciplinary proceedings, work-release, exercise and rehabilitation programs, bail, and infraction punishment. The court enjoined the prison officials from maintaining inferior housing conditions, mixing the separate classifications of inmates, and failing to furnish person hygiene items. The court also denied attorneys' fees and costs.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Prisons and prisoners -- civil rights of women inmates of county jail.

1. In a class action under the Federal Civil Rights Act (US Code, tit 42, § 1983), brought on behalf of all women inmates of the Monroe County Jail from February, 1974 until the resolution of the action, alleging deprivation of their constitutional rights with respect to various matters, and seeking money damages, declaratory relief, injunctive relief and attorneys' fees, claims made by them of violations of the New York State Constitution are not adjudicated, since liability under the Federal act (§ 1983) is predicated solely on violation of rights secured under the Federal Constitution, since dual recovery is barred, and since they have pointed to no relief available to them as a consequence of violation of State constitutional rights which they could not obtain under section 1983 as a consequence of violation of Federal constitutional rights.

2. The complaint is dismissed as against the County Manager, since it has not been shown that he was personally aware of, or affirmatively participated in, any of the matters alleged as constitutional deprivations, as required to hold a defendant liable under [***2] section 1983, whether for money damages or for equitable relief.

3. The complaint is also dismissed as against the county, for lack of jurisdiction to grant any relief as against it under section 1983, since liability under that section is asserted against every person who, under color of State law, subjects another to the deprivation of any constitutional rights, and a county or other subdivision of State government is not a "person" within the meaning of the section, either for purposes of legal or equitable relief. Nor could the county be found derivatively liable through one of the remaining defendants, the Sheriff of the county and the Superintendent of the jail. Nor is the doctrine of respondeat superior applicable in actions brought under section 1983.

4. Good faith is a defense which need not have been affirmatively pleaded in this action under section 1983, but, if a violation of civil rights were established and good faith were to become an issue, the Sheriff and the Superintendent would bear the burden of proving that defense, which, even if established, would not prevent the court from granting equitable relief.

5. No constitutional deprivation warranting relief [***3] is found with respect to claims made by plaintiffs concerning restrictions on their incoming and outgoing mail; restrictions on their use of personal stationery; restrictions on their receipt of books and publications; restrictions on their visitation privileges; restrictions on their use of telephones; alleged improper conduct of disciplinary proceedings; alleged improper exclusion of women inmates from a particular phase of a rehabilitation program; restrictions on their use of gymnasium facilities; lack of rehabilitation programs for unsentenced inmates; denial of bail to indigent pretrial detainees; alleged restrictions on access to counsel; alleged invalidity of regulations regarding punishment of inmates for infractions; alleged lack of a proper classification system separating inmates according to the security risk involved, and lack of outdoor exercise or recreation.

6. Declaratory and injunctive relief is granted with respect to claims by plaintiffs concerning lack of paying jobs for women inmates, as contrasted to those for male inmates; the conditions under which women inmates are housed, including the size of their cells, as contrasted to the conditions under which male [***4] inmates are housed; overcrowded facilities, and a failure to furnish inmates with personal hygiene items.

7. No legal liability is found as against the Sheriff or the Superintendent of the jail.

8. In the exercise of the court's discretion, no attorneys' fees are awarded to either plaintiffs' counsel or defendants' counsel, nor are costs awarded to any party.

9. It is noted that the ultimate responsibility for maintaining the jail lies with the county, against which the court has no power to grant relief in this action.

10. If it is necessary to release inmates to comply with the directions made by the court, priority of release is to be given to those inmates held for the longest time under the lowest bail, but the court will defer to any alternative method or priority of release which may hereafter be established by the State Commission of Correction.

 

2297 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Belle v. Town Bd. of Onondaga


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


91 Misc. 2d 618; 398 N.Y.S.2d 586; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2372



August 2, 1977 


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- town code of ethics -- restraint on "political activity".

Petitioners were unlawfully removed from their positions on the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Town of Onondaga by respondent town board pursuant to an unconstitutional provision of the town code of ethics which forbids any "town officer, employee or any member of the Town Board; Planning Board; Zoning Board of Appeals or any other Town administrative board, commission or agency" from also serving as a "political committeeman or committeewoman "or as the chairman or vice-chairman of a political party. Article 18 of the General Municipal Law which authorized the town to "adopt standards relating to the conduct of officers and employees" in order to avoid conflicts of interests, was not intended to include "political activity" among the types of conflicts of interest to be prohibited. There is no conflict of interest between the positions of a member of a zoning board of appeals and officer of a town political committee. A common-law incompatibility of public offices is not present since a political party officer or member of a political party committee does not hold a public office. The restraint [***2] placed on "political activity" by the town code of ethics violates petitioner's First Amendment rights to associate for political purposes. Respondent town board has failed to demonstrate a compelling governmental interest justifying the restriction placed on "political activity". There is no benefit conferred upon the public which outweighs the restraints on constitutional rights.

 

2298 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


State v. Unitized Bldg. Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Dutchess County


91 Misc. 2d 278; 398 N.Y.S.2d 34; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2300



July 28, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion of the plaintiffs is granted in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation filed a motion seeking an order pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7) dismissing the affirmative defense and counterclaim asserted by defendant property owners, upon the ground that it failed to state a cause of action. The department further moved for an order pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(b) dismissing the property owners' seventh affirmative defense.


OVERVIEW: The action was brought by the department to abate the discharge of sewage emanating from the property owners' homes, which were built by defendant construction company. The construction company had secured a permit to construct a sanitary sewage treatment plant from the department to process the waste from the property owners' homes. It failed to comply with the permit, abandoned the sewer system, and discharged untreated waste into a creek. The owners set forth two affirmative defenses and a counterclaim against the department. They demanded judgment declaring that the relief sought by the department constituted an unconstitutional deprivation of property. The property owners alleged that the department improperly issued the permit to the construction company and failed to make required inspections and was, therefore, responsible for the defects. The court granted the department's motion and held that the issuance of the permit was a discretionary act under N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 17-0701, so even if the department's commissioner, as an employee of the State, erred in issuing the permit, the State was not liable for the results of the performance of a discretionary act.


OUTCOME: The court granted the department's motion in its entirety.


HEADNOTES

Environmental conservation -- Water Pollution Control Law -- abatement of discharge of sewage from subdivision.

Plaintiff State Department of Environmental Conservation, which issued a permit to operate a sewage collection system and treatment plant to a subdivision developer which subsequently abandoned the sewer system which it erected allowing partially treated and untreated sanitary sewage emanating from homes in the subdivision to be discharged into the waters of Kinderhook Creek, may maintain an action to abate the discharge of the sewage against the owners of residences in the subdivision. Enforcement of the State Water Pollution Control Law ( ECL art 17) against the property owners does not constitute an unconstitutional de facto appropriation of private property without due process of law. The abatement and prevention of water pollution constitutes a reasonable exercise of the State's police power. Plaintiff is not responsible for the defects in the construction and operation of the sewage treatment plant. Even if the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation erred [***2] in exercising discretion in issuing a permit for the operation and construction of the sewage treatment plant ( ECL 17-0701), the State cannot be held liable for the results of the performance of a discretionary act. Plaintiff has also taken appropriate action to compel the subdivision developer to correct the defects in the sewage system.

 

2299 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Peterson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Bronx County


91 Misc. 2d 407; 398 N.Y.S.2d 24; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2661



July 27, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with robbery in the first degree and related offenses, brought a motion for dismissal of the indictment and for other forms of relief on the ground of discriminatory prosecution in connection with his treatment as a major offender by the district attorney.


OVERVIEW: The district attorney's office instituted a major offense program that identified cases in which the crime was particularly heinous or the alleged offender was a serious recidivist, and selected those cases for prosecution marked by limited plea bargaining, full disclosure to defense counsel, immediate and thorough case preparation, and the assignment of a single assistant district attorney to handle a given case from inception to conclusion. Defendant challenged his selection for inclusion in the major offense program on equal protection and due process grounds. The gravamen of the motion was that, by being cast as a defendant in the accelerated prosecution program, defendant was being deprived of the right to be treated the same as other defendants in the criminal process. The court dismissed defendant's motion because the program was constitutionally sound. It did not offend due process by by-passing the felony complaint hearing because such hearing was not constitutionally required where there had been a grand jury indictment. Also, the courts, by establishing the program, properly exercised the power to dispose of cases and ease the chronic problem of trial delay.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment because the speedy disposition of criminal cases that the major offender program allowed for was constitutionally sound.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- accelerated prosecution of major offenders -- due process.

Defendant's accelerated prosecution as a major felony offender by the Bronx County major offense bureau did not violate any of his constitutional rights in the criminal process. The purpose of the Federally assisted program of accelerated prosecution is to insure swift and certain justice for the perpetrators of serious crimes and repeat offenders. The median time between arrest and case disposition under the major offense program is 97 days compared to a median time of 400 days for all other felony cases prosecuted by the Bronx County District Attorney. Special parts of the Supreme Court in Bronx County are set aside solely to hear cases prosecuted by the major offense bureau. Plea bargaining, which is not a constitutional right, is severely limited. The District Attorney, in discharging the duties of his office, has the right to focus greater attention upon the prosecution of those charged with serious crimes and the career criminal. A program of accelerated prosecution involving the selective prosecution of perpetrators of serious crimes or repeat offenders [***2] does not constitute an unconstitutional invidious classification since an individual is not prosecuted on the basis of race, religion or some other arbitrary classification. The major offense program does not involve selective enforcement. A defendant not selected for prosecution under the program is prosecuted nonetheless. Absent the denial of some constitutionally protected right, a program of accelerated prosecution does not offend due process concepts. There is a rational basis for distinguishing between major offenders and those charged with lesser crimes. The prosecution of any case under the major offense program does not deprive a defendant of sufficient time to prepare an adequate defense. The denial of a preliminary hearing does not violate due process where there has been a Grand Jury indictment. The Bronx County Grand Jury has returned 99% of the indictments originating from the major offense bureau within three days of arrest thereby averting the felony hearing which is mandated within 72 hours of arraignment ( CPL 180.80). Finally, a defendant prosecuted as a major offender is not unduly prejudiced by the fact that the Judge is aware of his past criminal record.

 

2300 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bryant Westchester Realty Corp. v. Board of Health


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


91 Misc. 2d 56; 397 N.Y.S.2d 322; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2235



July 15, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, plaintiff's motion is denied and the cross motion is granted to the extent of directing judgment declaring sections 131.15 and 131.17 of the Health Code in all respects constitutional and valid.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlord moved for a preliminary injunction restraining defendant tenant from enforcing New York City, N.Y., Health Code § 131.15 on the ground that it was unconstitutional, at least as applied to the landlord. The tenant cross-moved for an order dismissing the complaint pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211 or alternatively for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The landlord challenged the constitutionality of §131.15 requiring him to install window guards in an apartment where a child under 10 years of age resided. He contended that compliance was a confiscatory financial burden, and there was no rational relationship between the installation of window guards and the prevention of window falls. Economic injury was the only damage alleged. The court held that economic damage was not a ground for an injunction. The court noted that there was a rational relationship between the requirement of window guards and the appropriate objective, within the police power, the prevention of children from falling from windows. The court found the landlord's allegation that § 131.15 was unconstitutional as applied to him due to a economic hardship was without merit. There were costs imposed by requirements involving the maintenance and operation of residential buildings, imposed for public well-being. That a statute or regulation resulted in reduced income, imposed additional costs or other pecuniary injury, or even made it impossible for some to continue in business, did not establish unconstitutionality where exercise of the police power was involved.


OUTCOME: The court denied the landlord's motion and granted the cross-motion to the extent of directing a judgment that the relative sections of the New York City Health Code were valid.


HEADNOTES

Health -- window guards to prevent children from falling -- validity of statute.

1. Section 131.15 of the New York City Health Code, which requires the installation of window guards in apartments where children under the age of 10 reside and in the hallway windows of such buildings, is constitutional. There is a rational relationship between the requirement of window guards and the proper objective of the statute, within the police power, the prevention of children from falling from windows. Moreover, a statute or regulation which results in an economic burden being placed on a particular landlord does not establish unconstitutionality where exercise of the police power is involved.

2. Section 131.15 of the Health Code is not invalid as a violation of the rent control provisions of chapters 371 and 1012 of the Laws of 1971, which prohibit a municipality from adopting any regulation affecting rent control housing more stringent than those in effect prior to June [***2] 30, 1971, without first obtaining the approval of the State Division of Housing. These provisions were not intended to restrict a municipality in adopting public safety legislation or regulations for purposes other than rent regulation even though more stringent than those in effect prior to 1971 and even though they may affect rent controlled housing.

3. Section 131.17 of the New York City Health Code, which provides a mechanism whereby those who find it difficult to comply with section 131.15 may seek a modification of its requirements from the Commissioner of Health, has not been shown to be unconstitutional.

 

2301 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Scime v. County Legislature of Erie County


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


90 Misc. 2d 764; 395 N.Y.S.2d 952; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2150; 97 L.R.R.M. 2191



June 20, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employees sought to compel respondent county to give salary increases that the employees claimed they were due for prior years.


OVERVIEW: The employees were nonunion, white-collar employees of exempt civil service classification. The employees brought an action against the county seeking to compel the county to pay salary increases that were adopted by the legislature. The lower court ruled in favor of the county. On appeal, the employees claimed that the withholding of their salary increases was discriminatory, arbitrary, and capricious, and violated their right to equal protection of the law. The court held that the county's actions were unconstitutional and null and void because the county discriminated when it denied the employees their raises.


OUTCOME: The court ruled in favor of the employees.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Civil service -- salary discrimination.

1. The requirement of section 115 of the Civil Service Law, that employees earn equal pay for equal work, applies only to State employees and not municipal civil service employees. Accordingly, the statute is not violated by a determination of respondent county to withhold salary increases from certain nonunion employees, while paying increases to union employees and other nonunion employees holding similar positions.

2. Respondent violated the equal protection guarantees of the State and Federal Constitutions by withholding salary increases from petitioners, since its salary grade plan has the force and effect of local law and it may not arbitrarily discriminate among individuals holding positions in the same salary grade, based upon union status, for purposes of fiscal economy. The economic objective must be accomplished by a consistent and equitable plan, while the basis for petitioner's nonunion status bears no relation to respondent's fiscal situation. Accordingly, respondent's actions are null and void.

 

2302 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Flushing Nat'l Bank v. Municipal Assistance Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special and Trial Term, New York County


90 Misc. 2d 204; 397 N.Y.S.2d 662; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2021



June 15, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Cross motion granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1012(a), paras. 2, 3 and N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1012(a), para. 2, proposed intervenors, the movants, filed two motions to intervene in connection with continuing litigation that involved defendant city's short-term notes. Defendant city filed a cross-motion to disqualify the movants' attorney from serving as counsel in this or any related action.


OVERVIEW: The New York State Emergency Moratorium Act for the City of New York, L. 1975, ch. 874, as amended by ch. 875, whereby the payment of certain short-term notes issued by the city was purportedly postponed, was found unconstitutional. A remittitur was issued, the court awarded relief, and the litigation continued. The court denied the movant's motion to intervene filed pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1012(a), paras. 2, 3, holding that the motion papers did not factually support the grounds stated in the motion and that the purpose of the intervention was not within the intent of the statute or the remittitur. The court also denied the motion filed pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1012(a), para. 2, citing its adherence to prior decisions in which intervention was likewise denied. The court granted the city's cross-motion to disqualify the movants' attorney from serving as counsel in the matter or any related matter. The court held that the counsel's representation of the movants offended Canon 9 of the Code of Professional Responsibility, which interdicted "even the appearance of professional impropriety," and Canon 4, which required that a lawyer preserve the confidences and secrets of a client.


OUTCOME: The movants' motions to intervene were denied. The city's cross-motion was granted.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- Emergency Moratorium Act for City of New York.

1. Movants, holders of short-term notes of the City of New York, may not intervene and be granted class action status in the continuing litigation resulting from the declared unconstitutionality of the New York State Emergency Moratorium Act for the City of New York (L 1975, ch 874, as amd by ch 875) which purported to postpone the payment of certain short-term anticipation notes issued by the city (see 40 NY2d 731), for the purposes of proposing "an offer of settlement to the City of New York" and filing a notice of appeal from the judgment awarding 6% interest from the date of maturity rather than the face rate (see 88 Misc 2d 1047). Pursuant to the remittitur issued by the Court of Appeals (40 NY2d 1094), the interest rate, a method of payment, deferments, safeguards and remedies have already been provided for. The delay attendant upon movants' intervention and the consideration of their proposals would serve only to disrupt the presently accelerated progress of the processing of the noteholders' applications for judgments and the entry and payment of the resultant judgments.

 [***2] 2. Movants' attorney, who, as an associate of the law firm which acted as bond counsel to defendant Municipal Assistance Corporation (MAC), worked on legal matters related to MAC's and the city's budget, is disqualified from serving as counsel in this or any related proceeding. Movants' attorney had access to files and confidential materials. His representation of movants would violate cannon 4 of the Code of Professional Responsibility which prohibits a lawyer from using "information acquired in the course of the representation of a client to the disadvantage of the client". Such representation would also violate canon 9 which prohibits a lawyer leaving "public employment" from accepting private employment "in connection with any matter in which he had substantial responsibility prior to his leaving". The fact that movants' attorney waived compensation is irrelevant since the receipt of compensation is not a determinative test of ethical behavior.

 

2303 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York Public Interest Research Group, Inc. v. Levitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


90 Misc. 2d 670; 395 N.Y.S.2d 608; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2129



June 14, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motions of the defendants are therefore granted and the complaint is dismissed. The cross motion of the plaintiffs for summary judgment is accordingly denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, comptroller, county, and city, filed motions to dismiss the complaint of plaintiffs, public interest group and citizens, for lack of legal capacity to sue the county and city, for expiration of the limitation period, for failure to state a claim, and for laches. The public interest group and the citizens sought summary judgment on their claim to void a public improvement contract and to enjoin disbursement of payments related to it.


OVERVIEW: The public interest group and the citizens brought an action against the comptroller, the county, and the city, for relief from a public improvement contract that created a debt in violation of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 11. Plaintiffs sought a declaration that the contract was void and sought to enjoin the comptroller's disbursement of rental or supplemental contract payments to the county. Defendants filed motions to dismiss the complaint, contending that it was time barred, stated no claim, and that standing was lacking. Plaintiffs sought summary judgment. The court granted defendants' motions, concluding that the cause of action arose on the date of the contract's execution, which rental payments did not extend. An action was risible against the city and the county by eligible taxpayers from the time of the contract's execution. Moreover, security agreements arose out of the contract in the form of bonds and pledges against rentals from the buildings that were constructed. Based on the foregoing, the doctrine of laches barred the complaint, which made a delayed demand for relief approximately 12 years after the contract's execution.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motions of the comptroller, county, and city to dismiss the complaint brought by the public interest group and the citizens for declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to a public improvement contract. The court denied the cross-motion for summary judgment brought by the public interest group and the citizens.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of actions-contracts-agreement between State and county for construction of State facilities.

1. An action for a judgment declaring that an agreement executed May 11, 1965 between the State of New York, the County of Albany and the City of Albany providing for the acquisition of land in the city and its transfer to the county on which land the county was to construct office buildings, a museum and an auditorium to State specifications (the so-called South Mall), the construction to be financed by county bonds with rentals to be paid by the State, is void as creating a State debt in violation of the State Constitution, is barred by the six-year Statute of Limitations. The contract is alleged to create an unconstitutional State debt, not the annual rental payments, and, therefore, the cause of action arose on the execution of the contract.

2. Although citizen taxpayers had no cause of action as such until the decision in Boryszewski v Brydges (37 NY2d 361) and the enactment of article 7-A of the [***2] State Finance Law in 1975, they did have the right to sue the city and county under section 51 of the General Municipal Law prior thereto.

3. The action is also barred by laches. There was a delay of 12 years in the commencement of the action. The action would deprive investors in county bonds of security and the county would be beyond its debt limit and unable to borrow money for essential purposes. Further, the buildings would be valueless for the most part to anyone except the State.

 

2304 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Schwartz v. Durning


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Town Court of New York, Town of Mamaroneck, Westchester County


104 Misc. 2d 1018; 429 N.Y.S.2d 834; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2710



June 14, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the court's award of costs to plaintiff, who had appeared pro se in the original action.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff filed an action and was awarded judgment and statutory costs against defendant. Plaintiff appeared pro se and defendant was represented by his insurance carrier's attorney. Defendant objected to the award of costs by noting that N.Y. Unif. Just. Ct. Act § 1902 only allowed costs for a party who appeared by attorney.The court awarded costs to plaintiff in accordance with its original decision, finding that the phrase "if he has appeared by attorney" was unconstitutional and void. Costs awarded in an action were separate and distinct from an award of attorney's fees, which were not recoverable as costs. As such, the award of costs under § 1902 should have been unrelated to attorney's fees and to any consideration of whether the party was represented by an attorney. By adding the phrase "if he has appeared by attorney," the legislators treated some parties differently from other parties and denied equal treatment under the laws of the state to certain persons in a class not denied to others in that class. Those who were unable to afford an attorney were denied the award of costs, while others who were able to afford an attorney could have been awarded costs.


OUTCOME: The court awarded costs to plaintiff as in the original decision and held that a portion of N.Y. Unif. Just. Ct. Act § 1902 was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Costs -- Award in Justice Court -- Appearance by Attorney

 Section 1902 of the Uniform Justice Court Act, which allows a party costs only "if he has appeared by an attorney", denies an award of costs to those unable to afford an attorney, and improperly and illegally discriminates against certain persons in a class in violation of the equal protection provisions of section 11 of article I of the New York Constitution; there is no relationship between the award of costs and the award of attorney's fees and therefore an award of costs under the Uniform Justice Court Act is unrelated to any consideration of whether a party is represented by an attorney.

 

2305 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Howell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Buffalo


90 Misc. 2d 722; 395 N.Y.S.2d 933; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2140; 3 Media L. Rep. 1146



June 13, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Prior to sentencing, defendants moved for an order setting aside the verdict convicting them of promoting obscene materials in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 235.05(1), and also moved for dismissal of the informations. Defendants argued that the statute, in conjunction with N.Y. Penal Law § 235.15(1), was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of promoting obscene materials. Defendants argued that under N.Y. Penal Law § 235.15(1), they could not have known with reasonable certainty when promotion of obscene materials was protected and when it was not. The court noted that § 235.15(1) provided an affirmative defense to an alleged violation of promoting obscene materials when persons disseminating such materials did so to persons using them for educational, governmental, scientific, "or other similar" reasons. First, the court held that § 235.15(1) did not present a problem of equal protection of the laws, since such equal protection was guaranteed to persons, rather than to activities. However, the court then held that the statute, especially the provision regarding "similar" reasons, was without reasonably definitive limits, so that it was in fact unconstitutionally vague. Accordingly, the court vacated the verdict against defendants and dismissed the informations.


OUTCOME: The motion for an order setting aside the verdict against defendants was granted, and the informations against them were dismissed.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- obscenity -- affirmative defense of scientific, educational, governmental or similar justification for possession.

1. Section 235.05 (subd 1) of the Penal Law, providing that a "person is guilty of obscenity in the second degree when, knowing its contents and character, he * * * Promotes, or possesses with intent to promote, any obscene material", in conjunction with section 235.15 (subd 1) of the Penal Law, providing that "In any prosecution for obscenity, it is an affirmative defense that the persons to whom allegedly obscene material was disseminated * * * consisted of persons * * * having scientific, educational, governmental or other similar justification for possessing * * * the same", does not adequately advise a would-be seller of obscene material what sales are criminal and what are not, since section 235.15 (subd 1) fails to define with reasonable clarity those uses which will justify possession of the material. Accordingly, verdicts finding defendants guilty of violating section 235.05 (subd 1), after a trial at which they asserted the affirmative defense provided for in section 235.15 (subd 1), are vacated and the informations against them are dismissed [***2] on the ground that the statute under which they were prosecuted is so vague as to be unconstitutional.

2. Since defendants raised the question of the constitutionality of the statute prior to their trial, although not on the ground that it was unconstitutionally vague, they are not foreclosed from making their present posttrial motion, pursuant to CPL 330.30 (subd 1), attacking it on that ground.

 

2306 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Serra v. Warden, Rikers Island Men's House of Detention


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Bronx County


90 Misc. 2d 654; 395 N.Y.S.2d 602; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2126



June 9, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The writ of habeas corpus is granted and the petitioner is discharged from custody.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner filed a writ of habeas corpus contending that N.Y. Penal Law § 250.20 was vague, overbroad, violated due process under the Fourteenth Amendment, and unlawfully violated his right to protected speech under the First Amendment.


OVERVIEW: A confidential informant divulged the existence of the wiretap order to petitioner. Petitioner was prosecuted under N.Y. Penal Law § 250.20 for divulging an eavesdropping warrant. Petitioner contended that his detention was unlawful. The court granted the writ and found that § 250.20 outlawed speech and affected expression which was sheltered by the First Amendment. The court held that a valid government interest existed for the state to insure confidentiality. Section 250.20 could apply to a certain class of citizens, but under no circumstances could the statute apply to petitioner. Petitioner's act could not be independently unlawful. The court construed § 250.20 so as to narrow its proscription and, by doing so, avoided the necessity of determining the need to strike the entire statute as unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioner's writ of habeas corpus and ordered him discharged from custody.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- divulging eavesdropping warrant -- constitutionality of statute.

1. Defendant, who learned of the existence of an eavesdropping warrant from the confidential informant whose information was the basis for the issuance of the interception order, allegedly told the party being investigated that his phone was being tapped, and was charged with divulging an eavesdropping warrant, in violation of section 250.20 of the Penal Law, which provides that a "person is guilty of divulging an eavesdropping warrant when, possessing information concerning the existence or content of an eavesdropping warrant * * * he discloses such information to another person; except that such disclosure is not criminal or unlawful when made to a state or federal agency specifically authorized by law to receive reports concerning eavesdropping warrants, or when made in a legal proceeding, or to a law enforcement officer or agency connected with the application for such warrant, or to a legislative committee or temporary state commission, or to the telephone or telegraph corporation whose facilities are involved."  [***2] On defendant's writ of habeas corpus, he is discharged from custody, on the ground that section 250.20 is unconstitutional as applied to him. The statute limits speech, and, while the restraint imposed by it might be reasonable and the governmental interest sufficiently compelling so as to override First Amendment considerations if it was applied to a certain class of citizens, such as one who, in his official capacity, unlawfully divulges the existence of an eavesdropping warrant, it makes no distinction as to the status of its prospective targets, but seeks to prohibit public employee and private citizen alike from disclosing information, making the mere transmission of information, by anyone to anyone, a crime. As to a private citizen such as defendant, who is neither an official nor an employee of the State, was in no way connected with the original wiretap proceeding, and had no knowledge of it until he was told about it by the confidential informant, after the order had been obtained, the statute is an arbitrary and unreasonable exercise of the police power of the State, infringing upon his guaranteed liberties.

2. In view of the holding that the statute is unconstitutional [***3] as applied to defendant, the issue of whether it is unconstitutional on its face is not considered. However, a redrafting of it might be prudent, since a proper target who would have no justifiable claim of unconstitutionality as to himself, might, nevertheless, prevail on the constitutional issue by claiming that its overbreadth made it so sweeping on its face that it violated the constitutional protections of those who could not be constitutionally justified targets.

3. Since section 250.20 of the Penal Law has been found unconstitutional as to defendant, his alleged criminal act could not be the basis of an additional charge of obstructing governmental administration, and that charge must also fall.

 

2307 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Finkelstein, Mauriello, Kaplan & Levine, P.C. v. McGuirk


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Orange County


90 Misc. 2d 649; 395 N.Y.S.2d 377; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2125



June 3, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorneys brought a civil proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to enjoin respondents, the town and the district attorney, from prosecution of a misdemeanor complaint filed by an individual who alleged that petitioners' erroneous issuance of a second restraining order in another proceeding was an unlawful collection practice under N.Y. Penal Law § 190.50.


OVERVIEW: An individual filed a misdemeanor complaint against petitioner attorneys based on their conduct in another proceeding. The complaint alleged that erroneous issuance of a second restraining order, valid on its face but later set aside by court order, constituted an unlawful collection practice under N.Y. Penal Law § 190.50. Petitioners filed a motion under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to enjoin respondents, the town and the district attorney, from prosecuting the complaint. The court found that because there was no claim that respondents acted in excess of their authority, the court lacked jurisdiction under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78. Because petitioners sought alternative relief in the form of a declaratory judgment and an injunction, however, the form of petitioners' motion did not prevent resolution of the case. The court concluded that petitioners' conduct in the other proceeding did not fall within the definition of an unlawful collection practice. The restraining notice in question was an authentic document issued by petitioners in their capacity as officers of the court. Thus, respondents were permanently enjoined from proceeding with the misdemeanor complaint filed against petitioners.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioner attorneys' request for a declaratory ruling enjoining respondents, the town and the district attorney, from prosecuting a misdemeanor complaint on the grounds that petitioners' erroneous issuance of an order did not amount to an unlawful collection practice.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Proceeding against body or officer -- pending criminal action -- unlawful collection practices.

1. The attorneys for a judgment creditor erroneously served the same person with a second restraining notice against the property of the judgment debtor without leave of the court, as required by CPLR 5222 (subd [c]), whereupon the judgment debtor filed a misdemeanor complaint against them, based on section 190.50 of the Penal Law, defining unlawful collection practices and making it a misdemeanor to attempt to foist off as authentic an instrument which simulates an official document but which possesses no judicial or official sanction. In an article 78 proceeding by the attorneys to enjoin prosecution of the misdemeanor complaint, treated as an action for a declaratory judgment and an injunction, it is declared that their conduct in issuing the second restraining notice without leave of the court did not constitute an unlawful collection practice within the meaning of section 190.50 of the Penal Law, and respondents, the Town Justice and District Attorney, are permanently enjoined from proceeding with the misdemeanor complaint.

2. An article 78 proceeding is not proper, since [***2] there is no claim that respondents are about to act in excess of their authority, but the attorneys have sought alternate relief in the nature of a declaratory judgment and injunction, and the article 78 form of their moving papers does not preclude the court from considering these latter prayers for relief.

3. While a collateral proceeding to review alleged errors in a pending criminal action is generally prohibited, and while a criminal action has, technically, been commenced against the attorneys by the filing of the misdemeanor complaint, no further proceedings have taken place, and the attorneys, who are threatened with irreparable injury and whose application involves solely a question of law, should not be foreclosed from seeking declaratory and injunctive relief at this pre-embryonic stage of the criminal proceeding. Additionally, the far-reaching implications of needlessly subjecting officers of the court to criminal prosecution if a particular criminal enactment was never intended to encompass their routine professional activities, even if erroneously performed, dictate that the application be entertained.

 

2308 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Health Ins. Asso. v. Harnett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


89 Misc. 2d 795; 395 N.Y.S.2d 372; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1976



June 2, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion for summary judgment is granted with respect to the first cause of action, and otherwise denied. Plaintiffs' cross motion for summary judgment is granted with respect to the second cause of action, and otherwise denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff insurance companies filed an action for a judgement declaring unconstitutional 1976 N.Y. Laws 843, which required that every health insurance policy issued include equal coverage for maternity care. Defendant, Superintendent of Insurance, filed a motion for summary judgment and the insurance companies filed cross-motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: 1976 N.Y. Laws 843 required that every health insurance policy issued include coverage for maternity care to the same extent that hospital, surgical, or medical coverage was provided for illness or disease under the policy. The insurance companies filed an action for a judgment declaring the statute unconstitutional and the Superintendent of Insurance filed a motion for summary judgment. The insurance companies filed cross-motions for summary judgment. The court held that it was not persuaded that the statute would have resulted in irrational and unreasonable regulation of the insurance business and that maternity coverage was not a business utterly foreign to the insurance companies but was merely an extension of that business. The court found that the statute did not deprive the insurance companies of due process and granted summary judgment to the Superintendent on the due process issue. The court held that the statute could not modify by operation of law those policies issued as guaranteed renewable policies and granted summary judgment in favor of the insurance companies as to that issue. The court held that the issue of adequate time for implementation was one for trial.


OUTCOME: The court granted in part and denied in part the parties' motions for summary judgment. The court issued summary judgment in favor of defendant, Superintendent of Insurance on the due process issue, but in favor of plaintiff insurance companies holding that the statute might not modify by operation of law those policies issues as guaranteed renewable policies.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- health insurance -- compulsory inclusion of maternity benefits.

1. Chapter 843 of the Laws of 1976 which requires that every health insurance policy issued in this State include "coverage for maternity care * * * to the same extent that hospital, surgical or medical coverage is provided for illness or disease under the policy" will not unconstitutionally result in irrational and unreasonable regulation of the insurance business. While the compulsory inclusion of maternity coverage in all health insurance policies will, to some extent, make plaintiffs' health insurance business more difficult or expensive it does not invalidate the statute. Plaintiffs' fears of unfair, irrational and unpredictable increases in premiums are entirely speculative. Plaintiffs have not yet prepared premium schedules nor proposed policies in order to comply with chapter 843. Plaintiffs can mitigate the effects of "anti-selection"  [***2] which would occur if couples permit their health insurance policies to lapse after obtaining the maternity benefits, by offering multiyear policies or pooling their maternity risks thereby decreasing the effects on any single insurer. Chapter 843 does not have the effect of destroying the health insurance business. The statute does not forbid the sale of a "nondeleterious" product, but simply requires that the product contain an additional ingredient which the Legislature has determined to be essential for the public welfare. Chapter 843 does not unconstitutionally compel plaintiffs to enter into a new and unwanted business. Maternity coverage is not a "business utterly foreign" to plaintiffs' health insurance business, but is merely an extension of that business.

2. Consonant with the constitutional prohibition against the impairment of the obligation of contracts, chapter 843 may not be applied to the renewal of "guaranteed renewable" policies which plaintiffs have no choice but to renew at the sole option of the insured.

3. The question of whether the January 1, 1977 effective date of the statute provides a reasonable preparation period to enable timely compliance may only [***3] be determined by a trier of fact.

 

2309 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Costello


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


90 Misc. 2d 431; 395 N.Y.S.2d 139; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2080



June 1, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] It may very well be that as newer legislators replace those "raised under repressive sexual adaptations" former taboos will gradually disappear, but until those halcyon days arrive this court is constrained to follow the current law and deny defendant's motion in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, convicted of promotion of prostitution, moved for a dismissal on the ground that the prostitution statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 230.00, was vague and overbroad, and that such sexual activity was a basic right.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of promoting prostitution. He moved for dismissal, contending that the statute defining prostitution, N.Y. Penal Law § 230.00, was unconstitutional in that it was vague and overbroad. He also alleged that such "recreational sex" could not be outlawed. The court denied the motion. The failure to define the terms "sexual conduct" and "fee" did not render § 230.00 unconstitutional because the terms were commonly understood to encompass intercourse and masturbation, performed for payment. The regulation of such conduct was within the state's police power. The court also found that such legislation of morality was proper.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion; the statute was not vague as terms within it had commonly understood meanings, and it was not overbroad, therefore the legislature was free to address morality in legislation.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- prostitution -- constitutionality of statute defining prostitution.

1. Section 230.00 of the Penal Law, which provides that a "person is guilty of prostitution when such person engages or agrees or offers to engage in sexual conduct with another person in return for a fee", is not unconstitutional. It was enacted to prohibit commercial exploitation of sexual gratification, a legitimate legislative concern, and, while the terms "sexual conduct" and "fee" are not further defined therein, the term "prostitution" itself has a commonly understood meaning.

2. That there may be marginal cases where the criminality of the conduct is not clear is not sufficient to render the statute unconstitutional. However, to avoid confusion and possible future attack on the statute, if the Legislature deems that sexual acts other than those within the common understanding of the term "prostitution" should [***2] come within the ambit of the statute, it might well define "sexual conduct" to include those acts.

3. Asserted policy considerations do not warrant judicial interference with the statute.

 

2310 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Salla v. County of Monroe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


90 Misc. 2d 427; 395 N.Y.S.2d 366; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2079



May 31, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff employees filed a declaratory judgment action against defendants, the County of Monroe of the State of New York and others, seeking a determination that N.Y. Lab. Law § 222 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The employees, who were non-residents of New York, were employed by a contractor who had been awarded a contract to construct sanitary systems for the County. The contractor terminated the employees' employment pursuant to § 222. Section 222 provided that, in public works construction, preference in employment was to be given to citizens of New York who had been residents of the State for at least 12 consecutive months immediately prior to the commencement of their new employment. In declaring § 222 unconstitutional, the court ruled that the statute created a classification of workers that denied the employees the equal protection of the laws as guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment. Section 222 denied the employees the opportunity of obtaining and engaging in lawful employment solely because they had not resided in New York for an arbitrarily prescribed period. It not only abridged their fundamental right to travel, but also their right to engage in business, which right was the very purpose of the Fourteenth Amendment. The court further ruled that the preference created by § 222 in favor of resident workers violated the Privileges and Immunities and Commerce Clauses.


OUTCOME: The court declared the challenged statute unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Constitutional law -- preference in employment in public works construction.

 Section 222 of the Labor Law, which provides that, in public works construction, "preference in employment shall be given to citizens of the state of New York who have been residents of the state for at least twelve consecutive months immediately prior to the commencement of their new employment", is unconstitutional. Protecting employment opportunities of State residents against out-of-State residents creates a classification of potential workers on the basis of where they live which is violative of the commerce clause and the privileges and immunities clause of the United States Constitution and the equal protection guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment thereto, and such a classification is not necessary to promote any compelling governmental interest.

 

2311 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Billi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


90 Misc. 2d 568; 395 N.Y.S.2d 353; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2113



May 20, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought an evidentiary hearing to determine the constitutionality of statutes classifying cocaine within a definition of narcotic drugs.


OVERVIEW: Defendants contended that the question was whether the court should place itself in the position of deciding whether the legislature was correct in passing a law listing cocaine as a narcotic substance and whether the court had the power to second guess the legislature. They urged that, as applied to cocaine, the law was unconstitutional substantively and that the penalties were also. The court held that a classification of cocaine within a definition of the term "narcotic drug" was not arbitrary or irrational. The court also held that statutes classifying cocaine within a definition of "narcotic drug" did not violate the equal protection and due process clauses of state and federal constitutions. The court further held that punishments imposed for the crime of possession of cocaine were not grossly disproportionate or cruel and unusual in the constitutional sense. Finally, in determining whether a penal statute imposed cruel and unusual punishment, the court required a consideration of the gravity of the offense, the harm it caused to society, the crime it generated, and the threat the offender posed to society.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- classification of cocaine as narcotic drug.

1. The control of cocaine, a nonnarcotic central nervous system stimulant, is in the public interest, and the classification of it as a narcotic drug for regulatory and penalty purposes has a rational basis and is constitutional.

2. A motion for an evidentiary hearing on the propriety of the classification is denied.

 

2312 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rolle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Onondaga County


90 Misc. 2d 392; 395 N.Y.S.2d 347; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2070



May 16, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Therefore, based upon the foregoing, the defendant's conviction is vacated and the charges dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted before a city court (New York) of illegal storage of alcoholic beverage, and he appealed.


OVERVIEW: The execution of a search warrant was issued upon allegations that defendant was involved in the illegal sale and storage of alcoholic beverages. Defendant was convicted, and he appealed. Defendant attacked the constitutionality of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 96, subd. 1. The court held that a statute that failed to distinguish between innocent conduct and action calculated to cause harm could not be sustained. The court also held that the provision of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act that no alcoholic beverage could be stored or kept on any premises which were not duly licensed as provided for in the chapter entitled "Special Permits" was unconstitutionally vague. Specifically, the statute did not give reasonable and sufficient notice of what was prohibited in that a permit would be required to store or keep alcoholic beverages in the home, regardless of amount or intent of the homeowner and control of private residences not involved in a sale. The court further held that distribution and manufacture of alcoholic beverages had no relation to the public good.


OUTCOME: The conviction was vacated, and the charges were dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Intoxicating liquors -- storing alcoholic beverages without license -- constitutionality of statute.

Section 96 (subd 1) of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, which is entitled "Warehouse permit" and provides that "No alcoholic beverage shall be stored or kept in or upon any premises which shall not be duly licensed", is unconstitutionally vague, in that it does not give a reasonable man notice of what is prohibited and what is permitted, and provides no guidelines for its enforcement. Under its wording a private citizen would be required to obtain a permit to keep alcoholic beverages in his residence even though his residence was not utilized for any activity covered by the law. Moreover, it does not direct itself to a prohibited amount or to the intent or object of the one storing the beverages, nor does it restrict its application to certain types of premises, but covers all premises in the State where alcoholic beverages may be found, regardless of amount and regardless of the intent and object of the one storing them.

 

2313 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Helms v. Reid


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Hamilton County


90 Misc. 2d 583; 394 N.Y.S.2d 987; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2118; 7 ELR 20519



May 11, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff seaplane operator filed an action against defendant state agencies and officers (state), and alleged that the state permitted unlawful uses of forest lands, that the plan for the Adirondack Park area was unconstitutional, and that the prohibition of seaplane landings in certain lakes was unconstitutional. An environmental group received permission to intervene. The state and the operator filed motions for partial summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The state had set aside certain forest preserves, and mandated in N.Y. Const. art. XIV, § 1, that those preserves remain wild forests. The parties agreed that the question of unlawful use of some of the forest lands was not amenable to summary judgment. The court held that although N.Y. Const. art. XIV, § 1 deprived the legislature of any power to permit commercial cutting of timber in the state forests, the legislature was permitted to make reasonable regulations for the public use and preservation of the forests. The court held that because the legislature had the authority to make reasonable regulations, it had the power to delegate that authority to agencies such as the Adirondack Park Agency. The court held that the Adirondack Master Plan, which divided the forest preserve areas into seven categories did not violate art. XIV, § 1's mandate that the forest preserves remain wild forest. The court held that N.Y. Comp. Codes R & Regs. tit 6, § 196.4, which prohibited the use of seaplanes on certain of the lakes within the forest reserves, served the bona fide purpose of preserving the natural character of the land and was not arbitrary and capricious.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the state on the constitutionality of the Adirondack Master Plan and the regulations prohibiting seaplanes from landing in certain lakes within the forest preserves. The court denied the operator's cross-motions for partial summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Environmental conservation -- State land in Adirondack Park -- State Land Master Plan.

1. The State Land Master Plan, which was developed by the Adirondack Park Agency in consultation with the Department of Environmental Conservation, pursuant to a directive contained in the Adirondack Park Agency Act (Executive Law, art 27, § 807), and which was approved by the Governor and thereafter by the Legislature (L 1973, ch 348), classifies the State land within the park into seven land use categories. This provision for different uses in different areas of the forest preserve, some of which uses entail the cutting of timber, does not violate the "forever wild" clause of the New York State Constitution, providing that the "lands of the state * * * constituting the forest preserve * * * shall be forever kept as wild forest lands * * * nor shall the timber thereon be sold, removed or destroyed" (NY Const, art XIV, § 1). Accordingly, in a suit instituted by the operators of an air taxi service, with the consent of the Appellate Division (NY Const, art XIV, § 5), a cause of action alleging that the plan is unconstitutional because of the classifications made therein, and because [***2] it was not adopted as a constitutional amendment, is summarily dismissed.

2. Another cause of action alleges that some of the uses permitted in the forest preserve actually destroy its wild forest nature because they entail cutting significant amounts of timber and overuse of the area where they are permitted. The language of the plan itself recognizes that some of the uses which it authorizes may be declared unconstitutional. However, unlike a determination as to the constitutionality of the plan itself, a determination as to the constitutionality of any given uses authorized by it can be made only after a trial, since there are questions of fact regarding the reasonableness of the uses, especially in light of the amount of timber which had to be cut in order to establish them.

3. A third cause of action challenges the validity of a regulation of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation which prohibits the operation of mechanically propelled vessels and aircraft on some 700 lakes and ponds which are wholly surrounded by State land within the park (6 NYCRR 196.4). In view of the discontinuance, with prejudice, of a prior article 78 proceeding challenging this regulation,  [***3] and the nature of this action, to restrain an alleged violation of the "forever wild" clause, the only question to be determined is whether that clause prohibits the making of such a regulation. While the clause would prohibit a regulation which arbitrarily restricts public access to or a reasonable public use of the lands in the preserve, this regulation does not do so. Accordingly, the third cause of action is summarily dismissed.

 

2314 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Harris v. Buffalo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


90 Misc. 2d 561; 394 N.Y.S.2d 794; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2111



May 9, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment is therefore granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs sought summary judgment in their action requesting a declaration that Buffalo, N.Y., Ordinance ch. VII, § 352 was unconstitutional, illegal, and void. The ordinance prohibited in the broadest possible terms, the use or display within the city of any and all types of "for sale" or "sold" signs on residential property.


OVERVIEW: Buffalo, N.Y., Ordinance ch. VII, § 352, according to the court, was a reasoned, well-intended effort to eliminate the unscrupulous real estate activities and substantial community damage that was associated with racial "blockbusting" and "panic selling" of residential property by white residents. The city contended that the signs constituted unnecessarily visible evidence of neighborhood change and served to create unfounded, unreasonable fears of diminished property values and neighborhood deterioration. In granting plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, the court ruled that the ordinance violated U.S. Const. amend. I and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8. The court found that the subject was appropriate for municipal legislation, but that an attempted solution could not be accomplished by unconstitutional or illegal means. The United States Supreme Court had declared that commercial speech was not wholly outside the protection of the First Amendment. Municipalities were without power or authority to accomplish what they perceived to be the peoples' best interests by denying them information that was neither false nor misleading.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motion.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- freedom of speech -- residential "for sale" signs.

Although an ordinance of the City of Buffalo prohibiting the display of "for sale" signs on certain types of residential property constitutes a reasoned and well-intended effort to eliminate racial "blockbusting" and "panic selling" of residential property, the ordinance unconstitutionally restrains the right of free speech. While some commercial speech is subject to regulation, the free flow of truthful commercial information may not be impaired, whether or not the persons receiving the information may act thereon in a manner inconsistent with their own self-interest or the public interest.

 

2315 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Guercio


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


90 Misc. 2d 256; 394 N.Y.S.2d 536; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2032



May 3, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendants' motion to suppress is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion to suppress evidence obtained as a result of an eavesdropping warrant on the ground that the warrant failed to comply with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 700.30(5).


OVERVIEW: Defendants filed a motion to suppress evidence that was obtained as a result of an eavesdropping warrant on the ground that the warrant failed to comply with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 700.30(5). The court found that the warrant at issue was totally silent as to the identity of the law enforcement agency that was authorized to intercept the communications. The court considered the legislative history and held that it was clear that the N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 700, which was reflective of controlling federal law, required strict compliance. The court held that, in the absence of strict compliance, state officials lacked authority to wiretap, and that any interceptions they made were unlawful and any evidence derived from the wiretap was inadmissible. Therefore, the court granted defendants' motion because the warrant at issue failed to strictly comply with the requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. § 700.30(5).


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motion to suppress.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- eavesdropping warrant -- identity of law enforcement agency authorized to intercept communications.

An eavesdropping warrant which did not contain the "identity of the law enforcement agency authorized to intercept the communications" as required by CPL 700.30 (subd 5) is invalid. Evidence obtained as a result of the invalid eavesdropping warrant must therefore be suppressed. "Each order authorizing or approving the interception of any wire or oral communication" must specify" the identity of the agency authorized to intercept the communications, and of the person authorizing the application" (US Code, tit 18, § 2518, subd [4]). The provisions of the State statute dealing with eavesdropping warrants ( CPL art 700) track the language of the Federal law. The requirements of article 700, which are reflective of controlling Federal law, must be strictly complied with. In the absence of compliance, State officials lack authority to wiretap, and any interceptions they make are unlawful, and any evidence derived from the wiretap is inadmissible.

 

2316 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Flushing Nat'l Bank v. Municipal Assistance Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special and Trial Term, New York County


89 Misc. 2d 783; 394 N.Y.S.2d 840; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1941



May 2, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion for summary judgment denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff noteholders filed motions for partial summary judgment and for reargument in its action against defendant city on the issue of the interest rate owed by the city on certain unpaid short-term notes.


OVERVIEW: The noteholders sought to relitigate the interest rated owed by the city on short term notes held by the noteholders. From a prior appeal, an appellate court's remittitur provided the noteholders a remedy for the noteholders to recover on their judgments against the city. The court denied the motion for summary judgment because the issue of the interest rate on the notes had already been litigated. The court noted that over 12,000 noteholders had resorted to the simplified, expeditious procedures fashioned by the appellate court to recover on their judgments and that the delays caused by separate, individual actions and concomitant motions for summary judgment would penalize all noteholders.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motions.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- Emergency Moratorium Act for City of New York -- interest rate payable on short term obligations following maturity.

Plaintiff, a holder of unpaid short term obligations of the City of New York, may not relitigate the issue of the interest rate payable on such notes after maturity (see Flushing Nat. Bank v Municipal Assistance Corp., NYLJ, March 7, 1977, p 11, col 2). The Court of Appeals remittitur, following the decision declaring the Emergency Moratorium Act for the City of New York unconstitutional, affords all noteholders a swift and efficacious remedy. As of April 29, 1977, some 12,639 noteholders had resorted to the simplified, more expeditious procedure fashioned by the court. Judgments are being entered at the rate of 400 per day. No such progress would have been possible had even a small proportion of the 12,639 claimants elected to ignore the remedy adopted for their benefit and proceeded, instead by separate actions and concomitant motions for summary judgment. The ensuing delay would penalize all claimants and benefit none, including plaintiff.

 

2317 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Marcus


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


90 Misc. 2d 243; 394 N.Y.S.2d 530; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2029



April 21, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(1)(h), defendants filed motions to dismiss their indictments in the New York trial court for felony drug charges. Defendants alleged that actions of law enforcement officials of the New York State Drug Enforcement Task Force constituted discriminatory prosecutions and violated their rights under the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the United States and New York Constitutions.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were arrested by federal agents as a result of drug investigations conducted by the state Task Force. Defendants were told that if they co-operated they would be prosecuted federally; but if they failed to co-operate they would be prosecuted in the state courts, with the consequent harsher penalties. Defendants refused to co-operate and were indicted for felony drug charges in New York. Defendants filed motions to dismiss the indictments on the grounds of selective or discriminatory prosecution in violation of their equal protection and due process rights. The court held that the procedures used to determine whether to prosecute in federal or state court were constitutionally valid. However, the court granted the motions to dismiss and ordered a hearing be held determine the validity of the allegations. Defendant's claimed they were singled out for prosecution under a specific statute in a specific jurisdiction, in order to expose them to harsher penalties, solely because they refused to co-operate and turn informers. This discouraged the assertion of their rights against self-incrimination or violated their rights of equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motions to dismiss the indictments to the extent that a hearing was ordered to determine the validity of their claims of selective or discriminatory prosecution.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- selective prosecution -- refusal to turn informer.

Defendants, who were arrested by special agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration as the result of investigations conducted by the New York Drug Enforcement Task Force (Task Force), a Federally funded tripartite organization consisting of Federal, State and local law enforcement representation, may not be prosecuted in the New York State courts in order to expose them to harsher or higher penalties upon drug convictions solely because they refused to co-operate and turn informers. Normally, the criteria followed by the Task Force in channeling cases to the State or Federal courts for prosecution involve such reasonable factors as the availability of a harsher sentence structure under State law, the amount of narcotics involved, with lesser cases going to State courts, the need for search warrants which are easier to obtain in State courts, the extent of conspiracy which is easier to prove in Federal courts, the easier corroboration requirements in Federal courts and the greater opportunity for trials in Federal courts as opposed to plea bargaining. Although defendants do not have a constitutional right [***2] to be prosecuted under a Federal rather than a State law where their acts violate both even where they are prosecuted under the statute which imposes the higher penalty, they may not be singled out for prosecution under the harsher statute solely because they invoked their constitutional rights against self incrimination. Whatever appropriate or commendable purposes the prosecutors may have had in setting up a system to determine which offenders are prosecuted in what jurisdiction, they cannot pursue their objective by any means that needlessly chill the exercise of basic constitutional rights. Accordingly, defendants' motion to dismiss the indictments are granted to the extent that a hearing is ordered to determine the validity of their claims of selective or discriminatory prosecution. Once defendants present sufficient facts to raise a reasonable doubt about the prosecution's purpose, the prosecution would then be required to go forward to justify in some rational basis their actions in selecting defendants for prosecution in the New York State courts.

 

2318 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Granchelli


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Monroe County


90 Misc. 2d 103; 393 N.Y.S.2d 894; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1999



April 18, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Under the circumstances presented here, including the lengthy period of living separate and apart (from 1962 to Jan. of 1976) and the lack of authority for revoking or otherwise terminating the decree of separation, the claim of the surviving spouse to an elective share is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1, petitioner estranged spouse filed for a proceeding to determine the validity of her right of election to a testator's estate.


OVERVIEW: The testator and the spouse were married. On the spouse's separation proceeding, the testator counterclaimed for separation on the grounds of abandonment. Judgment for separation was granted to the testator and the spouse's claim was dismissed. The spouse and the testator reconciled and lived together for six years. The spouse commenced a proceeding to revoke the judgment of separation. The testator opposed it, and the spouse's application was denied. The spouse left the testator. The testator died. The representatives of the testator's estate asserted that the spouse was barred from an election under N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.2(a)(4) by the separation decree. The court rejected the spouse's argument that there was an unjust distinction as to the effect of a reconciliation subsequent to a separation decree as opposed to a separation agreement. Although evidence of a reconciliation was adequate to overcome a separation agreement, a separation decree could only be revoked under N.Y. Dom. Rel.
