Law § 203, which the spouse had attempted without success. The spouse was not deprived of any constitutional property rights to the estate because the right of election was statutory.


OUTCOME: The court denied the spouse's claim to an elective share of the estate.


HEADNOTES

Wills -- elective share -- spouse against whom decree of separation has been rendered.

1. About one and one-half years after decedent was granted a decree of separation from his wife on the ground of abandonment, from which she did not appeal, they reconciled and lived together for a period of about six years, during which period she sought an order revoking the decree, but her application, which was opposed by decedent, was denied because it was not a joint application of the parties (Domestic Relations Law, § 203). She then left him and commenced an action for a separation, but her complaint was dismissed because of the existing decree. They thereafter remained apart until his death some 14 years later. Her claim to an elective share of his estate is denied. EPTL 5-1.2 (subd [a], par [4]) bars a spouse against whom a decree of separation has been rendered from claiming an elective [***2] share, and, while a reconciliation, accompanied by an intent to abandon a separation agreement, renders the agreement void, a decree of separation can only be revoked as provided in section 203 of the Domestic Relations Law, i.e., by court order after a joint application of the parties accompanied by satisfactory evidence of their reconciliation, or overturned on appeal.

2. A contention that EPTL 5-1.2 (subd [a], par [4]) and section 203 of the Domestic Relations Law are unconstitutional is without merit, since rights of succession to the property of a deceased are of statutory creation.

 

2319 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Levy v. Bahou


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


90 Misc. 2d 694; 395 N.Y.S.2d 891; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2135



April 15, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, petitioner/plaintiff's motion is denied and pursuant to CPLR 3212 (subd [b]), summary judgment is granted in favor of the respondents, dismissing the petition/complaint herein on the merits.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner applicant filed a "motion" for a judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 that sought a determination that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 60, subd. 3 to be unconstitutional. The applicant also sought to enjoin the appointment of certain civil service positions by respondent, the New York State Civil Service Commission, and to annul the commission's determination of the applicant's ineligibility for a position.


OVERVIEW: The applicant brought an article 78 proceeding that sought a declaration that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 60, subd. 3 was unconstitutional, and from this determination to enjoin the appointment of certain civil service positions or to set aside the appointment of any persons made to hose positions. The applicant also sought to require the commission to fill any vacancy in those positions pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 71, and to annul any determination by the commission that the applicant was ineligible for a designated appointment. The court held that to reach the merits of the applicant's petition, it was necessary to treat his motion as one for summary judgment in an action for declaratory judgment rather than the mere reinstitution of an article 78 proceeding. The court held that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 60, subd. 3 carried the strong presumption of constitutionality, to which the applicant presented no evidence to rebut such presumption. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the commission pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 3212, subd. (b).


OUTCOME: The court denied the relief sought by the applicant. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the commission, thereby dismissing the petition on the merits.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- certification of lists for State service -- preference given to residents of county where vacancy occurs

Subdivision 3 of section 60 of the Civil Service Law which authorizes the State Civil Service Commission to give first consideration in filling vacancies in positions in the State service to residents of the county in which a vacancy occurs, before making appointments from the general State-wide list, is not unconstitutional. Petitioner, who was declared ineligible for appointment as Head Estate Tax Clerk in the Surrogate's Court of Kings County, has failed to rebut the strong presumption of constitutionality which attaches to a legislative enactment. The test in cases of statutes or ordinances imposing residence limitations is one of rationality. Petitioner has failed to show that the residence limitations imposed by subdivision 3 of section 60 lack a rational basis.

 

2320 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Caban


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


90 Misc. 2d 43; 393 N.Y.S.2d 303; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1984



April 6, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion of the defendant Hector Suarez is denied; that of the defendant Caban is granted in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Two defendants moved for an order setting aside a jury verdict convicting them of criminal possession of more than one-eighth of an ounce of heroin in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 220.09. The main ground alleged was insufficiency of the evidence.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were in an apartment when police found three others dividing heroin for sale in plain view in the kitchen. One defendant lived in the apartment with his family and the other defendant, a minor, had been staying there as a guest. Under the statutory presumption contained in § 220.25(2), both were convicted because they were in close proximity to the heroin operation. The court held that the law was constitutional but found that the evidence was to be judged on a case-by-case basis. The evidence raised a reasonable doubt concerning the minor defendant's guilt. The male defendant was the only family member at home during the time of the raid, and he was presumed to know what was occurring. The minor defendant, however, was a guest and presumably had little say in what went on at the apartment when the male defendant was present.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion of the defendant minor and denied the motion of the other defendant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- controlled substances -- statutory presumption of possession.

1. Subdivision 2 of section 220.25 of the Penal Law, providing that the "presence of a narcotic drug, narcotic preparation or marihuana in open view in a room, other than a public room, under circumstances evincing an intent to unlawfully mix, compound, package or otherwise prepare for sale such controlled substance is presumptive evidence of knowing possession thereof by each and every person in close proximity to such controlled substance at the time such controlled substance was found", is constitutional.

2. To be "in close proximity" to a controlled substance so as to be within the ambit of the statutory presumption, one need not be in the same room or in an alcove off the same room.

3. Two defendants, convicted by a jury of criminal possession of heroin, had been found in an apartment, approximately 12 feet from a kitchen where others were conspicuously engaged in preparing the heroin for sale. One of them, then 21 years of age, was the only member of the family who regularly occupied [***2] the apartment on the premises at the time, and it is unlikely that the activity in the kitchen was without his knowledge, approval and participation. A motion by him to set aside the jury verdict is denied. However, the other defendant had recently taken up residence in the apartment, was only 16 years of age, was not a member of the family, and would presumedly have little to say about what went on there while the 21-year-old codefendant was present. These circumstances, coupled with her distance from the contraband, strongly tend to rebut the statutory presumption, and compel the conclusion that a reasonable doubt has been raised as a matter of law. A motion by her to set aside the jury verdict is granted.

 

2321 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Capelle v. Makowski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


93 Misc. 2d 436; 402 N.Y.S.2d 904; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2657



April 4, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant mayor filed a motion for dismissal of plaintiff citizens' action that sought a declaration that an excise tax on occupancy imposed by a city ordinance was unconstitutional and an injunction to prevent the city from collecting the tax or imposing penalties for nonpayment thereof.


OVERVIEW: The city adopted an ordinance, Buffalo, N.Y., Local Laws 5 (1976), which imposed an excise tax on occupancy. The citizens filed an action against the mayor of the city that sought a declaration that the tax was unconstitutional and sought an injunction against the collection of the tax or imposition of penalties for nonpayment of the tax. The mayor filed a motion for dismissal of the citizens' action, which the court treated as a motion for summary judgment and directed judgment for the mayor. The occupancy tax was not unconstitutionally vague. The ordinance set forth with clarity the obligations and liabilities of persons defined therein. The tax did not violate the citizens' due process rights. Public interest required the legislation. The means to collect the tax were reasonable and there was no interference with property rights. The tax required the application of fundamental due process in the use of the courts prior to the imposition of a lien. The ordinance was for the sole purpose the raising of revenue; therefore the citizens could not avail themselves of the due process clause to condemn it. Neither were equal protection guarantees violated by the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court held that the challenged ordinance was constitutional and directed judgment for the mayor.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Power of City to Enact

1. Section 110 of the Public Housing Law, which provides that a city may levy an excise tax on occupancy has not been superseded by article 29 of the Tax Law ( §§ 1201, 1203) permitting cities to impose certain taxes according to size, since such interpretation would be contrary to the intent expressed in section 1222 of the Tax Law and section 220 of the Public Housing Law.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Constitutionality of Local Law Imposing Occupancy Tax

2. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy is not unconstitutionally vague, since it sets forth with clarity the obligations and liabilities of persons defined therein.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on  [***2] Occupancy -- Constitutionality of Local Law Imposing Occupancy Tax

3. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy insofar as it provides for liability for failure to pay the tax does not constitute a taking of property without just compensation or due process, since it requires application of fundamental due process in the use of the courts prior to imposition of a lien and the tax is upon the occupant, not the property itself.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Constitutionality of Local Law Imposing Occupancy Tax

4. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy does not, by reason of the fact it requires the landlord of property to collect the tax from the tenant and pay it to the city, violate section 10 of article I of the United States Constitution which provides that no State shall pass any law impairing the obligations of contracts; since the obligations imposed are outside the landlord-tenant contract it does not add additional obligations to the lease.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Constitutionality of Local Law Imposing Occupancy Tax

5. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 [***3] of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy is not violative of the equal protection clauses of the New York and United States Constitutions because it exempts certain properties from the tax imposed and discriminates on the basis of family membership, since there is a rational basis for the classifications made in this regard.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Constitutionality of Local Law Imposing Occupancy Tax

6. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy does not violate the equal protection and due process provisions of the State and Federal Constitutions, since the ordinance has as its sole purpose the raising of revenue and the State Legislature has authorized imposition of the tax.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Constitutionality of Local Law Imposing Occupancy Tax

7. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy does not violate section 10 of article VIII of the New York State Constitution which limits the amount a city may raise by taxation of real estate, since a tax of this nature is not one on real estate and does not come under this prohibition.

 [***4] Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Constitutionality of Local Law Imposing Occupancy Tax

8. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy does not violate the Bill of Rights of the United States Constitution, since the ordinance as constituted requires an owner of real property with rental units to do no more than collect the tax and the tax is applied on the basis of the value of the real property and does not differentiate between types of occupants.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy as Violation of United States Housing Act

9. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy does not violate the United States Housing Act (US Code, tit 42, § 1437 et seq.), which limits the cost of shelter in low income housing, since there is nothing in the act which exempts occupants of public housing from taxation by local governments and in any event the tax does not affect the rental agreement.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Improper Delegation of Legislative Powers

10. Local Law No. 5 of 1976 of the City of Buffalo imposing an excise tax on occupancy does not improperly delegate [***5] authority to treasurer of the city without specific standards, since it describes the job to be done, who is to do it and that person's authority.

Taxation -- Excise Tax on Occupancy -- Scope of Court's Inquiry as to Validity

11. A court's inquiry is limited to whether a tax enactment is in compliance with the requirements of the State and Federal Constitutions. Whether an occupancy tax is the best means of raising needed revenue or whether a Legislature should have enacted a different taxing method are without the scope of the court's inquiry. Personal feelings as to the nature of the tax questioned and sympathy for those whose means make it difficult to comply with a particular law are irrelevant and cannot be considered.

Constitutional Law -- Presumption of Constitutionality of Ordinances -- Burden of Proof

12. Ordinances, as well as statutes, are presumed to be constitutional and those who seek to hold them otherwise must sustain a great burden of proof and this burden goes beyond a reasonable doubt. This is especially true when the law questioned involves the taxing power since the Legislatures possess their greatest freedom in this area.

 

2322 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lemp v. Town Bd. of Islip


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


90 Misc. 2d 360; 394 N.Y.S.2d 517; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2065; 7 ELR 20613



April 1, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner homeowner filed an action against respondent town seeking permission to construct a one-family dwelling on her oceanfront property.


OVERVIEW: After the homeowner's building permit was revoked on the ground that it had been issued without the town board approval, the homeowner filed an action against the town under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 directing that her application be granted, or, in the alternative, a declaratory judgment declaring the ordinance involved to be unconstitutional or unconstitutional as it affects the homeowner's property and directing the issuance of a building permit, or a judgment declaring that the board and the building department be estopped from canceling the building permit previously issued to her. The court held that the homeowner was entitled to a declaration that the ordinance as applied to her property was an invalid exercise of the police power under the due process clauses of the state and federal constitutions. However, the court noted that under the terms of the ordinance, a declaration of invalidity, even though cast in terms of a "taking" in the legislation, allowed the town board to either institute condemnation proceedings or approve the application.


OUTCOME: The court held that the homeowner was entitled to a declaration that the ordinance as applied to her property was an invalid exercise of police power under the due process clauses of the state and federal constitutions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- zoning -- construction of dwelling in oceanfront dune district on Fire Island.

Section 68-59.1 of the Islip Town Code which prohibits any structure from being erected or occupied in the oceanfront dune district on Fire Island except a "stair, lookout platform or fence" in order to "preserve the ecology of the dunes and grasses and to safeguard life and property on * * * Fire Island", is invalid as applied to petitioner's property which was purchased for the purpose of constructing a dwelling. Petitioner closed title on the premises within the dune district only after obtaining a building permit from the town building department. The building department revoked the building permit after petitioner commenced construction of the dwelling on the ground that the permit had been issued without the town board approval required for such construction in the oceanfront dune district under the town code. Once it is demonstrated that a zoning ordinance serves some legitimate public purpose, the property owner, in order to sustain an attack on constitutional grounds, must establish that the resulting hardship is such as to deprive him of any use of the property [***2] to which it is reasonably adapted or destroy the greater part of its value. A police power restriction is invalid if it frustrates the owner in the use of his property or deprives him of any reasonable use to which any owner would be entitled to put his property. The legislative restriction limiting construction on petitioner's property to a "stair, lookout platform or fence" deprives petitioner of any reasonable use of the property to which it is reasonably adapted and must be deemed unreasonable and a violation of due process. Under the terms of the ordinance, a declaration of invalidity requires the town board to either institute condemnation proceedings or approve petitioner's application for a building permit.

 

2323 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Calhoun


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


90 Misc. 2d 88; 393 N.Y.S.2d 529; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1996



March 31, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendant's motion to suppress is accordingly denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to suppress evidence in regard to an indictment that charged him with arson in the second degree, reckless endangerment in the first degree, and assault in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant sought to suppress testimonial evidence of observations that were made by a fire marshal and the photographs that were taken in regard to the condition of defendant's apartment following a fire. The fire marshal arrived at the scene in the afternoon to investigate a suspicious fire that had had occurred the previous morning. The court denied defendant's motion to suppress. New York City, N.Y., Admin Code § 488(2-1.0) commanded fire marshals to investigate, examine, and inquire into the origins of suspicious fires. Defendant did not have a sufficient objectively reasonable expectation of privacy in the burned premises when the building was no longer habitable and all of the windows on the second and third floors and the door to defendant's apartment was destroyed. Therefore, the entry of the fire marshal was reasonable under the circumstances and his observations and the photographs that were taken of the scene were admissible as evidence.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to suppress.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- search by fire marshals -- reasonable expectation of privacy in burned premises.

Testimonial evidence of observations made by two fire marshals and photographs taken of defendant's apartment within four hours after the fire in defendant's building was brought under control should not be suppressed as the products of an unconstitutional search since defendant no longer had a "sufficient objectively reasonable expectation of privacy in the burned premises". Defendant's apartment was destroyed by the fire. All the windows and the door to defendant's apartment were destroyed. The unhabitability of the apartment became tantamount to actual abandonment. The search of the burned-out apartment by the fire marshals, who have the statutory duty to investigate, examine and inquire into the origin, detail and management of fires in the city, particularly of supposed cases of arson, incendiarism, or fires due to criminal recklessness (Administrative Code of City of New York, § 488 [2]-1.0), was therefor not interdicted by the Fourth Amendment since a reasonable expectancy of privacy no longer existed. A prompt [***2] inspection by a fire marshal to ascertain the cause of a fire does not require a warrant. It is logical to presume that evidence of the cause of a serious fire might still be found on the premises or what was left of it after the fire was extinguished. The statutory mandate to investigate a fire and the continued fire scene investigation serve to lend authority to the fire marshal's presence at the scene.

 

2324 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Graser


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Town Court of New York, Town of Amherst, Erie County


90 Misc. 2d 219; 393 N.Y.S.2d 1009; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2023



March 30, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Therefore, the motion of the defendant to dismiss section 1193-a is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charges driving while intoxicated under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193-a and N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(3) on the grounds that the statutes defining the offenses were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested for the operation of an unregistered vehicle, refusal of a breath-screening test that tested for blood alcohol level, and for driving while intoxicated. He argued that it was violative of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution for him to have been statutorily required by N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193-a to submit to a breath test upon a routine traffic stop. The court held that the statute was not on its face unconstitutional. The breath test was not an illegal search if during the traffic stop the officer had reasonable belief that defendant was guilty of the crime of driving while intoxicated.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charge as unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- driving while intoxicated -- driving while impaired -- absence of chemical blood test.

1. Under section 1196 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which makes driving while impaired a lesser included offense of driving while intoxicated (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1192, subds 1, 3), a defendant charged with driving while intoxicated cannot be convicted of driving while his ability was impaired by alcohol in the absence of chemical alcohol blood tests. "Intoxication" is defined as such a condition as impairs to some extent the ability of a person to operate an automobile. Under such definition there is no distinction between intoxication and impairment. If the driver's ability to operate is impaired by alcohol, he is intoxicated. To determine whether there is an impairment, observational testimony is necessary at a trial. The Vehicle and Traffic Law no longer delineates a minimum blood alcohol level which would constitute prima facie or relevant evidence of intoxication. The statute does however provide that a blood alcohol level of .08% or .09% is prima facie evidence that the [***2] driver was operating the motor vehicle while his ability was impaired by alcohol (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1195). Section 1196 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law would be unconstitutionally vague if it were interpreted to mean that a defendant charged with driving while intoxicated could be convicted of the lesser included offense of driving while impaired in the absence of chemical blood test results.

2. Section 1193-a of the Vehicle and Traffic Law which requires a motorist to submit to a breath screening test if the vehicle he operated was involved in an accident, under penalty of a traffic infraction for refusal, is not unconstitutional on its face. The mere happening of an accident does not of itself give rise to "probable cause", or even suspicion of commission of the crime of driving while intoxicated. However, while investigating an accident, the police officer may obtain "probable cause" or "necessary suspicion" sufficient to justify a demand for a breath screening test. Under such circumstances, the compulsory submitting to the breath test would not constitute a violation of the motorist's constitutional rights.

 

2325 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wein v. Comptroller of New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


93 Misc. 2d 652; 405 N.Y.S.2d 915; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2665



March 29, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' motion to dismiss is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a state comptroller and others, filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff taxpayer's complaint, which alleged that bond anticipation notes were unconstitutionally issued to fund a state budget deficit. The comptroller also sought a change in venue.


OVERVIEW: A dispute arose between the taxpayer and the comptroller as to whether certain bond anticipation notes were issued in accordance with law. The taxpayer sought a declaration that the notes were unconstitutionally issued, and he sought to enjoin the further issuance of the notes to reimburse the state's general fund for capital expenditures incurred in prior years instead of for a specified work or purpose. The comptroller filed motions to dismiss, and for a change in venue. The court granted the comptroller's motion to dismiss, concluding that the taxpayer lacked standing to bring the action pursuant to N.Y. State Fin. Law § 123-b (1). That statute granted standing to taxpayers to maintain equitable or declaratory relief actions against state officers for misappropriation of funds, except in cases of the authorization, sale, execution, or delivery of a bond issue, or notes issued in anticipation of a bond. Thus, the taxpayer lacked standing to maintain his action against the comptroller, and standing was not expanded under decisional law. Nor did decisional law procedurally bar the comptroller from raising the defense of standing.


OUTCOME: The court granted the comptroller's motion to dismiss. That decision rendered the motion for a change in venue moot.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing to Challenge Validity of Bond Anticipation Notes

Plaintiff lacks standing to challenge the legality of bond anticipation notes issued by the State since the statute which authorizes the maintenance of taxpayers' suits against State officials to enjoin the wrongful expenditure, misappropriation or any other illegal or unconstitutional disbursement of State funds or property, does "not apply to the authorization, sale, execution or delivery of a bond issue or notes issued in anticipation thereof by the state or any agency" (State Finance Law, § 123-b, subd 1). The statute establishes an orderly procedure defining and delineating taxpayers' rights with regard to maintaining suits relating to State fiscal matters and is clearly intended to restrict the grant of standing so that it shall not apply to bond anticipation notes.

 

2326 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Roy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


90 Misc. 2d 35; 393 N.Y.S.2d 515; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1982



March 24, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court considered the request of petitioner, a social service agency, that the court authorize the adoption of a boy by his foster parents over the objection of respondent biological mother. The social service agency argued that under the permanent neglect statute, N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 6, the possessory claim of the mother should be terminated because of a failure to maintain substantial and continuous contact with the boy.


OVERVIEW: The 16-year-old boy had been placed in his foster home when he was less than a year old. With the help of his foster family, he developed into a well-educated, well-motivated, well-balanced youth who completely identified with his foster parents and his siblings as his family. The boy was strongly opposed to any contact or connection with his biological family and desired adoption by the foster parents. The social service agency brought an action under the Act for the purpose of enabling the boy's foster parents to adopt him. The biological mother claimed that she could prevent the adoption and the termination of her right to call herself the boy's parent. The court entered an order authorizing the boy's adoption by his foster parents, holding that the mother's claim could not lawfully or constitutionally frustrate the boy's best interests. The boy's compelling and overwhelming constitutional right to freedom from the mother's possessory claim overcame her claim. The court had ancillary inherent jurisdiction under the Act to afford the boy an appropriate remedy that promoted the general purpose of the Act in this extraordinary circumstance.


OUTCOME: The court granted the social service agency's petition that the boy be permitted to be adopted by his foster family over the possessory claims of the mother, and it entered an order authorizing the adoption.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Adoption -- termination of natural parent's possessory claim -- best interests of child.

1. The 16-year-old son of respondent natural mother has the right to the termination of respondent's possessory claim to him for the purpose of his adoption by his foster parents since such adoption is unequivocally in his best interest. Respondent's son has a constitutional right to freedom from respondent's parental possessory claim. Respondent's possessory claim cannot lawfully or constitutionally frustrate her son's best interests. He has been living with his foster parents for 15 years. He has developed with his foster family into a well-educated, well-motivated, well-balanced youth. He regards his foster parents as his permanent parents and their biological children as his older siblings. He is strongly opposed to any contact or connection with his biological family and fervently desires adoption by his foster parents. The child's best interests are not served by respondent's continued title to him. To refuse to consider the child's best interest because of a biological parent's title to him would be unconstitutional. Before a court can consider whether a child's best interests [***2] will be served by a nonparent's custody, a specified misfeasance or nonfeasance by the biological parent or "like extraordinary circumstances" must be shown. The child's compelling and overwhelming interest in the termination of respondent's title to him is an "extraordinary circumstance" permitting the court-authorized adoption by the foster parents.

2. The Family Court has the ancillary and inherent power to enforce the child's constitutional rights by authorizing the child's adoption by his foster parents.

 

2327 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Calderon v. Buffalo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Erie County


90 Misc. 2d 1033; 397 N.Y.S.2d 655; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2215



March 22, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff store owner brought an action for declaratory and injunctive relief, challenging the constitutionality of Buffalo, N.Y., Anti-Obscenity and Display to Minors Ordinance ch. 9, § 35(J)(1) and (2) (ordinance).


OVERVIEW: The shop owner was the sole proprietor of a shop that displayed sexually explicit materials and was visited by adults as well as youth. The shop owner was arrested and charged with violating the ordinance for displaying materials to youth that were deemed devoted to or principally made up of descriptions or depictions of illicit sex or sexual immorality or that consisted of pictures of nude or partially denuded figures. The charge was later dismissed but the shop owner sought declaratory and injunctive relief to test the validity of the ordinance based on its chilling effect and the threat of future prosecution. The court enjoined the enforcement of the ordinance because its ban on the display of sexually oriented material that might not be obscene was both overbroad and unconstitutional. Further, the ordinance was held unconstitutionally vague in that citizens could not know what exactly what it proscribed, which could lead to the discriminatory enforcement of the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court permanently enjoined the city from enforcing any part of the relevant subdivisions of the ordinance.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- display of sexually oriented materials to minors -- constitutionality of city ordinance.

1. Provisions of a city ordinance which, inter alia, prohibit the display of sexually oriented materials at newsstands or other business establishments frequented by minors, or where minors are or may be invited as a part of the general public, are unconstitutional for overbreadth, because they ban the display of materials which may not be obscene, and are also unconstitutional for vagueness, because they fail to define what is proscribed with sufficient specificity.

2. The provisions cannot be construed, without a wholesale rewriting, so as to proscribe the display only of materials which could be found obscene as to minors, or so as to cure the vagueness which permeates them.

 

2328 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Carneglia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


89 Misc. 2d 927; 393 N.Y.S.2d 154; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2715



March 22, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to reargue is granted. Upon reargument, the defendant's motion to declare the Grand Jury which returned the indictment to be illegally constituted is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State filed a motion to reargue defendant's motion for dismissal of his criminal indictment. Defendant argued that the grand jury which returned his indictment was illegally constituted when the grand jury was chosen from a panel that exempted women from service and thus violated his right to be indicted by an impartial grand jury that was drawn from a fair cross section of the community.


OVERVIEW: The court granted the State's motion to reargue. Defendant asserted that the United States Supreme Court held that a Louisiana conviction could not stand when the jury panels were established under a statutory scheme that required a woman to volunteer for jury service before she was eligible to be summoned. He asserted that he stood in the same position as defendants charged and tried under the unconstitutional Louisiana law. The court reasoned that the former New York law, N.Y. Jud. Law § 599(7), which granted women an automatic right to an exemption once summoned, differed from the Louisiana law. The standard for measuring the claim of an illegally constituted panel was whether defendant submitted sufficient proof to establish the intentional and systematic discrimination in the jury selection process. Defendant did not present proof of any intentional exclusion of a group. Women were allowed to volunteer and the fact that one group predominated or was lacking in the grand jury did not justify a declaration that the grand jury was illegally constituted. The court denied defendant's motion.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to reargue. On reargument, the court denied defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- Grand Jury selection process -- automatic exemption from jury service granted to women.

The fact that the 1975 Queens County Grand Jury which indicted defendant was chosen at a time when women were granted an automatic exemption from jury service (Judiciary Law, former § 599, subd 7) does not mandate dismissal of the indictment under the holding of Taylor v Louisiana (419 U.S. 522) which condemns the deliberate exclusion of a particular community group or class of persons from jury service. Defendant has failed to submit proof sufficient to establish intentional and systematic discrimination in the jury selection process. Everyone, including women, may volunteer for jury service and the fact that certain groups may predominate or be lacking in Grand Juries does not justify a declaration that such a Grand Jury is illegally constituted. The list of grand jurors which made up the 1975 pool was selected from a constitutionally acceptable pool of petit jurors and [***2] from outside volunteers who were qualified to serve upon a petit jury. Since the statutes for the selection of grand jurors were applied equally to all persons who were qualified to serve regardless of group or class, they are constitutional.

 

2329 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Waterloo Stock Car Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK


89 Misc. 2d 922; 392 N.Y.S.2d 839; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2754



March 21, 1977, Decided

 

2330 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Flushing Nat'l Bank v. Municipal Assistance Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


89 Misc. 2d 342; 393 N.Y.S.2d 873; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1845



March 17, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion in all respects denied, without prejudice to a motion, upon appropriate papers, to intervene for the sole purpose of appealing the determination of interest rate.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff noteholder filed a motion for class action status in its action against defendant city pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 904, and it also sought an order consolidating that claim with another proceeding brought by another noteholder against defendant, a municipal assistance corporation.


OVERVIEW: When a dispute arose between the noteholders, the city, the municipal assistance corporation regarding the applicable interest rate, the noteholder filed one action against the municipal assistance corporation and the other noteholder filed an action against the city. After the noteholder acquired a judgment against the municipal assistance corporation, the other noteholder sought to consolidate that action with the claim against the city and also to be awarded class status. The court denied the motions, but the denial was without prejudice to intervene in order to challenge the determination of the interest rate. Class action status was not appropriate because there was no demonstration of a representative party that would fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class or that a class action was superior to other available methods to adjudicate the controversy as required by N.Y. C.P.L.R. 901(a). Further, because the noteholder sought a declaration of unconstitutionality, there was no need for class status because any relief would inure to the benefit of all. Consolidation was not appropriate because one case had barely begun and the other had proceeded to judgment.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motions without prejudice to a motion to intervene for the sole purpose of appealing the determination of interest rate.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- New York State Emergency Moratorium Act for City of New York -- consolidation of actions.

1. Movant, the holder of certain matured and unpaid short-term obligations issued by the City of New York, may not maintain as a class action its action to have the New York State Emergency Moratorium Act for the City of New York (L 1975, ch 874, as amd by ch 875) declared unconstitutional as denying "just compensation" under the Federal and State Constitutions since there is no showing that the proposed "class action is superior" to other available methods of procedure ( CPLR 901, subd a, par 5). There is no need for class action status since the prior decision of the Court of Appeals declaring the Moratorium Act unconstitutional as violative of the faith and credit provisions of the State Constitution (see 40 NY2d 731) will inure to the benefit of all noteholders. The Court of Appeals by its remittitur (40 NY2d 1093) fashioned a remedy benefiting all noteholders. In compliance with the [***2] remittitur simple and expeditious procedures were established whereby noteholders who have not consented to an extension could recover judgments for the amounts of their notes with interest after maturity at 6% (see 88 Misc 2d 1047). Such procedures are far simpler and more expeditious than any relief obtainable by movant in an independent class action.

2. Movant's action may not be consolidated with the action which has proceeded to judgment in the Court of Appeals. The Court of Appeals remittitur affords movant, and all the other members of the proposed class, a swift, inexpensive and efficacious remedy. No proceeding pursuant to consolidation could obtain so desirable a result so promptly. The only issue left open between the noteholders and the city was that of the interest rate which has been fixed at 6% by Special Term. All of movant's rights can be protected and advanced by permitting it to move to intervene for the sole purpose of taking an appeal from the determination of the interest rate.

 

2331 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lerner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Bronx County


90 Misc. 2d 513; 394 N.Y.S.2d 514; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2097



March 15, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for an order finding unconstitutional the regulations under which he was indicted, namely N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, §§ 414.16 (c)(3), 730.3(c)(3). Defendant also sought dismissal of some counts because some of the regulations were not properly published.


OVERVIEW: After defendant accepted a one-third kickback on orders for nursing home supplies, he was indicted with violations of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, §§ 414.16 (c)(3), 730.3(c)(3). Defendant filed a motion that asserted the regulations were unconstitutionally vague and he also sought dismissal of some of the counts on the grounds that the regulations were not properly published. The court denied the motions, holding that defendant's constitutional rights were not violated because the First Amendment did not apply. Further, vagueness challenges to statutes that did not invoke the First Amendment had to be examined in the light of the facts of the individual case. The court reasoned that a man of ordinary intelligence would realize that accepting kickbacks was not conduct within normal business practices. Accordingly, defendant could not avail himself of a claim of vagueness because his own conduct struck at the heart of the prohibition in the regulations. Further, the failure to publish the regulations did not violate N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 8 because that constitutional provision did not mandate immediate publication.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Health -- management of nursing home industry -- receipt of illegal kickbacks from vendors -- "normal business practices".

1. The regulations under which defendant is indicted which prohibit any "operator or agent, consultant or representative" of a nursing home from accepting "any remuneration, rebate, gift benefit or advantage of any form from any vendor or other supplier because of the purchase, rental or loan of equipment, supplies or services for the nursing home or patient excluding normal business practices" (10 NYCRR 730.3 [c] [3], 414.16 [c] [3]) is not unconstitutionally vague as applied to defendant's conduct of allegedly accepting a one-third kickback on orders. Defendant and a coconspirator allegedly caused a vendor to submit bills for goods never delivered to the nursing home and then allegedly caused the vendor to return to them in cash the amount of the undelivered supplies which amounted to one third of the total order. The coconspirators allegedly changed and falsified their own records by listing nondelivered goods as if they were delivered. A law which does not proscribe First Amendment rights may only be void for vagueness if it is vague as [***2] applied to precise circumstances of the individual case. While marginal cases may exist where doubt about the meaning of the phrase "except normal business practices" would make application of the statute unconstitutional for vagueness, defendant may not avail himself of such instance where his own conduct strikes at the heart of the statute's prohibition. A man of ordinary intelligence would realize that such conduct is not within normal business practices.

2. The fact the properly filed regulation under which defendant was indicted was unpublished does not invalidate the indictment since a regulation becomes effective when filed with the Secretary of State and not when it is published (NY Const, art IV, § 8). The purpose of the filing requirement is to provide a central location where all rules and regulations may be examined by those who may be affected by them. The Constitution does not mandate immediate publication. In any event, defendant had actual notice of the regulation since a copy was mailed to his place of business.

 

2332 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sonmax, Inc. v. City of New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SPECIAL TERM, NEW YORK COUNTY


89 Misc. 2d 945; 392 N.Y.S.2d 810; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2727



March 10, 1977, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [**1] Local Laws Nos. 45, 46 and 47 of 1976 are declared constitutional and valid and the preliminary injunction is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners brought a declaratory judgment seeking to have New York City, N.Y., Local Laws Nos. 45-47, codified at New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ D17-4.0, E17-24.0, 415(1)-17.0, 415(1)-17.1, declared null and void, and sought a preliminary injunction enjoining defendant city from implementing the laws pending trial. The city sought dismissal of the property owners' complaint.


OVERVIEW: The property owners claimed that the city council exceeded its power in enacting New York City, N.Y., Local Law No. 45 and that it was unconstitutional because it did not apply to all defaulting owners equally; and that New York City, N.Y., Local Laws Nos. 46-47 were punitive, confiscatory, and in effect constituted an additional tax, and thus were beyond the power of the city to enact. The court declared New York City, N.Y., Local Law Nos. 45-47 constitutional and denied the preliminary injunction against the city that was requested by the property owners, holding that the legislature had authorized the city to pass such laws regarding taxation and that the city under Nos. 45-47 had the authority to foreclose a tax lien and to increase the interest rate for unpaid real estate taxes and unpaid water and sewer rents. The court further held that there was nothing in the New York Municipal Home Rule Law that prohibited the city from enacting a local law related to the collection of local taxes.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the city had the authority to pass laws regarding taxation, which were constitutional, and denied the preliminary injunction requested by the property owners against the city.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - in rem foreclosure action - adoption of local laws relating to collection of local taxes.

1. The City Council of the City of New York had the power to enact Local Law No. 45 of the Local Laws of the City of New York of 1976 (amdg Administrative Code of City of New York, ch 17, tit D, § D17-4.0) which reduced from three years to one year the period after which an in rem action for foreclosure of a tax lien could be commenced. Section 10 of the Municipal Home Rule Law expressly gives cities the authority to adopt local laws relating to the collection and administration of taxes not inconsistent with any general State law. Previously, in rem foreclosure provisions had been added to the Administrative Code by special laws enacted by the Legislature. There is nothing in the Municipal Home Rule Law prohibiting the city from enacting a local law relating to the collection of local taxes which is inconsistent with a special law. Plaintiffs have not shown that Local Law No. 45 is inconsistent with any general law.

2. Local Law No. 45 does not violate the equal protection clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions because owner-occupied one- and two-family homes with real estate taxes of not more than $ 2,000 per year are exempted from its provisions. The shorter one-year period was motivated in part to discourage owners from "milking" their property. Such problem is not presented with owner-occupied one- and two-family buildings.

3. Local Laws Nos. 46 and 47 of 1976 which increased the interest on unpaid real estate taxes and unpaid water and sewer rents to 15%, are not arbitrary, confiscatory illegal additional taxes. The City Council felt that many landlords were financing themselves on the city's back by a rate which was less than the prevailing second mortgage rate.

 

2333 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rosenthal v. New York State Employees' Retirement System


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


89 Misc. 2d 616; 392 N.Y.S.2d 354; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1904



March 2, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petition is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorney sought review of the determination by made by respondent, the New York State Comptroller, which suspended his retirement allowance and reduced his pension reserves in his action against the Comptroller and respondent, the New York State Employees' Retirement System.


OVERVIEW: The attorney was employed as a school district's attorney. The position was part-time and excluded litigation and other matters. Legal services for excluded matters were arranged for a retainer, and compensation was not a salary but a legal fee. The school district was a participating employer in the Retirement System, but the attorney's retirement allowance was based solely on his annual salary and did not include his fees for the excluded matters. The attorney retired and began receiving a retirement allowance. Later, the district had a vacancy for a school district attorney. The attorney was hired and worked for one year. During his tenure, he also rendered legal services on a fee basis. The Comptroller suspended the attorney's retirement allowance and reduced his pension reserves, finding that the attorney had rendered consulting services subject to the limitation of N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 211(4). The court reversed, holding that the limitation in § 211 was created by an amendment made after the attorney retired. Thus, it did not apply to him. The attorney's rights were fixed at his retirement and no legislative amendment could impair his retirement benefits.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the suspension of the attorney's retirement allowance and ordered that the allowance and pension reserves be returned to the attorney.


HEADNOTES

Retirement and pension benefits -- limitation on earnings for re-employed retiree -- consultant fees.

Subdivision 4 of section 211 of the Retirement and Social Security Law which provides that a retired person who returns to public service after January 1, 1974 as a consultant shall be subject to the $ 10,550 limitation on earnings applicable to a re-employed retiree, may not be retroactively applied to petitioner who retired from his position as a school district attorney in 1970, having become a member of the State Employees' Retirement System in 1956. Respondent State Comptroller improperly suspended petitioner's retirement allowance and reduced his pension reserves on the ground that the $ 18,550 in earnings received by petitioner in public service during 1975 consisting of $ 5,076 in salary as school district attorney, $ 11,474 as fees for legal services rendered to the school district as an independent contractor, and $ 2,000 as a retainer, exceeded his allowable earnings for 1975. The "consultant" services rendered by petitioner are not subject to the limitations of section 211 of the Retirement and Social Security Law. The right to accept [***2] retainers for legal services as an independent contractor without limitation after retirement was a benefit which became vested when petitioner became a member of the retirement system and could not thereafter be diminished or impaired (NY Const, art V, § 7). When petitioner retired, his rights were fixed and no official action can diminish or impair the retirement benefits to which petitioner is entitled, including the unlimited right to practice law as an independent contractor on a fee basis.

 

2334 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Brody v. Leamy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Dutchess County


90 Misc. 2d 1; 393 N.Y.S.2d 243; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1979



February 28, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant officer moved pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211 to dismiss plaintiff injured person's complaint under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, because there was another action pending between the same parties for the same relief, and for failure to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff injured person alleged that while he was stopped by defendant officer, the officer pushed him into a patrol car that was driven at a high rate of speed and then manhandled plaintiff prior to a court appearance. Plaintiff commenced suit against defendant under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983. The state attorney general assumed defendant's defense under N.Y. Pub. Off Law § 17(2) and moved to dismiss the complaint pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211. Defendant claimed that the court did not have subject matter jurisdiction over the claim, that another action was pending for the same relief, and that the complaint failed to state a cause of action. The court agreed to dismiss. The court held that while New York courts had concurrent jurisdiction with federal courts over 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 claims, the injuries sustained by plaintiff -- those from a mere assault -- were not sufficient to establish a 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 claim. The court held that defendant could simultaneously pursue a federal and state civil rights claim. Finally, the court held that U.S. Const. amend. XI did not bar a suit against defendant, even though the state was required to defend and indemnify defendant.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed plaintiff injured person's federal civil rights complaint against defendant officer. The court held that while the state court had subject matter jurisdiction over a federal civil rights claim and plaintiff could simultaneously maintain a federal and state cause of action, plaintiff's injuries from a mere assault were not sufficient to state a cause of action.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Civil rights -- Federal civil rights claim -- concurrent jurisdiction of State Supreme Court.

1. The State Supreme Court has concurrent jurisdiction with Federal courts over civil actions alleging a deprivation of civil rights under color of State law under section 1983 of title 42 of the United States Code. Section 1983 was intended to afford aggrieved persons access to Federal tribunals. The statute was designed to provide a remedy where State law was inadequate, or adequate in theory but not in practice, and constitutes a Federal remedy supplementary to State remedies. Although section 1983 is Federal in origin, grants a remedy unknown at common law and is governed by Federal substantive principles, unless and until the United States Supreme Court determines otherwise, there is no legal barrier to presentation of section 1983 claims in State Supreme Court (see Aldinger v Howard, US, 96 S Ct 2413). Federal District Courts are only granted "original" and not "exclusive" jurisdiction over civil actions arising under section 1983 (US Code, tit 28, § 1343, subd [3]).

2. Plaintiff, who was allegedly "assaulted, physically affronted, searched and maniculed" but not physically [***2] injured, while being arrested for traffic violations by defendant, a State trooper, does not have a Federal civil rights cause of action since only the use of excessive and unnecessary force during the course of an arrest leading to severe personal injury or death are within the ambit of section 1983 civil rights claims. While police officers may be civilly liable for unconstitutional acts, not every tort committed against a private person by an official under State law rises to the deprivation of a constitutional right. Grievances easily remedied under traditional State law concepts should not be the subject of national concern. Absent severe personal injury, simple assaults are not within the ambit of section 1983, and the insertion of language in the complaint to give the "appearance of a suit under the civil rights acts" will not defeat a motion to dismiss.

3. Plaintiff's claim would be barred if the State would ultimately be required to pay the judgment against defendant under subdivision 1 of section 17 of the Public Officers Law which requires the State to indemnify State employees from financial loss for alleged negligent acts taken in the ordinary course of employment,  [***3] since, under the Eleventh Amendment to the Federal Constitution, section 1983 monetary claims are not sustainable against State public officials where the award will be paid out of the State treasury.

 

2335 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Flushing Nat'l Bank v. Municipal Assistance Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 1047; 391 N.Y.S.2d 969; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1821



February 23, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff noteholder challenged the validity of § 5(B) of the New York State Emergency Moratorium Act, which limited the interest it received on a note issued by defendant city. Defendants, an emergency financial control board and a municipal assistance corporation, also appeared. Previously, the case was heard by an appellate court, and it declared the Act unconstitutional and remitted the matter to the court to determine an interest rate issue.


OVERVIEW: During a fiscal crisis, the Act suspended interest payments on the city's short-term obligations for three years. Section 5(B) of the Act required that interest on the city's notes be paid at the face rate fixed in each obligation until maturity, and thereafter at not less than six percent until the principal was paid or otherwise discharged. The notes in question all provided for the payment of an interest rate substantially in excess of six percent. The court held that even though the Act was found to be unconstitutional, § 5(B) was to be enforced, and the noteholder was only entitled to six percent interest on payments made on the notes after they matured. The court ruled that the finding that an act was unconstitutional did not automatically require that such act be deemed to be void ab initio. The court decided that in justice, considering the effect of the actual existence of the Act for a period of time, it was appropriate to enforce § 5(B).


OUTCOME: The court held that the provision of the Act requiring that interest be paid at a six percent rate after the notes matured was enforceable.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- New York State Emergency Moratorium Act for City of New York -- payment of interest after maturity of municipal notes.

The determination of the Court of Appeals (40 NY2d 731) that the three-year moratorium on actions to enforce the short-term obligations of the City of New York imposed by the New York State Emergency Moratorium Act for the City of New York (L 1975, ch 874, as amd by ch 875) unconstitutionally denied "faith and credit" to the short-term anticipation notes of the city (NY Const, art VIII, § 2) cannot be applied retroactively to invalidate the provisions of the Emergency Moratorium Act (§ 5, subd [B]) requiring that interest be paid at the face rate fixed in each obligation until maturity and thereafter at a rate not less than 6% per annum until the principal is paid or otherwise discharged. The notes held by plaintiff all provided for payment of interest at rates substantially in excess of the 6% rate. The remittitur from the Court of Appeals (40 NY2d 1094) directing the Supreme Court to hear and determine whether the 6% rate shall be paid from the date of maturity to the date of payment "as provided" in the act cannot be read [***2] as necessarily applying the declaration of unconstitutionality to the interest rate provision by implication. The "void ab initio doctrine" rendering wholly ineffective every part of a statute found unconstitutional is no longer rigidly applied. The Legislature was fully empowered to provide for payment after maturity at a rate lower than the face rate and higher than the 3% rate otherwise applicable to accrued claims against a municipality (General Municipal Law, § 3-a).

 

2336 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bartlett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Richmond County


89 Misc. 2d 874; 393 N.Y.S.2d 866; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1978



February 23, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the indictment is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted upon charges of conspiracy and bribery. He filed a motion to dismiss the indictment.


OVERVIEW: In his motion to dismiss the indictment, defendant claimed that he was denied his right to a speedy trial and he also challenged the array of prospective jurors, and the composition of the grand jury. The court held that defendant's challenge to the composition of the grand jury was untimely. However, the court granted the motion to dismiss the indictment, holding that defendant was entitled to the same relief that was granted to a defendant in a companion case. The court allowed defendant's challenge to the array of prospective jurors, finding that the underrepresentation of women in the venire and in the master pool was the result of systematic and purposeful discrimination against women. The court also sustained the challenge to the array upon the added ground that persons under the age of 30 had been improperly excluded from the pool and a venire representing a cross section of the community could not have been obtained by use of the existing pool of qualified jurors.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- challenge to array of prospective jurors -- purposeful underrepresentation of women in master pool.

1. Defendant's challenge to the array of prospective jurors summoned for jury service in Richmond County on February 7, 1977, the date fixed for the trial of the indictment, is allowed since the master pool and the venire, by reason of the continued purposeful underrepresentation of women, does not adequately reflect a cross section of the population suitable in character and intelligence for jury service. The underrepresentation of women in the venire and in the master pool is the result of systematic and purposeful discrimination against women rendering such jury selection system invalid (see Taylor v Louisiana, 419 U.S. 522). The nonrepresentative nature of the current pool and the February 7 venire is due to the continued reliance upon a qualified juror pool built up at a time when women were permitted to claim an automatic exemption from jury service. Richmond County, which has not fully reconstituted its jury pool since 1940, cannot freeze its present jury system into a mold created by a statute, which [***2] was repealed two years ago. Random drawings from the pool continue to improperly produce venires in which men are overrepresented by about five times their proportional strength in the community. Richmond County may not retain and maintain a dramatically unbalanced pool by doing nothing to correct the accumulated sexual disparity in the composition of the pool.

2. In addition, persons under 30 years of age have been improperly excluded from the master jury pool so that a venire representing a cross section of the community cannot be obtained by use of the existing pool of qualified jurors. The disparity between the number of jurors under 30 and their representation in the community is the direct result of the procedures used by the county to obtain its jury pool.

3. In view of the substantial economic loss sustained by defendant directly flowing from the indictment filed in April, 1974, and the delays encountered which were not of his making, the indictment is dismissed.

 

2337 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Buscemi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Suffolk County


89 Misc. 2d 174; 391 N.Y.S.2d 343; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1856



January 20, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all of the foregoing reasons, Count No. 1 of the information is dismissed, and the defendant is hereby found not guilty of the crime of unlawful imprisonment in the second degree.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss a count of an information that charged defendant with unlawful imprisonment in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged under a two count misdemeanor information with unlawful imprisonment in the second degree and endangering the welfare of a child, violations of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 135.05, 260.10. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the count of the information alleging unlawful imprisonment in the second degree. Defendant contended that N.Y. Penal Law § 135.05, when read in conjunction with N.Y. Penal Law § 135.00, should be declared unconstitutional because it was vague, ambiguous, indefinite, and failed to give clear warning of the rule to be obeyed. The court held that: (1) a criminal statute had to be sufficiently definite, clear, and positive to give unequivocal warning to citizens of the rule that was to be obeyed; (2) the legislature did not fairly warn citizens of that which was prohibited by the statute when it drafted N.Y. Penal Law § 135.00; and (3) as applied to the facts of the case, the statute was patently defective and the court could not find defendant guilty of any offense.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion and found defendant not guilty of the crime of unlawful imprisonment in the second degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- unlawful imprisonment -- invalidity of statute.

Defendant, a 16-year-old mandatory youthful offender who was charged with aiding and abetting a 14-year-old female runaway to remain away from her home for two nights, by suggesting a place for the "victim" to stay in her quest to run away, cannot be found guilty of the crime of unlawful imprisonment in the second degree in violation of section 135.05 of the Penal Law, which provides that "A person is guilty of unlawful imprisonment in the second degree when he restrains another person." It is uncertain whether the Legislature, in defining "restrain" in section 135.00 of the Penal Law, really intended the "acquiescence of the victim" to constitute a means of movement or confinement "without consent" so as to give the impression that no physical overt act is required for conviction under section 135.05 where a child under age 16 is concerned. Accordingly, the statute is not sufficiently definite, clear and positive to give unequivocal [***2] warning to citizens of the rule which is to be obeyed and, is, therefore, patently defective as applied to the facts of this case wherein the criminal conduct consisted of aiding a juvenile runaway.

 

2338 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bergman v. Whalen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


89 Misc. 2d 237; 391 N.Y.S.2d 341; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1823



January 19, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner nursing home operator brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 action to annul a determination by respondent Commissioner of the Department of Health of the State of New York that revoked the operator's license to operate a nursing home because of the operator's criminal convictions.


OVERVIEW: A nursing home operator brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 action to annul a determination by the Commissioner of the Department of Health of the State of New York to revoke the operator's license to operate a nursing home because of the operator's criminal convictions. The court held that there was no reason why a criminal act must be related to the operation of a nursing home in order to justify revocation. The court reasoned that conviction of a crime without doubt bore upon character, competence, and standing in the community. The public interest in the operation of nursing homes justified the adoption of a rule that nursing home operators be free from a criminal record. The operator had admitted unlawful conduct involving a member of the legislature in connection with the promotion of the application for establishment of the nursing home. The court concluded that neither N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2801-a(10)(a) nor the Commissioner's determination was arbitrary, capricious, or affected by error of law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commissioner's revocation of the operator's nursing home operator's license.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Hospitals and asylums -- nursing homes -- revocation of approval of establishment.

1. As a result of criminal violations to which petitioner pleaded guilty, including the crime of unlawful fees and payments and the crimes of conspiracy and filing of false statements on Federal income tax returns, petitioner's approval of establishment to operate a certain nursing home was revoked by respondent Public Health Council, acting pursuant to the general statutory authority of section 2801-a (subd 10, par [a]) of the Public Health Law, which directs the council to adopt rules and regulations to provide for the revocation, limitation or annulment of approvals of establishment. 10 NYCRR 600.5 (e), adopted pursuant thereto, allows revocation of approval upon a finding that the established operator has been convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of a crime. Section 2801-a (subd 10, par [a]) of the Public Health Law is not invalid as an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power. There is a clearly defined legislative policy that the character, competence and standing in the community of nursing home operators shall be subjects for consideration by the Public Health [***2] Council.

2. Nor is 19 NYCRR 600.5 (e) invalid in that it may proscribe conduct unrelated to the operation of a nursing home. There is no reason why a criminal act need be related to the operation of a nursing home in order to justify revocation, since conviction of a crime reflects upon fitness to operate a nursing home. Moreover, by petitioner's plea of guilty to the crime of unlawful fees and payments to a public officer, he has admitted unlawful conduct in connection with the promotion of the application for establishment of the very nursing home in question.

 

2339 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Thaler v. Thaler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


89 Misc. 2d 315; 391 N.Y.S.2d 331; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1843



January 19, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant ex-husband contested plaintiff ex-wife's annulment action and filed a motion for temporary alimony and a counsel fee while their action was pending.


OVERVIEW: Ex-husband, a citizen of Israel, could not contest ex-wife's annulment action effectively from outside the country and was required to remain in the United States without means of support. Ex-husband filed a motion for temporary alimony and counsel fees while the annulment action was pending. Ex-wife contested the motion because under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §§ 236, 237, alimony and counsel fees were not available to a husband, only to a wife. The court granted ex-husband's motion for temporary alimony and interim counsel fees. The court held that the New York alimony statute could not survive constitutional examination, and that in excluding women from ever paying alimony, it rested on a flat distinction between genders that had no rational basis and was a suspect differentiation that served no compelling state interest. The court held that alimony was always an individual affair; the particular facts and circumstances of relative need, standards, and resources were to always be weighed, and that so long as each case was examined individually, no reason existed to preclude husbands.


OUTCOME: The court found in favor of ex-husband, granted his motion for temporary alimony and counsel fees, and awarded him temporary alimony and a modest interim counsel fee in ex-wife's annulment action.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Husband and wife -- alimony and allowances -- counsel fees -- payments to husbands.

1. The New York alimony statute (Domestic Relations Law, § 236), in excluding women from ever paying alimony, discriminates unconstitutionally. The statute rests on the impermissible assumption that wives may depend on their husbands for suitable support, but husbands never so depend on their wives. This flat distinction between husband and wife has no rational basis and beyond that is a suspect differentiation which serves no compelling State interest. Individual need is a determinative factor in alimony, and, in fact, a self-supporting wife may be denied alimony altogether. So long as each case is to be examined individually, there is no reason to preclude husbands. Even if the preclusion of men were found to be rational, the sex distinction still fails because it is inherently suspect and the discrimination cannot be justified by a compelling State interest. New York legislative policy favors the elimination of gender distinctions in domestic relations and beyond, and, therefore, the sex distinctions of the alimony statute do not serve the State interest. Moreover, the rationale [***2] of equality of women excludes the denial of male alimony.

2. The court has the power to direct alimony to husbands. Even though section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law is rendered defective by virtue of gender discrimination, the court has the inherent power to remedy the discrimination of the statute without being required to strike the entire statute.

3. Under the temporary and permanent alimony provisions of section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law, which must also cover husbands, the court has discretion to award alimony as justice requires. A husband is entitled to suitable support and need not be reduced to a public charge. Accordingly, under the circumstances of this case, where the wife has significant savings and an apparent income and brought her nonimmigrant alien husband to this country, where he cannot legally work but where he must remain to effectively contest the annulment action, the husband is awarded temporary alimony of $ 60 per week pending the actual trial of the annulment action.

4. Section 237 of the Domestic Relations Law, pertaining to counsel fees, suffers the same infirmity as the alimony statute (Domestic Relations Law, § 236), by providing [***3] in part that in any action brought to annul a marriage "the court may direct the husband * * * to pay such sum or sums of money to enable the wife to carry on or defend the action". These sex distinctions are as invalid here as in the alimony statute and must be stricken. Accordingly, since the husband cannot afford counsel, he is awarded an interim counsel fee of $ 500.

 

2340 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Moore v. Board of Regents


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


89 Misc. 2d 23; 390 N.Y.S.2d 582; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1847



January 18, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the Trustees and Chancellor of the State University of New York, professors, and doctoral students in the history and English departments of the State University of New York at Albany, filed a declaratory judgment action concerned with program registration against defendants, the University of the State of New York Board of Regents and the Commissioner of Education, who moved to dismiss. Both sides filed summary judgment motions.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner decided not to continue his registration of the history and English doctoral programs at the State University of New York at Albany. The Trustees, Chancellor, professors, and students contended that the Commissioner had no authority to do so. They sought a declaration that the Trustees had the legal responsibility for educational programs, that N.Y. Educ. Law § 207 was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power, and that the Commissioner's decision to cancel doctoral programs in history and English was invalid. The Commissioner and the Regents moved to dismiss. Both sides moved for summary judgment. The court found that the action as to the history program was barred by the four-month statute of limitations in N.Y. C.P.L.R. 217. The court held that the Regents and the Commissioner had the power to approve, register, and cancel graduate programs under N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 8 §§ 13.1, 52.1 and N.Y. Educ. Law § 207, which was not unconstitutionally vague, and that the Commissioner's determination to do so had a rational basis.


OUTCOME: The court held that the action as to an English doctoral program was not barred by the statute of limitations, that the Commissioner and the Regents were authorized to oversee educational programs, and that the decision to not continue the registration of the English doctoral program had a rational basis.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Colleges and universities -- registration of doctoral programs in State University system.

1. The Regents of the University of the State of New York and the Commissioner of Education have the power to approve, register and terminate graduate programs in the State University system. The commissioner's determination in refusing to reregister the doctoral programs in English at the State University of New York at Albany was neither arbitrary nor capricious.
