The regents were within their authority to provide, through the commissioner, for the registration of courses in institutions of higher education in the State pursuant to the broad legislative power granted to the regents under section 207 of the Education Law to determine the educational policies of the State and to establish rules for carrying into effect the laws and policies of the State relating to education. Section 207 is not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power. The Legislature may validly enact statutes in broad outline leaving to administrative officials enforcing them the duty to arrange the details. The regents have registered programs since 1787 and have conducted such registration through [***2] the commissioner since 1910. The fact that the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York have the authority to administer the internal affairs of the State University (L 1961, ch 388) does not divest the regents and the commissioner of their power to approve programs in all institutions of higher education in the State.

2. The determination of the commissioner revoking the registration of the history doctoral program at the State University of New York at Albany is not subject to review in an article 78 proceeding since the action was not commenced within four months of the determination to be reviewed ( CPLR 217).

 

2341 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. A & C Trucking Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Geneva


88 Misc. 2d 988; 390 N.Y.S.2d 987; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1819



January 17, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion of the defendants is hereby granted to the extent that article IV of chapter 90 of the Ordinances of the City of Geneva (Refuse Collection Ordinance) is hereby declared unconstitutional under both Federal and State Constitutions, and the informations filed against the defendants, pursuant thereto, are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In the action by the State against defendant refuse collectors, the refuse collectors sought to invalidate Geneva, N.Y. Ordinance § 90.40 as unconstitutional because the ordinance required trash to be disposed of at a landfill site designated by the City of Geneva (city).


OVERVIEW: Geneva, N.Y. Ordinance § 90.40 required that trash generated from the city had to be disposed of at a particular landfill or at any other landfill site designated by the city. The city charged the refuse collectors with violating the ordinance. The court granted the collectors' motion to declare the ordinance unconstitutional. The court held that municipal ordinances were entitled to a presumption of constitutionality and that the regulation of trash was a matter that was directly connected to the protection of public health and within the proper exercise of the city's police powers accorded by N.Y. Const. art. IX, N.Y. Gen. City Law §§ 19 and 20, and N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10. The court found that the city had a duty to make provisions for the sanitary disposal of refuse, but that the ordinance violated both federal and state constitutions because it was unreasonable and arbitrary. The city had no control over who could use the landfill. The collectors would therefore be subject to the regulations of a third party.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion of the refuse collectors to the extent that the city ordinance was declared unconstitutional under the federal and state constitutions. The court dismissed the informations filed against the refuse collectors.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- refuse collection -- required disposal of refuse in landfill outside city limits.

The provisions of the refuse collection ordinance of the City of Geneva requiring that all ashes, rubbish and trash generated in the city be delivered for disposal to the Ontario County landfill site located seven miles outside the city limits are unconstitutionally unreasonable and arbitrary. Defendants are refuse collectors in the city who were charged with disposing of trash in another sanitary landfill located one mile from the city limits in violation of the ordinance. Although the city had the power to enact an ordinance providing for the sanitary disposal of collected garbage and trash at a landfill site outside the city limits within the exercise of its broad police power to protect the health and well-being of its citizens [***2] and visitors, the actual effect of the ordinance was violative of both the Federal and State Constitutions. Although the ordinance requires the disposal of all rubbish and trash at the county landfill site and prescribes substantial penalties for each violation thereof, the city has no control over who may be permitted by the county to use the landfill, nor does the city have any control over what rubbish and trash may be disposed and dumped at the landfill. A city license is valueless in assuring admittance to the landfill since each refuse collector who hauls refuse to the county landfill must also be licensed under the county's rules and regulations and be subject to the county's "necessary control procedures". A city-licensed hauler could therefore be denied the use of the county landfill after legally collecting refuse in the city, thereby unlawfully subjecting the hauler to the penalties imposed for violating the ordinance. A municipality may not demand certain performance by legislative fiat and at the same time provide for the punishment for such failure, when compliance may be rendered impossible by a third party.

 

2342 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Dixon v. Chairman of New York State Board of Parole


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Sullivan County


89 Misc. 2d 259; 390 N.Y.S.2d 811; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1828



January 17, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding seeking an order requiring respondent parole board chairman to modify his maximum expiration date of incarceration by removing the one year of reformatory delinquent time which was added thereto by reason of his most recent conviction.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was convicted of attempted robbery in the second degree and served his sentence. After being released on parole, the inmate was convicted of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree and sentenced. The parole board added one year of delinquent time from the reformatory sentence to the maximum expiration date of the new sentence pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 75.10(2)(c)(ii). The inmate argued that the addition of delinquent time was contrary to law. Upon review, the court found the inmate's argument without merit. The inmate was sentenced to the reformatory in 1973 upon his conviction for a class C felony, whereby he subjected himself to a 15-year penitentiary sentence, and his having been sentenced to the reformatory on a zero to four indeterminate sentence constituted an adequate quid pro quo. The inmate's second argument that N.Y. Penal Law § 70.25 was inconsistent with N.Y. Penal Law § 75.10, and that N.Y. Penal Law § 70.25 should have prevailed, was also without merit.


OUTCOME: The inmate's petition was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence.

Any constitutional infirmity in the sentencing provisions of article 75 of the Penal Law, whereby young adult misdemeanants are subjected to lengthier reformatory sentences than adult misdemeanants, is inapplicable in the case of a young felony offender convicted of a class C felony. Petitioner was subject to a 15-year sentence, and the imposition of a two- to four-year term for conviction of a class D felony as a second offender could properly result in the addition of one year of delinquent time to his prior indeterminate term of up to four years for conviction of a class C felony, where the second offense was committed over one year after conviction of the first and the later sentence was to run concurrently with the undischarged portion of the prior sentence. Accordingly, the petition to modify the expiration date of petitioner's sentence is dismissed.

 

2343 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gubala


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Cheektowaga, Erie County


89 Misc. 2d 189; 391 N.Y.S.2d 52; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1858



January 17, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with violating a local ordinance that prohibited discharging pollutants into the air, moved to dismiss the charge on the grounds that the ordinance in question was too vague and its applicability was overbroad.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with violating Cheektowaga, N.Y., Gen. Town Ordinance 4 which prohibited the unnecessary emission of pollutants into the air. He moved to dismiss the charge contending that the word "unnecessary" in the ordinance was too vague in that what was necessary in one case might be unnecessary in another, thus leaving too great of a possible interpretation to the trier of fact. The evidence at trial showed that defendant was sandblasting a car in his garage without using fans or any filtering system. Police officers observed a dust cloud coming from the garage. The court found that the term unnecessary could be used to define a standard if the intent of the statute, as it was in the instant case, was to prohibit a conduct which was something in excess of what was well understood to be the norm by a reasonable man through everyday knowledge. Therefore, the ordinance at issue was not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- "unnecessary emission" of pollutants -- sandblasting car without benefit of filtering system.

Town ordinance which prohibits "unnecessary emission of smoke, noxious gases, deposits, dust, trade wastes" and other pollutants from buildings is not unconstitutionally vague and overbroad. The term "unnecessary" may be used to define a standard where the intent of the statute is to prohibit a conduct which is something in excess of what is well understood to be the norm by a reasonable man through everyday knowledge. The unnecessary discharge of pollutants prohibited by the ordinance is that discharge which is greater than the amount considered to be reasonable with regard to the particular activity. Defendant is lawfully convicted of unnecessarily discharging pollution into the air by sandblasting a car in his home garage located on a residential street. Defendant unlawfully permitted sand to discharge into the air without benefit of ventilator fans or any type of filtering system and without any precaution to prevent the nuisance thus created.

 

2344 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bennett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Colonie, Albany County


89 Misc. 2d 382; 391 N.Y.S.2d 506; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1872



January 17, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants were charged with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 381(6), which required that any person operating or riding upon a motorcycle should wear a protective helmet. There was no dispute as to the facts of noncompliance with the statute on the part of defendants. They argued, however, that the statute was an impermissible invasion of their privacy and should be declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants argued that the statute was enacted only to qualify the State for federal highway construction funds and that the legislation was invalid where it was "special legislation" and discriminatory. Defendants argued that there was no rational basis between the statute and the purposes intended and that the legislation was not a proper exercise of the police power of the State. The court held that: (1) it was of no importance that the triggering device for the statute was the desire to qualify for federal highway funds; (2) the class upon which the statute fell was a large one, clearly identifiable, and the statute operated upon all of them equally and without exception; (3) it was not unreasonable for the legislature to come to a belief that a cyclist falling to the ground at great speed would sustain greater personal injuries to his head without a helmet than with one; (4) the right to operate a motorcycle on the public highways was not such a "fundamental right" as to require that regulation could be justified only by a "compelling State interest;" and (5) the statute appeared to be well founded and there was a clear and rational basis between it and the purposes intended.


OUTCOME: The court found defendants guilty and fined each the sum of $ 10.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- motorcycles -- helmet requirements.

Subdivision 6 of section 381 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, requiring operators of motorcycles to wear helmets, should not be declared unconstitutional. It is of no significance that the helmet requirements for State qualification for Federal highway funds, which triggered the enactment of the statute, have been eliminated. Section 381 does not constitute special legislation, since it applies to a large, clearly identifiable class with like effect upon all in the class for a public purpose. While the statistical evidence mandates no conclusion, it was not unreasonable for the Legislature to believe that helmets would reduce injuries, and the court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Legislature. The right to operate a motorcycle on the public highways is not so fundamental as to require a compelling State interest, and the statute protects the public health, safety and welfare from the effects of injuries to motorcyclists, such as the costs of medical care, unemployment, rehabilitation, increased welfare costs and unemployment taxes and the effect upon family relations. The failure of the Legislature to [***2] address itself to other matters affecting the public does not render the selected regulation arbitrary.

 

2345 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Almira v. Dumpson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


92 Misc. 2d 667; 401 N.Y.S.2d 367; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2603



January 14, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner recipient filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding against respondents, the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Social Services and the Commissioner of the State Department of Social Services, in which she sought permission to proceed as a poor person, an order that the City Commissioner comply with a prior fair hearing benefit decision, and the reversal of a second decision by the State Commissioner.


OVERVIEW: The recipient had a home health aide to assist her with daily living tasks. The aide was paid by the New York City Department of Social Services. She was also the recipient's daughter-in-law. The Department discontinued payment to the aide because N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 365-a(2)(d) (1973) disqualified her, as a family member, from being paid. Thereafter, a fair hearing was held and the City Commissioner held that the aid was not disqualified. That decision made no mention of the disqualification provisions of § 365-a(2)(d) or N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 505.14(g)(1). When the Department failed to comply with that decision the recipient filed her petition under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78. The State Commissioner thereafter held a fair hearing which upheld the initial decision to end payments. In an amended petition, the recipient sought affirmation of the first fair hearing decision and reversal of the second decision. The court held that the City Commissioner was required to comply with the first decision up to the date of the second hearing, but not afterwards. The court also held that there nothing unconstitutional, illegal, arbitrary, or capricious about the second decision.


OUTCOME: The court granted the recipient permission to proceed as a poor person and ordered the City Commissioner to comply with the first fair hearing decision and pay the recipient's aide up to the date of the second fair hearing. It held that the recipient was not entitled to payment after that date.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social Services -- Home Health Care Services Rendered by Recipient's Daughter-in-Law

Since a local welfare agency is bound by a fair hearing decision of the State Department of Social Services, respondent New York City Department of Social Services is required to comply with the fair hearing decision of the State Department of Social Services directing it to pay petitioner's daughter-in-law for health care and housekeeping services rendered to petitioner notwithstanding the fact such decision was palpably wrong being in violation of section 365-a (subd 2, par [d]) of the Social Services Law and 18 NYCRR 505.14 (g) (1), which prohibit the payment for home health aid or personal care services to members of the recipient's family including a daughter-in-law. However, since a local agency has the right to conduct another fair hearing on its own when it is of the opinion that another fair hearing is warranted because of an erroneous decision of the State Department of Social Services (Social Services Law, § 366-a, subds 5, 6), respondent is only required to pay petitioner's daughter-in-law for her services up to the date of the second decision after fair hearing which affirmed [***2] respondent's proper discontinuance of payment for services provided by petitioner's daughter-in-law.

 

2346 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kountz v. State University of New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Kings County


89 Misc. 2d 483; 391 N.Y.S.2d 942; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1927



January 10, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff physicians, who were teachers for defendants, a university and associated parties, sought a summary judgment and dismissal of defendants' defenses to the physicians' action to have N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 385-a to 385-i declared unconstitutional and inapplicable to the fees for their private medical services. The physicians also sought an injunction against defendants to prohibit them from enforcing the statute.


OVERVIEW: Defendants claimed that the physicians' action did not raise a case or controversy in that no corporation had yet been established pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 385-a to 385-i to collect the physicians' private income, but that the statute did authorize defendants to establish a corporation for that purpose. The court determined that the contention of defendants that they were authorized by §§ 385-a to 385-i to establish a corporation to collect the physicians' income from their private practices created a justiciable controversy that was ripe for the court to decide and it was appropriate for a summary judgment. The court held that the intent shown in N.Y. Educ. Law § 385-a, when read with the definitions contained in N.Y. Educ. Law § 385-b, showed that only the physicians' income related to their employment with defendants was to be collected under the statutory scheme and that the income from their private practices was not included. The court further concluded that it was not necessary to determine the constitutionality of the statutory scheme or grant injunctive relief to the physicians based upon the court's interpretation of N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 385-a to 385-i.


OUTCOME: The court granted the physicians' motion for summary judgment in so far as the court declared that the statute was applicable only to those services rendered by the physicians in connection with their employment with defendants and denied the physicians' request for injunctive relief and to have the statutory scheme declared unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Colleges and universities -- State medical college -- private practice income of teaching professionals.

Article 8-AA of the Education Law, which provides that State medical colleges could establish and require its teaching professionals, as a condition of employment, to become members of a Clinical Practice Income Management Corporation, which would "collect, manage and disburse, on behalf of the medical or dental school, all clinical practice income generated by employees of the school in connection with their employment" (Education Law, § 385-e), does not encompass services rendered by such teaching professionals and the fees they earn in their private practice. Article 8-AA is applicable to only those services rendered by doctors in connection with their employment as teaching professionals at State medical colleges. The purpose and intent of article 8-AA is to provide for a more improved system at a State medical center for the collection of, and accounting for, income generated by the teaching professionals for the medical center in the course of performing services related to their employment (Education Law, § 385-a). The doctors' private practice income has not [***2] been income to which the medical center was entitled and, consequently, has never been part of any ongoing system which the statute was designed to improve. In harmony with the over-all construction of the statute, the requirement that the services rendered be employment related is read into the definitions of "clinical practice" and "clinical practice income", which on their face, apply to "all income resulting from fees charged for professional services rendered in connection with clinical practice" (Education Law, § 385-b). Such construction of article 8-AA avoids the possibility of the statute being found unconstitutional as a deprivation of due process or equal protection of the laws.

 

2347 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York City Housing Authority v. Miller


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


89 Misc. 2d 141; 390 N.Y.S.2d 806; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1852



January 7, 1977 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the cross motion to dismiss the petition is denied and the petition is granted to the extent herein indicated. Settle judgment: (1) Denying the cross motion to dismiss; (2) granting prohibition against enforcement of the orders under review to the extent that they direct that the Authority provide or change living accommodations for the individual respondent-defendants and their families; (3) declaring that the Family Court has no power to make such orders or to institute or continue proceedings for such purpose under section 255 of the Family Court Act or any other statute; (4) declaring that the Authority is required to render assistance and co-operation to the Family Court and embodying a formal procedure to insure such purpose.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner housing authority brought an action for a writ of prohibition and declaratory judgment against respondents, family court judges and beneficiaries, to preclude the judges from exercising jurisdiction over the housing authority with respect to its tenant selection procedures. Respondent beneficiary brought a cross-motion to dismiss the action.


OVERVIEW: The family court judges entered orders compelling the housing authority to assist families to find or obtain repairs to suitable housing. The housing authority brought a petition for a writ of prohibition precluding the family court judges from exercising jurisdiction over it with respect to its tenant selection procedures. A beneficiary of one of the orders filed a motion to dismiss the action. The court granted the writ and, finding that prohibition was proper, denied the cross-motion. The court found that under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 255, the family court judges had authority to issue orders to any agency to render information, assistance, and cooperation concerning a child who was under the court's care, treatment, supervision, or custody. However, the court said, the housing authority was not an "agency" within the meaning of § 255. The court said that there was no constitutional or statutory obligation imposed on the housing authority or power conferred on the family court to interfere with legally established housing authority procedures as to tenant selection. The court noted that the housing authority was an independent public corporation with specific duties and powers.


OUTCOME: The court granted the housing authority's petition to preclude the family court judges from exercising jurisdiction over the housing authority with respect to its tenant selection procedures. The court denied the beneficiary's cross-motion to dismiss the action.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Family Court -- power to direct agency to provide housing.

 Section 255 of the Family Court Act which empowers the Family Court to order "any agency or other institution to render such information, assistance and cooperation as shall be within its legal authority concerning a child who is or shall be under its care, treatment, supervision or custody", does not confer upon the Family Court the power to direct petitioner [***2] New York City Housing Authority to provide immediate housing for parents and children who are the subject of Family Court proceedings. Section 255 was designed as a specific remedy to enable the Family Court to eliminate bureaucratic red tape and overcome the lack of interagency co-operation which combined to frustrate the provision of services for families and children. Family Court orders directing the furnishing or repair of housing, although issued for the laudable purpose of facilitating the transfer of children from foster care to their parents or other relatives, are not orders for information, assistance or co-operation and are, therefore, not within the jurisdiction of the Family Court. The Authority is an independent public corporation which has the specific statutory duty to construct, operate and maintain public housing and to make tenant selections based upon certain statutory priorities, constitutional considerations, its own rules and the availability of space. The appropriate remedy to review the acts of the Authority in the assignment of apartments or the selection of tenants is by a CPLR article 78 proceeding in Supreme Court not by orders of the Family Court.  [***3] The Housing Authority is ordered to render assistance and co-operation to the Family Court to provide or change living accommodations for the families and children involved in Family Court proceedings.

 

2348 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rapp v. Carey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


88 Misc. 2d 428; 390 N.Y.S.2d 573; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1814



January 6, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff managerial and confidential state employees moved for a preliminary injunction in their action to have an executive order declared unconstitutional and to permanently enjoin its enforcement. Defendants, the governor and others, cross-moved for summary judgment dismissing the amended complaint.


OVERVIEW: The employees challenged an executive order issued by the governor based on the argument that the order was an unwarranted exercise of legislative power. The court held that the governor did not have the power to issue the executive order. The order went far beyond mere enforcement of a statute; it extended and expanded the requirements of the legislation. Consequently, the order was an unwarranted exercise of legislative power that violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, which gave the legislature the power to make laws. Furthermore, the executive order also violated the expressed intent of the legislature when it enacted the conflict-of-interest statute. The inflexible proscriptions of the order were clearly at variance with the intent of the conflict-of-interest statute.


OUTCOME: The court granted the employees a judgment declaring the executive order to be unconstitutional and enjoining its enforcement.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Public officers -- financial disclosure -- prohibition of outside employment.

Executive Order No. 10.1 (9 NYCRR 3.10), which requires that all assets and liabilities of managerial and confidential State employees be disclosed, is an unwarranted exercise of legislative power violative of section 1 of article III of the State Constitution. Rather than merely enforce existing conflict-of-interest laws (Public Officers Law, § 73 et seq.), Executive Order No. 10.1 improperly extends and expands the requirements of the legislation. The requirement that all assets and liabilities of managerial and confidential employees be disclosed goes beyond the narrowly drawn statute requiring limited disclosure to bring to light possible conflicts of interest (Public Officers Law, § 74, subd 3, par j). While the Public Officers Law only prohibits employees from receiving any compensation for services rendered in connection with any matter before any State agency where the compensation is contingent upon any action of the agency or for rendering any services against the interest of the State in relation to any matter in the Court of Claims (Public Officers Law, § 73, subds 2, 3), Executive [***2] Order No. 10.1 improperly prohibits all outside employment and engaging in any business or other activity from which compensation is derived. The Executive Order also prohibits service as a director or officer, compensated or not, in any profit-making corporation. The inflexible proscriptions of Executive Order No. 10.1 are at variance with the legislative intent of establishing a more flexible code of ethics setting forth the general standards of conduct to be reasonably expected of State officers and employees.

 

2349 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Tucker v. Toia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


89 Misc. 2d 116; 390 N.Y.S.2d 794; 1977 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1851



January 4, 1977 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff applicants brought suit against defendant state for declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 158 was unconstitutional. The applicants brought a motion for summary judgment and for class determination. The state brought a cross-motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The applicants were denied home relief benefits under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 158. The applicants argued that § 158 violated N.Y. Const. Art. XVII, § 1, which created in the citizens of New York State a fundamental right to aid, care, and support of the needy. The applicants contended that the state failed to show a compelling interest to justify the infringement of the applicants' rights. The court agreed that the state constitution established a right fundamental to the relationship between the State of New York and its needy citizens. The court concluded that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 158, insofar as it raised a substantial barrier to the efforts of some needy children to obtain the public assistance necessary to their maintenance of a minimal level of health, nutrition, and security, but left other needy children, similarly situated, without such a barrier, violated the equal protection clause of N.Y. Const. Art. I, § 11. Accordingly, the court enjoined the state from permitting any further implementation of the statute.


OUTCOME: The court granted the applicants' motion for class determination and denied their motion for leave to represent a class of persons similarly situated. The court also denied the state's cross-motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social services -- home relief public assistance to minor children -- eligibility requirements -- equal protection.

1. Subdivision (a) of section 158 of the Social Services Law (as amd by L 1976, ch 76, § 15), which denies all home relief public assistance to certain needy children under the age of 21 years who are living apart from a legally responsible relative until a final order of disposition is obtained against such responsible relative in a support proceeding, while not imposing the same eligibility requirements upon other similarly situated needy children eligible for benefits under the Federally subsidized aid to families with dependent children program, is violative of the State equal protection clause (NY Const, art I, § 11). The State's obligation to provide for the "aid, care and support of the needy" (NY Const, art XVII, § 1) is a constitutionally protected "fundamental" right which cannot be abridged unless there can be shown both a compelling governmental interest requiring the infringement and that there exists no less restrictive means available to the State to achieve such a compelling State interest. The interest of the State in effecting fiscal savings [***2] in the implementation of welfare programs is not of a sufficiently compelling nature to permit the infringement of a "fundamental" constitutional right resulting from the disparate treatment of similarly circumstanced needy children. In seeking to achieve the legitimate governmental purpose of effecting fiscal savings the State may not make an "expedient selection" of a distinct minority of its needy citizens and impose upon them extraordinary burdens in violation of their constitutional rights.

2. Plaintiffs may not maintain this suit as a class action since governmental operations are involved and the interests of the proposed class will be adequately protected by the issuance of a final order enjoining the Department of Social Services from implementing the statute which will run to the benefit of each person affected by said statute.

 

2350 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hunter v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 562; 391 N.Y.S.2d 289; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2706



December 23, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, city, mayor, and acting city clerk, moved for summary judgment dismissing the complaint of plaintiff city employees, who sought a declaratory judgment that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 1106-5.0, dealing with financial disclosures by city employees, was unconstitutional and should not be enforced.


OVERVIEW: A group of city employees filed suit seeking a declaratory judgment that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 1106-5.0, which required elected officials and city personnel to file annual statements disclosing information of a personal financial nature, was unconstitutional and enjoining its enforcement. The city, mayor, and acting city clerk moved for summary judgment dismissing the complaint. The court found that (1) the action was appropriately maintained as a class action covering appropriate individuals earning a salary in excess of the minimum requirement for enforcement of the code, (2) those city employees whose base pay did not meet the minimum requirement lacked standing, (3) the classification of those positions meeting the minimum salary requirements as managerial or policymaking in nature was not arbitrary and did not involve a curtailment of a constitutional right, (4) particularly in light of the fact that the city employees' contentions of vagueness were relatively speculative, it was reasonable that the ordinance require city employees, though not their spouses, to file the required reports, and (5) therefore the motion for summary judgment was granted.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion of the city, mayor, and acting city clerk for summary judgment against the city employees and dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Public officers -- financial disclosure -- right of privacy.

1. Section 1106-5.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York (Local Laws, 1975, No. 1 of City of New York), which requires city employees whose base salary is $ 25,000 a year or more and their spouses to disclose personal financial data which is then made available for public inspection (New York City Charter, §§ 1113, 1114), does not unconstitutionally violate such employees' rights of privacy. An expectation of privacy with respect to an individual's financial affairs is not a fundamental right entitled to special constitutional safeguards. The methods of disclosure employed by the statute are "reasonable and appropriate" to accomplish the legitimate governmental purposes of discouraging and detecting corruption and the appearance of corruption, of avoiding conflicts of interests and of instilling in the public a sense of confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the public service. The city council reasonably concluded that those earning $ 25,000 or more presented entirely distinct problems justifying [***2] disclosure even if some nonmanagerial personnel were drawn into the classification. Plaintiffs have not rebutted the statutory presumption that those positions in the classified civil service which fall above a minimum salary of $ 25,000 involve functions or responsibilities of such a nature as to require public disclosure of outside financial interests.

2. The broad scope of required financial disclosure, which might require reporting of financial data unrelated to any city activity or to the public office in general, does not warrant holding the financial disclosures law unconstitutional on its face. It would be an insurmountable legislative task to tailor disclosure to each of a myriad of public posts and an anomaly to enact a statute designed to eliminate conflicts of interests so as to permit the person affected to decide when a financial interest relates to his public employment.

3. The availability of the financial statements to the public is not unrelated to the purpose of the statute of fostering public confidence in the integrity of the public service.

4. The absence of administrative machinery to review the propriety of public disclosure in individual cases (cf. Executive [***3] Order No. 10; 9 NYCRR 3.10) does not render the statute constitutionally defective. A requirement that a line be drawn which insures that no city employee whose responsibilities might not be expected to give rise to a conflict of interest will be subjected to unnecessary financial disclosure would unreasonably encumber effective administration and permit many clear violators to escape regulation entirely.

5. The alleged infringement on the right of association which might result from the required disclosure of income sources, debts, gifts and honoria is highly speculative, and absent a showing of an actual chilling effect on associational activities, does not justify holding the statute unconstitutional on its face.

 

2351 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Barrett


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Town of Tonawanda, Erie County


89 Misc. 2d 631; 393 N.Y.S.2d 225; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2853



December 14, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State sought to convict defendant of driving while intoxicated under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. § 1192(3). Defendant contended that at most he was driving while impaired and that the statute was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was stopped after he was observed swerving. Defendant appeared intoxicated to a police officer. Defendant took a breathalyzer test, which registered a .15 percent level of blood alcohol. Prior case law had found the statute unconstitutional. The court convicted defendant of driving while impaired. While case law held the statute unconstitutional, new case law at least in part upheld its constitutionality. Driving while intoxicated required a finding that a defendant was "very, very drunk." The court rejected the argument that a blood alcohol level beyond .09999 percent created a conclusive presumption that a person was intoxicated. Rather, a rebuttable presumption was created, and the use of a blood alcohol test did not alter the presumption. The State did not establish that defendant was "very, very drunk."


OUTCOME: Defendant was convicted of driving while impaired.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- driving while intoxicated -- rebuttable presumption of intoxication.

Under subdivision 3 of section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, a blood alcohol reading of .10 or greater merely gives rise to a rebuttable presumption that a person is driving while intoxicated. Consequently, even after a blood alcohol reading of .10 or greater has been admitted into evidence, any proof indicating that defendant was not "very, very drunk" would tend to upset the presumption of intoxication. In the absence of a blood alcohol test, the proof required to convict for driving while intoxicated must be overwhelming. If a person is intoxicated, he is no more or less so because a blood alcohol test has been administered. If the proof necessary to sustain a conviction without a test is that a defendant must have been "very, very drunk", the same standard must apply when there is a test. Accordingly, defendant, whose car was observed swerving slightly, who had some difficulty speaking and bloodshot eyes, and a blood alcohol reading of .15, is only guilty of driving while impaired (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1192, subd 1).

 

2352 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Perloff v. Melton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


89 Misc. 2d 103; 390 N.Y.S.2d 372; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2822



December 13, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff driver sought a injunctive relief from additional fees charged to renew her driver's license by defendant Commissioner of Motor Vehicles (New York). Defendants, the Commissioner and others, moved for summary judgment and dismissal of the action, claiming the driver had failed to state facts sufficient to entitle her to any relief or to demonstrate that she was entitled to the remedy sought.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner promulgated new regulations, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 15, § 170(M), which doubled or trebled fees for operators against whom was recorded one or more convictions or bail forfeitures that occurred within a 36-month period preceding renewal of the operator's license. The driver had one such conviction and was compelled to pay an increased fee to obtain a renewal of her operator's license. She filed suit for declaratory and injunctive relief. The Commissioner sought summary judgment and dismissal, asserting he was entitled to levy the additional fees to fund driver improvement programs. The driver claimed that the Commissioner was without authority to increase the fees. The court agreed, holding that the Commissioner had misconstrued 1976 N.Y. Laws ch. 50. His authority was limited to appropriating existing fees to fund driver improvement programs. The driver's license fees that could be charged were specified and limited by N.Y. Veh. & Traff. Law § 503(2)(6), which the Commissioner's regulations and additional fees had improperly exceeded.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment, declaring that the additional license fees imposed were invalid, permanently enjoining enforcement thereof, and directing the Commissioner to reimburse the driver for fees unlawfully assessed against her. All other motions were denied.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- increased fee for renewal license -- funding for driver improvement program.

The Commissioner of Motor Vehicles was without authority to promulgate regulations increasing the fees that must be paid for renewal driver's licenses for those operators who have had one or more convictions recorded against them within the preceding 36-month period. ( 15 NYCRR Part 170). The statute appropriating a sum in excess of $ 1,300,000 for the "administration of the driver improvement programs" requiring that expenditures from such appropriation be "reimbursed by the receipts from fees established by the Commissioner that are sufficient to cover the total cost" of operating such programs (L 1976, ch 50), did not authorize the commissioner to devise and impose a new fee structure which would impliedly amend or repeal the existing statutory fee schedule (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 503, subd 2, par [b]). Had the Legislature intended to delegate to an administrative official the power to decide which segment of the public should be compelled to fund the driver improvement programs, it would have selected more specific and clearer language to accomplish that purpose. The [***2] statute may reasonably be construed to mean that the commissioner was empowered to spend only so much of the appropriation for driver improvement programs as could be funded from fees which had already been, or could thereafter be, established by the commissioner pursuant to the discretionary authority which was already his under existing statutes.

 

2353 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Stock


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


88 Misc. 2d 1058; 390 N.Y.S.2d 367; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2830



December 8, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant operated a passenger vehicle that had a sign attached to its roof, advertising the election of a judicial candidate. He was charged with violating N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 415.6(k). At the end of the trial, the court reserved decision on defendant's motion for a judgment, seeking to dismiss the information on the ground that he was not guilty as a matter of law, and that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1683 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant operated a passenger vehicle with a sign attached to its roof advertising the election of a candidate for a judgeship. Defendant was charged with a violation of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 415.6(k), an ordinance adopted by the Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission providing that vehicles with signs attached for business or advertising purposes were prohibited on parkways. At the end of trial, the court reserved decision on defendant's motion for a judgment. Defendant argued that because N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1683 gave the Commission the discretion to erect signs that regulated traffic insofar as it deemed practicable, it violated due process; therefore it was unconstitutional. The court disagreed, determining that the sign on top of defendant's vehicle could have been construed as a distraction to drivers and affected public safety, therefore the Commission's regulation of said signs was not violative of due process. The court also stated that defendant was on notice of the Commission's rules regulating road usage since they were filed with the Secretary of State pursuant to N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 8.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty of violating a rule on the use of the roads and highways adopted by the Commission and denied defendant's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Highways -- regulation of vehicles having advertising thereon -- posting of signs giving notice of regulation.

Defendant, who operated a passenger vehicle which had attached to its roof a sign advertising the election of a candidate for the Family Court in Nassau County, violated subdivision (k) of section 415.6 of the Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission Rules and Regulations (9 NYCRR 415.6 [k]), which prohibits from parkways vehicles having any advertising, except for certain small lettering which would not be distracting to other motorists. No signs were posted on the highway informing motorists of this regulation. Subdivision (b) of section 1683 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law provides that the park commission shall post signs giving notice of highway regulations and gives the commission discretion to erect such signs insofar as it deems practicable. This provision is not a violation of due process or freedom of speech and there was no improper delegation of legislative power or unreasonable exercise of the police power. It would be impractical to require the Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission to post signs for all of its ordinances, and [***2] the motorists using the highways are on notice of the rules adopted by the park commission since they are filed with the Secretary of State.

 

2354 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pashcow v. Babylon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Suffolk County


96 Misc. 2d 1036; 410 N.Y.S.2d 192; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2896



December 8, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlords and defendant town agreed to submit a controversy regarding the constitutionality of Babylon, New York, Ordinance ch. 10, art. VI to the court. The landlords were being prosecuted in a criminal proceeding based on their alleged failure to comply with the ordinance, and a temporary injunction was issued on the criminal proceeding pending a determination of the ordinance's constitutionality.


OVERVIEW: The town enacted an ordinance requiring landlords to make a sworn written application once every two years or each time a unit became vacant for the right to lease it again. A building inspector could enter the premises at any time to insure that it complied with the housing laws. Failure to comply with the ordinance carried criminal penalties. The landlords filed an action seeking a declaration that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The court held that the ordinance was unconstitutional because failure to comply with any provision, including failure to permit an inspection, carried criminal sanctions in violation of the prohibition of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution against searches and inspections by municipal building inspectors without consent or a warrant. Further, the applicability of the ordinance to half of the geographical area of the town a year before it applied to the other half violated the landlords' rights under the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution by subjecting some landlords to criminal prosecution while others of the same class who were similarly situated were immune from prosecution.


OUTCOME: The court held that the town's ordinance relating to residential rental property inspections and permits was unconstitutional as written in the landlords' action seeking a declaration that the statute was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Searches without Consent or Warrant

1. Searches and inspections of homes, residential rental property and commercial structures by municipal building inspectors without consent or a warrant [***2] are prohibited by the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

Constitutional Law -- Searches without Consent or Warrant

2. A town ordinance relating to residential rental property inspections and permits violates the prohibition of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution against unconsented warrantless searches and inspections by municipal building inspectors even where inspectors are instructed to obtain a warrant if permission to enter and inspect the premises is refused, since the owner is subject to criminal prosecution under the ordinance if he fails to permit an inspection; regardless of the final disposition of that proceeding, the landlord should not be subject to the notoriety and expense which is part of a criminal proceeding.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws

3. A town ordinance relating to residential rental property inspections and permits which applies to one half of the geographical area of the town one year before it applies to the other half violates the rights of landlords in the first area under the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution by subjecting some [***3] landlords to the criminal sanctions of the ordinance while others of the same class who are similarly situated are immune from prosecution during that period.

 

2355 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bensen v. State


Claim Nos. 60459, 60460, 60461, 60462, 60463, 60464, 60465


Court of Claims of New York


88 Misc. 2d 1035; 389 N.Y.S.2d 760; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2800



December 7, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Said allegation is thus stricken and the cause of action related thereto is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In seven consolidated actions, the state filed motions to dismiss as untimely filed claimants' causes of action for false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, and negligence.


OVERVIEW: The claims arose from a mass arrest of the claimants. The next day, after all claimants were formally booked, the criminal charges were dismissed and each claimant was released from custody. The state sought to dismiss the claims on the ground that they were untimely filed. The court granted the motion in part and denied it in part. Although the claims were timely filed under the Court of Claims Act, § 10, subd. 3, the state argued that the limitations period for these claims was really only one year because of the language in N.Y. Const. art. III, § 19 and the Court of Claims Act, § 12, subd. 2. The court upheld the Court of Claims Act, § 10, subd. 3 because it did not subject the state to less favorable time limitations than private citizens. The causes of action for false imprisonment and malicious prosecution were timely and constitutionally filed. The causes of action for malicious prosecution and negligence were sufficiently included in the notices of intention and therefore timely filed, except as to the alleged negligence of the state in training and supervising its police members. That allegation was stricken and the cause of action related to it was dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state's motion to dismiss as to the alleged negligence of the state in training and supervising its police members and struck that allegation. The court denied the motion as to the causes of action for false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, and the remaining claims of negligence.


HEADNOTES

State -- claims against State -- timely filing.

1. On August 15, 1974, the day after claimants were subjected to a mass arrest, charges against them were dropped and each was released. Within 90 days identical notices of intention were filed on behalf of each claimant, and within two years identical claims (except as to damages) were filed (Court of Claims Act, § 10, subd 3), with each generally alleging causes of action for false imprisonment, malicious prosecution and negligence. Based on the contention that if the false imprisonment and malicious prosecution causes of action had been brought between citizens a one-year Statute of Limitations would apply ( CPLR 215, subd 3), and that since both section 19 of article III of the New York State Constitution and subdivision 2 of section 12 of the Court of Claims Act state in substantially similar language that no action may be brought against the State that would be time-barred if brought as against citizens, defendant made a motion to dismiss these causes of action for untimely filing. The motion is denied. Subdivision 3 of section [***2] 10 of the Court of Claims Act does not conflict unconstitutionally with section 19 of article III of the New York Constitution. Since a notice of intention contains all that is required in a summons and more, the notice is deemed sufficiently comparable to a summons to find that the filing of such notice affords the State a more, not less, favorable time limitation than that applicable between citizens. Moreover, the notices of intention filed here may be treated as claims with respect to false imprisonment, and satisfactorily include causes of action for malicious prosecution.

2. Allegations of negligence in the notices of intention were sufficient to support the claims of negligence against the State Police for participating in an unlawful arrest and search, with the resulting alleged deprivation of claimants' civil liberty, and of the negligence of agents of the State in failing to verify the existence of probable cause. However, nothing in the notices referred to the State's alleged negligent training and supervision of members of its police, and the cause of action of negligence emanating from it is stricken.

 

2356 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kapsuris


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Erie County


89 Misc. 2d 634; 392 N.Y.S.2d 785; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2854



November 29, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss a simplified information charging him with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. § 1192(2), (3).


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved to dismiss a simplified information charging him with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. § 1192(2), (3), on the basis that the statute was unconstitutionally vague. The court found the statute did not unconstitutionally charge defendant because proof could be made that defendant was intoxicated either by chemical test or by proof defendant was very, very drunk. In this case, defendant had submitted to a chemical test, so defendant could be convicted under the statutes he was charged with violating. The information charged properly and the case was remanded for trial.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to dismiss the information and remanded for trial.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor vehicles -- driving while ability impaired -- driving while intoxicated.

Subdivision 1 of section 1192 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law which defines driving while ability impaired, is sufficiently clear and is not unconstitutionally vague where a defendant submits to a blood alcohol test since the results of such test would under section 1195, clearly differentiate between driving while ability impaired, a violation, and driving while intoxicated (Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 1192, subd 3), a crime. In order to sustain an indictment or information for driving while intoxicated, a chemical blood test will be required, or in the absence of such test, the indictment or information and proof must show that the defendant was very, very drunk. Where a defendant has not submitted to chemical analysis and the indictment or information does not clearly show that defendant was very, very drunk, the charge must be limited to driving while ability impaired. Since defendant submitted to a chemical test his case is remanded for trial.

 

2357 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Criterion Ins. Co. v. Commercial Union Assurance Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


89 Misc. 2d 36; 390 N.Y.S.2d 953; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2813



November 24, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner at-fault insurer sought to stay compulsory arbitration proceedings under N.Y. Ins. Law § 674 in an attempt by respondent not-at-fault insurer to recover first party benefits to its insured.


OVERVIEW: Two cars collided. One of the drivers who was not at fault was seriously injured. Her insurance company compensated her for her injuries. The insurer of the not-at-fault insured then sought arbitration to recover first party benefits paid to its insured from the insurer of the at-fault insured pursuant to N.Y. Ins. Law § 674. The at-fault insurer petitioned the court to stay the arbitration proceedings. The court determined that the not-at-fault insurer was entitled to recovery of the money paid to its insured from the at-fault insurer and was not limited by the amount specified on the at-fault insured's policy. Arbitration was the appropriate remedy. The petition to stay the arbitration proceeding was dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition to stay the arbitration proceedings.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Insurance -- no-fault automobile insurance -- reallocation of loss through intercompany arbitration.

The obligation of petitioner insurance company under section 674 of the Insurance Law to reimburse respondent insurer for payments of first-party benefits made to respondent's insured is not constitutionally limited by the underlying limits of petitioner's liability coverage for its insured. Petitioner's insured was allegedly the atfault party in causing the automobile accident in Suffolk County which seriously injured respondent's insured. In addition to containing provision for no-fault benefits, petitioner's policy provided liability coverage of $ 10,000/$ 20,000 for personal injuries and $ 5,000 for property damage. The statutory mandate permitting respondent insurer to recover by arbitration the first-party benefits paid to its insured from petitioner insurer to the extent that petitioner's insured would have been liable, but for the no-fault act, to pay damages in an action at law (Insurance Law, § 674, subd 1), does not unlawfully impose on petitioner a liability which it did not contract to assume. Petitioner can have no greater right to a common-law action than [***2] its insured has. Its only redress is the arbitral process created by the statute to which a right of trial by jury does not attach. Reallocation of loss through an intercompany arbitration procedure helps achieve the objects of the no-fault law of eliminating the vast majority of auto accident negligence suits from the courts and assuring prompt compensation to accident victims of substantially all of their economic loss without regard to fault. In writing insurance in this State, petitioner necessarily assumed the obligations imposed by the statute.

 

2358 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Overton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 531; 389 N.Y.S.2d 253; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2699



November 19, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Consequently, the defendant's motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 30.30(5)(c) seeking to dismiss a complaint, in which he was charged with assault in the second degree, with criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree, and with criminal mischief in the third degree, under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 120.05, 265.01, 145.05, on the ground of violation of his speedy trial rights.


OVERVIEW: After several adjournments following defendant's arraignment on a felony complaint for assault in the second degree, for criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree, and for criminal mischief in the third degree, under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 120.05, 265.01, 145.05, the original charges were reduced to misdemeanors of harassment and of criminal mischief in the fourth degree, under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 240.25, 145.00. The case was then set for trial, but more adjournments followed. Defendant then sought a dismissal under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law art. 30.30 alleging violation of his speedy trial rights. The court held that: (1) the delay was within the prescribed 90-day period, as calculated from the date of the filing of the new accusatory instrument; (2) there was no due process violation because a 90-day speedy trial rule was not a constitutional requirement for all misdemeanor cases; and (3) there was no equal protection violation as defendant was not being singled out for special treatment from among all those whose prosecution commenced with a felony complaint, which was then replaced or converted to an information, to a prosecutor's information, or to a misdemeanor complaint.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint against him.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- denial of speedy trial -- reduction of felony charge to misdemeanor.

1. CPL 30.30 (subd 5, par [c]) which provides that where a "felony complaint is replaced or converted to an information, prosecutor's information or misdemeanor complaint" the 90-day period within which a trial must be commenced ( CPL 30.30, subd 1) is "calculated from the date of the filing of such new accusatory instrument" provided that the permissible time period, not counting that which is expressly excludable, does not exceed six months, does not deprive defendant of his constitutional right to due process. Defendant was arraigned on August 20, 1975 on a felony complaint. On November 5, 1975 after a number of adjournments, the original felony charges were reduced to misdemeanor charges and set down for trial for December 1, 1975. Defendant's motion pursuant to CPL 30.30 to dismiss the charges against him on the ground of denial of his right to a speedy trial was properly dismissed since the delay involved was well within the 90-day period permitted by CPL 30.30 (subd 5, par [c]) as calculated from the date of the filing of the new accusatory [***2] instrument. Where a criminal action is commenced by the filing of a felony complaint and is then replaced or converted to an information, prosecutor's information or misdemeanor complaint it does not necessarily follow that a defendant's constitutional rights have been abridged by reason of the fact that more than 90 days may have elapsed between the bringing of the initial charge and the start of trial. The 90-day speedy trial limitations within CPL 30.30 are stricter than those required by constitutional standards. The denial of a speedy trial depends upon such factors as the length of the delay, the reason assigned by the prosecution to justify the delay and prejudice to the defendant.

2. CPL 30.30 (subd 5, par [c]) does not arbitrarily and capriciously deprive defendant of a speedy trial as guaranteed to others initially charged with misdemeanor offenses. There are legitimate reasons why a criminal action may be commenced through a felony complaint and end up being prosecuted as a misdemeanor.

 

2359 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Phillips v. Agway, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Cattaraugus County


88 Misc. 2d 1087; 389 N.Y.S.2d 977; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2835



November 19, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion for apportionment of plaintiff's costs of recovery is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee received $ 15,238.63 in workmen's compensation benefits. The employee was successful in his action against third parties, and the amount recovered was sufficient to repay respondent insurer for the money it paid him. The insurer sought full reimbursement, and alleged it had a lien for the full sum. The employee asked for the apportionment of 1/3 of his costs in recovering his third party claim against the lien.


OVERVIEW: In his motion, the employee asked for 1975 N.Y. Laws 190 to be construed retroactively. In objecting to the employee's motion, the insurer argued that retrospective application of 1975 N.Y. Laws 190 would have been improper, illegal, and perhaps even unconstitutional. Upon review, the court found that the employee was not entitled to having his motion granted. If the employee succeeded, $ 5,000 would have been removed from the insurer's coffers and placed in the employees because an action was brought to judgment after June, 1975 rather than before June, 1975, the effective date of the statute. That would have been a very concrete substantive result of an adjective, procedure change. The insurer's lien on any third-party recovery was a vested right. The insurer's lien vested when it applied its first dollar to the employee's use. It was then a full lien. It could not have been diminished.


OUTCOME: The motion for the apportionment of the employee's costs of recovery was denied.


HEADNOTES

Workmen's compensation -- liens of compensation insurance carriers -- retroactivity.

As a result of sustaining injuries in 1971 during the course of his employment, plaintiff received workmen's compensation paid by the State Insurance Fund, which was plaintiff's employer's compensation carrier. Plaintiff later brought suit for negligence against third parties and recovered an amount sufficient to repay the State Insurance Fund. Prior to June 10, 1975 section 29 of the Workmen's Compensation Law granted compensation insurance carriers full liens against third-party recoveries, but chapter 190 of the Laws of 1975 provided for equitable apportionment of the costs of a third-party recovery between the insurance company lienor and the covered employee. Upon plaintiff's motion that chapter 190 of the Laws of 1975 be construed retroactively and that one third of his costs in recovering the third-party claim be apportioned against the lienor carrier's lien, the motion is denied. The statute is not to be given retroactive effect since to do so would bring about a substantive result of a procedural change.  [***2] The State Insurance Fund's lien on the third-party recovery was a vested right which vested when it applied its first dollar to plaintiff's use.

 

2360 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Alvarez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 709; 389 N.Y.S.2d 980; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2731



November 19, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Therefore, the motion is granted to the limited extent of setting aside the jury verdict on conspiracy in the first degree and dismissing that count of the indictment. The motion with respect to the other charges on which the defendant was convicted is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to set aside the jury verdict, which, after a retrial following the dismissal of the conspiracy in the first degree charge, convicted him of conspiracy, of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree, and of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first and third degrees. Defendant alleged that the retrial on the conspiracy count violated the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment.


OVERVIEW: At the conclusion of the state's case in defendant's trial for conspiracy in the first degree, criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree, criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first and third degrees and criminal possession of a weapon, the trial court dismissed the conspiracy charge for failure to establish a prima facie case, and declared a mistrial in holding that hearsay evidence was elicited under the theory of conspiracy. On retrial, the indictment was deemed to contain all the counts it contained at the time of the first trial, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 280.20, and defendant was convicted on all counts, including the conspiracy count. On appeal, the court held that: (1) section 280.20 was unconstitutional, and the conviction on the conspiracy count violated the Fifth Amendment double jeopardy prohibition because there was a judgment during trial discharging him of the conspiracy count; (2) retrial on the substantive crimes were permissible because they were not dismissed before the mistrial was declared; and (3) the trial of the indictment containing the conspiracy count were not precluded by res judicata or by collateral estoppel.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to set aside as to the conspiracy in the first degree count and dismissed that count of the indictment. The court denied the motion with respect to defendant's conviction for criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree, for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first and third degrees, and for criminal possession of a weapon in the second and third degrees.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- former jeopardy -- trial order of dismissal.

1. Defendant's conviction on a conspiracy charge, which had been dismissed by a trial order of dismissal prior to the declaration of a mistrial in defendant's first trial, is barred by the double jeopardy clause of the Fifth Amendment. Defendant was convicted of conspiracy, criminal sale and possession of a controlled substance and criminal possession of a weapon in his new trial, which resulted from the declaration of mistrial in the first trial. CPL 280.20, which provides that an indictment in a new trial resulting from a mistrial, "is deemed to contain all the counts which it contained at the time the previous trial was commenced, regardless of whether any count was thereafter dismissed by the court prior to the mistrial order", is unconstitutional as applied to the facts of this case.

2. The improper inclusion of the conspiracy charge in defendant's second [***2] trial did not affect the validity of the conviction obtained on the substantive crimes since the conduct of the trial and the admission of evidence would not have been materially different without the conspiracy charge. Since defendant was charged with criminal liability for the acts of his conspirators pursuant to section 20.00 of the Penal Law, the acts and declarations of said coconspirators in furtherance of a proven joint criminal undertaking were admissible with respect to substantive crimes charged, irrespective of the existence or lack of a conspiracy charge.

3. The dismissal of the conspiracy charge in the first trial on the ground that there was no direct proof of an express agreement did not bar the subsequent prosecution for the substantive crimes under the doctrines of res judicata and collateral estoppel. The findings of fact supporting the trial order of dismissal did not determine any issue necessarily decisive in the second trial. There is no reasonable possibility that any evidence presented at the second trial was precluded by the prior trial order of dismissal. The dismissal did not go to proof of the overt acts charged in the conspiracy or the substantive [***3] crimes. No finding was made with respect to the proof of the requisite knowledge or intent for the substantive crimes or whether defendant intentionally aided any other person in the commission of the crimes charged. The proof that defendant's actions constituted the elements of the substantive crimes either as a principal or an accessory, did not require direct proof of any express agreement.

 

2361 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Woodside v. Board of Inspectors of Election of 56th Election Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


88 Misc. 2d 696; 389 N.Y.S.2d 242; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2728



November 12, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner voters, on behalf of the people of New York, challenged a decision by respondents, two district boards of inspectors of election, in which the boards found they were entitled to vote in a general election for president, but did not afford them a reasonable means to do so.


OVERVIEW: It was determined on election day, by the boards, that the voters were qualified, and were improperly denied the right to vote. Each voter had appeared at his local polling place an hour or two before the closing time for the polling places, and had had their eligibility determined at 20 minutes before the closing hour. Upon determining eligibility, the board sent the voters back to their local polling place, but that was insufficient time for the voters to arrive at the local polling place in order to vote. This action was brought to determine if the boards' actions were correct. The court held that the board was required to do one of two alternate things under these circumstances. It was required to provide a facility for the exercise of the vote at the place where the voter's application was officially upheld, or it was required to direct the local polling place to remain open for a reasonable period to await the voter's arrival. The reasoning was that the right to vote was fundamental, and the administrative convenience of the board could not act to prevent the voter his fundamental right to vote.


OUTCOME: The court found the board was required to either provide a central facility for the exercise of the unlawfully refused vote, or it must direct the local polling place to remain open for a reasonable period to await the voter's arrival.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Elections -- right to vote.

If a voter timely appears at his local polling place and is denied his right to vote by the elections officials presiding there, but goes to the county board of elections, where his right to vote is upheld by a Supreme Court Justice sitting there, before the time that the polls close but too late for him to return to his local polling place before it closes, the board of elections must either provide a facility for him to exercise his vote at the place where his application to vote is officially upheld, or direct the local polling place to remain open for a reasonable period to await his arrival.

 

2362 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mantel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 439; 388 N.Y.S.2d 565; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2682



November 10, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendants' motion is, therefore, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion to dismiss three health and building code violations on the ground that the summonses were issued pursuant to a plan of selective and discriminatory law enforcement of the Administrative Code against "sex related" establishments. Defendants were employees of an adult bookstore in the downtown area, which specialized in viewing machines for "peep shows."


OVERVIEW: The people claimed that the task force's concentrated prosecution of health and building violations against certain establishments was a legitimate response to the public concern over conditions in the midtown area which included the recognized, long-standing problem of the high incidence of crime and general deterioration of the area associated with the proliferation of businesses catering to commercial sex. At issue, was whether constitutional boundaries had been violated by the enforcement activities conducted by the task force. A decision had been made to deploy resources against sex-related establishments. Defendants claimed their right to nondiscriminatory prosecution under the Fourteenth Amendment had been violated. The people conceded that defendants had been purposefully selected for intentional emphasis on prosecution. The court held the concentrated effort of the task force, assuming it was aimed at sex-related establishments, was rationally related to legitimate law enforcement objectives. The court held that until the city had resources to prosecute all code violations, the selective enforcement decided upon was both rational and permissible.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- building and health code violations -- selective enforcement.

Although purposeful selective enforcement of building and health code violations has been shown against defendants, employees of "sex related" establishments, by the Midtown Task Force, defendants have been unable to demonstrate that the decision to concentrate enforcement upon members of their class was based upon an arbitrary classification. The test of whether a prosecutor has made a reasonable classification should be judged along lines of permissible prosecutorial discretion, as well as by whether a particular classification bears a rational relationship to the broad purposes of the criminal law and is reasonably related to law enforcement objectives. The mandate of the Federally funded Midtown Enforcement Project is the "identification, investigation, and prosecution of illegal activities endemic to the midtown area of New York County." As a result of past ineffective efforts to curtail these illegal activities, it was determined to concentrate efforts on insuring compliance with safety and health-related ordinances. This concentrated effort, even [***2] if aimed at sex-related establishments, is rationally related to legitimate law enforcement objectives. Health and building codes are well within the police power. Accordingly, in view of the lack of resources to vigorously prosecute all such offenses, the selective enforcement of the Administrative Code of the City of New York decided upon herein is both rational and permissible.

 

2363 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hasson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]
