Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, Richmond County


89 Misc. 2d 28; 390 N.Y.S.2d 507; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2812



November 9, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the indictment in the interest of justice and, also, because of the denial of the right to a speedy trial is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was an attorney that was indicted for bribery of a witness in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 215.00 and perjury in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 210, sought dismissal of the indictment obtained against him based upon the denial of a speedy trial and in the interest of justice.


OVERVIEW: Defendant claimed that the jury panel selected for his trial did not fairly represent the community because females had been systematically excluded from jury service by allowing them to excuse themselves and there had been a delay in the trial that denied him a right to a speedy trial. The court determined that the jury panel that had been selected for his trial was not representative of the community in that it had a percentage of females that was not similar to the makeup of the community. The court further determined that after an objection was sustained to the jury panel, a jury panel was not selected that was consistent with the makeup of the community. Defendant was denied a speedy trial by the failure of the State to provide a forum for the charges brought against him.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment against defendant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- composition of jury -- speedy trial.

The charges against defendant arose out of incidents which occurred in early 1972, but an indictment was not signed and filed until April of 1974, with the case being set down for trial in February of 1975. In January of 1975 the United States Supreme Court decided Taylor v Louisiana (419 U.S. 522), and thereafter defendant moved to dismiss the indictment because of the New York statutory exemption of women from jury service and their consequent underrepresentation on the Grand Jury which voted the indictment. A challenge was also made to the composition of the petit jury venire. The case was then adjourned to await reconstitution of the Richmond County venire or pool of qualified jurors to bring it into compliance with constitutional requirements. The motion to dismiss the indictment in the interest of justice and because of the denial of the right to a speedy trial is granted. The entire petit jury panel of Richmond County is hopelessly and irredeemably tainted by methods of [***2] qualification which are contrary to established constitutional requirements, State law and court rules in that the systems and procedures for selecting qualified persons for the jury pool precludes the obtaining of a fair cross section of the community as to age and sex, and is overly imbalanced by persons who have previously served. Since defendant was ready for trial in February, 1975 and the county has had considerable opportunity to correct the unlawful condition, the State has failed to fulfill its obligation of providing a forum for the resolution of the charges it has brought. Nor can the condition be corrected by a make-shift selection from the present jury roll, since there is no reason why, almost two years later, a court should have to invent an impromptu method of giving defendant a constitutionally acceptable jury.

 

2364 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Perez v. Dumpson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Queens County


88 Misc. 2d 506; 389 N.Y.S.2d 279; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2696



November 8, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The plaintiffs' complaint is dismissed for lack of legal sufficiency, with costs to defendants.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, current and former public assistance recipients, filed suit against defendants, the New York City Department of Social Services and its commissioner, challenging their policy of obtaining confessions of judgment. Plaintiffs filed an application for a determination that the suit be permitted to be maintained as a "class action" pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 9 and that, as such "class action," summary judgment be granted to plaintiffs.


OVERVIEW: The case arose from the overpayments made by defendants to recipients in excess of the sum to which they were entitled or because of fraud or ineligibility. Plaintiffs sought summary judgment seeking to declare that defendants' practice of taking confessions of judgment from former and present recipients of public assistance who received overpayments of assistance be enjoined; that the confessions of judgment previously obtained from former and present recipients and filed in the state courts be vacated, and that defendants make restitution to those members of the class from whom payments were received or exacted through court sanctioned enforcement of judgment procedures. The court dismissed plaintiffs' complaint. The court was of the opinion that it could not be said that defendants' effort to recoup funds fraudulently or improperly obtained from defendants by unjustly or fraudulently enriched recipients was an act of assuming unauthorized power, power beyond legislative intended limits. The court held that the past or future acts of defendants in accepting, receiving, or even in demanding confessions of judgment for overpayments was not in derogation of the common law.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed plaintiffs' complaint for lack of legal sufficiency in plaintiffs' action challenging defendants policy, procedure, and practice of obtaining confessions of judgment.


HEADNOTES

Social services -- recoupment of overpayments -- "confessions of judgments".

1. Defendant New York City Department of Social Services has the inherent right and implied power to demand and obtain "confessions of judgment" from former and present recipients of public assistance who received "overpayments" of assistance as the result of ineligibility or misrepresentation or concealment by the recipient. The department has no authority to enter into a "stipulation" relinquishing its right to recover "overpayments" of assistance. The fact that the Social Services Law does not specifically authorize the department to obtain "confessions of judgment" in order to recover "overpayments" does not prohibit the department from utilizing said method of recoupment. To criminally or civilly prosecute recipients who have obtained public assistance illegally because of ineligibility or fraud, or to make legal efforts to seek reimbursement from those who have obtained "overpayments" erroneously is within the implied power of the department if not statutorily spelled out. Section 106-b of [***2] the Social Services Law only requires the department to recoup "overpayments" from eligible recipients who received such "overpayments" through honest error on the part of the recipient or the department by reducing future payments to such recipient. Other "overpayments" whether made to "ineligible" persons or to persons who received assistance by fraudulent methods or representations may be collected by whatever legal means are available.

2. Plaintiff's action to enjoin the department from taking "confessions of judgment" from former and present recipients of public assistance who received "overpayments" of assistance, to vacate "confessions of judgment" previously filed and to compel "restitution", cannot be maintained as a class action ( CPLR 902) since there are no questions of law and fact common to a "class" which predominate over any questions affecting individual members nor are the claims or defenses typical of a specific class. Since "overpayments" can have an innocent as well as fraudulent base, each matter must be considered separately.

 

2365 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Country-Wide Ins. Co. v. Di Bona


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 798; 388 N.Y.S.2d 990; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2747



November 4, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, petitioner's motions to vacate or modify the award is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner insurance company sought a judgment vacating or modifying an award rendered in favor of respondent, rendered in an arbitration proceeding involving an insurance claim.


OVERVIEW: The insurance company requested vacation or modification of an arbitration award relative to a claim for insurance benefits under the no-fault provisions of N.Y. Ins. Law § 675. The insurance company disputed the inclusion of a $ 1000 award of attorney's fees on a claim for $ 265. The court affirmed the award holding that the alleged "unreasonableness" of the arbitrator's findings was not a basis for vacating an award under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7511. The court concluded that if an arbitration award was reviewed for unreasonableness then the court would be required to pass on the record of innumerable arbitration awards and the parties would be forced into a second tier of litigation. The court further held that vacating an award because it was excessive under the circumstances, because it was "unreasonable," an "abuse of discretion," or "shocking to one's sense of fairness," imported into N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7511 proceedings a degree of substantive review which it was the purpose of the statutory scheme to preclude. The court also found that the award did not violate public policy because the award did not countervail law or declared policy.


OUTCOME: The court denied the insurance company's motions to vacate or modify the arbitration award in favor of respondent.


HEADNOTES

Arbitration -- scope of review.

The compulsory nature of arbitration of a claim for no-fault automobile insurance benefits does not subject the proceeding to a broader scope of review than that authorized under CPLR 7511, and review under CPLR 7511, utilizing a substantial evidence test, does not warrant interference with the fixing of attorney's fees. To vacate an award because it is excessive, unreasonable, an abuse of discretion or shocking to one's sense of fairness would import into CPLR article 75 a degree of substantive review not therein intended. So long as an award is not completely irrational, it must prevail, and it is not improper in a small but meritorious claim that the value of legal services rendered might exceed the claim.

 

2366 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Velez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Trial Term, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 378; 388 N.Y.S.2d 519; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2674



October 26, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Prior to trial, defendant moved to suppress evidence and incriminating statements. The motion was denied but the court postponed its written order. Defendant was convicted him of murder in the first degree and murder in the second degree, and was sentenced to death. Defendant also moved for an order declaring the mandatory death penalty prescribed by N.Y. Penal Law § 60.06 unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of murder in the first degree and murder in the second degree. Defendant claimed that certain statements he made to police and certain physical evidence should have been suppressed. The court held that defendant was adequately informed of his Miranda rights, and knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently elected to waive them when he made the statements he sought to suppress. Also, the court determined that facts were sufficient to warrant the police belief that fleeing fugitives were in defendant's apartment when they elected to make a warrantless entry into the dwelling. The police's warrantless entry into defendant's apartment was thus justified. Defendant's motion to suppress physical evidence and statements was thus denied. Further, the court found that the mandatory death penalty prescribed by N.Y. Penal Law § 60.06 was unconstitutional as violative of U.S. Const. amends. VIII, XIV prohibitions against cruel and unusual punishment, as it precluded a trial court from considering the character and circumstances of a defendant prior to imposition of a death sentence. Defendant's conviction was thus entered, and he was given a life sentence.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to suppress and entered judgment that convicted defendant on two counts of murder. However, the court determined that the New York statute that mandated imposing the death sentence on defendant was unconstitutional because it prohibited a trial court's consideration of the character and individual circumstances of a defendant prior to imposition of a death sentence. Defendant was thus sentenced to life imprisonment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- mandatory death penalty -- cruel and unusual punishment.

1. The mandatory death penalty prescribed by section 60.06 of the Penal Law upon a conviction for murder in the first degree (Penal Law, § 125.27) is unconstitutional as violative of the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against the imposition of cruel and unusual punishment. Defendant, who killed a police officer while participating in an armed bank robbery with two other codefendants, is therefore sentenced to life imprisonment upon his conviction for murder in the first degree. The death penalty for an aggravated form of murder is constitutionally permissible only if the sentence is discretionary and individualized within the framework of clearly prescribed and reasonable guidelines that safeguard against the arbitrary and capricious imposition of the death sentence (see Gregg v Georgia, 428 U.S.    ; 19 Cr L 3249). The Eighth Amendment does not sanction a death sentencing scheme which either rests upon unbridled jury discretion or which inexorably imposes a death sentence upon every defendant convicted of a capital offense. Section 60.06 is unconstitutional since it proscribes any semblance of a [***2] discretionary sentence and fails to focus on the character, background and propensities of the convicted defendant. The statutory scheme unconstitutionally accords neither the court nor the jury an opportunity to consider and assess any mitigating or aggravating factors respecting the offense or the offender. Developing standards of decency in a mature and stable society repudiate an automatic death sentence however heinous the condemned conduct may be. The constitutional defectiveness of a mandatory death sentencing scheme is not corrected by legislative action that narrows the scope of capital murders to those where the defined attendant circumstances describe certain aggravating factors. A bifurcated trial is required before the ultimate sanction of death is imposed upon a convicted murderer. The United States Constitution requires that a jury, before recommending or fixing the death penalty, be accorded an opportunity to consider the character and background of the defendant as well as the attendant circumstances of the crime itself. The sentencing authority must consider, after a guilty verdict, why the death penalty should be imposed and why it should not be imposed. This [***3] consideration must be made within the context of clear standards and guidelines.

2. Defendant, a diabetic who was wounded in the upper arm during the course of the robbery, knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently waived his Miranda rights. Defendant's diabetic condition and the minor shoulder wound did not impair his ability to appreciate and understand his Miranda rights, nor did his physical condition impair his capacity to effectively waive such rights. Defendant was not subjected to lengthy or harassing questioning. His confessions to the police investigators were the product of a "rational intellect and a free will". Defendant was composed and in full control when he made the incriminating statements.

3. A steno pad containing the bank floor plan and a "stickup note" were lawfully seized from defendant's apartment pursuant to a valid search warrant. Defendant was seized immediately after the shooting. However, his two codefendants escaped. Defendant admitted that the robbery had been planned in his apartment the night before and then gave the police the keys to his apartment which was located less than one mile from the victimized bank. The police lawfully proceeded [***4] to make a warrantless and unannounced entry of defendant's apartment for the sole purpose of searching for and effecting the arrest of two dangerous and armed robbers who had just perpetrated a felony murder. Once inside the apartment, the police observed the steno pad and "stickup note" in plain view on a coffee table. Once they determined that the two fugitives were not in the premises, the police left the apartment to obtain a search warrant which was issued at 8:40 p.m. without a "night time" search authorization ( CPL art 690). The search was properly commenced before 9:00 p.m. The fact that one item of evidence was found and seized after 9:00 p.m. does not vitiate the validity of the warrant and the concomitant search and seizure.

 

2367 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Clinton v. Whalen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


88 Misc. 2d 958; 389 N.Y.S.2d 229; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2783



October 25, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Respondent's motion to dismiss is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent health commissioner filed a motion, seeking dismissal of petitioner funeral director's application to prohibit the commissioner from conducting a hearing pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 3451(3), investigating charges that the funeral director aided and abetted an unlicensed person to practice funeral directing or undertaking for a number of specified funerals.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner sought dismissal of the funeral director's application to prohibit the commissioner from conducting a hearing to investigate charges that the director aided and abetted an unlicensed person to practice funeral directing. The court granted the commissioner's motion to dismiss, rejecting the director's argument that provisions of the Health Department Administrative Rules and Regulations, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, §§ 77.7, 78.1, were unreasonable and conflicted with the statutory scheme of the Public Health Law pertaining to the regulation of funeral directing. N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 3401(1)(b) empowered the commissioner to govern and regulate the conduct and transaction of the business and practice of funeral directing, undertaking and embalming. Thus, the court held that it followed that any rules adopted in pursuance of this statutory scheme of regulation were valid. In the opinion of the court it was reasonable that only a licensed funeral director should arrange with one charged with the control of burial for the sale, purchase, or rental of funeral merchandise or services.


OUTCOME: The court granted the commissioner's motion to dismiss the funeral director's application to prohibit the commissioner from conducting the hearing.


HEADNOTES

Dead bodies -- funeral directing -- funeral directing by unlicensed person.

1. A Health Department regulation, 10 NYCRR 77.7, which provides that only a duly licensed funeral director or undertaker shall make arrangements with one having the right to control the incidents of burial "for the purchase, sale or rental of funeral merchandise, services or paraphernalia" ( 10 NYCRR 77.7 [a] [5] [iii]) is not invalid insofar as it pertains to petitioner's funeral home operations. The section is not unreasonable and does not conflict with the statutory scheme of the Public Health Law pertaining to the regulation of funeral directing, whereby the Commissioner of Health is empowered to "govern and regulate the conduct and transaction of the business and practice of funeral directing, undertaking and embalming" ( Public Health Law, § 3401, subd 1, par [b]). It is reasonable that only a licensed funeral director should arrange with one charged with the control or burial for the sale, purchase or rental of funeral merchandise or services, since such a requirement serves to carry out the legislative direction for regulation of the [***2] funeral business.

2. Nor is 10 NYCRR 78.1, which merely implements a statutory direction ( Public Health Law, § 3440-a) by specifying the form of the itemized list of services and merchandise, invalid. The requirement in the regulation that the statement be furnished by licensed personnel follows almost precisely the statutory language.

3. A writ of prohibition is not a proper remedy in this situation, since any determination made after the hearing to be scheduled by respondent is reviewable ( Public Health Law, § 3450, subd 3).

 

2368 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Horizon Adirondack Corp. v. State


Claim No. 58949


Court of Claims of New York


88 Misc. 2d 619; 388 N.Y.S.2d 235; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2714; 7 ELR 20122



October 21, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The defendant's motion to dismiss the claim herein is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant State moved to dismiss plaintiff property owner's action alleging that 1973 N.Y. Laws 348, which provided for a comprehensive and extensive system of land use controls applicable to privately-owned land within the Adirondack Park, constituted a "taking" of its property. The state contended that the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction and that the claim failed to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The sole question presented was whether 1973 N.Y. Laws 348, which for the purposes of the motion was assumed to have substantial and severe economic impact upon the market value of the property owner's real property, might be considered as being tantamount to a de facto appropriation of such property for which just compensation must be awarded. The essence of the property owner's allegations of "taking" were that the controls imposed by the State were so restrictive that it had become infeasible to develop the property as planned or, in fact, to put it to any reasonable economic use. The court held that such were not the type of governmental acts that would constitute a "taking" as that term was used in appropriation law. On its face 1973 N.Y. Laws 348 was regulatory in nature. Its effect was not aimed specifically or directly at the property in issue. Rather, its restrictions were generally applied throughout the park, and would not necessarily be considered a "taking" of private property in all cases. The act was not an "avowed taking statute." Thus, the court answered the question in the negative.


OUTCOME: The court granted the State's motion to dismiss the claim.


HEADNOTES

Environmental conservation -- Adirondack Park Agency Act -- de facto appropriation of property.

1. Claimant's action for money damages is not a constitutional challenge to the validity of the Adirondack Park Agency Act (Executive Law, § 800 et seq.), wherein the demand for money is merely incidental, but is a claim that the controls imposed under the act deprive claimant of almost all economic use of its property and constitute a taking. Accordingly, the Court of Claims has jurisdiction.

2. Assuming a substantial and severe economic impact upon the value of claimant's real property, the land use regulatory act nevertheless does not constitute a de facto taking for which compensation must be awarded. Although the restrictions are a direct legal restraint upon the economic use of the property, any interest taken is not compensable, since the restrictions merely alter the value of the property and make it infeasible for claimant to use the property as planned. Allegations of such governmental action are more consistent with cases dealing with unreasonable exercises of police power than with those [***2] brought under the theory of de facto appropriation. On its face the act is regulatory and the required filing of a map, rather than evidencing a taking, is a common feature of zoning law. Proximity to State forest preserve lands, as a basis for project classification, is not an indicia of a taking but of regulation. Absent a systematic program of acquisition and condemnation, it cannot be said that a land use measure is necessarily a taking.

3. The balancing of public and private interests required by the restriction of Adirondack Park lands would best be evaluated in an action in Supreme Court to have the controls declared unconstitutional in view of various policy considerations, including the vast financial impact which an award of money damages would entail. Accordingly, the claim should be dismissed.

 

2369 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sorbonne Apartments Co. v. Board of Health


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 970; 390 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2786



October 20, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court finds the action of the respondent is not arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable and accordingly the application is denied and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioner landlord sought review and to annul the enactment of New York City, N.Y., Health Code § 131.15 by respondents, the Board of Health of the City of New York and its members, on the primary ground that respondents proceeded in excess of the Board's jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: Following a study regarding injuries and deaths to children under 10 as a result of widow falls, the Board enacted § 131.15, which required landlords to install window guards in apartments where children under 10 years of age resided and in the public halls of such buildings. The court dismissed the landlord's petition and found that New York City, N.Y., Charter §§ 1703-1706 granted the Board's parent, the Health Services Administration, power over all matters affecting health and the preservation of life in New York City. The court reasoned that New York City, N.Y., Health Code § 131.15 was designed to eliminate deaths and injuries and was within the powers to provide for security of life and health pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Charter § 1706. The court found that: 1) the Board conducted extensive hearings and provided proper notice pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 1119-1.0; 2) the statute did not place an unconstitutional burden on the landlord when weighed against the public gain; 3) the regulation was presumed constitutional and the landlord failed to rebut the presumption; and 4) respondents' actions were not arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court denied the landlord's application and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Health -- window guards to prevent children from falling -- Board of Health of City of New York.

1. The Board of Health of the City of New York was acting within its jurisdiction when it enacted section 131.15 of the New York City Health Code, which requires all owners of multiple dwellings to install window guards in apartments where children under 10 years of age reside and in the public halls of such buildings. The city charter grants to the Health Services Administration power over all matters affecting health and the preservation of life and section 131.15 is designed to eliminate deaths and injuries from window falls.

2. The cost of complying with the regulation does not impose an unconstitutional burden on property owners when weighed against the public gain.

3. The regulation is not vague with respect to the types of guards found to be acceptable and the presumption of constitutionality has not been rebutted.

4. The action of the board of health was not arbitrary, capricious or unreasonable and, accordingly,  [***2] the petition is dismissed.

 

2370 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 590; 388 N.Y.S.2d 221; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2709



October 15, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the above-stated reasons the defendant's motion is granted in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was arrested for violating N.Y. Penal Law § 240.37, loitering for the purposes of engaging in prostitution. Defendant filed a motion seeking to strike down § 240.37 on the ground that it violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 6, 12 in that it was vague and encouraged arbitrary and discriminatory law enforcement.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and an unidentified male exited a building shortly after entering, whereupon an officer arrested defendant for violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.37. Defendant claimed that § 240.37 was unconstitutional. The court agreed with defendant. The court held that (1) § 240.37 was void for vagueness because a reasonable man could not have known from reading the statute exactly what actions were prohibited; (2) the presumption of constitutionality was overcome because the statute impeded freedom of speech; and (3) the statute proscribed conduct that would ordinarily be innocent.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- loitering -- loitering for purpose of engaging in prostitution offense.

 Section 240.37 of the Penal Law, which prohibits loitering for the purpose of engaging in a prostitution offense, inhibits free speech and is so vague and overbroad as to be unconstitutional. It proscribes conduct which would ordinarily be innocent but becomes criminal when it is done for the purposes of prostitution, and leaves it to the subjective judgment of the police officer to determine, by observation of the conduct, whether or not it is criminal, without providing any objective standards which can serve as a guide and transform a mere suspicion into probable cause for arrest.

 

2371 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Legrand


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


88 Misc. 2d 41; 387 N.Y.S.2d 807; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2378



October 14, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants' motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion for an order pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.35(1) dismissing the indictment issued against them on the grounds that the grand jury that issued it was improperly constituted. Defendants challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Jud. Law § 598 on due process and equal protection grounds.


OVERVIEW: Neither defendant was a public employee, and neither explained how he was singled out for unequal treatment under § 598. The court stated that there was a strong presumption that a statute enacted by a legislature was constitutional, and the burden of proving that a statute was unconstitutional was on defendants. The court determined that defendants failed to explain how they had been singled out for unequal treatment, different from that afforded other defendants indicted in New York. The court held that because defendants were not public employees, it was all more unlikely that the mandate of the statute had an unequal impact upon them due to the exclusion of the group. The court further held that § 598 was constitutional because it was not apparent that the exempting public employees from grand jury service posed any substantial threat to the remaining pool of prospective grand jurors. The court concluded that the state was free to grant exemption from jury service to individuals engaged in particular occupations.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- exclusion of certain public officers and employees from Grand Jury service.

Section 598 of the Judiciary Law, which excludes from Grand Jury service a "public officer or employee of the United States government, or of any state, city, or municipality, or of any political subdivision of any of them, or any official board, authority, council, commission, corporation, or other agency of any of them, receiving annual compensation in excess of one thousand dollars from the aforesaid sources", is constitutional.

 

2372 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Harris


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Wayne County


88 Misc. 2d 60; 387 N.Y.S.2d 796; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2622



October 12, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner executor sought an order for the rejection of a claim against the estate. Claimant department of social services (department) requested reimbursement of Medicaid payments made on behalf of the decedent's husband.


OVERVIEW: Decedent's husband received Medicaid until his death. After the decedent died the department filed a claim against her estate for reimbursement of the Medicaid paid to her husband. The executor contested the claim. The claim filed for reimbursement of Medicaid paid to her was uncontested. The court rejected the claim. The court held that there was no right to reimbursement for Medicaid correctly paid to a recipient from a responsible relative of the recipient. The department could recover Medicaid for medical assistance properly paid only from the estate of the recipient under certain conditions. The Legislature intended to meet all necessary Federal requirements under the Social Security Act. Thus, the court was required to interpret the law to insure that the Legislature's intent was carried out and so as not to jeopardize Federal reimbursement. The court determined that Congress did not want to permit the impoverishment of a recipient of medical assistance, or his otherwise responsible relatives, except in limited circumstances.


OUTCOME: The court rejected the department's claim filed against the decedent's estate for recovery of medical assistance paid to her husband during his lifetime.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social services -- recovery of correctly paid medical assistance.

The Department of Social Services is not entitled to reimbursement from decedent's estate for Medicaid correctly paid to her husband during his lifetime. Prior to his death at age 78, decedent's husband had been paid Medicaid in the amount of $ 25,618.79. Decedent, who was 82 years of age at the time of her death, had been paid Medicaid in the amount of $ 513.60. The estate of decedent's husband had no assets which could be applied to the department's claim for reimbursement for the medical assistance paid him. Decedent's estate, after payment of expenses totals $ 20,000. It is the intent of Congress not to permit the impoverishment of a recipient of medical assistance, or his otherwise responsible relatives, except under limited circumstances. No recovery for medical assistance properly paid may be had from the estate of a deceased recipient except from the estate of a deceased recipient who was 65 or over when he received such assistance and then only if he is not survived by a surviving spouse (US Code, tit 42, § 1396a, subd [a]). Recovery is permitted from a living spouse providing such spouse was [***2] of "sufficient ability" during the period of assistance ( Social Services Law, § 369). However, there is no statutory authority allowing recovery from the estate of such spouse.

 

2373 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dwyer v. Kahn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


88 Misc. 2d 73; 387 N.Y.S.2d 535; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2625



October 4, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, summary judgment is granted to the defendant, the constitutionality of the rules is declared, and the plaintiffs' complaint is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Chairman of the Public Service Commission of the State of New York filed a motion for summary judgment in a declaratory judgment action brought by plaintiff public employees to test the constitutionality of rules adopted by the Commission. The public employees filed a cross-motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The Chairman argued that the rules concerning the disclosure of private financial holdings by the public employees were constitutional. The court stated that the rules under N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 74(3)(g) and (h) were intended to avoid conflicts of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest by public employees who held any interest in public utility companies. The court noted that no disclosure was required at all if the public employees signed a sworn certification that they were in compliance with the statute. The court also determined that there was an exemption for the public employees if they disclosed to the Commission the names of the companies in which they had holdings, which threatened a conflict of interest and obtained permission to keep them. The court held that the public employees were not required to disclose all of their holdings and there was a process for judicial review of the Commission's decision. The court reasoned that the state had a compelling state interest in the financial privacy of its public employees and a limited intrusion was justified. The court concluded that the statute was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the Chairman's motion for summary judgment and declared that the Commission's rules were constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Public officers -- disclosure of conflict of interest financial holdings.

Rules adopted by the Public Service Commission requiring covered employees to disclose conflict of interest financial holdings to the secretary of the commission, in accordance with the legislative policy of having public employees avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest (Public Officers Law, § 74, subd 3, pars [g], [h]), are not unconstitutionally broad. The rules prohibit the covered employees and their spouses and minor children from holding stocks, bonds or other interests in public utility corporations or in companies which derive 25% of revenues from supplying equipment to such utilities. No exemptions are allowed for holdings in the utility itself except for the holdings of a spouse or minor child. An exemption may be sought by disclosing to the secretary of the commission only the names of companies in which they have holdings that threaten a conflict of interest and obtaining permission to keep them. The State has a legitimate [***2] governmental interest in preventing conflicts of interest on the part of public officials and employees without unreasonably intruding into the personal privacy of such public employees. The rules adopted by the commission do not require an indiscriminate public disclosure of all holdings of every employee covered by the rules so as to invade constitutional privacy. No disclosure is required if there is private compliance and disclosure is only required in a questionable situation in which the employee desires to retain his holdings, and then the disclosure is only required to be made to the secretary of the commission for a ruling which is subject to judicial review. Intrusion upon privacy is properly limited to matters of public concern by public employees and no employee is thereby barred from any investment that does not constitute a conflict of interest.

 

2374 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Pergament


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


District Court of New York, Second District, Nassau County


87 Misc. 2d 1098; 387 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2368



September 29, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the informations against them alleging that Town of Hempstead, N.Y., Code § 114-1, which they were charged with violating, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with violating Town of Hempstead, N.Y., Code § 114-1, which prohibited commercial sales on certain holidays. Defendants alleged that § 114-1 was unconstitutional. The court stated that § 114-1 was constitutional because it did not prohibit all commercial sales. The court reasoned that the ordinance was merely a regulation of business hours and not a prohibition of business on Memorial Day and Independence Day. The court held that the ordinance provided for fair regulation, and it was not in any sense prohibitive of the conduct of business on the days involved. In conclusion, the court determined that as long as the relationship between the means used and the end desired was not arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable, the court could not substitute its judgment over that of the Town.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion to dismiss the informations and vacated the stay of prosecution contained in the order to show cause.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Municipal corporations -- ordinance regulating business hours on holidays -- constitutionality of statute.

Section 1 of chapter 114 of the Code of the Town of Hempstead, which provides for the closing of businesses from 9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. on Memorial Day and Independence Day is a reasonable regulation and is, therefore, constitutional. The ordinance provides for a fair regulation of business hours, and is not in any sense prohibitive of the conduct of business on the days involved. Accordingly, the informations must stand.

 

2375 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Finch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Village of Monticello, Sullivan County


88 Misc. 2d 581; 388 N.Y.S.2d 820; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2707



September 29, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is in all respects denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In two cases, defendants filed motions to dismiss charges that they violated a village ordinance on the ground that the ordinance was a nullity. The ordinance prohibited the consumption of alcoholic beverages on any public street, public sidewalk, or public parking area within the village limits.


OVERVIEW: Defendants contended the village was without authority to enact the ordinance and that the ordinance deprived defendants of due process of law under the state and federal constitutions. The court disagreed. Under N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2, N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10, and N.Y. Village Law § 4-412, the village had broad power to regulate the use of the village streets, sidewalks, and parking areas and to provide for the preservation and promotion of the health, safety, and general welfare of its inhabitants. Any use of the streets that interfered unduly with the use of the streets by others for travel could doubtless be prohibited. The court found that the ordinance was unambiguous and left no question as to what conduct was prohibited. Further, the ordinance did not violate defendants' due process rights. It was a reasonable exercise of the municipal police power. In the light of local circumstances, the village board might reasonably have determined that the conduct prohibited would be unnecessarily offensive to the visual sensibilities as well as the safety, comfort, and general welfare of its citizens.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss the charges against them.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- restriction of public consumption of alcoholic beverages -- aesthetic considerations.

1. The Village Ordinance of the Village of Monticello, which prohibits any person from drinking or consuming "an alcoholic beverage on any public street, public sidewalk or public parking area" within the village limits, is a valid exercise of the municipal police power reasonably calculated to achieve a legitimate public purpose. The village has the broad power to regulate the use of the village streets, sidewalks and parking areas and to provide, by local law, for the good government of the village and the preservation and promotion of the health, safety and general welfare of its inhabitants (Village Law, § 4-412; Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10; NY Const, art IX, § 2). Aesthetic considerations and the appearance of the community are proper subjects of legislative concern in enacting reasonable laws designed to promote health and safety. The ordinance does not prohibit the public consumption of nonalcoholic beverages nor does it prohibit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on private property or in [***2] any place other than a public street, public sidewalk or public parking area. The village board reasonably determined that the conduct prohibited would be unnecessarily offensive to the visual sensibilities as well as the safety, comfort and general welfare of its citizens and would materially and economically detract from the community or impair good order or adversely affect trade.

2. The fact that the State has pre-empted the field in the regulation of the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages does not prohibit the enactment of the village ordinance which only restricts the public consumption of alcoholic beverages and does not deal with becoming intoxicated nor with the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages. The village has not prohibited that which the State has specifically permitted.

 

2376 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Nassau Chapter, Civil Service Employees Asso. v. County of Nassau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


88 Misc. 2d 289; 387 N.Y.S.2d 772; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2667; 93 L.R.R.M. 2615



September 28, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a civil services employees association (CSEA), filed a suit against defendant county to recover damages on behalf of certain members who were not granted an annual salary increase.


OVERVIEW: Under a collective bargaining agreement executed by the county and the CSEA, employees were granted annual salary increases. After the county forecast a significant budget deficit, it directed administrative department heads to suspend the payment of the salary increases to county employees who earned more than a certain amount. The CSEA filed a complaint against the county and challenged the suspension of the salary increases. The court held that the suspension violated the collective bargaining agreement and that the affected employees were entitled to recover the monies withheld. There had been no legislatively declared emergency in the county, only an apprehension of an impending budget deficit. Judicial relief accorded to a nearby city, which had experienced a fiscal crisis and which was the object of a financial emergency act, was not applicable to the county in the absence of a legislatively declared emergency in the county. Moreover, the classifications relating to those employees whose salary increases were withheld violated equal protection. Withholding salary increases from one percent of the labor force would have a marginal impact on the projected deficit.


OUTCOME: The court held that the suspension of salary increases to a small group of county employees violated a collective bargaining agreement and that the employees could recover the monies that were withheld.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Counties -- fiscal emergency -- suspension of salary increases.

1. Defendant Nassau County improperly withheld salary increments due on January 1, 1975 to employees earning in excess of $ 25,000 per annum in violation of the "graded service plan" in the parties' collective bargaining agreement which grants annual step increments to all county employees who are in the employ of the county on January 1 of each year. The county Commissioner of Social Services, on his own initiative, improperly withheld the annual step increment from employees who had not been in the employ of the Social Services Department for less than one month prior to January 1, 1975. In response to a forecasted $ 4,000,000 budget deficit for 1975, the County Executive directed administrative department heads to suspend the payment of annual step increments in salary to all county employees earning in excess of $ 25,000 per annum, who then numbered 45 employees out of 14,000. Although the collective bargaining agreement provided that the head of a department could disapprove the granting of any increment, the parties by past practice interpreted the contract so as to allow the employer to withhold the increment [***2] from an employee only for cause. The county's fiscal emergency did not justify its actions against a handful of employees. The suspension of benefits due government employees may be permissible in a time of extreme emergency. However, unlike the New York City fiscal emergency which caused the Legislature to suspend all "increases in salary or wages of employees of the city" (New York State Financial Emergency Act for City of New York; L 1975, ch 868, § 2, as amd by L 1975, ch 870), there was no legislative declaration of fiscal emergency in the county, merely an apprehension by the Chief Executive of an impending budget deficit and the anticipated tax increase to flow therefrom.

2. The selection of employees to be denied salary increments based only on the two standards of high income and late hirings created arbitrary unconstitutional classifications, which did not bear any reasonable relationship to the purpose put forth by the county. The withholding of the step increment alone of 1% of the labor force would not do much to decrease a $ 4,000,000 budget deficit. Had there been State legislative action declaring a financial emergency in Nassau County followed by local legislative [***3] enactments setting forth a plan at reducing or eliminating this deficit, such classifications may have been constitutional.

3. The county was not empowered to temporarily impair contract rights of its employees because of an emergency in the absence of a legislative declaration that a financial emergency existed.

 

2377 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Di Franco v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 852; 389 N.Y.S.2d 968; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2760



September 27, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the cross motion to dismiss the petition is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent City of New York sought dismissal of petitioner policeman's N.Y.C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding for reinstatement to the police department.


OVERVIEW: The policeman was discharged from the police department because he was not a U.S. citizen when he applied. He sought reinstatement on grounds that the statutes and regulations requiring citizenship as a prerequisite for the job were unconstitutional. The City sought, and the court granted, dismissal. Although N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 53, which made U.S. citizenship a prerequisite for appointment to a position in a competitive class, was unconstitutional, the state could still exclude aliens from certain civil service employment if it showed a compelling interest. One such area of employment was the police force. Police played a similar role to jurors, and the state had a compelling interest in excluding aliens from jury service. New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 434a-8, which required citizenship for appointment to the police force, was equivalent to N.Y. Exec. Law § 215(3), which required citizenship to the state police, and was not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the City's motion to dismiss the policeman's petition.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- requirement of citizenship for appointment to police force.

One who has been found not qualified for the position of patrolman in the New York City Police Department because he was not a citizen at the time of his appointment, as required by section 434a-8.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, requiring citizenship for appointment to the city's police force, is not within the class protected by Sugarman v Dougall (413 U.S. 634), in which the United States Supreme Court declared unconstitutional section 53 of the Civil Service Law, requiring citizenship for appointment to any position in the competitive class. In Foley v Connelie (419 F Supp 889), decided subsequent to the Sugarman decision, a United States District Court concluded that that decision did not prohibit a State, upon a showing of a compelling State interest, from excluding aliens from specific areas of employment, and that the police force was an area of employment from which a State might properly exclude aliens. For the reasons set forth in the Foley decision, section 434a-8.0 of the [***2] Administrative Code is not unconstitutional.

 

2378 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Northrup v. Kirwan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Monroe County


88 Misc. 2d 255; 387 N.Y.S.2d 221; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2663



September 24, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all of the foregoing reasons the petitioners' application is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner Commissioner of Elections brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding commenced by an order to show cause to set aside the appointment of respondent Commissioner of Elections.


OVERVIEW: Respondent and petitioner were each nominated as their party's choice for Commissioner of Elections to be recommended to the County Legislature for appointment. Respondent received the greater number of votes and was certified, pursuant to N.Y. Elec. Law § 30, to the County Legislature. The County Legislature rejected the recommendation and its minority members, as permitted by N.Y. Elec. Law § 30(1), voted and appointed respondent. The court denied petitioner's application to have respondent's appointment set aside. Section 30(1) was passed to correct a quirk in the election law whereby the members of one party were asked to approve the Commissioners of Election of a second party. Section 30(1) was both governed and authorized by N.Y. Const. art. II, § 8, and the court denied petitioner's application to declare it unconstitutional. The court held that there were no improprieties in the calling and conduct of the meeting. The court held that courts were reluctant to interfere with the internal affairs of an association as long as its procedures did not violate standards of fair dealing and the claimed irregularities did not violate such standards.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's application to set aside respondent's appointment as Commissioner of Elections.


HEADNOTES

Elections -- Commissioner of Elections -- minority party selection.

1. The procedures of subdivision 1 of section 30 of the Election Law, under which the minority members of the County Legislature select a Commissioner of Elections, are consistent with the home rule provisions of article IX (§ 1, subd [b]) of the State Constitution. In 1963, article IX was adopted to replace former article X and provided that nonelected county officers would be "appointed by such officers of the local government as may be provided by law", indicating a wider mandate than the former appointment by "other county authorities as the Legislature shall direct". Section 8 of article II provides for equal representation by the largest two political parties on boards and among officers charged with various election duties, creating an exception to local home rule requirements.

2. Petitioner incumbent minority party Election Commissioner has no standing as a nonmember of his party's county committee to object to its procedures, but a member petitioner does have such standing, and the incumbent commissioner has standing [***2] to challenge the section of the Election Law on which his ouster depends.

3. The county committee properly gave notice that there would be "New Business" considered at its meeting, and no more particularized notice was needed that a new Commissioner of Elections would be selected, nor was it more than a mere irregularity that notice was sent to committee members who might be elected rather than those in office.

4. Proxies donated for vote on previously unexpressed opinions were valid and were properly included in the counting of a quorum of the party committee, notwithstanding that more than one donee's name appeared on some of the proxies.

5. It was reasonable and proper for the committee to take a preference vote for nominees for the office of Commissioner of Elections, rather than merely determine the fitness of candidates.

 

2379 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Estate of Thomas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, New York County


87 Misc. 2d 1033; 387 N.Y.S.2d 216; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2353



September 22, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Objectant, a decedent's alleged child, opposed an accounting proceeding and introduced an order of filiation and support that declared that the decedent was the child's father. The order was made on the decedent's consent and during his life, and the mother testified that the decedent was the child's father. The proceedings in family court in which the order entered were brought more than six years after the child was born.


OVERVIEW: The child's mother testified that she lived with the decedent without marrying him. The court found that N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 4-1.2(a)(2) permitted inheritance from the putative father if a court of competent jurisdiction had, during the father's life, made an order of filiation declaring paternity in a proceeding instituted during the mother's pregnancy or within two years from the child's birth. It held that even though the paternity proceeding was not brought within the first two years of the child's life, the filiation order was effective to legitimatize the child for inheritance purposes based on the decedent's voluntary admission of paternity during his life made in the paternity proceeding. The court found that the admission constituted a waiver of the statute of limitations and a voluntary relinquishment of that defense. The court found that the waiver was binding on the decedent's estate and that the child was, therefore, entitled to share in the estate as a distributee. The court did not reach the issue of the constitutionality of § 4-1.2.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the objections filed on behalf of the child.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children born out of wedlock -- inheritance -- limitations period applicable to paternity proceedings.

The objectant child born out of wedlock is entitled to inherit from the putative father, although the paternity proceeding resulting in an order of filiation was not commenced until six years after the birth of the child and EPTL 4-1.2 permits inheritance only where such proceeding was instituted within two years. The decedent had consented to the entry of the order, thereby waiving the Statute of Limitations.

 

2380 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Flickinger


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


88 Misc. 2d 64; 387 N.Y.S.2d 957; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2623



September 20, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss his indictment for violation of N.Y. Pub. Health Law §§ 3331 and 3335 on grounds the statute was unconstitutionally vague and that the People had failed to procure authorization for resubmission to the Grand Jury pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(4). The indictment charged that defendant had prescribed a controlled substance not in good faith and not in the course of his professional practice.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted by the Grand Jury of Kings County after a prior indictment on the same charges by the Special Narcotics Court of New York City (sitting in New York County) was dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The court dismissed the indictment. N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(4) provided that upon dismissing an indictment for the reason that it was defective within the meaning of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.25, the order of dismissal constituted a bar to any further prosecution of such charges in any criminal court within the county unless the court authorized the People to resubmit the charges to a Grand Jury. N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.25(2) stated that an indictment was defective when the allegations demonstrated the court did not have jurisdiction of the offense charged. The court noted that the Special Narcotics Court of New York City had citywide jurisdiction over cases involving the sale or possession of narcotic drugs in Kings County. Thus, since that court had not authorized a resubmission of the charges against defendant, the indictment was required to be dismissed. The court upheld the constitutionality of N.Y. Pub. Health Law §§ 3331 and 3335.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to dismiss the indictment for failure of the People to procure authorization for resubmission to the Grand Jury, denied the motion to dismiss the indictment by reason of the unconstitutionality of the provisions of the New York Public Health Law, and granted the motion to inspect the Grand Jury minutes to the limited extent that the court had examined said minutes in camera.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- indictment -- resubmission of charges to Grand Jury upon dismissal of indictment.

1. After the Special Narcotics Court dismissed the first indictment by a New York County Grand Jury as a matter of law, upon the ground of lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and the District Attorney failed to contemporaneously procure authorization for resubmission of the charges to the same or another Grand Jury, pursuant to CPL 210.20 (subd 4), defendant was entitled to be discharged. As a result, the District Attorney is now barred from making an application to the Special Narcotics Court for authorization to resubmit this case to a Kings County Grand Jury. Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss the second indictment is granted.

2. The words "good faith" and "in the course of his professional practice" as used in sections 3331 and 3335 of the Public Health Law have a definite and well-understood meaning, and are clear and unambiguous. Accordingly, the statutes are not unconstitutionally vague.

3. Defendant's motion to inspect the Grand Jury minutes is granted to the limited extent that the court has examined said minutes in camera. There was sufficient evidence before [***2] the Grand Jury to establish reasonable cause to believe that the defendant committed the acts charged.

 

2381 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lee v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, New York County


87 Misc. 2d 1018; 387 N.Y.S.2d 952; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2352



September 17, 1976 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Affirmed by Lee v. Smith, 58 A.D.2d 528, 394 N.Y.S.2d 1021, 1977 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12493 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, 1977)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was petitioner supplemental security income (SSI) recipients' challenge to a provision under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 158(a), which provided state home relief, but rendered petitioners ineligible to receive supplemental public assistance solely on the ground that they were SSI recipients.


OVERVIEW: The supplemental security income (SSI) recipients had filed a challenge to a provision under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 158(a), which provided state home relief, but rendered them ineligible to receive supplemental public assistance solely on the ground that they were SSI recipients. The court issued a judgment in favor of the SSI recipients, and found § 158(a) was unconstitutional in denying them equal protection of the law. The court held that § 158(a), insofar as it barred any individual citizen from asserting his right to public assistance where needed, so that it deprived him of privileges similar to those possessed by his fellow citizens was unconstitutional. The court further held that § 158(a) had violated the SSI recipients' constitutional rights that were established by the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution in that, although they were as needy as other recipients of assistance who also had income, the regulation had operated to their financial disadvantage.


OUTCOME: The court issued a judgment in favor of the supplemental security income (SSI) recipients' favor, and found the social services law under attack that had made them ineligible to receive supplemental public assistance was unconstitutional in denying them equal protection of the law.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Social services -- social security income -- eligibility for State Home Relief.

Subdivision (a) of section 158 of the Social Services Law, insofar as it renders petitioners ineligible to receive State supplemental public assistance solely on the ground that they are recipients of Federal social security income (SSI), is unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection clause since it deprives petitioners of public assistance available to all other needy recipients of home relief and of petitioners' rights to receive "care and support" under article XVII of the State Constitution. Public assistance to the aged, blind and disabled is administered by the Social Security Administration. A basic grant is provided to every aged, blind and disabled person in the country with appropriate provisions authorizing each State to make an additional grant for each SSI recipient so that the Social Security Administration could issue one check for the combined total. In replacing the need based public assistance grant (Social Services Law, § 131-a) with a flat grant to persons receiving SSI, the State has failed to give due recognition to all of the defined standards of need for recipients [***2] who fall into the SSI group. The statute deprives a special class of citizens of the assurance that, when all other programs fail to meet their needs, other grants would be made available to them for that purpose. Had the statute in establishing eligibility requirements contained additional provisions for supplementation of inadequate grants up to the subsistence level for all SSI recipients, its validity could not be questioned. The local welfare district is directed to accept applications on an individual basis, from SSI recipients, for public assistance based on home relief standards similar to those available to all other classes of citizens.

 

2382 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


F. v. F.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, New York County


88 Misc. 2d 165; 387 N.Y.S.2d 593; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2640



September 14, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent father sought to dismiss petitioner mother's petition on behalf of the couple's two illegitimate children for their support on the grounds that § 516 of the New York Family Court Act, dealing with the support of illegitimate children, provided that the performance of a judicially-approved agreement to support them, which the father had signed, barred any other remedy.


OVERVIEW: The father was a physician who cohabited with the mother for 11 years. They resided together as a family with their two sons who were eight and seven years old when the couple separated. Until the separation, the father supported the children and their mother. Upon separation, the father acknowledged paternity of the two boys and signed a support agreement, which agreement was approved by a court. Thereafter, the mother filed the subject petition to increase child support and to provide for college expenses. The court denied the father's motion to dismiss and held that § 516 was unconstitutional under the equal protection guarantee, as applied to illegitimate children whose paternity was clear at the time of the agreement. However, the court declined to rule on the constitutionality of § 516 where the father had not acknowledged paternity of an illegitimate child. The court also entered a support order, increasing the amount of child support to be paid by the father, and held that the illegitimate sons were entitled to be supported in the same standard of living that approximated the father's.


OUTCOME: The court denied the father's motion to dismiss the mother's petition for the support of the parties' illegitimate children and entered an order, increasing the father's child support obligations.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Children born out of wedlock -- support agreement -- modification.

1. Section 516 of the Family Court Act, providing that a judicially-approved agreement to support illegitimate children bars any other remedy, unconstitutionally deprives the children of equal protection where paternity is clear, since the support of legitimate children is subject to escalation on the basis of increased need of the children or increased means of the parent.

2. Illegitimacy has not been determined to be a suspect category, but applicable United States Supreme Court cases indicate a requirement that the means taken by a State advance a State purpose unattainable by less discriminatory means.

3. Section 516 does not advance the State purpose of promoting legitimacy, since it allows a father of an illegitimate child to escape escalating payments otherwise imposable.

4. While section 516 may supply an incentive to execute support agreements, the benefit thereof is no greater for an illegitimate than a legitimate child where paternity is clear, and the public interest in sufficiency of support should preponderate.

5. Based upon the father's substantial means and the modest request of the mother [***2] for child support consistent with her standard of living the amount of the support agreement should be modified upwards.

6. Section 513 of the Family Court Act cannot constitutionally be read to require that a part of the burden of child support of an illegitimate child be allocated to the mother, in contrast to sections 413 and 414, which provide for primary support of a minor child by the father.

 

2383 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Associates Discount Corp. v. Harris


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Dutchess County


87 Misc. 2d 839; 386 N.Y.S.2d 982; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2316



September 13, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendants' motion to vacate the order of seizure is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff seller brought an action against defendant purchasers for the unpaid purchase price of a tractor after the purchasers defaulted under a retail installment contract, and obtained an ex parte order of prejudgment seizure from the court. The purchasers brought a motion to vacate the order of seizure, alleging that the ex parte procedures violated their due process rights.


OVERVIEW: The purchasers entered into a retail installment contract with the seller for the purchase of a tractor. When the purchasers defaulted in payment, the seller brought an action against the sellers to recover the balance due. The seller then obtained from the court an ex parte prejudgment order of seizure of the tractor pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7102. The purchasers brought a motion to vacate the order of seizure, alleging that the ex parte procedures violated their due process rights. The court denied the purchasers' motion. The court held that the ex parte order was not unconstitutional for failure to afford the purchasers with notice and an opportunity for a hearing prior to seizure of the tractor because to require notice and a hearing would defeat the purpose of such a provisional remedy. Notice, if given in such a situation, would be an open invitation to a defendant to take steps to accomplish exactly those acts that the provisional remedies were intended to prevent. Because the court order complied with statutory requirements, the court found that any constitutional requirements were satisfied.


OUTCOME: The court denied the purchasers' motion to vacate the ex parte order of seizure of the tractor, in the seller's action against the purchasers to recover the balance of the purchase price of the tractor.


HEADNOTES

Replevin -- order of seizure -- motion by defendants to vacate order of seizure issued by court on ex parte application made by plaintiff pursuant to CPLR 7102 is denied -- failure to afford defendants notice and opportunity for hearing is not violative of constitutional due process requirements, which are satisfied if papers submitted on application comply with requirements of CPLR article 71 -- plaintiff's position as "secured party" under Uniform Commercial Code does not preclude it from proceeding under CPLR article 71.

1. A motion by defendants to vacate an order of seizure issued by the court on an ex parte application made by plaintiff pursuant to CPLR 7102 is denied. The failure to afford defendants notice and an opportunity for a hearing prior to seizure of the property in question is not violative of constitutional due process requirements, which are satisfied if, as in this case, the papers and documents submitted on the ex parte application comply fully with the requirements of CPLR article 71.

2. Plaintiff's position as a "secured party" under the Uniform Commercial Code ( § 9-503)  [***2] does not preclude it from proceeding under CPLR article 71.

 

2384 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Morales v. State Dep't of Social Services


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Suffolk County


89 Misc. 2d 360; 391 N.Y.S.2d 268; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2844



September 13, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the recipient of benefits under the Aid to Dependent Children program, brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 38 proceeding against respondents, the New York State Department of Social Services and its Commissioner, to (1) annul the decision of the Department sustaining the Commissioner's determination, (2) restore statutory entitlements to the recipient, and (3) declare N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 352.7(g)(5) invalid.


OVERVIEW: At the recipient's request, the county social services department advanced benefits to prevent a shut-off of utilities. Such an advance was authorized by N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 352.7(g)(5). However, the regulation required that the recipient's grant be reduced over the next six months to repay the amount of the advance. The recipient argued that any reduction without a prior agency determination that undue hardship would not result was contrary to 42 U.S.C.S. § 601 et seq., 45 C.F.R. § 233.20, and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 352.31(d)(4). The court rejected this contention. The recipient offered no evidence that hardship resulted. Further, the regulation limited the advance allowance to the four-month period immediately preceding the advance and permitted recoupment of the advance over the next six months. This built-in limitation would, in almost all cases, limit a budget reduction to 10 percent or less. Here, the monthly reduction amounted to less than 3 percent of the budget. This reduction was unlikely to result in undue hardship. Moreover, there was no assurance that a denial of recoupment would inure to the benefit of the children involved.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Social services -- advance payments of public assistance -- recoupment.

Petitioner and her five children, recipients of Aid to Dependent Children at a monthly grant of $ 695, were advanced the sum of $ 197.32 to prevent a shut-off of utilities as authorized by 18 NYCRR 357.2(g)(5), which limits the advance allowance to the four-month period immediately preceding the advance payment and permits recoupment of the advance over the next six months. The reduction in petitioner's monthly budget in accordance with the regulation, without a prior agency determination that it would not result in undue hardship, is not violative of or inconsistent with Federal and State laws and regulations. Petitioner has shown no evidence that hardship resulted, nor has she explained her failure to pay the utility bills with the moneys allocated to her for that purpose. Moreover, the built-in limitation in the allowance and period of recoupment by its very nature, would, in almost all cases, limit a budget reduction to 10% or less. Here, it is unlikely that the monthly reduction of less than 3% of the budget could possibly result in undue hardship. And,  [***2] even if there were to be a denial of recoupment, there is no assurance that it would inure to the benefit of the children involved.

 

2385 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


N. v. K.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Onondaga County


88 Misc. 2d 280; 387 N.Y.S.2d 367; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2666



September 7, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Ordered, petitions dated July 16, 1974, May 13, 1975 and March 31, 1976 are and hereby are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother filed three petitions pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 171 over a three-year period for upwards modification of the court's prior order of child support against respondent father. The court dismissed two petitions and reviewed the modifications sought on the most recent petition.


OVERVIEW: The parties' child was born out of wedlock. The parties had stipulated to the amount in the prior child support order. The mother asserted that the amount of child support that the child was entitled to should have been governed by the father's standard of living from N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 4, which governed the child support obligations of children born in wedlock. The mother asserted that the distinction between the amount due to legitimate children and natural children violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The court noted that parentage was not a suspect classification for equal protection purposes. The court distinguished the mother's proffered case law as improperly based on sin, whereas the distinction between N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 4, 5 were based on a reasonable and rational legislative goal of the preservation of harmony within the custodial family unit. The court was entitled to greater latitude for setting the child support obligations when there was great disparity of the standards of living of the parents. The court held that the child was entitled to less than the parties had stipulated to in the prior order.


OUTCOME: The child denied the mother's petition for modification of the child support order against the father.


HEADNOTES

Children born out of wedlock -- support -- father's standard of living.

1. Section 513 of the Family Court Act which requires the father of an out-of-wedlock child to pay a "fair and reasonable sum for the support" of such child, does not deny an out-of-wedlock child equal protection of the laws notwithstanding the fact that section 413 of the Family Court Act establishes a different standard of support for a legitimate child requiring the father of such child to pay a "fair and reasonable sum according to his means" for support. Although the father's standard of living should be given consideration in determining his ability to pay, an out-of-wedlock child is not allowed to receive support determined solely on the father's standard of living. The distinctions between the support awards test of sections 413 and 513 are not "patently arbitrary" or irrationally related to a valid governmental interest. Section 513, unlike section 413, does not make the father primarily responsible for support, but makes both parents jointly and severally liable. Section 513 provides a reasonable [***2] and rational test to determine support since it is within the best interests of an out-of-wedlock child to be within the relative lifestyle of the members of his household. Fixing support for an out-of-wedlock child solely according to the father's standard of living would tend to cause strife in that child's household where there is a great disparity between the standards of living of the father and mother. On the other hand, a legitimate child in an article 4 support proceeding has usually lived in a household which included both of his parents.
