Thus, the legislative reason for allowing the child to receive support according to his father's standard of living is to maintain that child's standard of living. Otherwise, the child would have to cope with adjusting to another economic standard of living in addition to dealing with the emotional crises that confront a child due to the breakup of his family. The legislative interest in easing the burdens of a child from a separated family is a valid concern of the government.

2. Petitioner mother is not entitled to an annual increase in the $ 125 weekly support order to meet inflationary trends since there has been no material change [***3] of circumstances between the parties since the prior support order. Petitioner, her out-of-wedlock child, and her disabled 26-year-old son from a prior marriage, reside as a family in the same house. Petitioner is unemployed and the family income, other than the support for the child, is the disability payment received by her 26-year-old son from which he contributes $ 25 per week to her for his room and board. Respondent father is only required to contribute one third of the total family shelter bill as the share for the shelter of his son. Respondent is required to pay for cost of tuition for a private school since the child has responded favorably to private school and respondent has the ability to pay for it. The sum of $ 100 per year is an adequate amount to be used to defray the cost of medical treatment.

 

2386 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kessel v. Board of Supervisors


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


87 Misc. 2d 842; 386 N.Y.S.2d 970; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2317



September 2, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, Nassau County registered voters that were enrolled members of the Democratic Party, alleged that N.Y. Elec. Law § 51 was unconstitutional because their Democratic county committee members were not permitted to participate in choosing the commissioner of elections. Democratic county committee members in all but three counties of the state participated directly in the commissioner's selection under N.Y. Elec. Law § 31.


OVERVIEW: Under N.Y. Elec. Law § 31, a majority of the Democratic county committee in each county selected a person to be recommended for appointment as a commissioner of elections. In three counties including plaintiffs' county of residence, the chairmen of the county committees selected a person to be recommended pursuant to N.Y. Elec. Law § 51. Plaintiffs alleged that N.Y. Elec. Law § 51 was unconstitutional because their duly elected county committee members were not able to participate directly in the choosing of the commissioner of elections like committee members throughout the state. The court declined to dismiss plaintiffs' complaint solely on the ground of standing. The court concluded that N.Y. Elec. Law § 51 was presumptively valid and that it could not set aside the statute as unconstitutional unless that conclusion was inescapable. The court declared that § 51 was constitutional, finding that plaintiffs had ample means to bring pressure to bear on the county chairman to conform to the wishes of the majority of the county committee members. Plaintiffs were not deprived of any constitutional rights by this method of selecting a commissioner of elections.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment in favor of the county board of supervisors.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Elections -- commissioners of election -- section 51 of Election Law, applicable to Nassau County, permitting chairman of county committee to select person to be recommended to board of supervisors to be appointed commissioner of elections, is constitutional -- it is not rendered constitutionally offensive by reason of fact that, in other counties of State, Suffolk and Monroe excepted, it is majority of county committee, rather than chairman, which selects person to be recommended for such appointment -- residents of Nassau County who are registered voters and enrolled in Democratic Party but who are not county committee members have, at best, tenuous standing to challenge constitutionality of section, but, in view of expansive concept of standing in recent years, their complaint will not be dismissed for lack of standing to sue.

1. Section 51 of the Election Law, which is applicable to Nassau County, and which permits the respective chairmen of the county committees of the two political parties casting the highest and next highest number of votes for Governor at the last general election to select the person to be recommended to the board of supervisors to be appointed a commissioner [***2] of elections, is constitutional. It is not rendered constitutionally offensive by reason of the fact that, in the other counties of the State, Suffolk and Monroe excepted, it is a majority of the county committee, rather than the chairman thereof, which selects the person to be recommended for appointment as a commissioner of elections (Election Law, § 31).

2. Residents of Nassau County who are registered voters and enrolled in the Democratic Party but who are not Democratic county committee members have, at best, tenuous standing to challenge the constitutionality of section 51. Although they are allegedly aggrieved because their elected county committee members, unlike those in other counties, do not participate in the selection of a commissioner of elections, their county committee members do participate in the election of the county chairman who chooses the person to be recommended. However, in view of the expansive concept of standing in recent years, their complaint will not be dismissed solely for lack of standing to sue.

 

2387 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Pellnat v. Buffalo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Erie County


87 Misc. 2d 742; 386 N.Y.S.2d 965; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2293



August 24, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The judgment is hereby reversed without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision of the Small Claims Court of Buffalo (New York), which awarded appellee taxpayer a judgment against the city in an amount equal to that portion of the real property tax the city collected from the taxpayer that exceeded the city's tax limit. The city appealed claiming that it had the right to continue to exceed its tax limit, even after the case relied on by the taxpayer was decided.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer paid his property taxes under protest and filed suit against the city for a refund claiming that a recent court decision limited the city's right to tax the property. The trial court awarded the taxpayer a judgment. The city appealed claiming it had the right to continue to impose and collect the tax even after the recent decision. On appeal, the court reversed. The court found that the city exercised proper discretion in continuing to impose and collect the tax. The court found that in prior cases the appellate division had found that city administrations, which had relied on the taxing authority granted to it to prepare its budgets, and which had collected taxes under that power, could not be forced to refund amounts later determined to have been illegally collected due to the impossible burden that it would cause. The court found that the city had not acted in bad faith and that no one could have predicted the result of the case on which the taxpayer had relied. The court found that the governmental process of budget preparation and adoption and of tax billing and collection could not possibly be halted when the decision of the prior case was rendered.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court without costs.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- repayment of illegal tax -- defendant City of Buffalo properly continued to impose and collect 1973 taxes after 1971 real property tax levy was held unconstitutional by Appellate Division (see Hurd v City of Buffalo, 41 AD2d 402, affd 34 NY2d 628); mandating repayment of amounts illegally collected in past would place impossible burden on city which relied in good faith on its taxing authority; budget preparation and tax billing and collection could not have been halted when decision of Appellate Division was published.

Plaintiff taxpayer was improperly granted judgment against defendant City of Buffalo in the sum of $ 112.10 representing that portion of the 1973 real property tax which exceeded the city's tax limit. Plaintiff based his claim for refund on his having paid the tax under protest and on the decision in Hurd v City of Buffalo (34 NY2d 628, affg 41 AD2d 402), which held that the 1971 tax levy by the city was unconstitutional. The common council adopted the 1973 budget after the Appellate Division held that the 1971 tax was illegal. The city received second tax installments from taxpayers prior [***2] to the Court of Appeals decision. The city's legislative and executive branches exercised proper discretion in continuing to impose and collect the tax in 1973 after the Appellate Division held the tax unconstitutional. Mandating repayment of amounts illegally collected in the past would place an impossible burden on the city, which relied in good faith on the taxing authority granted by section 11.00 (subd a, par 42-a) of the Local Finance Law in preparing its budget. The governmental process of budget preparation and adoption and of tax billing and collection could not have been halted when the decision of the Appellate Division was published.

 

2388 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gerzof v. Gulotta


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


87 Misc. 2d 768; 386 N.Y.S.2d 790; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2302



August 23, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendants are granted summary judgment. Plaintiff's motion for a stay of the Appellate Division's suspension order is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant justices filed a motion for summary judgment in plaintiff attorney's action seeking a declaration that N.Y. Jud. Law § 90 was unconstitutional under both the federal and state constitutions and requesting an order permanently enjoining the justices from carrying out the suspension order against him. The attorney filed a motion for a stay of the appellate division's suspension order.


OVERVIEW: In a § 90 proceeding, the appellate court suspended the attorney's license to practice law. The attorney subsequently filed an action seeking a declaration that § 90 was unconstitutional. The attorney also sought an order permanently enjoining the justices from enforcing the suspension order. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the justices and refused to stay the suspension order. The court found that the justices failed to meet their burden of showing that the prior decision by a federal court was on the merits in order to avail themselves of the defense of res judicata. The federal claims were dismissed based on the Younger abstention doctrine, and the state claims were never before the federal court. The court found that the attorney was afforded the less stringent due process standards that were required in the suspension proceedings. The court found no authority for the attorney's claim that the process of presenting evidence to a referee rather than directly to the appellate court that suspended his license denied his right to a meaningful hearing. The absence of an absolute right to appeal the suspension did not violate due process or equal protection standards.


OUTCOME: The court granted the justice's motion for summary judgment and denied the attorney's motion for a stay of the suspension order.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and client -- disciplinary proceedings -- res judicata -- right to appeal -- plaintiff's action to declare section 90 of Judiciary Law unconstitutional is not barred by res judicata, based upon Federal three-Judge court decision dismissing complaint for like relief, since such dismissal was not on merits, but was abstention based upon impropriety of Federal court interference in State attorney disciplinary matter; accordingly neither Federal nor State constitutional issues were reached and may now be raised in State court -- plaintiff did not waive his right to raise constitutional issues arising out of disciplinary proceedings against him by failure to timely raise such issues, since it appears that he unsuccessfully sought review thereof before Appellate Division and Court of Appeals, and issue of deprivation of right to appeal could not have been earlier raised -- quasi-criminal nature of disciplinary proceedings does not mandate that attorney be granted procedural rights identical to criminal defendants; accordingly, Appellate  [***2] Division could act as Grand Jury, prosecutor, Judge and jury and could appoint referee -- failure to accord plaintiff appeal does not violate due process and equal protection clauses, since there is no constitutional right to appeal where due process is accorded in trial court, and equal protection does not require appeal absent showing of lack of reasonable basis for treating attorney disciplinary proceedings differently from other professional disciplinary proceedings; relationship between courts and lawyers justifies vesting original jurisdiction in courts instead of administrative agencies -- accordingly, plaintiff's motion for stay of order of suspension is denied.

1. Plaintiff's action to declare section 90 of the Judiciary Law unconstitutional is not barred by res judicata, based upon a Federal three-Judge court decision dismissing his complaint for like relief, since such dismissal was not on the merits, where one Judge urged abstention, the second urged dismissal on the merits and the third dissented. United States Supreme Court affirmance of the decision does not indicate that the decision was on the merits, since the latter decision implied that it was upholding [***3] the lower court's dismissal, based upon the impropriety of Federal court interference in a State attorney disciplinary matter. Accordingly, neither the Federal nor State constitutional issues were reached, and they may now be raised in State court.

2. Plaintiff did not waive his right to raise the constitutional issues arising out of the disciplinary proceedings against him by failure to timely raise such issues, since it appears that he unsuccessfully sought review thereof before the Appellate Division and Court of Appeals, and the issue of deprivation of the right to appeal could not have been raised until his application for appeal were denied.

3. The quasi-criminal nature of attorney disciplinary proceedings does not mandate that an attorney be granted procedural rights identical to those of criminal defendants. Accordingly, it was not improper for the Appellate Division to act as Grand Jury, prosecutor, Judge and jury, nor for that court to appoint a referee, and plaintiff was not deprived of due process by denial of any right to present his oral argument and summation before the trier of facts instead of the referee.

4. Plaintiff was accorded a fair and open hearing in which [***4] detailed factual findings were recorded, there was an opportunity to confront and cross-examine witnesses, there was representation by counsel, and in which a full transcript and memorandum was transmitted to the Appellate Division for review.

5. The failure to accord plaintiff an appeal does not deprive him of due process or equal protection, since there is no constitutional right to appeal where due process has been accorded in the trial court, and equal protection does not require an appeal, absent a showing that there is no reasonable basis for treating attorney disciplinary proceedings differently from other professional disciplinary proceedings. The relationship between courts and lawyers justifies the vesting of original jurisdiction in the courts instead of an administrative agency, affording the attorney an initial determination by the body which would otherwise conduct a review.

6. Accordingly, plaintiff's motion for a stay of his order of suspension is denied.

 

2389 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Doria Hotels, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Justice Court of New York, Village of Larchmont, Westchester County


88 Misc. 2d 9; 386 N.Y.S.2d 961; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2371



August 20, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant hotel was charged with three violations of Village of Larchmont, N.Y., Rev. Gen. Ordinances § 2201, which required all hotels and clubhouses in the village to have a night watchman. Defendant challenged the constitutionality of the ordinance. It also claimed that enforcement of the ordinance without a search warrant was unconstitutional and that the prosecution had not sustained its burden of proving the three violations.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended the prosecution was insufficient in that there was no proof that the hotel was occupied at the time of the alleged violations. The court rejected this contention. A reading of the ordinance clearly showed that occupation was not an element of the offense of having no night watchman. The court also rejected the contention that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague. The ordinance required that the watchman visit every portion of the building at frequent regular intervals, but in any case not less frequently than hourly. This was a precise standard of conduct that could reasonably be complied with by the property owner. The court rejected the contention that the ordinance was discriminatory, and thus a violation of equal protection, because of its separate classification for hotels and clubhouses. Hotels and clubhouses were open to the public. They had large kitchens. The danger of fire and other hazards was more likely in such accommodations. These facts justified the separate classification. Finally, no search warrant was required because the police officers only entered the public portions of the hotel.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty in each of the prosecutions.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Innkeepers -- ordinance requiring night watchman.

1. The only hotel in a village is found guilty of violating a village ordinance which requires all hotels and clubhouses located within the village to employ a watchman to visit every portion of the building between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., not less frequently than hourly, for the purpose of detecting fire or other sources of danger and giving immediate and timely warning thereof to all occupants. The ordinance is not unconstitutionally vague, but sets forth a standard of conduct which can be reasonably complied with, and, in view of the nature of hotel and clubhouse facilities, and the hazards and dangers inherent therein, has a reasonable basis and is not discriminatory.

2. Occupation of the premises is not an element of the offense set forth in the ordinance. Accordingly, lack of proof that the hotel premises were, in fact, occupied at the time of the alleged violation is no impediment to prosecution.

3. Police officers had entered public portions of the hotel premises and remained there at least one hour without observing a night watchman. The officers did no more than any ordinary member of the public [***2] was permitted to do under the circumstances, and their conduct did not require a search warrant.

 

2390 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lechtenstein v. Suffolk County Dep't of Environmental Control


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Nassau County


87 Misc. 2d 1014; 386 N.Y.S.2d 958; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2351



August 13, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Upon all of the foregoing, the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner developer filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 seeking an order directing respondent County department of environmental control to approve the developer's proposed subdivision map without requiring him to pay any cash contributions in lieu of the installation of lateral sewer lines and seeking an order that N.Y. Town Law § 277(5)(d) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The developer submitted to the County a proposed subdivision map. The County directed the developer to install lateral sewer lines in the streets located within the plot, to make a cash contribution for the future construction of a sewage treatment plant, and to make another cash contribution in lieu of the sewer line installation along the public roads running along the developer's plot. The developer filed an action seeking an order directing the County to approve the subdivision map without requiring the developer to pay cash in lieu of the public roads' sewer lines. The developer also sought an order declaring N.Y. Town Law § 277(5)(d), upon which the County made its decision, unconstitutional. The court found that the County was charged with the systematic regulation of its sewer systems, that there was no evidence that the County's mode of calculating the assessment made against the developer was arbitrary, capricious, or an abuse of discretion, and that the developer failed to show that § 277(5)(d) was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the developer's petition.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- subdivisions -- sewerage systems.

Section 277 (subd 5) of the Town Law, which authorizes the Suffolk County Department of Environmental Control and the Suffolk County Sewer Agency to determine, specify and direct the means and methods by which communal sewerage systems shall be developed, is constitutional, and those agencies may properly require, as requisites for approval of a subdivision plat, not only that the developer construct cesspools and lateral sewer lines in the interior streets within the proposed subdivision and make a cash contribution for the future construction of a sewerage treatment plant, but that he also make a further cash contribution in lieu of construction of lateral sewer lines in peripheral public roads.

 

2391 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Dudley v. West


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Kings County


87 Misc. 2d 967; 386 N.Y.S.2d 555; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2335



August 11, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petitioner's application is dismissed without a hearing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner filed an application pro se for a writ of habeas corpus after conviction for criminal possession and sale of narcotics, criminal possession of a hypodermic needle, and criminal possession of a defaced revolver.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner filed an application pro se for a writ of habeas corpus. Petitioner framed his application on the ground that his detention was illegal in violation of his constitutional rights. Petitioner contended that a revised penal law was enacted pursuant to an unauthorized delegation of legislative authority to the State Commission on the Revision of the Penal Law and Criminal Code. The court found the Commission merely proposed legislation to the Legislature; it did not enact the new law. Therefore, the Legislature did not delegate its legislative authority to the Commission, and as a result, the revised Penal Law of 1965, as proposed by the commission and enacted by the Legislature, survived petitioner's constitutional challenge.


OUTCOME: Petitioner's application was dismissed without a hearing because petitioner's contention that there was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority to a Commission was completely devoid of merit.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- delegation of legislative authority -- upon application for writ of habeas corpus whereby petitioner contends that revised Penal Law of 1965 was enacted pursuant to unauthorized delegation of legislative authority to State Commission on Revision of Penal Law and Criminal Code, thereby making sections of Penal Law under which he was indicted and convicted, void, application is denied; commission merely proposed legislation to Legislature, it did not enact new law and therefore Legislature did not delegate its legislative authority -- further, pending of petitioner's direct appeal from judgment of conviction makes granting of habeas corpus improper.

1. Petitioner was indicted and convicted of criminal possession and sale of narcotics, criminal possession of a hypodermic needle and criminal possession of a defaced revolver. An appeal is still pending. Upon an application for a writ of habeas corpus whereby petitioner contends that the revised Penal Law (L 1965, chs 1030, 1031) was enacted pursuant to an unauthorized delegation of legislative authority to the State Commission on the Revision of [***2] the Penal Law and Criminal Code (Bartlett Commission), thereby making those sections of the revised Penal Law under which he was indicted and convicted, void, the application is denied. The commission merely proposed legislation to the Legislature, it did not enact the new law. Therefore, the Legislature did not delegate its legislative authority to the commission, and as a result, the revised Penal Law survives petitioner's challenge. Moreover, as documentary proof negates defendant's contention of an unauthorized delegation of authority, petitioner's application for a writ of habeas corpus can be denied on that ground without a hearing.

2. Further, the pendency of petitioner's direct appeal from the judgment of conviction makes the granting of the petition in this proceeding improper. The law is well settled in this State that habeas corpus is not available as a substitute for the normal process of appeal.

 

2392 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re R.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Family Court of New York, Bronx County


87 Misc. 2d 900; 386 N.Y.S.2d 774; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2326



August 10, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent mother moved for return of her children and for dismissal of a petition to remove children, arguing that the case relying on N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 1046(a)(ii) deprived her of her constitutionally guaranteed right to her children without due process of law.


OVERVIEW: After a boy suffered traumatic head injuries, petitioner state removed respondent mother's children from her home after finding abuse of her children in reliance on a presumption set forth in N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 1046(a)(ii) that the injuries would not exist except by parental acts. Respondent moved for return of her children and for dismissal of a petition to remove children. Respondent argued that the presumption deprived her of her constitutionally guaranteed right to her children without due process of law. On appeal, the court concluded that the injuries to the boy had not been explained satisfactorily. The court found that a prima facie case of child abuse was established by a preponderance of the evidence. The court ordered that all paroles and remands remained in effect pending the scheduled adjourned date because the preponderance of the evidence standard was not unconstitutional. The court dismissed the petition against respondent father because it had not been proven. The court adjudicated the children as abused children.


OUTCOME: The court denied respondent mother's motion to return her children, because the preponderance of the evidence standard was not unconstitutional and the children were adjudicated abused. The court dismissed the petition against respondent father, because it had not been proven.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parent and child -- child protective proceedings -- child abuse -- section 1046 of Family Court Act, providing that proof of injuries sustained by child of such nature as would ordinarily not be sustained except by reason of acts or omissions of parent or other person responsible for care of child shall be prima facie evidence of child abuse or neglect, and establishing preponderance of evidence as measure of proof for determination that child is abused or neglected child, is constitutional -- in child protective proceeding based upon alleged abuse of injured infant, as target child, and his sister and brother, injuries to target child have not been explained satisfactorily, and prima facie case of child abuse has thus been established by preponderance of evidence -- children are adjudicated to be abused children.

1. Section 1046 of the Family Court Act, which provides that proof of injuries sustained by a child of such nature as would ordinarily not be sustained except by reason of acts or omissions of the parent or other person responsible for the care of such child shall be prima facie evidence of child abuse or neglect, as the case may be, of the parent or other person [***2] legally responsible, and which establishes a preponderance of the evidence as the measure of proof for a determination that the child is an abused or neglected child, is constitutional.

2. In a child protective proceeding, based upon alleged abuse of an injured infant, as target child, and his sister and brother, the injuries to the target child have not been explained satisfactorily, and a prima facie case of child abuse has thus been established by a preponderance of the evidence. The children are adjudicated to be abused children.

 

2393 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


State by Lefkowitz v. Hudson Home for Aged


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


86 Misc. 2d 1063; 386 N.Y.S.2d 283; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2580



August 5, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In view of the foregoing, the motion of the plaintiff for summary judgment on the complaint is granted, and the cross motion of the defendant declaring section 759 of the Executive Law unconstitutional is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff State of New York filed a motion for an order for summary judgment permanently enjoining defendant, a home for the aged, from the continued violation of N.Y. Exec. Law § 759 and the Rules of the State Board of Social Welfare promulgated thereto.The home for the aged cross-moved for summary judgment dismissing the complaint and declaring the law and regulations to be unconstitutional and unenforceable as applied to the home.


OVERVIEW: The home for the aged returned to the Board an operating certificate. The home claimed that because it did not receive any public funds, it was not subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 759 or the regulations thereto. The Board notified the home that it was required to conspicuously post the certificate in the facility and brought the complaint predicated on the home's failure to do so. The home contended that N.Y. Const. art. XVII, § 2 limited the powers of the Board to regulate institutions which did not receive public funds. The court did not agree. It held that N.Y. Const. art. XVII, § 2 rather than limiting the powers of the Board, affirmed its right to properly exercise its inherent police powers to further regulate the operation of homes for the aged. The owner of private property did not acquire immunity against the valid exercise of the police power of the State. All property was held subject to the right of the State reasonably to regulate its use under the police power in order to secure the general safety and public welfare, especially of the State's aged and senior citizens.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment on the complaint to the Board and denied the home's cross motion for summary judgment, finding the statute to be constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Social services -- homes for aged -- operating certificates -- section 759 of Executive Law, requiring facility subject to visitation, inspection and supervision by State Board of Social Welfare to possess operating certificate issued by board, is not unconstitutional as applied to home for aged which does not receive public funds -- constitutional provision for inspections by board (NY Const, art XVII, § 2) does not limit its powers to regulate such institutions, but affirms its right to properly exercise its inherent police power to further regulate their operation.

1. Section 759 of the Executive Law, which requires a facility subject to visitation, inspection and supervision by the State Board of Social Welfare to possess an operating certificate issued by the board, is not unconstitutional as applied to a home for the aged which does not receive public funds.

2. Section 2 of article XVII of the New York State Constitution, which provides for inspections [***2] by the board of institutions of a charitable, eleemosynary, correctional or reformatory character, but provides that, in the case of institutions of such character which are not in receipt of public funds, the inspections shall be made solely as to matters directly affecting the health, safety, treatment and training of their inmates, does not limit the powers of the board to regulate institutions such as homes for the aged which are not in receipt of public funds, but affirms the right of the board to properly exercise its inherent police power to further regulate the operation of such institutions.

 

2394 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Modjeska Sign Studios, Inc. v. Berle


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


87 Misc. 2d 600; 386 N.Y.S.2d 765; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2263



August 4, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction and the motion of the Outdoor Advertising Association of New York to intervene are denied, and the cross motion of the defendant for summary judgment declaring the subject statute to be valid is granted, all without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff sign owner moved for a preliminary injunction restraining defendant, the Commissioner of the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, from enforcing N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 9-0305, which regulated the use of advertising signs in the Catskill Park. The Commissioner cross-moved for an order dismissing the complaint. An outdoor advertising sign association moved to intervene as an additional party plaintiff.


OVERVIEW: The owner contended that N.Y. Highway Law § 88 required payment of compensation for the removal of those signs that were located within 660 feet of federally aided primary highways. The court disagreed. The history of the legislation that made N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 9-0305 applicable to advertising signs in the Catskill Park showed a legislative intent to provide an amortization period as an alternative to the payment of compensation for pre-existing advertising signs in that park. The court held that § 9-0305 did not violate state and federal constitutional prohibitions on the taking of property without just compensation. The statute had a valid objective under the police power, the means employed were reasonably related to this objective, and it was not arbitrary, unreasonable, or oppressive. The statute did not violate the First Amendment guarantee of free speech because its restrictions were justified without reference to the content of the regulated speech, they served a significant government interest, and there were alternative channels for communication of the information. The owner's equal protection claim was without merit. The court denied the intervention petition.


OUTCOME: The court denied the owner's motion for a preliminary injunction and the motion of the association to intervene. It granted the Commissioner's cross motion and dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Environmental conservation -- regulation of outdoor advertising signs -- ECL 9-0305 which prohibits erection of advertising signs within Catskill Park without permit, is constitutional; outdoor advertising signs may be regulated by State pursuant to police power for aesthetic purposes alone -- six and one-half-year period for removal of pre-existing signs is reasonable amortization period for outdoor advertising signs -- First Amendment does not preclude State from adopting reasonable measures to regulate erection of advertising signs and billboards -- ECL 9-0305 does not require payment of compensation for removal of advertising signs for which compensation would otherwise be required by section 88 of Highway Law; Legislature intended to provide amortization period rather than monetary compensation for pre-existing signs in Catskill Park.

1. ECL 9-0305 which prohibits the erection of advertising signs [***2] or structures within the Catskill and Adirondack Parks, except under written permit from the Department of Environmental Conservation, is constitutional. ECL 9-0305 provides that signs within the Catskill Park existing prior to May 26, 1969 may continue to be maintained without a permit until January 1, 1976. Plaintiff is the owner of 97 pre-existing outdoor advertising signs located in the Catskill Park which are not presently eligible for permits (see 9 NYCRR Part 195) and, therefore, properly subject to removal without compensation. Outdoor advertising signs may be regulated by the State pursuant to the police power for aesthetic purposes alone. In creating the Catskill Park and in extending the regulation of outdoor advertising signs to the park, the Legislature has recognized the special natural beauty of the land in the park and has reasonably acted to conserve and preserve the area for future generations in its relatively unspoiled and undeveloped condition ( ECL 9-0305, subd 1).

2. The fact that plaintiff possessed valid and subsisting property rights which the statute abrogated does not provide a sufficient basis for declaring the statute unconstitutional. The six and [***3] one-half-year period provided for in the statute is a reasonable amortization period for outdoor advertising signs.

3. The First Amendment does not preclude the State from adopting reasonable measures to control the "ugliness, distraction and deterioration" which can result from the erection of advertising signs and billboards. The regulation is intended to serve the important governmental interest implicit in the exercise of the police power, and there are ample other alternative channels for communication of the information available in the affected area.

4. ECL 9-0305 does not require the payment of compensation for the removal of advertising signs for which compensation would otherwise be required by section 88 of the Highway Law, which was enacted to implement the Federal Highway Beautification Act (L 1968, ch 581, § 1). The majority of plaintiff's signs are located within 660 feet of Federally-aided primary highways running through the Catskill Park. Section 88 provides for the payment of compensation for the taking of such pre-existing advertising signs. However, the subsequent enactment of ECL 9-0305 shows a clear legislative intent to provide an amortization period [***4] as an alternate to the payment of compensation for pre-existing advertising signs in the Catskill Park.

 

2395 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Fonfa v. State


Claim No. 59698


Court of Claims of New York


88 Misc. 2d 343; 388 N.Y.S.2d 65; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2609



August 4, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] A short form order is being signed (a) granting the motion of the defendant State to dismiss this case against the movant, and (b) dismissing this case against the defendant Sheriff of the City of New York, sua sponte.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state filed a motion under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(2,) (7) to dismiss claimant judgment debtor's complaint that the state and defendant sheriff unlawfully detained him under N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 756, 757, 770, 772, 774, 775, statutory provisions for supplementary proceedings to collect money judgments, because the laws were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The judgment debtor was detained, arrested, incarcerated, and confined in penal institutions under the supplementary proceedings to collect money judgments, N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 756, 757, 770, 772, 774, 775. The same laws earlier had been found unconstitutional in a federal district court and the injunction against their enforcement was stayed by the United States Supreme Court pending appeal. The judgment debtor claimed damages from the state and a sheriff for the promulgation and enforcement of unconstitutional laws to which he was subjected. The state filed a motion to dismiss, which the court granted, and also sua sponte dismissed the sheriff from the action. The court held that even if the laws were unconstitutional, there was no cause of action against a state for the exercise of its sovereign function that could not be likened to functions that could be carried on by a private person or corporation. The state had only waived its immunity for its acts that could be carried on by private entities. The sheriff was not a state officer and could not be liable for the state's actions.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the judgment debtor's action against the state for damages allegedly incurred by the promulgation and enforcement of unconstitutional laws relating to judgment debtors. The court sua sponte also dismissed the sheriff from the action.


HEADNOTES

State -- liability of State for enactment of unconstitutional acts -- arrest for alimony arrears.

1. Claimant has no cause of action against defendant State of New York based upon his three-month incarceration and confinement in a criminal penal institution for alimony arrears (Judiciary Law, §§ 756, 757, 770, 772-775). Even if the statutes pursuant to which claimant was arrested and confined in jail were unconstitutional, the State cannot in any event be held liable for the enactment of statutes which are later declared unconstitutional. The waiver of immunity by the State (Court of Claims Act, § 8) is inapplicable where the activity complained of is sovereign in character and cannot be likened to functions which could be carried on by a private person or corporation. Since the legislative acts attacked were sovereign in character, the claim must be dismissed.

2. The claim against defendant Sheriff of the City of New York, whose deputies arrested [***2] claimant, is dismissed since the Sheriff is a "local" not a State officer (Public Officers Law, § 2) for whose acts the State can be held liable.

 

2396 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Gnerre


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Albany County


87 Misc. 2d 700; 386 N.Y.S.2d 763; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2282



August 3, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner administrator filed a petition to determine the validity and enforceability of a claim filed by respondent Commissioner of the Department of Mental Hygiene of the State of New York against the decedent's estate.


OVERVIEW: The decedent was admitted to a state hospital where he was determined to be an incompetent person. After his death, the Commissioner presented the administrator with a written notice of claim alleging that the decedent's estate was indebted to the Department for services rendered. The court found that several issues were raised in the proceeding: (1) whether N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law §§ 24 or 43 governed the situation; (2) was the applicable statute constitutional; (3) was there a waiver of the claim by the state by acceptance of moneys at a lesser rate than was being asserted; and (4) did the applicable statute of limitations bar any or all of the claim. The court allowed the Commissioner's claim. N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 24 was applicable to the case. That statute was not unconstitutional. There was no waiver of the claim. The claim was not barred by the statute of limitations. The court held that the state, through the Commissioner, was to be reimbursed for the cost of care given to the decedent from his estate before others were entitled to receive a legacy.


OUTCOME: The court allowed the claim against the estate.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Insane and other incompetent persons -- reimbursement of State hospital -- decedent, patient at State hospital since 1966, died in 1970, and, in 1974, Commissioner of Department of Mental Hygiene presented his estate with claim for services rendered -- claim is valid and enforceable under section 24 of Mental Hygiene Law, in effect on date of decedent's death.

Decedent, who had been a patient at a State hospital since 1966, died in 1970, and, in 1974, the Commissioner of the Department of Mental Hygiene presented his estate with a claim for services rendered. This claim is valid and enforceable. The situation is governed by section 24 of the Mental Hygiene Law, which was in effect on the date of decedent's death. Under that section, which has been upheld as constitutional, the commissioner is given broad discretion to fix reimbursement rates for the care, maintenance and treatment of patients at State institutions; a claim by him for reimbursement is not waived by nonassertion during the patient's lifetime, and it is not time-barred if, as here, it is filed within six years after the death of the patient.

 

2397 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


State by Lefkowitz v. Fey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Special Term, Albany County


87 Misc. 2d 987; 386 N.Y.S.2d 549; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2340



August 3, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The several motions are denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant made a motion to strike from the complaint of plaintiff, the State of New York, the allegations that were included in causes of action asserted against defendants other than defendant and for severance. The motion also sought to dismiss the complaint on the ground of unconstitutionality of N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(12) and N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §§ 349, 350. Codefendants made a cross-motion and joined in the motion for severance.


OVERVIEW: The State, by its attorney general, had instituted an action that alleged fraudulent, illegal, and deceptive practices and acts in the marketing and sale of certain products pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(12) and N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law art. 22-A and sought to enjoin such alleged practices. The court found that the attack on the constitutionality of the statutes was without merit. N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(12) was sufficiently clear and unambiguous and defined the proscribed conduct in language that could be understood. In addition, there was not an unauthorized delegation of legislative authority to the attorney general. Unfettered delegation would have had to be struck down. However, the court determined that the attorney general was empowered to enforce the sections under attack within the guidelines stated and discerned no constitutional prohibition. The court concluded that the other issues raised by defendant and codefendants were without basis.


OUTCOME: The court denied the several motions.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- fraudulent marketing and sale of products -- in action against defendants alleging fraudulent, illegal and deceptive practices in marketing and sale of certain products, defendants' attack on constitutionality of subdivision 12 of section 63 of Executive Law and sections 349 and 350 of General Business Law is without merit; subdivision 12 of section 63 is sufficiently clear and unambiguous and defines proscribed conduct in language that is able to be understood, nor is there unauthorized delegation of legislative authority to Attorney-General.

In an action against defendants alleging fraudulent, illegal and deceptive practices and acts in the marketing and sale of certain products, defendants' attack on the constitutionality of subdivision 12 of section 63 of the Executive Law and sections 349 and 350 of the General Business Law is without merit. Subdivision 12 of section 63 is sufficiently clear and unambiguous and defines the proscribed conduct in language that is able to be understood. Nor is there an unauthorized delegation of legislative authority to the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General is empowered to [***2] enforce the sections under attack within the guidelines stated and no constitutional prohibition is discerned.

 

2398 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Donaudy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Suffolk County


87 Misc. 2d 787; 386 N.Y.S.2d 326; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2304



August 2, 1976 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss the indictment is in all respects denied. The motion to sever is also denied with leave to renew as indicated (supra).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from the judgment of the trial court (New York) after defendants were charged in a grand jury indictment with conspiracy in the fourth degree and with receiving unlawful gratuities allegedly committed while both were public officials.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged in an indictment with conspiracy in the fourth degree and with receiving unlawful gratuities allegedly committed while both were public officials. Defendants moved for dismissal. The supreme court held that (1) defendants were not denied their right to a speedy trial because they were not prejudiced by a delay of only six months; (2) the State did not fail to comply with an order of the trial court that required it to serve one of the defendants with a bill of particulars and provide other ordered pretrial discovery items; (3) the State did not improperly use the grand jury, after indictment, to gather evidence for the prosecution of the case; and (4) the motion to sever was denied with leave to renew if at any time before or during the trial it appeared that codefendant had made a statement inculpating defendant that was to be offered into evidence.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motion to dismiss their indictment of conspiracy in the fourth degree, and for receiving unlawful gratuities allegedly committed while both were public officials, was in all respects denied because they failed to establish any reversible error.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- right to speedy trial -- defendants were not unconstitutionally denied speedy trial by reason of justifiable six-month delay occasioned by investigation conducted by Special Prosecutor; after defendants were indicted, Special Prosecutor commenced investigation into whether any improper influence was brought to bear upon members of District Attorney's staff to prevent indictment of defendants on felony charges; Special Prosecutor requested that case against defendants "be held in abeyance" -- People did not improperly use Grand Jury, after indictment, to gather evidence against defendants; no information obtained by Special Prosecutor was handed over to District Attorney.

1. Defendants, charged with receiving unlawful gratuities while they were Suffolk County officials, a class A misdemeanor (Penal Law, § 200.35), were not unconstitutionally denied a speedy trial by reason of a six-month delay in bringing the case to trial. After defendants were indicted, the Special Prosecutor appointed by the Attorney-General, pursuant [***2] to his authority to investigate "any and all unlawful acts or omissions" of members or employees of the District Attorney's office, commenced an investigation into whether any improper influence was brought to bear upon members of the District Attorney's staff to prevent the indictment of defendants on felony charges. The Special Prosecutor issued subpoenas and questioned witnesses before an Extraordinary Special Grand Jury. He requested that the case against defendants "be held in abeyance" until the files in the case were reviewed. The six-month delay caused by the interest and activities of the Special Prosecutor was a justified delay occasioned by "exceptional circumstances" ( CPL 30.30, subd [4], par [g]). Any precipitous action by the District Attorney might have been construed as an attempt to thwart the ongoing investigation. There is no proof that defendants' ability to defend themselves was prejudiced.

2. The People's delay in serving defendants with a bill of particulars does not mandate a dismissal. The People responded at the earliest practical time.

3. The People have not improperly used a Grand Jury, after indictment, to gather evidence against defendants.  [***3] No information derived from the investigation conducted by the Special Prosecutor was handed over to the District Attorney. The inquiry of the Special Prosecutor was conceived and carried out in good faith. There is no evidence that the Special Prosecutor improperly assisted the District Attorney in the prosecution of this case.

 

2399 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. S.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


87 Misc. 2d 951; 386 N.Y.S.2d 536; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2332



July 28, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.40 to set aside an order by the trial court (New York), which adjudicated defendant a youthful offender and sentenced him to a term of probation for five years. The state filed its motion after an appeal by the state was dismissed by the clerk for the state's failure to prosecute.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was adjudicated a youthful offender after pleading guilty to an A-III felony and was sentenced to five years' probation. After imposition of the sentence and within the time provided by law, the state filed a notice of appeal from the judgment. It was conceded that no further action was taken by the state to perfect that appeal, and the appeal was presumed to have been dismissed by the clerk, pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 670.4(a)(5), for the state's failure to prosecute. The state then filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.40 to set aside the adjudication of defendant as a youthful offender and the sentence. The court denied the motion, holding that the provisions of § 440.40 were applicable solely to a motion to set aside a sentence and not to the previous adjudication of defendant's youthful offender status. The court found that the sentence and adjudication as a youthful offender involved separate component parts of the judgment and were not synonymous and that no authority existed to set aside the adjudication.


OUTCOME: The court denied the state's motion to set aside the adjudication of defendant as a youthful offender.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Crimes -- youthful offender -- sentence of probation -- setting aside verdict -- sentence of five years' probation imposed upon defendant adjudicated youthful offender after pleading guilty to A-III felony, based upon finding that CPL 720.10 unconstitutionally deprived defendant of consideration for youthful offender treatment by reason of his indictment on A felony, is not set aside in exercise of discretion ( CPL 440.40); subsequent decision, by divided appellate court, holding CPL 720.10 constitutional (see People v Santiago, 51 AD2d 1), is not given retroactive application; CPL 440.40 does not authorize setting aside adjudication of youthful offender.

Defendant was adjudicated a youthful offender after pleading guilty to an A-III felony (see 81 Misc 2d 305) and sentenced to five years' probation (see 82 Misc 2d 884) upon a finding that CPL 720.10 unconstitutionally deprived defendant of consideration for youthful offender treatment solely by reason of his indictment for an A felony. In the exercise of discretion, the motion by the People to set aside the sentence and adjudication of youthful offender pursuant to CPL 440.40, based upon a subsequent holding, by a divided [***2] appellate court, that CPL 720.10 is not unconstitutional (see People v Santiago, 51 AD2d 1), is denied. While CPL 440.40 grants leave to the People to move to set aside the sentence on the ground that it was invalid as a matter of law, it does not authorize the setting aside of the youthful offender adjudication. The adjudication and the sentence involve separate component parts of the judgment and are not synonymous. The People should have moved to vacate the sentence of probation as not being authorized by law instead of focusing the entire thrust of their attack upon setting aside the adjudication of youthful offender on the principal ground that subsequent decisions should be given retroactive application. In any event, the appellate decision upholding the constitutionality of CPL 720.10 should not be given retroactive effect in light of that court's statement that "the issue remains open" and should be appealed to Court of Appeals for an authoritative ruling. In view of the totality of the circumstances, the unsettled condition of the law and the fact that the People did not diligently prosecute an appeal from the judgment, the interests of justice would be better served [***3] by letting the sentence stand.

 

2400 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. New York v. Morbel Realty Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


87 Misc. 2d 989; 386 N.Y.S.2d 925; 1976 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2341



July 22, 1976 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law §§ 2320, 2324, plaintiff State brought an action against defendants, a hotel operator and the hotel owners, for permanent injunctive relief. Because the hotel was allegedly being used for prostitution, the State claimed that defendants were guilty of maintaining a nuisance.


OVERVIEW: After being arrested in and adjacent to a hotel, four women were convicted of prostitution, and a hotel clerk was convicted of permitting prostitution. Pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law §§ 2320, 2324, the State brought an action against defendants, claiming defendants were guilty of maintaining a nuisance and seeking permanent injunctive relief. In granting the injunction, the court held that pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2324, the convictions and the community's reputation were presumptive evidence of the nuisance and prima facie evidence of defendants' knowledge, acquiescence, and participation. The court also held that it did not matter whether the clerk was on the hotel's payroll or not because § 2324 applied to "any person" found guilty of permitting prostitution.


OUTCOME: The court granted the injunction.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Nuisance -- places of prostitution -- at trial of action for injunctive relief pursuant to Public Health Law ( §§ 2320-2334), providing that whoever uses, owns or leases building for purpose of prostitution is guilty of maintaining enjoinable nuisance, evidence elicited with respect to convictions of females, arrested on hotel premises, upon their pleas of guilty to prostitution, and conviction of male, allegedly clerk of hotel, upon his plea of guilty to permitting prostitution, and evidence of hotel's general reputation, constituted presumptive evidence of existence of nuisance and prima facie evidence of knowledge, acquiescence and participation in nuisance by lessee-operator and owners of hotel, within purview of section 2324 of Public Health Law -- operator and owners of hotel have not adduced sufficient evidence to overcome statutory presumptions -- they are enjoined from operating premises as nuisance and directed to abate nuisance -- statute is not unconstitutional.

1. At the trial of an action for injunctive relief pursuant to the Public Health Law ( §§ 2320-2334), providing that whoever uses, owns or leases any building for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution [***2] is guilty of maintaining an enjoinable nuisance, evidence was elicited with respect to arrests and six convictions in and adjacent to hotel premises during a 12-month period, including convictions of four females, arrested on the hotel premises, upon their pleas of guilty to prostitution, and the conviction of a male, allegedly a clerk of the hotel, upon his plea of guilty to permitting prostitution, and with respect to experiences of businessmen in and near the hotel and its general reputation. The convictions of prostitution and permitting prostitution and the evidence of the hotel's general reputation constituted presumptive evidence of the existence of the nuisance and prima facie evidence of knowledge, acquiescence and participation in the nuisance by the lessee-operator and the owners of the hotel, within the purview of section 2324 of the statute, which provides that, in an action for injunctive relief pursuant thereto, evidence of the general reputation of the place, the occupants thereof, or those resorting thereto shall be competent evidence to prove the existence of the nuisance; that an admission or finding of guilt of any person of permitting prostitution at such place [***3] shall be presumptive evidence of the nuisance, and that evidence of the general reputation of the place or occupants thereof, if sufficient to establish the existence of the nuisance, shall be prima facie evidence of knowledge, acquiescence and participation in, and responsibility for, the nuisance on the part of the owners and lessees of the place. The operator and owners of the hotel have not adduced sufficient evidence to overcome the statutory presumptions, and they are enjoined from operating the premises as a nuisance and directed to abate the nuisance.

2. The statute is not unconstitutional.
